NB



>Precedence: bulk
>
>Normally don't post much, but had to pipe in when it came to Dune!
>Definitely the BEST party of my life and one of the best events in my 
life.
>Nothing ever will come close to dancing the night away to the best
>progressive trance dj's around (Christopher Lawrence, Sandra Collins, 
Doran,
>Brad) in the most magical desert location.  Amazing projections on to 
the
>face of a sheer cliff.  A natural amphitheater seemingly made for a 
party,
>as it created warehouse-quality sound.  People who came from
>everywhere-Spain, Canada, SF!  As amazing as the night was, the sun 
rising
>across the desert, with beautiful blue skies and puffy white clouds, 
was the
>definite high point of the day.  Right as the sun peaked out from the 
top of
>the rocks, dozens of chirping birds flew over head in a V shape at the 
same
>time as the music climaxed and broke down.  Hundreds of kids, mad 
dancing,
>started going off, yelling and screaming at the top of their lungs, 
over the
>miraculous unity of the sun, birds, music, and each other.  Looking 
around,
>you could see that every person just experienced the same, overwhelming
>emotions and I think everyone came away a different person.
>
>Needless to say, it was a once-in-a-lifetime experience.  The only
>unfortunate thing is that other parties have never come close to being 
as
>special, as a new standard has been set!  If anything's going to beat 
it
>though, it'll be Dune 4!!!  See you there...
>
>-brent
>
>

Subject: rave documentary
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hello, everyone.  I'm new to the list and all, but I've been raving almost
a year now in
sf and oakland.  It's changed my life and when the subject came up about
making a documentary
for my film class at UCB, guess what I chose to make my film about?

So, now, I am asking for your help.  Please tell me what raving means to
you.  Feel free
to talk about anything about raving that matters: what you think people
outside the scene think, i.e. misconceptions or prejudices, etc. and just
whatever you've noticed about raving that you want to go off on.  I'm
especially interested in the organization of the production crews and
massives, and economics and race issues: who goes to what parties, how much
money's involved not only in promoting and attending parties, but how much
people spend for raves: tickets, clothes, accessories, recreational
others.....;)

Also, if you do respond (and I REALLY hope you do!) please tell me if it's
ok to quote you in my film.  If you don't mine my including your thoughts
and ideas, then please tell me if you'd like to be anonymous, or give me
whatever name you'd like to be identified by.

Let me say this: I am not out to slander the scene or the people in it. I
just want to show anything and everything that happens at parties.

Thanks for duking it out through this LONG message and I hope to hear from
you.

much love
& besitos!   marie

I wasn't in the mood for static last night.

I mean really not in the mood.  8 hours on my feet
working the machines at kinko's did not leave me much
energy to dance.  I was tempted to go sleep, but I
saw my roomate headed down the street, so I told
myself to not talk myself out of going.

I'm glad I did- it was one of those nights where
dancing was extremely theraputic for me.  It was one
of the nights where I could block out all the people
around me and left the music wash over me and I can
go into some kind of hyper tai chi state.  Which is
not always a good thing at static because usually the
press of bodies in that small space is sensual but
when you go into hyper mode it can get dangerous>
apologies to all whose eyes I nearly poked out.;)

I am hoping to repeat my therapy tonight.  Is anyone
going to the release of net5 party, or the sabotage
crew with t1000 gig or the crash worship show?  My
roomate wants to do it all.  I'll either reach a new
level of consciousness or die...

pjf
ps I thought the crash worship show was girls
only(anyone know?)

Precedence: bulk

HMMMMMM raving.......Ok here is my 2 bits.....I have only been raving for 6
months.....its completely changed my views of everything. Before I was going
to parties, I was happy but I still felt confined...like I had to fit into the
description and do the things that people thought were normal. I went to my
first party and my jaw was dropped open when I got there. I was like WOW! I
didnt understand it all, but it was beautiful. It made me smile ear to ear. I
have not stopped smiling since. To me,raving means so many things....freedom,
expression, the choice to feel and be how you want to , and not to give damn
about what others think. I love it, I hope I am doing it untill my legs are
toasted, then I'll go on a wheel chair!
Raving is also the joy of the music...as I love the sound of the bass. I love
to feel it when I push my body up against the bass speaker and  it gives me a
gentle massage...
I just have never been able to find a description of raving that can do any
justice.
Harmony, the feeling ,not the party crew, is one word that I can think of.
Inner joy, a child like view of things, a release.......See, this all doesnt
describe how I feel ...its very hard tput it all in words but I hope that
helped. 
Ok, views from other people.....seeing as how thats still in my memory bank
only being 6 months ago......my views before I started raving.....I was like
the majority of people....images of extacy and black lights went floating in
my head....thats all I knew of it. Even the kind of music that is heard at a
party ....I was thinking it was like the techno they play on wild 107 or
something! So a good friend of mine invited me to my first one. My view of it
when I first got there was it looked fun but completely insane....I loved it,
but didnt know how to put it all together.....it was crazy!  But other people
who have not been fortunate enough to go to one...well, I have heard them
called ex parties by people who have never been to one. I have heard the words
not of their mouths, but the words of a 20/20 special being vocalized through
the mouths of the uneducated people who say "they know" because they saw some
tv show by people who dont even fucking rave!  I know people who are
curious.....they want to know what its all about....I love that! I try to get
those people to come with me. I also have heard of people who have never been
to one that honestly have no clue .....they are like " a rave, whats that?" 

My folks......they are real supportive. of course I am 21, and they dont
control what I do. They said if I was in highschool they would have never
aloowed it.....and then they started talking about a well klnown info show
that  did a story on raves.....I did my best to tell them, its not about all
drugs....a lot of people party sober....its about choice...but like many
others they said " but I read this article, I saw that show"  funny things is,
more people have dies and gotten hurt leaving frat parties than raves....and
yet no one freaks when their kid goes to a footbal after party or a "keger"
so I think peoples views are mixed....wich I guess is better than being one
sided in the negative spectrum of it all......

Tix- I usually pay around 10-15 bucks for a ticket....but I have seen them as
low as 3 bucks, and as high as 25 bucks. I wont pay 25 bucks any more though!
As far as party crews, I have never helped with a party so I dont know the
exacts of what goes on. I can tell you this. People put a lot of love,
effort,energy and hard hard work and dedication to make these things
happen....everyone I know who goes to help with a party gets there in the
middle of the day and doesnt leave until like 8am or later the next
morning.....major props! 
Clothes-I buy almost everything at thrift stores! I can go in with 50
bucks,walk out with at least 5 pairs of pants, and some shirts to boot!
Sometimes I go to head shops to buy shirts...they are like 20-25 bucks there
so I dont do it a lot. 
I hope all this has helped. I hope you are doing this with love and honesty to
the scene and if you are, best of luck to you! 
*hugz4ever*
W/love&Harmony
Guy

This message sent to staff@kzsu.stanford.edu.

Tommorrow is KZSU spring quarter organizational meeting for 1998!

Come to Tressider Memorial Union, centrally located on the Stanford 
Campus.  The meeting will be in the Cypress room on the second floor.

Introductory portion of the meeting is at 7:30 pm with a reception/tour 
immediately following.  8:30 pm is for people returning or already 
trained in radio and looking to sign up for new shows and get a current 
status of the station.

-Thanks
Darell Tibbles
General Manager
KZSU 90.1 FM

To remove yourself from announce@kzsu.stanford.edu, send mail to
<majordomo@kzsu.stanford.edu> with the single line,
	unsubscribe announce

"announce@kzsu.stanford.edu" is administered with Majordomo software.

"staff@kzsu.stanford.edu" is administered with Majordomo software.

"subscribe" or "unsubscribe" or "help" to alter your subscription.

From: Robert Pointer <rwpointer@citiscape.com>
Subject: Denver RAVES! Activated #9 - Kenya
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Gang,

I just got back from Denver last night (on business) but was able to sneak
away for awhile to see what was going on in the land o' mile high stadium.
I found this cool rekkid shop called synaptic records on one of the main
strips (Broadway, go figure...).
Picked up a couple of CD's from Submerge (Detroit Techno - which I was
pleasantly surprised to see DJ-T1000 making an appearance here :) and
picked up a few flyers. The city seemed pretty dead, but I really didn't
have enough time to explore fully like I usually do.
To my point: I found this mag called Activated, a free zine outta
Baltimore. Reading the masthead it looks like it is distributed at
Housewares in the city. Anyway, I like reading reviews of music, and there
is this reviewer called Kenya that cracks me up. Let me write verbatim a
coupla of his reviews:

"Double 99 Rip Groove (Logic Records)

SPEED GARAGE. It's here, Logic is selling. Pushing it on kids, cause
really, it's the next big thing. I was late on the speed garage thing. I
didn't catch it until i heard Feelgood at "Think". For all i feel, you can
keep it. It all sounded like Sugar Daddy remixes and spin offs. This record
is the same; it's okay for a house record but it just gets real tired real
quick. House pattern and supposed "jungle basslines". I didn't know jungle
had a certain bassline; I've heard thousands of them, but hey speed garage
has it. I swear to god it all sounds like Sugar Daddy. Spin it if ya want.
Rock on."

Fatboyslim The BeatBurger EP (Astralwerks)

"I always knew that a) the Chemical Brothers would in time influence a lot
of people and that b) they would create many Chemical Brothers spawns. This
EP sucks. When I got all these promos, weeks and weeks ago, i went to
Flavor to drop them inna mix and just to see how people hangin out reacted.
I swear to god people wouldn't stop laughing until i did a nasty rewind and
yanked it off the table. This stuff is like pop rock meets candy raver
meets DJ Dan meets the Chemical Brothers, (with) over burdened hiphop
stolen beats with metal guitar riffs or cheesy samples and old stolen piano
lines from people more talented. Sadly though in some places i bet this
shit leaps off the 1200s and into the crowd at a rave they eat it up. Go
Ravers. Rave on."

or....

Toxic 220 Subliminal Sewage (Sugar Spliff, US)

" Toxic 220 is part of the infamous Spiral Tribe. So delighted iwas to hear
this. It's jungle, it's Sprial Tribe .. it's gonna be good. After all the
Shite i have been reviewing this was it. WRONG. PLEASE COME AGAIN. THANK
YOU. This is shit. Everyone is saying jump up is shit. No way. THis is
shit. Darkside rocks, i have just discovered my darkside/techstep other
half as a DJ. But with any form of music, too much is a bad thing. Two
tracks, both dark. I like them both but then the programming just gets
silly. Both tracks sound like they have 5 different rhythm pattterns...nice
listening, but it doesn't communicate well on the dancefloor and either way
it gives me a migrane."


THis is funny stuff considering most of the review you read these days are
filled with non-meaningful words like "the sound is deep. This track is
smooth." etc. Usually I'm a stickler for grammer, but this sounds like any
conversation at a DJ store that could be had.

They have a web site:
http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/studio/9391/active.htm

didn't test the link, however. maybe it works?

Anyway, props to this mag for printing the stuff raw w/o regard to status quo.

later!

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com

rob.
http://www.citizenmag.com
http://www.citiscape.com

From: Catweasel <cat.weasel@usa.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Staticattack

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Static just goes from strength to strength. Last night completely rekindled my passion for small techno nights, the music was from another dimension, the crowd were so diverse and up for it, not a cheesy quaver or glowstick in sight. 
Who the hell was the DJ on from 11-12.30 who did a Mills at the end of his set by dropping Strings of Life? Wikked, brought many smiles and cheers.
Then I think it was Brad who went on with more killer techno - everyone completely going ballistic on the dancefloor. Tunes were beautiful hard mindfunk trippy techno, just as I love it. It just got more and more insane and in the last half hour switched to techstep jungle - yus! The mood of the night was summed up by this guy arriving alone at 1AM dressed in a pinstripe suit and tie, looking completely cleancut and slightly out of place. 5 minutes later I turn around, and right next to me this guy is going off on one, dancing like a demented lunatic, screaming an pumping his fist in the air, still with his suit jacket done up. Welcome to the club!
Bodes well for Sabotage at El Pirata tonight - be there or be an orange. I'll be in my "Fuck goa trance" t-shirt again. Say hello, I'll be the one dancing like a loon.
C@weasel

http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Underground/5185

A bit late, I know, but I had to say it: the jungle being spun before the 
reprazent crew went on (dj suv spinning?) was the most amazing I've ever 
heard. Not to mention, roni size & co. gave the most entertaining live 
musical performance I've ever seen, of any genre. 

The show was so much _fun_, I couldn't believe it. Wish you all could have 
made it (and props to those that did: science, lara, meganhug and 
others). Did anyone record it?

-radon

well here it goes......
 Raving to me is a big part of my soul and heart....
        a person the other day asked me what i was like before i was
raving....and the truth is that i was the happy open minded kid that i am
now....raving hasn't changed my views....i realized that people should be who
they wanted and not worry about what everyone else thought before i started
raving... when i realized that most and i do underline most......ravers were
open minded and open hearted and loving and willing to share that love no
matter what kind of clothes you wore or what color skin......and you and i
were all excepted as who we were deep down inside.. i knew that i had found my
nich.....the place that i was looking for to have fun....and listen to
music....and dance....and meet new and wonderful people... and to talk about
feelings....and opinions.... ands not worried about being excepted.... now see
i am thankful to have found this at a young age because raving is beautiful
and intense and some people my age aren't ready to bring in that kind of
intesnse beauty.....and there are some people no matter what age that aren't
ready but that is also my opinion but i am not here to judge...i am here to be
free of the mad drama of not being the right person wearing the right cothes
or whatever.....society sucks....and no matter if you are raving or not you
will always have to deal with some sort of drama.....there is just more
exceptance in raving (but there still is drama sometimes) so yeah...keep on
dancing and keep it real-- p.l.u.r.m  peace love unity respect music.....
without the music we wouldn't be there...love  MoOnBaBy--Jenn

Music at Static was otherworldly/outofbody last night, fer sure.  The
pinstripe suit was a suspicious character though....he took our picture on a
disposable camera, then mumbled something @ his website comrade.com, which
when I checked this morning was populated by busts of Lenin's head.  Very
disreputable activity overall ;)  LaurenG.




At 07:43 PM 4/1/98, Catweasel wrote:
>Static just goes from strength to strength. Last night completely rekindled
my passion for small techno nights, the music was from another dimension,
the crowd were so diverse and up for it, not a cheesy quaver or glowstick in
sight. 
>Who the hell was the DJ on from 11-12.30 who did a Mills at the end of his
set by dropping Strings of Life? Wikked, brought many smiles and cheers.
>Then I think it was Brad who went on with more killer techno - everyone
completely going ballistic on the dancefloor. Tunes were beautiful hard
mindfunk trippy techno, just as I love it. It just got more and more insane
and in the last half hour switched to techstep jungle - yus! The mood of the
night was summed up by this guy arriving alone at 1AM dressed in a pinstripe
suit and tie, looking comp
>letely cleancut and slightly out of place. 5 minutes later I turn around,
and right next to me this guy is going off on one, dancing like a demented
lunatic, screaming an pumping his fist in the air, still with his suit
jacket done up. Welcome to the club!
>Bodes well for Sabotage at El Pirata tonight - be there or be an orange.
I'll be in my "Fuck goa trance" t-shirt again. Say hello, I'll be the one
dancing like a loon.
>C@weasel

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

oh my god, portishead was so completely ON last night i still have the 
echos rolling through my body...


the show started with a dj spinning some nice records, i should have 
noticed something was up because he would switch records every 20 
seconds or so.  he started playing some portishead stuff, different 
instrumental mixes of some older tracks.  

then some other people come out and he just starts *going off*...
man o man, i've never seen anybody with the skills like this guy, he
had two of just about every record and would work it so he could just pick
a loop and loop it over and over, faster, slower, his hands were dancing...


eventually the whole band is out there, a guitar, bass, another turntablist,
keyboardist, and of course, Beth.  her voice is even better live, so full
of emotion and experience i was just blown away.  

a few times they would be cruising along through a song and all of a sudden
it would break and be really loud full on groove and then mellow back out.


i can't recall which songs they did, but i liked them all :)  the encores
were sweet.


if you are even considering going tonight (and can find a ticket) GO!!!


that is all,
 justin

>I read a pretty lame review of it in the examiner and was wondering if
>those who went liked it.
>
>=)
>dan
>

> disreputable activity overall ;)  LaurenG.

Subject: The Day of Noise on KZSU

From: Joe Brenner <doom@kzsu.Stanford.EDU>

Precedence: bulk


I'm in the midst of organizing another "Day of Noise" event
on KZSU (the Stanford radio station, 90.1 FM).  This time
around it's going to be all day Thursday, from midnight to
midnight.  

This year a number of the performers are into things in the
ambient/techno direction.  Robert Rich is going to kick
things off at Midnight on Wednesday night (yes, that's
TONIGHT), followed by "superdave" (think post-jungle) at
around 2am.  On Thursday night at 7pm, Matmos is going to do
a 45 minute set, and Weird Blinking Lights is going to close
down the event (with a bang?) with an hour long set starting
at 11pm.

There's actually a bunch of things going on I might
recommended to the open-minded (open-eared?) raver, like
Philp Gelb doing a half-hour of solo-shakihaci (japanese
flute) at 4:30pm, maybe Totemplow's guitar drone at 1pm, and
so on.   The full schedule is posted here if you're into it:

   http://kzsu.stanford.edu/~doom/noise4all.html

And if you're one of the folks living outside of KZSU range,
you might want to listen in on real audio: 

   http://realaudio.stanford.edu/

I got a call from Martin O Brien last night. Those of you who dont know,
Martin is the person who is responsible for The Gathering, Basics, Vision and
Freedom. Anyhow, he was really excited because he had just got home from an
interview he did with Ed Bradley for 60 Minutes. 

It's kind of bizzare, but they're doing a story on raves. I've been told
though that part of the story involves something else. Apparently, they have
unearthed information that glitter may be carniogenic. The whole piece is
about 10 minutes long, and Martin and footage from his parties is used. They
also talk to other promoters and this girl who now has Hodgkins Disease(a
relatively mild and curable form of cancer mainly found in men in their late
20 and early 30's); apparently resulting from using glitter quite a bit. She
lives in Vancouver. In talking with Martin about it, we havent been able to
figure out why they felt the two stories are linked, but he says his part of
the interview went well from his end.

I don't know about everyone on this list, but I'll be watching 60 minutes this
Sunday night for sure.

--Monty

On Wed, 1 Apr 1998, Hernio Iglesia's wrote:

&e>There is no "dip" at zero. Which means a 'pure' fade through zero.
&e>
&e>If you have the money I recommend it. Even if you have to do without 
&e>food for a couple monthes.
&e>

A really easy mod to do to a existing 1200 by the way...

Costs all of one two pole switch, a couple dabs of solder, and some wire.

Write me if you seriously want to do it, but it's pretty self explanatory
with a little background in electronics and a good look at the soft pink
underbelly of a 1200 (if it's not, consider having someone else do the
mod...).  The physical "detent" stays there (although I'm sure there's a
way to take that thing out too, might require installing another fader
though, and I wouldn't want that... the stock technics ones are pretty
bulletproof... or perhaps they have it as a spare for the mk3?), but it's
very small... smaller than the zone within which the light and "locked
zero" activiates. 

Anyways, I think there's a beauty to "bumping" the other record pitch
slider up or down a little to get both of them out of the green.  A bump
of maybe .25 of a percent on the other decks will take it out of the
"green 0" zone. 

A properly calibrated 1200 only loses maybe 1/8 (.00125 rpm) of a percent
precision to either side of the "green light dip", it really isn't all
that big a deal... not worth the cost of new decks if you already own a
pair.

Finally... how many parties do you get booked at where you get to bring
your own decks... mk3 owner or not, you'll probably end up spinning on the
same old same old mk2's, so you might as well get used to it (and if you
want to ride the future, get on with CDs...). 

If anybody has info on the "backwards" mods that I've heard some guy out
of the UK does, let me know (a switch on the decks which "turns the motor
around" and causes the tt controls to work exactly the same as normal, but
while turning backwards). 

AndyW

             ...nevaeh ot yawriats eht gniyub s'ehs dna...

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 02 03:10:01 1998

Received: from [206.251.16.103] by send1a; Wed, 01 Apr 1998 19:00:01 PST
Date: Wed, 1 Apr 1998 19:00:01 -0800 (PST)
From: messiah wannabe <messiahw@yahoo.com>
Subject: Re: rave documentary (too damn long...)
To: Marie <mickie@uclink.berkeley.edu>
Cc: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk




hi, my name is messiah wannabe, and i've been raving for 9 years (hi
messiah!).

i started raving back in the mountains of north carolina.  i was going
to school in a small college town, and there wasn't much to do, so my
friends and i were used to making our own fun.  my buddy craig was
from orlando, florida, one of the first places in the u.s. where
raving caught on, so we decided to throw one ourselves.  it was in a
ski cabin outside of town, about 50 people showed up, and we all had
the time of our lives.  so we kept throwing these little parties...

eventually i started going to raves that other people threw.  there
were a lot of things i really liked about raves.  the crowd was always
pretty mixed up, blacks and whites, straights and gays, grungers,
clubbers, goths, everyone was pretty much welcome.  and the music was
cool, no singers to steal the spotlight, leaving room to focus on your
own thoughts and feelings, rather than someone else's.  plus it was
constantly changing, styles and genres came and went so quickly, it
was hard to get bored with it.  also, raves had a very sexy vibe, not
like some pick-up bar, but everybody was kissing everybody else, and
giving backrubs, and wearing sexy (but comfortable) outfits. 
basically, it was like "sex (and sensuality) is good" which was a
welcome attitude after the uptight, anti-sex 80's.  but there was one
thing about raves that really got me hooked: dancing!  growing up a
middle-class white kid in suburbia, i had really never danced before. 
oh, the occasional slam dance at a punk show, which was fun too, but i
had never seriously moved my body to the rhythm of the music for hours
on end.  what a feeling!  and it didn't really matter that i wasn't
graceful or smooth, no one else was either, we all looked kinda silly.
 but that was ok, raves were very accepting environments, it was hard
to do something that was frowned upon.  and the high you got after
dancing non-stop all night, wow.  drugs or no drugs, it really didn't
matter, that great rush of endomorphins or whatever always made me
feel great for weeks!  the experience, at times, was extremely
powerful.  i felt like i was experiencing god, or at least some sort
of spiritual force, first hand, something i had never really believed
in before...

i've had friends that got really wrapped up in the scene, djing at big
parties, promoting, buying and selling massive amounts of drugs.  a
lot of those people eventually got very disillusioned with it all, and
dropped out of the scene, never to return.  but i never really took it
for more than it was:  a great party, an open, accepting atmosphere to
have fun, often with people who weren't just like me, a place to dance
all night.  now, 9 years later, i still find that there's a place in
my life for all those things.  if anything, as i've grown older, and
my life more complicated and stressful, i find i appreciate them now
more than ever...

-messiah wannabe


---Marie <mickie@uclink.berkeley.edu> wrote:
>
> Hello, everyone.  I'm new to the list and all, but I've been raving
almost
> a year now in
> sf and oakland.  It's changed my life and when the subject came up
about
> making a documentary
> for my film class at UCB, guess what I chose to make my film about?
> 
> So, now, I am asking for your help.  Please tell me what raving
means to
> you.  Feel free
> to talk about anything about raving that matters: what you think
people
> outside the scene think, i.e. misconceptions or prejudices, etc. and
just
> whatever you've noticed about raving that you want to go off on.  I'm
> especially interested in the organization of the production crews and
> massives, and economics and race issues: who goes to what parties,
how much
> money's involved not only in promoting and attending parties, but
how much
> people spend for raves: tickets, clothes, accessories, recreational
> others.....;)
> 
> Also, if you do respond (and I REALLY hope you do!) please tell me
if it's
> ok to quote you in my film.  If you don't mine my including your
thoughts
> and ideas, then please tell me if you'd like to be anonymous, or
give me
> whatever name you'd like to be identified by.
> 
> Let me say this: I am not out to slander the scene or the people in
it. I
> just want to show anything and everything that happens at parties.
> 
> Thanks for duking it out through this LONG message and I hope to
hear from
> you.
> 
> much love
> & besitos!   marie

To everyone who has responded and anyone who may yet respond (hopefully!)

THANK YOU SO MUCH!!!!! You have been wonderfully thoughtful and eloquent
and I'm glad no one is blowing this off because it means so much to me.  
I'm tempted to make a version for myself and scale it down into another
version for class...

To clarify: Your responses over the list, if I use them, will be quoted 
in a voice-over narrative, either by myself or most likely a friend I'll
enlist to speak cause I don't really want to be in it myself. I doubt that
I'll run them as subtitles or in title cards between shots because it's too
hi-tech, expensive, and I think kinda boring to read text in a film if you
don't have to.

If anyone is interested and would like to speak on film, I'll be at Feel Good 
Friday (10th) for sure.  I'm working on getting permission to film at The
Gathering on the 11th and the big F-8 party also the 11th.  Just look for a 
short Asian chick with a videocamera!  Also, if you like, contact me and maybe
we can arrange for interviews in person outside of these parties.

And thanks to everyone for your helpful tips on the archives and other 
documentary projects....you've been so supportive so far.  THANK YOU THANK YOU
THANK YOU for your interest and help.  You have put a HUGE smile on my face!

much love
& besitos!
marie

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 2 Apr 1998 14:18:32 -0000

	Thu, 02 Apr 1998 06:18:31 PST

From: "Nathan B" <nbeckord@hotmail.com>

Subject: short P head review

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Portishead was an enjoyable concert. Damn we were high up in the 
balcony, nosebleed seats 4 sure.  We hiked up to our seats, booted the 
klownz squatting in them, and proceeded to settle and sink lower and 
lower-- it was so mellow!  Now I'm not a huge Portishead fan, but I 
enjoy the stuff.  I like it because it's sort of a crossover between a 
rock band (guitar bass singer and all) plus funky beatz and the DJ.  A 
good transitional band to play to your friends who mebbe come from Live 
105 experience and you're trying to turn them on to electronic stuff

Anyhoo has anyone ever seen what she looks like?  I talked to a few 
pee-opals and no 1 had ever seen her actual face.  She was in shadows 
the whole time.  

Did I mention how mellow it was?  People sat placidly in their seats, I 
suppose captivated by her/them (peeps definitely WERE into it).  But 
even the floor below just stood there, an occasional 
head-bobb-to-the-beat.  

Did I mention it was mellow?  

NB

Hey,

A friend sent me this so I thought I'd send it along to you guys:

A Persistent Thumping
                  How Techno Music Has Outlived Its Obituaries

                  By Matthew Collin
                  Special to The Washington Post
                  Sunday, March 29, 1998; Page G01

                  Tough times for electronica. Barely a year ago,
electronic dance music in all its
                  many forms was being hailed by critics,
music-television programmers and
                  industry pundits alike as a phenomenon gathering
commercial force. But by the
                  end of 1997, the hype was in free fall.

                  "For the next big musical movement, electronica has
its work cut out," noted a
                  Washington Post critic. Another newspaper observed:
"As far as the masses
                  were concerned, electronica's major attack was as
easily squashed as house
                  spiders after a heavy rain."

                  The honeymoon had turned sour because -- with two
exceptions, the Prodigy
                  and the Chemical Brothers -- European musicians on the
crest of what had
                  been packaged as pop's new wave failed to make the top
200 best-selling
                  albums of 1997. Perhaps, the pundits mused, America
wasn't ready for a
                  techno revolution right now -- if ever. And then they
congratulated their
                  compatriots for not being bamboozled by the sales guff
exhaled by the record
                  industry.

                  But what got missed when the crits were tossing around
the obits was an
                  understanding of the dynamics of pop culture. Major
labels pick up a catchy
                  marketing phrase, run some ads, call in the pluggers,
get the sales forces
                  pumped, and you have yourself an instant "phenomenon."
Well, it just doesn't
                  work like that. Not for long, anyhow. A genuine pop
movement is never imposed
                  from above; it bubbles up on a groundswell of popular
belief, driven by the
                  passion and commitment of fanatics who create their
own sense of community.
                  Businessmen can sell product, but community can't be
manufactured.

                  "I think the expectations surrounding the genre were
unrealistically high," says
                  Billboard dance music editor Larry Flick. "The
industry was looking for a sales
                  savior and the instant buzz around electronica
triggered a lot of hope. Things
                  were definitely blown way out of proportion. Sometimes
major labels can kill
                  the golden goose long before it's actually laid that
golden egg. There were too
                  many questionable records released at once. The
bandwagon almost
                  collapsed from so many people climbing aboard."

                  Darren Ressler, editor of New York-based national
dance monthly Mixmag, is
                  cautious too, mainly because he's seen it all before.
Back in 1992, when the rave
                  scene with its techno soundtrack first took off in the
States, it proved to be a
                  false dawn, at least in commercial terms. "In 1992, I
saw the dance
                  departments at major labels go wild. The word 'techno'
was suddenly on
                  everyone's lips, and after releasing tons of mostly
horrible compilations,
                  everything went underground again," Ressler says.
"Still, the upside was that
                  the seeds of the culture were planted."

                  Not that anyone within "the culture" really liked the
word electronica anyway.
                  Most found it crass, even offensive; they were only
too aware that it was a
                  catch-all tag foisted on them for economic
convenience: a pidgin translation of
                  a much subtler tongue. The differing (and often, for
outsiders, confusingly
                  complex) sensibilities of techno, house, garage,
ambient, trip-hop, big beat
                  and drum 'n' bass were forced into an uneasy alliance
that pleased no one. "
                  'Electronica' was a marketing term invented by the
music industry to box up
                  everything from [techno trio] Underworld to [drum 'n'
bass hero] Goldie in one
                  neat little package, removing the music from its
subcultural origins and placing
                  it alongside Hanson, Mariah and Puffy," says Tamara
Palmer, editor of the
                  West Coast music monthly URB. "From this perspective,
electronica is a failure."

                  Liam Howlett of the Prodigy became incensed when the
phrase was mentioned
                  to him during the band's U.S. tour last summer: "I
hate this whole electronica
                  thing!" he raged. "It's so difficult trying to make
Americans understand -- I get
                  really frustrated sometimes doing interviews with them
and they go on about
                  this electronica thing and it really annoys me. I have
to say, 'Electronica is
                  [expletive]!' or 'Electronica, what the [expletive's]
that?' The whole thing is just so
                  hyped, it's crap."

                  There is a more serious point here, even if Howlett
couldn't quite articulate it.
                  The black musicians from Detroit and Chicago who
invented techno and house
                  in the mid-'80s always gave as many props to George
Clinton and James
                  Brown as German electronic innovators Kraftwerk. The
coining of "electronica"
                  represented a covert attempt to excise the funk
element from dance music and
                  ignore its origins in inner-city black and gay
subcults, to make it safe for the
                  affluent white consumer. Black music repackaged by
white entrepreneurs is the
                  shadow history of postwar pop, and sure enough, in the
flurry of enthusiasm
                  surrounding electronica, we heard little about Derrick
May, Juan Atkins, Larry
                  Heard, Jeff Mills or Mike Banks, the black auteurs who
breathed life into the
                  machines. While the predominantly Caucasian newcomers
basked in glory,
                  none of the originators was rewarded with a
substantive record deal. Each one
                  was more celebrated in London, Berlin, Madrid and
Paris, where they are
                  regarded as visionary heroes, than in their home
country.

                  The Birth Process

                  Let's rewind the tape and check back on some history,
see how this techno thing
                  really operates. Here's the archetypal tale: Couple of
young guys pick up some
                  cheap equipment in a secondhand store, a few obsolete
drum computers long
                  forgotten by their Japanese manufacturers. They hook
up the boxes in their
                  basement, make a tape. Cut it to 12-inch vinyl in a
run of 1,000: white label,
                  plain bag, title scribbled in Magic Marker. Sell it
direct to specialist dance
                  stores: no middleman, no record deal, no rehearsal, no
gigs, no ad campaign.
                  The only promotion is a few copies passed to club
deejays, the only media
                  coverage appears in some obscure local 'zine. The
stores pay them on
                  sale-or-return basis, and they reap a little cash to
fund the next release.

                  This is the mother lode, this is what every technohead
will tell you it's all about:
                  do-it-yourself music, an entrepreneurial movement
based on personal
                  involvement. Inclusive; open-access. Get up, get into
it, get involved.

                  Techno's democratization of the creative process links
it back to two other, more
                  longstanding DIY pop movements: hip-hop (assembled
from rudimentary
                  equipment: two turntables and a microphone) and punk
rock (a couple of
                  guitars plus three chords). It took a couple of
decades for hip-hop to rise from its
                  origins in block parties in the Bronx to its current
mainstream dominance. With
                  punk rock, the similarities are even more striking and
constitute a handy
                  deconstruction of the pop process.

                  On its release in 1977, a seminal punk album, the Sex
Pistols' "Never Mind the
                  Bollocks," topped the charts in the band's home
country, but only reached 106 in
                  the United States. When the Sex Pistols arrived in the
States in 1978, they were
                  hyped as the latest Brit invasion, come to save the
U.S. pop market as disco
                  threw its last satin-swathed shapes under the
"Saturday Night Fever" mirror
                  ball. At least that's what Warner Bros., the Pistols'
label, wanted people to
                  believe. Of course it never happened: The pimply
freaks with the peculiar
                  hairdos might as well have been aliens for all the
American public cared. But in
                  L.A., in Austin, Seattle and Washington, D.C.,
disaffected bohemians picked up
                  on the Pistols' do-it-yourself anarchist slogans and
took them seriously enough
                  to start their own bands, their own 'zines, their own
record labels. And this
                  industrious, low-tech punk network was the
entrepreneurial motor that
                  ultimately drove Nirvana up from the underground to
bestride the country with
                  "Nevermind" in 1991.

                  By the time of their 1996 comeback jaunt -- an overtly
cynical venture titled the
                  Filthy Lucre Tour -- things had changed. "Bollocks"
had been acclaimed as one
                  of the all-time rock classics by Rolling Stone
magazine, and the Pistols legacy
                  had inspired a whole generation of American bands from
R.E.M. through
                  Nirvana to Green Day.

                  If punk took over a decade to filter through, what
stage is techno at now? "In
                  terms of the nationwide acceptance, popularity or
integration of electronic
                  music into daily life that I see happening in England,
America is not yet on the
                  same page," suggests URB's Tamara Palmer.

                  Nevertheless, she says, "techno is definitely a
cottage industry in the U.S.,
                  serving as the inspiration for everything from
independent clothing lines to
                  record labels. It is a rapidly expanding system.
Nearly every region in the
                  country is informed by a local 'zine of some sort,
from Massive in the Midwest
                  and Synergy in the Southeast to Resonance in the
Pacific Northwest."

                  Techno undoubtedly has an image problem, being based
on participation
                  rather than performance, on the nocturnal community of
the nightclub rather
                  than the charisma of the performer, but although that
constitutes a drawback
                  in commercial terms, it is also its strength and its
appeal. And there are signs
                  that a section of the public may already be getting it
by proxy, assimilating
                  electronica through audio osmosis. Electronic
techniques underpin the new
                  albums by Madonna and Garbage, indicating that
America, if not ready for
                  techno's "Full Monty," is beginning to tune in.

                  Garbage includes in its ranks Butch Vig, producer of
Nirvana's "Nevermind" and
                  a man with a keen sense of which way the wind blows.
The band's "Version
                  2.0" album "pushes the electronic angle pretty hard,"
says guitarist Steve
                  Marker. "There's some aggressive, chattery techno
electronic stuff."

                  Madonna is a notoriously canny player who emerged from
the same gay dance
                  subcult as house music, and for her new album, "Ray of
Light," she employed
                  esteemed producer William Orbit to supply some techno
ambiance. "People
                  think of techno and drum 'n' bass, and they don't
equate emotion to it," she has
                  said. "I wanted to put a face on it."

                  "A mainstream champion like Madonna will help," says
Billboard's Larry Flick. "
                  'Ray Of Light' will do wonders for electronica. It's a
credible album that is going
                  to open a lot of doors for new artists. People are
hearing Madonna's album
                  and are intrigued to hear more of the genre."

                  Pop cultures need to adopt indigenous agendas to grow
genuine roots in new
                  host countries. And the United States is one of the
largest and most socially and
                  geographically dislocated of all nations, so this
organic development will
                  necessarily take longer than in Europe. As New
York-based journalist Joy Press
                  wrote, "America is a vast, diffuse territory where
ethnic, class and regional
                  allegiances have as much of an impact on pop as they
do on politics. While in
                  the U.K., rave became an essential part of music
culture and influenced
                  everything that came in its wake, in the U.S. it is
just a niche market."

                  To make sense to a wider listenership and chime with
mass tastes across such
                  a large market, the first techno band to break big may
well prove to be one
                  with a more developed sense of onstage showmanship and
songcraft. An
                  American Prodigy, perhaps, with big guitars and
swelling choruses. The early
                  warnings are already sounding: Mixmag's Darren Ressler
cites Rabbit in the
                  Moon from Tampa, DJ Icey from Orlando and the Crystal
Method; all snagged
                  deals as the majors scrabbled to process the
electronica signal.

                  "Like any genre, the second you have an identifiable
figure with a catchy song,
                  you have a hit. That really hasn't happened yet,"
Flick says. But "there is very
                  definitely an authentic club subculture. The
underground scene is incredibly
                  strong and creatively plush. There are no real stars
yet, but it looks promising.
                  The problem is that it's so expansive, almost too much
so, for such narrow
                  categorization. It also moves and evolves far too fast
for majors to keep up
                  with."

                  The Sound of Things to Come

                  Ultimately, none of this top-line stuff really matters
much. It's the geek-wizards
                  in their lofts, the tweaked-out club kids and the
'zine scribblers from the
                  boondocks, the obsessives who populate Internet
newsgroups like alt.rave who
                  represent electronica's future, if it is to have one.
"Musical innovation today is
                  happening in 17-year-old boys' bedrooms," says deejay
Justin Robertson, "like
                  the Aphex Twin recording his mum laughing and turning
that into a tune."

                  "Science and technology are transforming our world,
providing an age of
                  possibility and a time of change as profound as any we
have seen this
                  century," President Clinton told Congress last year.
He was talking about
                  industry but could equally have been mapping the pop
landscape:
                  Transformation is inevitable when the coming
generation is weaned on
                  computer games, sound cards and the Net. As Renaat
Vandepapeliere, head
                  of the respected European techno label R&S, once
declared: "People from this
                  generation learn computers in school like we learned
to write. Can you imagine
                  the music that these kids are going to make? The way
they are going to use
                  modern technology is going to be mind-blowing. This is
only the beginning."

                  And there are indications that the little guys are
growing in confidence,
                  beginning to walk with a swagger, just like their
counterparts did in Europe at
                  the turn of the '90s. Sample this letter to Mixmag,
written by a kid from Boise,
                  Idaho, who styles himself Dance Patriot: "We invented
techno and house music,
                  so why should the Chemical Brothers, Prodigy, and
Underworld take all the
                  credit? We should support our fledgling scene. Buy
American, and it's cheaper
                  than buying imports!" It's the ranters and ravers like
Dance Patriot, and his
                  compatriots in Orlando, Cleveland, Dallas -- the
evangelists, the hardcore
                  believers -- who will mutate the gene to breed an
intrinsically American strain
                  of electronica. The teens and twentysomethings who
want to breathe that
                  curious air, that heady compound of druggy
psychedelia, utopian reverie,
                  digital networking and militant urban attitude that
characterizes techno music
                  -- and to inhabit the eternal now that is the guiding
current of pop.

                  It could go something like this: After blurting out
his spleen on paper, our
                  letter-writer takes a moment to calm down. He switches
his computers on, taps
                  in a few digits and sets a cybernetic loop spooling
out of the speakers. It's a
                  clear night, so he opens the window, sparks up a
cigarette and watches the
                  smoke drift away into the cool air as the machines
sing gently to themselves.
                  Yes, he thinks, I can do it, it's time to cut this
track. Do it now.

                  Matthew Collin is the author of "Altered State: The
Story of Ecstasy Culture and
                  Acid House."

                  GLOSSARY

                  House: Disco stripped down to drumbeat and bass line,
then rebuilt using
                  electronic equipment. Origin: Chicago, mid-'80s.

                  Techno: Strictly technology-based house music with
influences from British
                  electronic pop and German avant-garde. The term
"techno" is often used to
                  describe all forms of electronic dance music. Origin:
Detroit, mid-'80s.

                  Garage: A more overtly disco-influenced form of house
music, often with diva
                  vocals. Origin: New York, mid-'80s.

                  Ambient: New Age music meets techno, with quieter
drums. Origin: London, late
                  '80s (based on theory from producer Brian Eno, London,
mid-'70s).

                  Trip-Hop: Hip-hop without the rap, plus an intoxicated
psychedelic feel. Origin:
                  Bristol, England, early '90s.

                  Big Beat: Techno meets hip-hop and indie rock in the
style of the Chemical
                  Brothers. Origin: London, mid-'90s.

                  Drum 'n' bass: Speeded-up hip-hop beats with
reggae-style bass lines and
                  techno effects. Alias "jungle." Origin: London, early
'90s.

                  -- Matthew Collin


                              Copyright 1998 The Washington Post
Company

!!!!!!!!!!Greetings SFravers!!!!!!!!!!!!
My name is bobbi, I live in Vancouver, BC.
I'm finally getting the chance to visit!!!
I've been waiting months for this, so I want to do it right! It was
suggested to me by my fellow NorthWestravers that I enquire within your
list for suggestions on parties, clubs, music and used clothing stores,
and any other goings-on of the week of April 20 to 26. I have a listing
from the events calender (so I know I'm missing Dubtribe by two
days....sob), but I'm not sure where to go, so any suggestions would be
very much appreciated. I'm going to try to attend Divinity Returns,
anyone going who wouldn't mind a foreigner tagging along, or if you know
how I can get a ticket, please let me know!
I'll mention that I'm a 25 year old female who's been enjoying the
Vancouver scene since '91. I'm into almost everything:  progressive
house, funky and acid breaks, drumandbass, acid trance, trip hop,
ambient, some hip hop and some speed garage. I do not like (no offence!)
anything epic, gabber, or  overly cheesey house. I'd like to know which
parties and clubs have the friendliest, craziest crowds (as you already
know, vancouverites are lovely, but they can be a bit subdued), and the
best music. I'm very open-minded, but travelling alone for the most
part, so please warn me if any venues aren't in the safest area, or
difficult to get to, or if there's anything else I should know before I
venture out. Thanx everybody!
xxxooo!!!
bobbi

Speaking of noise, does anyone else out there religiously tune in to KFJC? If so, you may have caught yesterdays complete insanity - an entire days worth of broadcasting this WEIRD noise stuff (as in, I listened to it on the way to work at 8AM, and it was still going at 10PM.
What it was was broadcasts from shortwave radio stations of secret codes used by the intelligence networks - i.e. its lots of static with voices going 5..4..8..2..9..4 etc.. for hours on end, mixed in with strange distorted music.
Completely beautiful.
Andy T trainspotted it as a 5CD set on Irdial records. Pretty whacky.
Big up the KFJC massive - who's going to their Sit and Spin party on Sat with Mr Hate spinning? Should be wild.
C@weasel

aaaaaaaah no pleeeeeeeeeease.
you candy ravers just don't know where to stop.
teletubbies is not funny, there's no entertainment value (not even on
drugs). there's no content. it might be cute at first but that wears off
after the first 3 minutes. it's totally brainless. it's not for slow
learners. it's for babies. it's annoying and stupid and babyish. hate hate
hate! it's up there on the hate scale w/ the spice girls.

take it. you can have it. we don't want it. it's revenge time, for all the
american soaps. i wish you would get some cool good stuff from england like
*father ted* or *red dwarf*.

ben + iris

how awful!

	a TV show targeted to 1 year olds???

what is this world coming to???

...the day i sit my 1 year old child down to watch television...
if that's the sort of entertainment you want to feed your child at that
early of an age (if _any_ age for that matter...)- you shouldn't be
'qualified' to have children!

GEESH!

>this is a t.v. show *for 1 year-olds*.....how much were you able to
>understand when you were that age??
*probably enough to know whether my parents cared for me and wanted to give
me quality entertainment... like their love and attention!

i know i'm going off on a tangent... but that whole idea of TV for 1 year
old has gotten me outraged!

nothing compares to you was written by prince, not sinead o'connor
thanks to the peeps who informed me, gotta give credit where its due : )



>it's been seven hours and fifteen days
>since you took your love away
>i go out every night and sleep all day
>since you took your love away
>i can eat my dinner in a fancy restaurant
>but nothing, i said nothing can take away these blues
>cause nothing compares
>nothing compares to you...
>...i went to the doctor and guess what he told me
>guess what he told me
>he said girl you better try to have fun no matter what you do
>well he's a fool
>cause nothing compares
>nothing compares
>         to you
>
>-Sinead O'connor "nothing compares 2 u"

Hi Rave Friends,

        I have seen positive articles and features on raves, although
perhaps not as many as the negative ones if you're considering only
non-scene-oriented media.

        Also, having a bit of firsthand knowledge of the media, I've rarely
known an editor-type to reject a well-written letter to the editor simply
because they didn't agree with what the writer was promoting.  Remember,
they thrive on controversy; they *want* people to write who disagree with
them!

        Also often overlooked is that whether or not a letter is published,
it is being read in the newsrooom, often by multiple people, and sometimes
discussed.  Attitudes among media people are informed and changed by the
feedback they get from the public.

        Why not be part of that feedback?  Here's a short list of S.F.
media contact information to get you started...


Channel 2 (KTVU-TV)       (510) 874-0242        451-2610
www.bayinsider.com
Channel 4 (KRON-TV)             561-8905        561-8136        www.kron.com
Channel 5 (KPIX-TV)             765-8610        765-8844        www.kpix.com
Channel 7 (KGO-TV)              954-7926        956-6402
Channel 9 (KQED-TV)             553-2100
San Francisco Chronicle         777-7100        543-7708
chronletters@sfgate.com
San Francisco Examiner          777-7850        777-2525
letters@examiner.com
San Francisco Bay Guardian      255-3100                        letters@sfbg.com
SF Weekly                       541-0700        777-1839
letters@sfweekly.com
San Franciso Independent        826-1100        826-5371
letters@csindy.com
San Francisco Observer          863-6397        431-2021
sfobserver@aol.com
San Francisco Beacon            431-4792        431-6450
mail@sfbeacon.com


        And back to the perennial drug issue.  If someone says, "Oh yeah,
it's all about drugs," I don't necessarily see that as negative.  Why does
it always have to be the drugs vs. the music?  I don't think raves would be
raves without either one of them.  If the U. in PLUR means anything -- and
I admit that personally I've always thought it was the vaguest part of the
acronym -- surely it means that we should be accepting of the various
musical and pharmicological tastes within our community.  If you can't even
achieve a semblance of unity with other ravers, who will you achieve it
with?

Far from PLURfect,
                                <<< Starchild >>>


Dan shared:
>>       On the other hand, it's not always the journalists' fault;
>>       they're looking for respectable sources to talk to, and there
>>       simply aren't very many people willing to go on record as
>>       being in favor of illegal drug use.
>
>        I think you have to pick your journalists and publications. Almost
>every
>newspaper, magazine and tv news show, no matter how safe or beneficial a
>recreational drug was, most would distort the story into a negative view. A
>lot of them don't want to be known for _promoting_ drug use. For example,
>I've never read or seen an article on raves that is positive, they'll talk
>to 20 ravers,  and only include quotes from the people who say stuff like
>"Oh yeah, it's all about drugs." instead of the guy or girl who says "It's
>all about music and the people who go." The late Timothy Leary had many
>articles published in newspapers and magazines in the "Reader's Opinion"
>section... But only under false names. No one would even consider printing
>his articles, just because he was involved in the whole pro-acid movement
>and helped get it out there. Although his articles often had nothing to do
>with drugs, just because the man himself did, the newspapers wanted nothing
>with him. I just personally think most newpapers and journalist are under
>very biased opinions...
>
>        Anyone agree/disagree?
>        Teknion 8-)
>
>
>---"I've been to lots of parties.. I've heard tons of tracks... But I have
>yet to see a DJ spin the City Bus track I keep hearing on my way home 8-)"

Subject: NRR: Two types of socialism
Cc: *Rave Friends* <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Rave Friends,

        I'd read this thread a while ago, and noticed that e.menon said
Hitler was not a socialist.  I wanted to say something about this, because
there seems to be a lot of confusion about what socialism is.  As I see it,
there are two distinct types.

        Hitler was indeed a socialist, but more to the point, he was what I
call a "top-down socialist," i.e. one who favored social engineering by
force.  The Nazis believed in public education, gun control (for the
people, not the state), worker control of workplaces, better health care
for the elderly, etc., and they believed in using the power of government
to force others to support these changes.

        Sound like our government today?  You bet.  The only difference is
the extremes to which the politicians regularly go to impose their agenda.
(So far mass extermination by oven or gas chamber is not considered an
acceptable means in the U.S.A.)

        The alternatives to top-down socialism as practiced in Nazi Germany
or Soviet Russia or other miserable states are individualism, where people
work independently or in groups organized for non-violent competition, or
"bottom-up" socialism, where they band together in *voluntary* collectives.


        Sometimes these voluntary socialist mini-collectives may even do
radical and subversive things like throwing rave parties without the proper
permits.

Peace, love & liberty,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

so _that's_ what that was! i tuned in on my way home from work today, at
one point there was a cement truck next to me on the fwy, it was white
w/ black stripes, and since it was churnning, major spirals were
happening, NO i didn't hit happy hour after work, it's just that a that
moment the trippy sounds coinsided w/ the Betelguese cement truck,
~weird~
had to turn it off, traffic was getting to me :\
actually, it would be perfect elevator music for the one in my new
building, my boyz [Mook~Guy~Byron] know what i'm talking about [shudder]
i take the stairs ;)
Elena

Catweasel wrote:
> 
> Speaking of noise, does anyone else out there religiously tune in to KFJC? If so, you may have caught yesterdays complete insanity - an entire days worth of broadcasting this WEIRD noise stuff (as in, I listened to it on the way to work at 8AM, and it was still going at 10PM.
> What it was was broadcasts from shortwave radio stations of secret codes used by the intelligence networks - i.e. its lots of static with voices going 5..4..8..2..9..4 etc.. for hours on end, mixed in with strange distorted music.
> Completely beautiful.
> Andy T trainspotted it as a 5CD set on Irdial records. Pretty whacky.
> Big up the KFJC massive - who's going to their Sit and Spin party on Sat with Mr Hate spinning? Should be wild.
> C@weasel
>

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Fri Apr 03 03:07:25 1998

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

Received: from [208.196.121.68] (sf-ip-1-96.ziplink.net [208.196.120.96])
	by ziplink.net (8.8.7/8.8.7) with SMTP id WAA25913;
	Thu, 2 Apr 1998 22:07:15 -0500 (EST)
X-Sender: dreamer@pop3.ziplink.net
Message-Id: <v01530501b149e9fc7a64@[208.196.121.68]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Thu, 2 Apr 1998 19:13:28 -0800
To: *Rave Friends* <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: Crash Worship review
Cc: TeKnODiVa <TeKnODiVa@aol.com>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Rave Friends,

>In a message dated 98-04-01 22:08:40 EST, Teknodiva shared:
>
>Very interesting.... My hair caught on fire....

        Well, my hair did not catch on fire, but my white jumpsuit is
trashed.  Definitely the wrong thing to wear to a Crash Worship show!  The
area in front of the stage was practically a mosh pit, with half-naked,
sweating people and lots of body paint.

        The most amazing thing about this event was that when we got there
around 9pm, the crowd was one of the most sedate I have seen.  People were
mostly sitting in small groups on the floor, or in chairs around the edge
of the big upstairs room at the Maritime Hall.  Somebody told me it would
get wild later, and I said, 'I don't think so, everybody's too relaxed.'
If you would have taken a picture at 9 o'clock, and another a few hours
later, and showed them to me, I would not have believed it was the same
bunch of people.  Even during the opening act, a girl-guitar band, everyone
was very laid back, with the notable exception of this one obnoxiously
drunk guy who kept shouting dumb things at the singer.  It was downright
roomy in front of the stage, with everyone sort of standing around,
eyes-forward.  Lots of cigarettes being smoked, although in the
high-ceilinged room I didn't find the smoke that noticeable.

        There did seem to be high expectations before the show, despite the
mellow vibe and smaller number of attendees than I'd expected to see for
this "cult" band.  One guy told me he'd come all the way from Cleveland to
see them, and was going to another show next week in Texas or someplace.
Still, most of the people there looked pretty average -- only a few looked
heavily punk or goth, the majority could have been at just about any event
anywhere.

        At some point after Crash Worship started though, the atmosphere
did a 180, and people really got into some frenzied dancing.  More body
paint appeared, and lots of shirts came off.  It was definitely an
experience.  There were several topless women on stage, dancing very, um,
sexually, and a float was carried through the crowd accompanied by drummers
and fire-eaters, at one point with a woman dispensing some kind of liquid
(?) from a sack, at another time a woman wearing a giant horned mask.  Some
of the footage would make an excellent fundraising video for the Christian
Coalition.  8)  There were some pretty cool visuals with text bits telling
a story about the Tower of Babel.  The music was mostly drums, but there
was some electronic stuff going on as well, overall it seemed very
trance-inducing, something that ravers might enjoy.  But of course the
friendly rave-vibe was absent.  The band also seemed to want to "control
the creative vision" as one person I talked to put it, limiting the amount
of audience participation.  One example:  Tired of being crushed and
jostled by the sea of bodies, and feeling exhibitionist as well, I got up
on stage for a bit to start dancing there as I'd seen a couple women do.
After a few brief exhilirating moments, one of the guys in the band without
warning tried to throw me into the crowd.  When that rude attempt failed,
he asked me to leave the stage.  I got the impression they are not as crazy
about having cute guys as cute girls up there with them, which also led me
to wonder about tonight's "women only" show advertised in the paper.

        Another lesson learned is that pot leaves one too relaxed and
mellow to get into truly proper Crash Worship mode.  Although I do wish
some of the folks there had been a bit mellower -- body contact while
dancing is good, but at a certain level it becomes downright dangerous.
I'm 6' tall and weigh about 165 lbs., but I felt it would have been quite
easy to suffer some grievous bodily harm while enjoying the show.

        I also lost my pager somewhere in the thick of things.  The first
time it fell off, a very sweet girl found it and gave it back to me, which
I should have taken as a warning to go and put it with my jacket in the
coat check.

        Slam-dancing your way to a bloody nose, or bloodying someone
else's, is not my idea of a good time.  The Crash Worship crowd was not
quite to that point I don't think, but they were definitely treading on the
edge.  On the bright side, you could hang on the edges of the main body of
dancers and still have a very unique, primal experience without having to
worry about your physical safety.

        Anyway, I didn't meet any other SFRavers there, although I ran into
Joe of peace-necklace fame, who I've seen at lots of raves.  I think it's
the first time in probably a dozen or more events I've seen him at that he
was without his booth, just there to enjoy the show.

        The overall verdict?  I had fun, and would recommend checking it
out, but I can't give a wholehearted endorsement.  The atmosphere reminded
me of some of the pagan abandon of Burning Man, which is a do-not-miss on
my list.  But BM has a lot of other elements that make it what it is that
were not present at CW, and I haven't witnessed the same level of physical
mayhem at Burning Man either, although it's certainly possible I just
wasn't in the wrong place at the wrong time.

May the bass be with us,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

I think an important thing to remember when discussing this kind of stuff 
is that there is a difference between "socialism" and "communism".

One deals with how individuals, groups and government interact 
(read: politics) and the other deals with the distribution of wealth 
(read: economics). 

:)

-Uncle Noah
"It's hard to be a socialist in the music industry."

From: Catweasel <cat.weasel@usa.net>
To: gtech@hardcorps.org
Subject: T-1000 at Sabotage
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

It all started with a visit to the hottest geekfest in town, the Netscape Mozilla source code launch party. Weird. Geeks completely going for it - turned out to be quite raging, all in all. 2000 people packed into a maze of a club (the Sound factory) with queues round the block - weird. Visuals of the source code scrolling past projected onto a huge screen were a nice touch.
Anyway, the main entertainment of the evening was Sabotage at El Pirata. Turned up at 11 - residents doing tag team with some funky techno and a bit of electro. The TV screens projecting a negative image of the DJ from the viewpoint of the mixer was a touch of genius.
The place got pretty full by midnight, when Alan Oldham, aka DJ T-1000, took to the decks. For the first half hour he kept it really deep and trancy, beautiful headfunk techno. Then, with one mix that just kept going over at least 5 minutes, he brought in a harder edge, and by then the quietly dancing crowd were ready for it - upping the ante and starting to cheer and shout. Up and up it went, harder and harder, more and more insane. A whole room of clued up clubbers writhing to the hard edged beats and crazy mixing skills. And finally Jeff Mills' "The Bells" was dropped (as it inevitably is at any techno gathering), and totally destroyed the throng - everyone jumping and hitting the air with their fists and screaming with the raw energy coursing through their bodies, extravenously injected through the big gateway speakers.
On and on it went, until 2.15 when all had to come to an end and the ovation T-1000 received was beautiful. We staggered out into the crisp San Francisco air, fully understanding how music can be a drug - and we had just got our fix. A great start to the new Sabotage night.
C@weasel

http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Underground/5185

tv is sick, tv for kids is sicker.  i have a friend with a couple a
rugrats, they don't have a tv.  while other kids their age are
hyperactive brats who can't talk or think about anything but the power
rangers, mike's 2 kids are these amazing little otherwordly beings,
hyperactive too but in a much better way.  better adjusted, way more
creative, interested in the world around them...

but on the other hand, they do tend to get up and demand attention at
6 am sat morning, ugh.  which is where a television set comes in
handy.  it's the ultimate babysitter - just plop the little tykes in
front of the box, and they're guaranteed not to move again till you
make them...

but i would like to check out the teletubbies sometime.  sounds wierd...

due to interest on the list, i am reposting an old review of a crash
worship show i saw last year in oakland.  btw, tonight they are doing
another show, for women only ("crash worship asks that only women
attend this show...")  wish i could go, it should be interesting - cw
tends to take a theme and run with it...




crash worship review - thanksgiving day, '97
--------------------------------------------

after seemingly endless misadventures, chris, martha stewart, pjfuzzy
and myself finally made it to the warehouse at 2nd and jackson, only
to wait about 3 hours for cw to start playing.  beyond race was making
swirly arabian/ambient shadow music while a dj spun in the other room.
 then some slacker with a distorted acoustic guitar made beckish
beefhearty skronking noises for a while (normally i dislike anything
that smacks of indie rock but i had to admit the guy was rather
entertaining, whoever he was). i listened and danced till finally at
3:13 am crash worship stormed the warehouse.  wow.  how can you
possibly describe a crash worship show?

dozens of torches were lit to drum swells and the germano-yiddish
strains of a string trio.  topless dancers spun flaming batons as
platters of semi-clad girls were hoisted around the warehouse.  a
woman standing next to me whistled a long drone along with the
violins, i accompanied her by whistling an indian melody as the dozen
drumers softly banged their way through the crowd...  a 6 foot tall
man with flaming horns threw handfuls of firecrackers into the masses,
dousing the floor and audience with flammible liquids before burning
his hat in a flaming pyre that mushroomed up to the wooden rafters. 
then things started to get crazy...

the drum core beat a furious tattoo as the mosh pit started to
writhe... band members wandered through the crowd with mylar sacks of
red franzia, soaking the crowd in dyonesian revelry.  wine drenched
shirts came off...  celebrating the harvest season, i scarfed half of
a "special" cigarette with pj, then passed it off into the swirling
masses...  the same platters that held the half-naked women now held
fruit and spit-roasted suckling pigs.  the element of danger added a
keen edge to my high - an orange hit me on the side of the face,
stinging my eye - what if that had been one of the bottle rockets the
guy with the horns was shooting into the oil soaked crowd?  a
beautiful woman did acrobatics hanging from a rope attached to the
ceiling as the strings lilted.  the drummers beat louder and faster as
she spun and spun and spun...  the tempo picked up again, those guys
could make a pretty phat beat when they put their minds to it, i was
sucked into the crowd once again...  a semi-neud couple necked in the
middle of it all, i lightly caressed them as i floated by, they didn't
seem to mind...  louder, faster, louder, louder, my ears were
splitting as the whole scene built to a crazy creshendo till suddenly
at 4:23 the cops busted in and shut off the sound system.  but of
course that couldn't stop the drummers, who continued to wander
through the crowd beating furiously as the police tried to chase them
down.  meanwhile the string quartet was now being pushed through the
crowd by naked men on a viking ship with wheels as they handed out
grapes to the revelers and the beautiful woman had stripped off her
fishnets and was doing more erotic ballet hanging from another spot on
the ceiling...  the five cops and ten security guys were still trying
to get the 400 or so people out the door, they were arguing with the
drummers, who (practically at gunpoint) led a bunch of us out the door
and onto the street, where they continued to play and dance till 4:36
am - one hour and 23 minutes later.


funny thing about crash worship - the first time i saw them they did
the same show (minus circus acts and pigs) to 13 people in a small
club in raliegh n.c. one wednesday.  my roomate knew one of the band
members from art school, so we invited them to stay the night at our
20's farmhouse in bynum (pop 223).  ALL RIGHT, i thought, THE PLACE IS
GONNA GET TRASHED!  COOL!  you can imagine my (pleasant?) surprise
when, upon their arrival at our house, their drummer dreike made
herbal tea for everyone while chit-chatting with me and my wife, and
then they all went promptly to sleep - but not before washing out all
their mugs and placing them neatly to dry on the dishrack.  _very_
nice people...

-messiah wannabe

um, i'm gonna restrict this to what i've been listening to lately
(like this week), lifetime faves is just too hard to chose...

5. van morrison
4. marvin gaye
3. vivaldi guitar concertos
2. foxy brown soundtrack (foxy not jackie)
1. missy/aaliyah/timbaland

i _really_ dig those timbaland produced cd's, yeah they're pop r&b,
but in the best way possible.  timbalands production reminds me of
jungle sometimes, the way he switches the beat around, but it's slow
and deep instead of hyper like jungle.  the alliyah cd is like upbeat
pop and "quiet storm" stuff, while the missy cd is darker, more rap,
heavier beats.  both are exellent, i think they stand up with any of
the motown classics, or any other "classic" r&b - i listened to them
all last summer, and all winter, and they're still in heavy rotation
in my car...

-messiah

Hey all,
   theres a program on the web called winamp
   < http://www.mindspring.com/~farsyde/winamp.html>
 i've been using for a few months. Basicly it's c/d quality sound,
 from the web. 
 the program to record mp3's (the files that Winamp plays)
 is freeware. I'm telling all of you this in hopes that some of you,
 the ones who spin, will record some of your work in mp3 format.
 if anyone can tell me of any existing mp3 techo sites 
 I'd love you forever, (not that I don't already)

i'd like to ask this sweet girl how long she's been into jungle, and/por
how many parties she's been to..
coz...
every true junglist would know that dancing is the ultimate release of
stress and emotion for a nuttah. it's all GOOD not WEIRD... what's wrong
with dancing like a nuttah? it's all GOOD! how can y
i thought the show was a little weird coz of all the people STANDING
AROUND... whats upw ith THAT !!! weird...
i mean, are you people TIRED, that's all good yeah.. coz i know what its
like to have a bad back and all.. but i dunno, how can you call as show
weird cox of crazy dancers when you're talking about a JUNGLE GIG?!
if the guy's dancin a lil crazy, so be it.. he's groovin to the shit
HARDCORE and i give him MAD PROPS no matter HOW weird he looks -- coz at
least he GOT THE PASSION! 
 and
singing to drumnbass -- have you ever heard of MC'S?!?!?! they're
essentail to a kickass live show! they're singing in a sense, rapping,
whatever... 
funky divas and shit, they know what's up.. they add FLAVA to the beats,
SOUL to the groove. 

well to make a long story short:
if you've never heard of singing to drumnbass
and if you think dancing crazy at a junglegig is weird...

you got alot to learn about junglists.

give it up for the crazyass true  junglists
they got mad stylez and funkalicious flava!!

much respect that you had fun jumpupgrrrl but you gotta learn to respect
and understand all aspects of the scene, whether you're into it or not.
coz the singers and the dancers hold it together... they're contributing
to the mad amount of frenzy and love and passion that bust out a phat
wicked party. ya dig? 
 xo
lara
