Date: Sun, 5 Apr 1998 09:38:24 -0700 (PDT)
From: Zach Lawryk <goombata@best.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: A "Bionic" Tragedy
Message-ID: <Pine.BSF.3.96.980405091903.23348A-100000@shell13.ba.best.com>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


     It was just an average night before going to a party. Anticipation is
high and nothing but time's passing by seems to matter. After arriving in
dowtown Oakland the excitement grows. The location that In-Touch
productions chose for this "Bionic" party looks like a well thought out
location. When calling the info line I was urged to get my pre-sale
tickets early because there was a very limited capacity. This statement
brought my excitement up a notch. It looked like a great party with some
big name dj's and plenty of room to dance. Arriving at the door I started
to realize that everything I thought was wrong. The line was deceptively
short and it looked like not too crowded of a party. I was dead wrong. As
I walked through the door it was only 10'oclock and already the dancefloor
was packed. It was nearly impossible to move around the place and when you
found a nice spot to dance more people came through the door flooding the
floor. By 12 it seemed that there was not an inch of cold wet pavement to
dance on. 70 percent of the people were not even moving just standing
around. The sound system could not handle and tracks with a hint of bass
in them. The speakers sounded like a stock system in a car on full blast.
recieved many , "Get the fuck outa the way." and "Move bitch." The vibe of
this party was horrific. I can understand why people were mad. Nobody
likes being at a party that is hotter than a New York august. No fans or
windows allowed for no airflow and the stench of sweat and smokes. The
Drum'n'Bass room was so packed that it was an adventure to get in far
enough to hear what set the Dj was playing. In the main room DJ's were
made to sound like crap with a system that could not support the beats in
their set. It seemed that almost every dJ shopped at the same record shop
for there was at least 3 records played more than twice. To top it all off
after you are sweating more water than the Salt Lake they charge you 2
dollars for water in a line located at the most inaccesible place in the
whole wherhouse(spell check). I recomend that you never attend another
In-Touch party in your life or never attend your first. In-Touch needs to
learn that there is more to making a party than booking the dj's. The main
reason they exist is because of us. Treating people like caged animals is
no way to thank a bunch of people that just payed for your rent.


               One Love,

                  Goombata

Anybody recommend any RA sites with better audio quality and rates
closer to 40K (most seem to be 16-24 K). I wanna see all the cool
things my new 56K modem (USR V-Everything External) and PPP gateway
(www.ugate.com) can do!

Even better would be places w/ MPEG3's of people's mixes. I'd just love
to get my hands on the Betalounge's winter music conference sources in
DAT or MPEG3 format! Even though the RA stuff sounds kinda yucky,
it's still nice to be able to hear all those great DJ's.

PS: I've found that through judicious use of multiband
compression/expansion/eq (combined w/ direct SPDIF digital output of RA
stream from my computer), when piped through my TC Electronic Finalizer
(digital dynamics processor), I can make AM-radio sounding RA sites
(e.g. www.betalounge.com or www.pirate-radio.com)  sound downright
snappy coming out of the Genelec studio monitors! But like they say,
you can't shine  shit and I sure would like some better sounding stuff
with higher bitrates and a stereo image.

Subject: Thanks Jill! Happy Story (NRR)

Hey Kidz,

I wanted to write this note and send it personally
but after thinking about for a sec. I thought you
might find this story kind of cool.

On Friday I took my good friend Eric snowboarding for
the first time. We experienced some difficulties with
our car but had a good time and made it off the hill
with about 5 hours to spare before the rest of our
party made it up the hill.

I had remembered that Jill (cheerio 80) worked over at 
the Starbucks in Truckee so we decided what the heck
lets call her up and say hola'. Now you have to
understand I have never met Jill and talked to her
once via:e-mail. Without hesitation she said, "stop
by and see me!" so it was off to Starbucks (the ONLY
place to hang out if your in high school and live in
Truckee).

We meet Jill and she says,"I'll take my lunch!" and it
was off to "the King" for some chicken sandwiches. We
instantly clicked, you know those weird instances where
you just meet someone and you feel like you have known
them forever? Well Jill asked her boss to let her
off early and said, "Since you have no-where to go lets
go back to my place and you can kick it and wait for 
your friends." We were super stoked! Her parents took
us in like we were family and we both had a great time
hanging with Jill, messing around on her tables
(junglist DJ's beware) she is just an absolutely
SUPER person!! Mind you we were supposed to be there
a couple of hours and left at like 1 in da' morning
do to lagging raver time. 

I just wanted to thank you Jill, publically for opening
your home to Eric and I. You are a very special person
and if you ever need a place to stay (we got the house
in S.F ;) my home is open to you and your friends. All
because I happend to be on "sfraves". You rock the
house Jill! Come see us when you visit your man ;)

Layne

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Tue, 7 Apr 1998 11:27:56 -0400 (EDT)
X-Sender: dreamer@pop3.ziplink.net
Message-Id: <v01530511b14fd39c8913@[208.196.121.32]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Tue, 7 Apr 1998 08:34:12 -0800
To: *Rave Friends* <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: Re: NRR: Two types of socialism
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Rave Friends,

Noah shared:

>You can only profit if there is gain in the trade of goods or services.
>In a system of group ownership of property, you could try day and night to
>sell
>something and you'd never get a buyer because if someone really wanted
>that item, all they'd have to do is come and get it and use it.

        One of the problems I see with extreme socialism (aka communism) in
which not only the means of production and distribution, but ALL property
is owned by society at large, is illustrated by the common phrase,
"Possession is nine tenths of the law."  Say you want to wear to your next
rave a colorful outfit which is currently in the possession of a big, mean,
professional wrestler who sleeps with an Uzi under his bed.  Are you really
going to be able to just walk into the house where he resides (note: not
*his* house) and take it?  Probably not, unless you're willing to bring a
small army or break in when he's not home.

        If you wanted the outfit badly enough to go to that kind of
trouble, you might be willing to pay some amount of money to him, or to a
third party, such as a sympathetic mutual friend, to obtain the transfer of
the group-owned property in question without going to the trouble of
exercising your legal rights to it directly.

        Of course this is overlooking all kinds of custody and transfer
problems that would obviously arise when multiple individuals wished to use
the same item over a period of time.  Considering how such a system would
actually work makes it seem even more unlikely to me that private property
will ever be abolished on any scale larger than among a small group of
friends or in a limited environment such as a workplace.

        But that's not necessarily a bad thing.  Take away ownership and
sharing no longer carries the same qualities of generosity and kindness.
Instead it brings resentment and guilt, as people take things that others
really don't want to give.

Peace, love & liberty,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

>
>Hey Kidz,
>
>I wanted to write this note and send it personally
>but after thinking about for a sec. I thought you
>might find this story kind of cool.
>
>On Friday I took my good friend Eric snowboarding for
>the first time. We experienced some difficulties with
>our car but had a good time and made it off the hill
>with about 5 hours to spare before the rest of our
>party made it up the hill.
>
>I had remembered that Jill (cheerio 80) worked over at 
>the Starbucks in Truckee so we decided what the heck
>lets call her up and say hola'. Now you have to
>understand I have never met Jill and talked to her
>once via:e-mail. Without hesitation she said, "stop
>by and see me!" so it was off to Starbucks (the ONLY
>place to hang out if your in high school and live in
>Truckee).
>
>We meet Jill and she says,"I'll take my lunch!" and it
>was off to "the King" for some chicken sandwiches. We
>instantly clicked, you know those weird instances where
>you just meet someone and you feel like you have known
>them forever? Well Jill asked her boss to let her
>off early and said, "Since you have no-where to go lets
>go back to my place and you can kick it and wait for 
>your friends." We were super stoked! Her parents took
>us in like we were family and we both had a great time
>hanging with Jill, messing around on her tables
>(junglist DJ's beware) she is just an absolutely
>SUPER person!! Mind you we were supposed to be there
>a couple of hours and left at like 1 in da' morning
>do to lagging raver time. 
>
>I just wanted to thank you Jill, publically for opening
>your home to Eric and I. You are a very special person
>and if you ever need a place to stay (we got the house
>in S.F ;) my home is open to you and your friends. All
>because I happend to be on "sfraves". You rock the
>house Jill! Come see us when you visit your man ;)
>
>Layne
>

lasted 10 minutes.  My ears just tell me what speed the track is relative to

In a message dated 4/7/98 5:42:09 PM, kincy@tibco.com wrote:

<<just a question for all you peeps out in dj-land. how do you keep track of

the bpms for all your records ? In my case, I am somewhat a-retentive and

meticulously time and label all my records. it's not as bad as it soundz,

kincy>>

there is a nifty piece of software for the mac that i use to identify bpm...i
just send the input to my computer and VOILA! it measures and verifies the
bpm. This works perfectly for 4-on-the-floor beats; more complicated rhythm
structures require a longer sampling time, but it still gets it accurate just
the same.

i found this 'lil program on cnet's webpage, shareware dept.

--vortex

<<Maxims for the Internet Age
 
 1.     Home is where you hang your @
 2.     The E-mail of the species is more deadly than the mail.
 3.     A journey of a thousand sites begins with a single click.
 4.     You can't teach a old mouse new clicks.
 5.     Great groups from little icons grow.
 6.     Speak softly and carry a cellular phone.
 7.     C:\ is the root of all directories.
 8.     Don't put all your hypes in one home page.
 9.     Pentium wise; pen and paper foolish.
 10.    The modem is the message.
 11.    Too many clicks spoil the browse.
 12.    The geek shall inherit the earth.
 13.    A chat has nine lives.
 14.    Don't byte off more than you can view.
 15.    Fax is stranger than fiction.
 16.    What boots up must come down.
 17.    Windows will never cease.
 18.    In Gates we trust (and our tender is legal).
 19.    Virtual reality is its own reward.
 20.    Modulation in all things.
 21.    A user and his leisure time are soon parted.
 22.    There's no place like http://www.home.com
 23.    Know what to expect before you connect.
 24.    Oh, what a tangled website we weave when first we practice.
 25.    Speed thrills.
 26.    Give a man a fish and you feed him for a day; teach him to
use
 the Net        and he won't bother you for weeks.

 New Words for the 90's
 

 Assmosis       The process by which some people seem to absorb success
 and advancement by kissing up to the boss rather than working hard.
 
 
 Chips and Salsa        Chips = Hardware; Salsa = Sofware.  "Well, first
 we gotta figure out if the problems in your chips or your salsa."
 

 GOOD Job       A "Get-Out-Of-Debt" job. A well-paying job people take
in order to pay off their debts, one that they will quit as soon as they are solvent
 again.
 
 Idea Hamsters  People who always seem to have their idea
generators running.
 
 Irritainment   Entertainment and media spectacles that are
annoying, but  you find yourself unable to stop watching them.  Prime example:  the 
O.J. trials on CNN.
 
 Keyboard Plaque        The disgusting buildup of dirt and crud found on
 computer keyboards.
 
 Mouse Potato   The online, wired generation's answer to the couch
 potato.
 
 Ohnosecond     That minuscule fraction of time in which you realize
 that youve just made a big mistake.
 
 Percussive Maintenance The fine art of whacking the crap out of
an electronic device to get it to work again.
 
 Perot  To quit unexpectedly, as in "My cellular phone just
 perot'ed."
 
 
 Seagull Manager        A manager who flies in, makes a lot of noise,
 defecates over everything and then leaves.
 
 SITCOMs        What yuppies turn into when they have children and one of
 them stops
 working to stay home with the kids.  It stands for Single Income, Two
 Children, Oppressive Mortgage.
 
 Squirt the Bird        To transmit a signal to a satellite.
 
 Starter Marriage       A short-lived first marriage that ends in
divorce with no kids, no property and no regrets.
 
 Stress Puppy   A person who seems to thrive on being stressed out
 and whiny.
 
 Treeware       Hacker slang for documentation or other printed material.
 
  
Have a fun day everyone.

	><{{{">   <"}}}><

		foolish fish

At 01:46 PM 4/7/98 -0700, Rudi Rughoonundon wrote:
>you guys can flame me for this but i am going to come out and say it
anyways ... why the hell do we have 2 weeklies on monday evenings in san
jose now ... i mean the san jose scene does not have enough people to

COMPETITION forces people to perform at their absolute best.  if you've got
two weeklies going down on the same night you can bet they'll each be
grabbing the best talent they can, making the most visually entertaining
flyers they can, putting together the best nightclub atmosphere they
can...just to snag your hard-earned dollars.

even if this isn't happening right now sooner or later one of the clubs is
going to have to up the ante in order to increase their numbers.  

me, i like the idea of a choice.  if one club is getting overly housey,
let's say, and i'm bored with that, it's nice to have another option to
turn to.

At 10:37 AM 4/7/98 -0700, Kincy Clark wrote:
>just a question for all you peeps out in dj-land. how do you keep track of
>the bpms for all your records ? In my case, I am somewhat a-retentive and
>meticulously time and label all my records. it's not as bad as it soundz,
>but i was just curious how other people did it.
>
>kincy
>

it seems rather easier to simply get a feel for manually beatmatching,
rather than doing it arithmetically.  besides, riding the groove...keeping
your fingers loose yet tight on that mysterious revolving label in the
center, all the while your right hand not knowin' what the left is doing
just goin' crazy on pitch control, smooth slide heading down..."madre de
dios!  i am approaching the dreaded plus 8, o can it be that these records
won't match?"

NO!  somewhere around 7.5 you tentatively lift your shaking,
low-blood-sugar digits from the label, and listen with sweaty, perked-up
ears as the mix screams through the headphones for the murderous
dropped-marble chaos of a beat mismatch (o yah, we in "da biz" call dem
"car crashes" or sumtin like dat).

but it's smooth and clean and o yeah you bring that fader up just like you
was Jeno himself...oh the needle rolls into a break, so CUT THE MIDRANGE,
DROP THE BASS!

now start all over.  and do that for a couple hours.

-----------------------
"sweet in winter.  sweet in rain.  shake well before use.  she said 'you'll
never touch me anymore this way.'"

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 7 Apr 1998 21:36:09 -0000

	id AA13209; Tue, 7 Apr 98 17:36:09 EDT
Received: from BENCHUN.MIT.EDU by MIT.MIT.EDU (5.61/4.7) id AA12324; Tue, 7 Apr 98 17:35:59 EDT
Message-Id: <3.0.32.19980407173559.00ad02d0@po8.mit.edu>
X-Sender: benchun@po8.mit.edu
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 3.0 (32)
Date: Tue, 07 Apr 1998 17:36:00 -0400
To: sayzone@juno.com (miss heart), sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: b e n c h u n <benchun@MIT.EDU>
Subject: Re: pitch control
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

At 03:51 PM 4/7/98 EDT, miss heart wrote:
> how much does the pitch control mathmatically
>change the bpm? (what does +2 mean? 2%?)

you got it.. it actually changes the speed of the motor, so if you had it
on 33 RPM, locked on 0 and then move it up to +2 then it's now going
33*1.02=33.66 RPM...

>what do the dots lit up by the strobe signify? i've 
>had people explain this to me before, but my brain
>hasn't been able to  grasp the concept. 

related concept. the dots are spaced so that when the table is locked at 0,
the dot will arrive in front of the strobe just as it flashes, and appear
to stand still. if you speed up the table, dots begin arriving "ahead" of
the flash. to look at it another way, each consecutive dot is beyond the
spot where the previous dot was during the strobe flash. thus they appear
to slowly move off to the side.

the different rows of dots are for 33 or 45 RPM... essentially, this is a
hard-wired physical way to tell if your turntable is calibrated correctly,
and to get visual feedback as you adjust the pitch. i hope this made sense...


. . . . . . .
benchun@mit.edu
http://mdma.mit.edu/

Any one seen those new records with a chip implanted in the
center part? You need a special adapter for the turntable
to read them but they contain lots of info like bpm,track length,
etc that is then displayed on a lcd readout. The chips can be attached
manully to the records you already have and programed with another
little gizmo.

I have been listening to a few home made mix tapes lately and I found
something in common with several of them that really erked me. I felt as a
listener and a buyer of mix tapes that I would make a suggestion to those
DJ's and any other aspiring DJ's.

My suggestion: please please please fade out the last track on your tape. It
is most painful to my heart my mind and my ears to be really into a track
and to have it cut off right in the middle because it's the end of the tape.
However if the song faded out smoothly at least I would expect the track and
the tape to end and not have a heart attack when it did.

Thanx to those of you who already do this and to those of you who now will

MooK<><

hey bobbi,

i don't know if i qualify for the catwalk or anything, but i buy a lot
of clothes in the vintage clothing stores around valencia and 16th.  i
see other thriftravers in them as well sometimes.  das pussycat on
16th btwn valencia and guererro has nice stuff, more spendy but
generally under $20.  lots of mod stuff there.  clothes contact on
valencia, btwn 16th and 15th, has clothes by the pound, it's much
cheaper, i got a cool safety-yellow jacket there recently for about
$6.  and theres a few other places within a couple of blocks.  plus
the mission is fun to hang out in, lots of bars, clubs (liquid on 16th
btwn mission and van ness, for instance), scarification studios...
plus you can get indian ice cream at bombay ice cream on valencia btwn
16th and 17th.

gee, i oughtta be a tour guide...


-messiah

sorry if this is kinda late, but i only have so much time to read sfraves
and write emails at work, but i wanted to say something

i went to the advanced screening for this movie in la last tuesday. i
believe the film is scheduled to be released sometime next november. these
are just some brief thoughts on the screening:

essentially, i hope they fix it in time for release. there are many things
i like about what theyve got so far. for example, johnny depp does a pretty
good raoul duke. his rendition seemed very cartoony, reminded me a lot of
the ralph steadman drawings

the first half covering the dirt bike races was quite good

in the second half, about the dea's convention, i feel the director took
too much of a liberty rearranging things a little bit. it made it difficult
to stay focused on the story. they change the ending slightly too

they definitely do their best to try and shock the audience as best as they
can. after a while, it gets a little bit too much. in my opinion, it
downplayed a little bit the big message i got from the book, which is: this
is what we believed in the 60s, and this is what we are left with now

i dont remember who played dr gonzo, but i never really liked his character
in the book anyway and so i didnt really like the way the character was
handled in the movie

i believe november is the date to look out for as far as a release goes

anyway, have a good day everyone, and ill see you this saturday at
frequency 8!

joe

I apologize, I don't think the two posts I posted before my last post that showed up made it to the list. My mail server has been acting whacky, and I wanted to make sure that I got my thing in.

RUDI, I apologize that you feel the way you do, and that it was such a problem about the BSP I posted about the Monday nite weekly.. I was not aware that Afterglo was a Monday night party in San Jose.  Also, the party TOP SHELF, is thrown by the same person who throws VelvetShop on Thursday nights and also The GREEN GORILLA LOUNGE this past weekend... Which is Manny.  

I am sorry that it was such an ordeal for me to post what was going on, but I am not trying to create COMPETITION.  I was just INFORMING people of the party, and not knowing that Afterglo was on the same night, ALSO afterglo has a little advantage over Top Shelf, its an actual 18+ party in SJ, not a 21+.  

Once again I am sorry, but I also thank Layne, I do have the right to post BSP's. This list is to INFORM of parties not just have rave discussions.  I am on 10 different mailing lists, so it is hard for me to keep up with posting all the time, but when I think of something or something comes up, I do post it.  Getting 400 emails a day is a little crazy, and you can lose your self in it sometimes.  

Sorry for any problems I have caused, but I really don't see what the big deal is.

In-Reply-To: <19980407235508.27677.qmail@www08.netaddress.usa.net>
Message-ID: <Pine.LNX.3.95.980407202550.23314I-100000@avalon.slackers.net>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I've gotta side with Rudi on this issue.

I don't think Rudi was trying to flame you for posting BSP's or anything
like that, or because your event is on the same night as afterglow.

But the facts are simple:  We'd all like to foster a scene in SJ.  But,
assuming that there are only a limited number of people to support that
scene, both events, when scheduled for the same night, are hurt.

Say that on any given Monday night, there are only 100 ravers that decide
to go out.  20 might go to Top Shelf, 80 go to Afterglow.  The managers of
whatever club Top Shelf is get bummed, because they aren't making any
money, because there are only 20 people there...so they start to wonder if
they should even be open on Mondays, or maybe give that timeslot to some
other event.   The managers of the Cactus Club, on the other hand,  are
more satisfied, because they have more business.

Or vice versa.

Even in a perfect world, if 50 people go to one and 50 go to the other,
from the managers' POV, that's not alot of heads, and they don't make much
profit.

It's supply and demand.  True, having the option to go to either is nice,
but let's face it, unless both places get packed and stay packed, one or
the other is going to be cancelled, because the clubs' owners won't be
feeling like they're making enough profit to stay open.

On the other hand, if Afterglow is on Mondays, and Top Shelf is on some
other night, then those 100 people will most likely ALL go to one, and
then ALL go to the other.  Mangers everywhere are happy, because their
clubs are full.

Just a thought,

-jimg

--skoop@slackers.net
--http://www.slackers.net/~skoop

Quoth b e n c h u n:
>the different rows of dots are for 33 or 45 RPM... essentially, this is a
>hard-wired physical way to tell if your turntable is calibrated correctly,
>and to get visual feedback as you adjust the pitch. i hope this made sense...

On a Technics SL1200mk2 that's not quite true. All the dots work the same
for 33 and 45. There are four sets of dots: +6%, +3.3%, 0, and -3.3%.
You're right of course, they're very usefull fo checking calbration. Great,
now I know that my decks are way off.

Ulrich                                               standish@sirius.com

here i go playing tour guide again...

on mason st, right up from the youth hostel (downhill from post) are a
bunch of 24 hour diners i really like.  the pinecrest is where this
waitress got shot last year, made all the papers.  given the service
we got there, i'm not surprised, but it is pretty diner-ific.  i like
one of the other places better, it's 1/2 block downhill, this 50's
lookin place w/checkered floors and lotsa chrome.  it's pretty cool,
for instance there's nothing but 50's and early 60's stuff on the cd
jukebox, plus they make killer malted shakes, and a great breakfast
any time of day.  plus you see a real wide variety of people there at
3am, tourists, ravers, asian gangsta kids, businessmen, hookers...

the one a few doors downhill from it is bigger, but not as good.  look
for the one with the (much) smaller shopfront w/the grill in plain
sight and the 50's choons piped out onto the street...

-messiah

i agree that we should be trying to create togther instead of competing
against each other, but that would be like asking martin not to throw a
gathering because vlad is throwing a fge. sometimes our own agendas don't
quite mesh with those of others. we need to stop trying to find what is
wrong with each situation and start seeing the good in it all. think about
this. when i left san jose in october 97, there was no 18+ dance night at
least not the kind of dancing that i wanted to do. there are plenty of 21+
weeklies and i am sure they aren't going to lack for support. we need to
support 18+ weeklies, so that they keep happening. i give mad props to the
afterglo kids for all the hard work that they are doing.

matt

>compression/expansion/eq (combined w/ direct SPDIF digital output of RA
>stream from my computer), when piped through my TC Electronic Finalizer

>(e.g. www.betalounge.com or www.pirate-radio.com)  sound downright
>snappy coming out of the Genelec studio monitors! 


errr... how bout just put it all thru a heAvyMeTal pedal 8)
(almost as good as an Alec Empire set)

>But like they say,
>you can't shine  shit and I sure would like some better sounding stuff
>with higher bitrates and a stereo image.

AFTERGLO :) 
well i had 3 hours wack sleep this morning but it was well worth it..

never before have i seen a buncha guys have so much fun throwing their own
weekly -- YEAH!!! PROPS to the boys! i found myself a new home for monday
nights, even though it won't always be jungle (sniff) the crowd is plush
and vibey and well, how can i resist...
the jungle was great, a bit alcohol-influenced near the end *ahem* NOAH
YOU ROCK which just made the night taht much more fun! the crowd too, i
was surprised there are so many SoBay junglists out there... PROPA !!!!
:))
got there early, left late and danced the majority of the night, running
into SFRavers new and oldz alike (if i named you all it'd be like rollcall
or something, and i KNOW i'd be mispronouncing your names) but dear lord
be nice to me, i was tipsy. and my head couldn't get off that dancefloor,e
ven though i sat it out a bit..
	SOOPER PROPS for AndyW's RAGGA and oldskoolin jumpup tracks he was
throwin ddown in the beginning, yeah thats what it is he was playin btw :)
even origin unkown's 31 seconds YEAH makin a comeback (once again).. 
	and SCIENCE's LOVELY LOVELY set with his diverse selection that
flows like it's all one song..
	and HAK/THAD who just kicks in all aspects, his style just blows
my mind straight *UP* (you had me running back in the club all night
evertime i just lit a cigarette goin *DAMN! again?*) 
	and of course SIPHON for his inceredibly enthusiastic,
smile-abundant set that kept everyone nutting and screamin and beggin for
more.. nice scratchin, brotha ;))

i have to say, i saw alot of people i haven't seen in ages and it FELT
GOOD to see you all, and meet you all, and hang with people i saw in
recent times as well.. and if you wonder who i was, i was wearin a purple
shirt and really short blonde hair..
*DINK*
see you all at afterglo next week! and if you miss it, you're missin OUT
:) 
+ these guys are just tryin to give us somethin to do on a monady night,
$3 at the door $5 for 18+ doesn't make for a profit, i don't think... just
representin the south bay the way they can do it best.. and they DO DO IT
THE BEST!!!!  TRUE THAT!!!!!!!!
:)))
xo
lara

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi. it's me again, and I need more help.  I want to structure the documentary
into little chapters or sections, each dealing with various aspects of raving.
seems logical, right?  I also have to keep in mind who the audience is going
to be: people who don't know about raves or think they do, based on nasty
little
one-sided things like the 20/20 special.  In other words, I want to define or
explain terms and other things and in doing so, hopefully show a balanced
view of what the rave scene is.

And as I am new to raving, I thought I'd seek advice from you more experienced
people. what aspects of raving do you think should be defined or presented?
For example, I'm considering sections like massive vs. underground, candy
raver/
candied up, music (to include DJs, trainwrecking, types of music, etc.),
fashion,
drugs.....
suggestions?

Basically, assume you have to explain raving to someone who doesn't know.
what are the major areas you would outline?  don't be afraid to gimme both
good and bad things, cause I do want to show ALL of it.

thanks to everybody out there. I hope to meet you all one day.

much love 
& besitos!
marie

Subject: spring break review (days 1,2,&3 of 10)
Message-ID: <19980407.212353.3446.4.mook007@juno.com>

I was too ragged last week to post my reviews of parties and stuff so I
am going to do a SHORT series of posts reviewing everything i did last
week with emphasis on the highlights(I know you don't want all of the
gorry details ;D)

Day 1:
After getting off of work and going to a friends sorority bbq (oh the fun
=P) I pick up a bunch of folks (fit 6 FULL siz peeps in a Camry) and went
to Tranceforce. Definite a dope party. Highlights include the downstairs
room especially w/ Michael Liu, and MystrE's set upstairs. I usually like
DRC's set's but that night I just couldn't get into it. Also the group
hug and the ever present SLO-tribe representin'. 

Day 2:
Spent the day helping ~e~l~e~n~a~ moving into her new apartment with guy
and Byron and some of her other frenz. Then dealt with the Wells Fargo
not clearing my check because of system problems drama. did some rekkid
shopping at Crazy Eddie's on telegraph (if you got patience you can find
some cool rekkids there) then drove up to Terri's party in Sac with Byron
and danced the night away, while drinkin' her home made guarrana punch.

Day 3:
After an hour and a half of sleep drove back home from Terri's and went
to T&J Factory and picked up a few nice Trance Compilations. Then drove
down with Feathr333 to Nick's Sunday Sanctuary and Played on his tables
for a few hours. As more people showed up i hung out and grubbed and
listened to others spin like vets(Nick, Derek, and Geoff) and other try
out the tables for the first time (Minh) This weeklie is turning out to
be a neccessary part of my week in order to wind down and meet more
folks. Props to Nick, his rommies and the regulars.

Stay Tuned for more brief reviews to come

MooK<><

miss heart wrote:

> inquiring minds want to know...
>
> 1. what is a compressor?

A compressor reduces the dynamic range, by the compressionratio, of any
program material you feed into its inputs.  Most
compressors also include attack and release envelope controls
to flatten or smooth out the peaks or transient program material.

Good compressors offer a "happy medium" effect of flattening the
source material's dynamic range while retaining the integrity of
the overall mix, especially in the mid and high frequence ranges.

Dramatic amounts of compression can produce breathing or
pumping effects which most accoustic engineers will keep to a
minimum but which can produce some very interesting artifacts
for experimental or techno producers.

Oh and there are 365 days in most years, however,
every fourth year there is a leap year which has 366 days.

Jen you good missy nub nubbin

>
>Im new to this list and i just hope you guyz are not like the peeps 
down here
>in socal, cuz the list is just a bunch of bitching....i hear the scene 
is phat
>up north...see ya...
>
>GiZmO
>

Hey, I'm a long time socaler who can see your point, but I must say 
something:

Socal is only as good as its participants make it.  Our whole community 
is based on the idea of doing it yourself and that goes for the list, 
too.  The list is very symbolic of the scene down here right now.  If 
Elevation had gone off, you would see a very different list right now.  
But, since it didn't, people are crabby.

Socal has a certain something that SF lacks.  And SF most certainly has 
something Socal lacks.  That's what makes them special and unique.  Try 
saving your own before running to a new scene and discarding the old 
one.  Socal has a LOT to offer.

Todd Spero

I'm so thrilled that someone wants to make an honest
documentary about an undefinable group of childeren
that stay out all night getting high in confined spacez
dancing uncontrolably non stop for hourz in front of
wallz of 25 inch subz blasting distorted and boisterous
muzic while security teamz and cops watch with amazement.

AWESOME!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

I'm assuming this iz for a film,sooooostarthere
ifitsnotforafilmthenillpostanewmessagewithanideaforabookokay?

herez what you do:
First break your project down into two parts...
Control and Out of...
the first part should have an intro that describez ravez.
Not some webster dictionary collegiate edition educated 
guess making pocket protecter wearing hypothesis forming
pencil necked geek saying,"A rave iz defined az a loud
or boisterous party characterized by its unorganized
organization," in some annoying nazal voice...
You should get yourself a party kid, (^_^).oO(I'm a party kid)
and have them be either the host or have them inroduce
themselvez at the beginning and narrate the film...
After the descriptive introduction, break off into different 
sectionz...
 Introduction:I've never been to a party and don't know where
they are thrown at but I want to go to 1
 Selection:Deciding where to go, picking good partiez
and not falling for over advertized bunk-rave flierz
(Planetrock98,Tribal Massive97,Bigfloor97)
 Preparation:How and where to go about getting
tix b4 the nite of the show, what to bring 
 Appearancez:How should I dress, whats everyone gonna be 
wearing
 Arrival:what to expect in your first few mins inside
 Showtime:After every1 takes their medication
 Clozing:Last set of the night,possible afterparty
 Crash:Vizual demonstration of the E-ffects of expending
large amounts of N-rgy for X-tended periodz of time
 Aftermath:Returning to your normal routine after a never
again to be repeated or forgotten evening.

Part 1 iz called 'Control' right? and it should cover 
every aspect of a rave that a first timer should know about .
Part 2 iz called 'Out of...'right? and it should cover
every negative aspect of compulsive party behaviour,
or addiction to the lifestyle az I like to think of it.
This part can be introed w/something generic like
"We learned that ravez are not bad but bad thingz do happen
inside of one in 'Control'. Well now we'll go over the 
side effects and negative aspects of party life..."cheezier
and cheezier, so on and so on...
Then Break your sectionz down into something like
 Addiction:Can't seem to stop going to partiez
 Love of the life:Just cause the music stops doesn't mean
that I am...(in reference to vitaminz A and Cr and E)
 Ouch:Effects of Dancing for 8 hourz non stop without
going pee or taking the time to drink some water
 Reality Check:When Party kidz realize that raves are for
muzic love and dancing, not the drugz...
And then Sign off....
Short little conclusion by the party kid(Me)(^_^).oO(pleazzze!!!)
Short little clozing statement from the director(U)
Roll the credits
How hard iz that?
SotheresmyideaandIhopeyoulikeditcauzeIcantcomeupwithanythingelse!

livin life and havin fun...
Gettin high late at night,
Alwayz rollin through hiz life
Not knowin what to do or where to go
Eatin shroomz and snortin blow...

Does anybody remember the days when you could bring a cassette tape to a
party and the DJ would drop it into a cassette deck and record his set
for you?  I still have old Jeno, Josh, Buck, Thomas, etc. tapes that
satisfy to this day. You can hear all the trainwrecks & coffin bumps.
Even cooler...they're the only copies and didn't cost me a cent.  Do any
DJs still do this?  
- Molly

Hello again, peeps.
   It seems that people got the wrong impression of what I was trying to 
say. We don't plan on having a line-up of ALL the DJ's listed below, 
only some of them. But usually a couple of the ones you want are already 
booked, or maybe we can't aford them right now. we still, however, would 
like to be able to contact them. Someday we may be able to have a party 
as such, and I'll be sure to let you guys know. But not yet, not on our 
first party. 
   Thanks to everyone who replied. If I din't send you a message 
already, let me know. Pobody's Nerfect.
   For everyone who wants to help, or has a demo tape they'd like to 
send, call me on fri, sat, or sun, or just mail the tape and I'll call 
you when we review it.

S.U.S.K. Productions (Stands for 'Society Under Siege Krew')
c/o David Olazabal
445 40th St. #3
Oakland Ca, 94609
(510)547-0969

Peace and Love,
Dave

P.S. Here is the original list. And BTW, Deepfog is one of the best 
trance Dj's I've heard lately. He gave me a tape, Champagne Trance, and 
I havn't stopped listening to it. Send him some mail at 
deepfog@hooked.net
 
Hey all...
   Some friends and I have been thinking about putting together a party 
for quite awhile, and we finally started doing something about it. We 
have had a few meetings, secured funding, and have a good idea of what 
we want to do. Now all we need is the DJ's. Following is a list of the 
ones we voted on. Anyone with any contacts that could reach these guys 
(or gals! - DRC's Awsome!), please send them along. And just as a 
question, has anyone thought of making a list and posting it on the 
hyperreal site? It sounds like a good idea if it hasn't already been 
done.

(in no particular order)
Doc Martin
Jeno
Simon
Tony
Jerry Bonham 
DJ Doubt
DJ Dan
Donald Glaude
Carlos
Frankie Bones
Sasha - england
Drc
Dutch
Crystal Method

   Now don't feel bad if we didn't mention your name, or a friend of 
yours. We DEFINITLY want any local or upcoming talent to be shot our 
way, so please send Name, Location, Music Type, and Contact to us.
   Thanks everyone for the help. This party is tenativly scheduled for 
the 27th of June, but that is not, NOT, set in stone yet. The name of 
the party will be "Incarnation, the chapter of earth." Please e-mail me 
any questions, comments, or ideas. All are welcome.

Peace and Love,
Dave

Greetings SFRavers =)

Apologies for the grossly commercial nature of this post - I wouldn't make
it if this group hadn't expressed interest in the past.

In any event, I've just finished digitally remastering and burning my first
CD release - Live @ Disco Dave's. This set was recorded at (Gateway) Dave
Abel's warehouse on November 27, 1997 at a farewell party for our friend
Rachel.

It's 73 minutes of acid techno trance, sliced, diced and well fucked up =)
(I can't take it out of my damn player ;)

It's been digitally remastered in my studio (the bass-station) with the
subsonic bass punched up and the the high end sparkled a bit... Put it on a
real system and it'll floor you =)

No color J card as yet (I might or might not ever get around to it,) so for
the time being it's all about the music, but I think the price is right.

If you want one, send a *stamped, self-addressed envelope* (big enough to
hold a CD) and $8.00 to:

Live @ Disco Dave's!
1425 Santa Fe Ave.
Berkeley, CA
94702

Please don't respond to the list about this.

take it easy
ethan

Today's semi-rave-related movie review:  Fans of Dr. Hunter S.
Thompson aka Raoul Duke might also want to check the 1980 flick 'Where
the Buffalo Roam'.  This one was inspired by Hunter's coverage of
Nixon's re-election campaign - needless to say, the two men had
issues.  Bill Murray plays a haggard Hunter pretty well, and some
psychopath delivers the goods as the Samoan drug attorney cum Mexican
survivalist cum 2nd Extremely Dangerous Maniac.
Matt.

"Mook" <mcarey@triad.com> wrote:
> My suggestion: please please please fade out the last track on your tape. It
> is most painful to my heart my mind and my ears to be really into a track
> and to have it cut off right in the middle because it's the end of the tape.

theres a moontribe dj named treavor who has a tape out called "hugs" and
what he does at the end of the tape is suddenly switch the turntable off,
in the middle of the song! so you hear the thing just slow down and stop
all of a sudden right when youre there peaking off of it

first time i listened to it was with friends morning after a party and we
sorta just zoned out into our own respective worlds, we were coming down
and such, and hearing that at the end of each side of the tape was the most
jarring experience ever

its kinda awful, but at the same time, funny. like treavor is fucking with
your head or somethin

joe

On Tue, 7 Apr 1998 simplycosmic@usa.net wrote:

&e>I apologize that you feel that way about my BSP, but actually its a
&e>FREE party thrown by Manny (M3) from the Velvet Shop and he has been
&e>around for a long time.  I am not creating competition JUST informing
&e>people of what is going on.  Maybe afterglo started before TOP SHELF,
&e>but Top Shelf isn't there to make any money at all either, so it isn't
&e>really that big of a deal.  Anyway, I once again apologize that you
&e>feel that way, but I think I have the freedom to post things such as
&e>BSP's on this list if I want too... This list is to INFORM people as
&e>well as discuss things in the scene. 

Props to Manny, his party was part of the inspiration for what we do (I
know I've been to Velvet Shop and had a damn good time on several
occasions).  As well as props to Mad, and Static, and Phunkatech, and a
lot of other "done right" nights out there.

There's nothing wrong with two people (or groups of people) having similar
ideas at the same time.  People starting clubs often get asked to do
Monday nights... so we had two new monday night clubs start in a month... 
that means options... it's not just that there is something to do... there
are now multiple things to do in San Jose on a Monday.  SF has tons of
good stuff going on all the time and nobody worries about it there... 

How many times have you thought of something, and seen it come out months
or years later (even though you didn't tell anybody about it)?  It
happens. A club night takes a while to organize, and I don't see any
disrespect here from anybody.

There's differences between the two clubs, and there are differences in
people.  I think people will go to the club they want to go to, and that's
probably something that's not best decided via this list as a group or
community... it's a personal choice. 

Do what you like.

Peace,
AndyW

afterglo + mondays + cactus club + sanjose + $3>=21 + $5>=18 + 9:30pm-1:30

next week:
"Mom... how come my record player keeps making banging techno noises..."
with guests: Catweasel (triology-UK) & James King (SJ)
& residents: Science and Li

Hello,
You haven't met me, but I don't post much. I usaual just read what
others have to say and sometimes shed my opinon. I love to hear what
others have to say. It give me such insight and I always try to blend
everything new and unique I hear into my life good or bad. Right now I'm
sorrta in the same situation you are, A male that I was dating in the
scene him and I ended on bad terms also. We don't even speak anymore.
It's very uncomfortable to see him at parties. It was also his choice
not to be friends. So I just ignore him and go on with my life.
First off you need to be strong and remember that you are a wonderful
person, and you shouldn't let anyone get you down, no matter what. Raves
to me are my oulets to a stress free enviroment. This girl is obviously
very immature and you are way above her maturity. That potrays alot
about this girl. So you need to forget about her. It might be hard. but
you deserve so much better. Please don't sink to her level. That's
exactly what she wants. So the only way to not, is to ignore her. Show
her that you can have a great time without her, that your better than
that. Show her that you can continue your life without her. Remeber it
was her choice not to be friends. Msbey she'll wake up and relize  what
relaity is, and then maybe she'll come back to the real world and make
amends. You never know you could even be the bestest of friends. My
advice might not be helpful, but this is what I'm doing to deal with my
problem. You just seem like such an amazing person. I can tell that you
are a very positive person to the scene and us ravers can't afford to
lose such vaulable people. I don't know you but just by the way you
express yourself so beautifully I can tell your an open and caring
individual. So please turn that upside down grin to a smile. 
Remember I wuv you..
Love Victoria
"Sunshine"

Dsfunshnl1 wrote:
> 
> Hey everyone...
>      I am embarassed to even talk about this... but it's not just something
> that's affecting me... it's something that's affecting some of my friends in
> the scene too... so I'm asking you for some advice on how to deal with this
> little drama thing that's going on with me lately...
>      First of all... there's a girl in the scene that I used to date.  Things
> didn't work out... and we didn't part on the best of terms.  No big deal,
> right..?  I mean, it happens to everyone sometime in their life.  O.K.  So I
> haven't talked to this girl since October... I have seen her at a few parties
> lately... (The Gathering, Harmony, Skillz, skillz afterparty, Tranceforce, and
> last night at Bionic...).  Though I regret that she and I aren't friends now,
> I accept that it's her choice, and I respect her wishes.  The times I've seen
> her at parties, I haven't tried to talk to her.  I haven't approached her. I
> haven't followed her.  I don't look at her.  In short, I respect her.  The
> last thing I would ever do is try to bring a bad vibe into the scene which has
> shown me much love and a feeling of community.  A sense of belonging...  When
> she sees me at a party, if she's dancing and sees me, she looks at me with
> evil eyes.  I look away.  If I walk into a room where she's just chilling...
> she will bail.  At first, that reaction toward me really bothered me because
> I've never in my life had such a negative reaction towards my "existence".
> But I've come to accept that it's just the way it is and I don't let it bother
> me anymore.  I've talked to some of you about this drama before and everyone's
> agreed that it sucks, but what else can you say...!  I feel the same way.
>      But for some reason, I guess the fact that I don't do any of those things
> I mentioned isn't enough for her.  For last night, she was at Bionic and had
> brought many of her friends with her.  (As this post has already gone long....
> I will sum up some of the events that took place....)
> 1.  her little brother (age 13...) and another guy were <always..> right
> behind me when I was dancing... and I caught them both kicking empty water
> bottles toward me while I was dancing... whenever I would move somewhere else,
> sooner or later, they were there too. <my guess is to try and make me trip on
> the bottles>
> 2.  I was giving a friend a back rub in the chill area... and another one of
> her friends came by and took a picture of that.  my friend is alot younger
> than I am... and I've known her since january.  <my guess is that a picture is
> soon to appear at a party near you... flaming me or something....>
> 3.  another guy was following me all night.  at first I thought I was
> tripping... but I wasn't on anything hallucinagenic, so you be the judge...
> and once when I went from the main room to the jungle room, this guy walked
> through the room looking left and right for someone.  he passed me without
> noticing me, so I followed him.  when he got to the end of the room and turned
> around, it startled him to see that I was following about 15 feet behind.
> <the shocked look on his face confirmed my suspicions...>
> 4.  I went with a couple of friends from the list into the chill area to relax
> a little and I noticed one of her friends talking to a security guy.  <why am
> I noticing these things you ask?  because weird things had been happening all
> night!> he then made 3 trips to the chill area checking things out.  the first
> two times he just came and left.  but the third time, he walked to the cyclone
> gate and let himself into the "off limits" area but didn't close the door
> completely.  he kept poking his head out looking toward me, but when he would
> see me looking back, he would step back.  then he would look again.  finally,
> he just kept staring... so I approached him and started up a conversation.
> during our conversation, he asked me things like "what time did I get
> there..?", "who did I know there..?", "did I come with anybody..?", and "did I
> come with the people I was sitting down with..?".  <I don't know what her
> friend said to him, but it was obvious that he was there because of me. but I
> am not! a dealer, and have not EVER harrassed anyone at a party!  ....or ever,
> for that matter....>
> 5.  while I was talking to some other friends on the list who were on the
> dance floor, one of her friends walked by and spit something out of her mouth
> onto my female friend's back.  I yelled at her but she kept walking.  <this
> whole drama has now reached a new low....>
> 6.  toward the end of the party, I separated myself from my friends because if
> someone has a problem with me, IT STAYS WITH ME!!!  I don't want anybody to
> suffer as a result of (my...) personal problems.  <but as I was sitting at the
> tables near the front entrance to the party, I noticed 3 security personnel
> just staring at me.  my returned stares did not stop them from staring.  and
> some of the people who I'd encountered during the evening had also stopped
> near the exit and were staring at me.  at this point, as dramatic as this may
> seem, I feared for my personal safety and asked another friend from the list
> (rather intimidating in size...) to walk out with me.  I did  not tell him
> about the drama, but only wanted a show of support...>
> **Now.... I've met many of you peeps and have made some really great friends.
> Those of you who know me I trust will have a VERY favorable thought in regards
> to me.  And for those of you who don't know me... let me tell you this:  my
> screen name refers only to a play on the word dysfunctional and refers to my
> having been brought up in an alcoholic, 2-marriage family.  I do not, however
> use my upbringing as an excuse for ANYTHING!  In fact, I use it as a stimulus
> to achieve more out of life.  The results thus far include: I am a supervisor
> for a contract manufacturing machine shop in Hayward, I own my own home and a
> cabin in Tahoe, and have completed 6 years of post-secondary education.  I am
> in fact still continuing my education.
>      While I don't look for any recognition for anything I do... for the
> benefit of those who have not met me, I will tell you that I have gone out of
> my way to pick up people for a party, returned them home (or others who didn't
> have a ride...), payed for some to go to a party, helped with setting up
> and/or tearing down at a party, and I've never... ever!  tried to "pick up" on
> anybody at a party.  I feel I contribute positively to the scene which has
> shown me such a feeling of belonging, but as I type this post, I'm wondering
> if my being involved in the scene is a bad thing because I do not want to
> bring any negativity into it.  (My sister always told me I'm too sensitive for
> my own good... but I've shed tears over this whole drama... and I'm really
> asking for some advice on how to deal with it.  In short, I guess I'm putting
> it into your hands.  So please advise).
> Thank you in advance for your suggestions...
> Peace. Out.
> ~Michael

On Wed, 8 Apr 1998, joe salas wrote:




The whole turning of the table thing while the records playing is
dangerous to do.  The dj may think he's being clever but most people know
exactly whats going on and it gives you a dragging passing out sort of
vibe.  The only savior is if the next record slips in real smooth like.
I've tried it and I've heard people try it but never really heard it sound
good.  I'm sure the right record at the right time could work but I'd be
careful.


chris


> "Mook" <mcarey@triad.com> wrote:
> > My suggestion: please please please fade out the last track on your tape. It

>

i do something where i turn off the record, let it wind down, then
manually wind it back up to 33 with my finger, kill it again, but this
time i wind it up to 45, let it slam at 45 til this particular break
in the song...then i slam it into 33 again.  The record now gives u
the illusion that it is still going MUCH faster than it actually is. 
I've only had this work on one of my records though..."get down" (for
those of u that know what i am talking about).

=)
dan

Uhhhh.... thought we all (me...) could use a break from the drama, so I wanted
to share this with you peeps...  hope nobody's offended!  
p
e
a
c
e
~michael


Little girl asked her Mom, "Mom, may I take the dog for a walk around
the
block?"

 Mom says, "No, because the dog is in heat."

 "What's that mean?" asked the child.

 "Go ask your Father. I think he's in the garage".

 The little girl goes to the garage and says, "Dad, can I take Susie for
a
walk around the block. I asked Mom but she said the dog was in heat and
that I
should ask you".

 Dad said, "Bring Susie over here".

 He took a rag, soaked it with gasoline, and scrubbed the dog's butt
with it
and said, "Ok, you can go now but keep Susie on the leash and only go
one time
around the block".

 Little girl left and returned a few minutes later with no dog on the
leash.

 Dad said, "Where's Susie?"

 Little girl said, "Susie ran out of gas about halfway down the block
and
there's another dog is pushing her home".  

=)

I'm reading a book right now called _Reviving Ophelia: Saving the Selves of
Adolescent Girls_ that talks about all the hard stuff girls go through
naturally and how our western culture makes it much harder on them.  A good
read for all you women out there and anyone else that is interested.  Not to
downplay what she's doing - I agree, sounds like just a very immature
personality, but being aware of the challenges all women face makes a little
sense out of the chaos.

Beth

As a proud owner of a tc electronics finalizer (new finalizer plus
info -- http://www.tcelectronic.com/finalizer_plus.htm), i'm into
compression...

Here's some quickies to get you started.

	http://www.proaudio.co.uk/comppa.htm
	http://www.proaudio.co.uk/comp.htm

Ultimately, the theory of compression will just point you in the right
direction. you just have to put various kinds of music through it and
listen to what it does. After about 6-12months of critical listening,
you start figuring things out. I think I'm almost there.

I was going to say something, but didnt want to get bashed my my friends
here.....so 2 people posted about weeklies. People will maybe go to one, then
go to the other, maybe stop by both. The thing is they will decide what they
like better. If someone stops going to afterglo because they like top shelve
better, then thats means that weekly is right for them. Look at the SF Raves
calender......3-5 parties in one night....all different, maybe equaly as good,
maybe not. The point is we all have the right to be informed about other
events....I think the SanJose scene will still be tight even if there are 5
weeklies all on a Monday, because almost all of us are looking for the same
thing, A good time. I dont think we need to bash on people for posting their
weeklies. My 2 bits..... =-)
W/Love&Harmony
Guy

 I'm still here but really busy so I just skim the list these days. 
Being the first email list I ever subbed to I just can't stay away.

 Dionysus Dreams is still alive and well. We helped out Martin O'Brian 
(sp?) at Vision recently and we will be helping with The Gathering on 
April 11th.

 For those that don't know Dionysus Dreams has assisted such groups as 
Harmony (3 Year, Spring Massive, 4X4), Mantra, CCC, Hunab-Ku, Koinonea, 
Sacred Dance Society, The Gathering, LightSeed, Warmth 2, St. Johns, 
Expansion 2 and many others.

i subscribed to the socal list, hoping to meet some people to hook up
w/ at DUNE later on.  you think sfraves has a lot of traffic?  i
steped away from my computer for about four hours soon after
subscribing.  when i came back, the score: sfraves 37, scraves 123. 
one-hundred and twentythree posts in four hours!?!  phew!  the thing
was, about 117 of them were all flames, and flames of flames, all
about like _one_ post, where some kid snuck into a rave, and posted
about it, and a bunch of people came down on the guy for "stealing
from the scene", and then a bunch of people came down on the people
who came down on the other people.  whatever.  it could have been an
interesting conversation about crime as counterculture, morality, or
something, anything, but really most of it was just a bunch of people
bitching at each other and calling each other names...

not that there weren't some interesting moments.  i responded to a
post about shel silverstien, and wound up talking to noah a bit.  but
then that could have happened here.  there were some other cool posts,
but everyone seemed more interested in responding to the flames,
rather than getting something else going.

there was one really interesting thread, though.  apparently, a girl
had posted a bitter letter about some guy who was abusive to her, and
how she hated him but kept coming back to him.  or something like
that, i don't think i ever saw the original, just the responses to the
responses.  this started a conversation about how sleazy, scumbag guys
("dogs" according to scraver slang) always seem to be constantly
surrounded by tons of fine babes, even though everybody and their
mother knows what the guy is all about.  saw some well written
responses that were pretty damn honest, well, blunt, actually.  which
is something i don't see as much of here, that sort of eyes-open
cynicism.  but maybe it's better that way...

oh, one other thing.  there are two groups on scraves:  ThOsE wHo
WrItE eVeRyThInG iN aLtErNaTiNg CaPiTaLs, and those who dont.  the
OnEs WhO wRiTe LiKe ThIs AlL hAvE aCcOuNtS oN aOl.  everybody else
hates them.  i think it's a generation gap thing.  well, dont worry,
WnDrTwIn29, we don't care if you write in alternating capitals or not.
 at least i don't.  most folks up here seem to get along just fine,
regardless of their age, race, sex, religion, and capitalization
style...

which is one of the many reasons i like sfraves so much :)

peace,
messiah

Date: Wed, 8 Apr 1998 21:39:45 -0700 (PDT)
From: messiah wannabe <messiahw@yahoo.com>
Subject: no tv review
To: sfraves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



no, i didn't make it to notv at 1015 this week, though i've been
before, and liked it.  actually, i'm just talking about not having a tv.

i don't own one, and neither do my roomates.  it's a personal choice
we've all made, and one that we're all pretty happy with.  when you
lose that fuckin box sitting in the living room, all sorts of neat
activities spring up to fill the gaps.  talking for instance.  sure,
we all like chatting with friends, but when the tv is around, it's all
to easy to turn it on, and turn your friends (and yourself) off.  lose
the tv, and suddenly you're forced to entertain each other.  and
believe me, my roomies are _definitely_ funnier than any tv program
out there.  well, except maybe for mst3k...

we also play a lot of games: poker, backgammon, chess, scrabble,
grass...  i never used to play most of those games, but i find i
really enjoy them now.  they're like these little microcosms,
miniature replicas of the game of life, or some facet of it.  i can
feel my mind expanding, getting more limber, especially playing
something challenging like chess.  learning little lessons that can be
applied to the real world...

granted, there have been times i've come home from work and found
myself too tired to do a damn thing, even talk.  but on those rare
occasions, i simply allow myself to "turn off" on the couch, as if i
had a television, and just veg.  sure, i probably look sorta funny,
but that's just cause everyone associates that vegetative state with
watching tv.  i find i enjoy it better without, i just sit back, maybe
roll one, listen to some tunes, and let my thoughts wander.

tv is like this fucking drug, you turn it on and you just sit there,
immobile, eyes glassy, staring at this one spot.  well, i've been in
that state without the help of a television set, but the thing was, i
was at least thinking my own thoughts.  if you're watching tv, you're
silently absorbing all kinds of sick little messages:  i'm fat, i'm
ugly, i need to diet, i need to eat some burgers, i need a new car,
new clothes, i don't need it but it's on sale so i can save money by
buying it...  it's not just the commercials, the commercials pay for
every second of tv you see, and that's reflected in the programs,
implicitly.  everybody lives in these dream apartments with furniture
they couldn't afford if they really worked at a newspaper or whatever,
and you just sit there and feel more and more inadequate, but
subconsciously...

ok, maybe that sounds a little paranoid, and perhaps it is.  and there
are plenty of other socializing mechanisms in this culture to make you
a little consumerclone, and i'm still vulnerable to some of them.  but
honestly, i think that's what tv's all about, selling shit, and i
wouldn't put it past the networks to find a thousand little ways to
implant suggestions in your brain, all of them centered around your
buying the sponsor's product.  certainly they would if they could,
don't you think?

anyway, i don't think i'm gonna go back to owning a tv anytime soon...


-messiah

Subject: A story from me! (cross-posted; so sue me :)
Message-ID: <Pine.SOL.3.96.980408235341.1941A-100000@apocalypse.OCF.Berkeley.EDU>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


			     _Monday's Finals_


	Sunny, sunny and bright.  I would approach a friend to tell me all
the things I thought of myself, but then there is no cause.  All the birds
have flown on spirals up and down.  Into the sky so blue and gray and
boiling for days on end.  I would approach my friends to tell me why I am
so sad, but then there is no cause.  
	Yes, the sky is sunny.  Sunny and bright.  Blinding me with the
mirror of gases aflame and hot all over  so very bright.  I did not see
the rain, nor feel it strike the ground in ever growing circles that
spread.  Spread for very far and wider, and wider, and wider.  The
grasses, they bend their heads and whisper.  To the ground they touch with
psalms to the wind in dry heather voices.  
	The flowers I have sown, they did not grow this year.  Their
petals dried and colour faded within the ground.  Blossoms opened for the
pleasure of heaven and hell.  Who knows what lurks beneath the earth I
tread on worn weary shoes with dust within the crannies and gravel
grinding under the soles.  They used to shine in black leather splendour
all new and wet with father's money.  But all the running, the walking,
the turning  has covered the shine and hidden with dust.  The laces so
chewed with tears from sharp edges.
	The leaves tremulous over birch bark so white and unsoiled.
Powdered and lacquered with little black marks.  The leaves tremulous so
yellow and orange.  Shaking like butterflies on empty branches, sheltering
from the wind, the rain, the cold.  Falling and littering the ground in
islets and  rivulets of gold on black asphalt.  The ground so dark and
viscuous, smelling like new air and dead worms and squeaking with slippery
steps up and down the concrete hill.
	I walked through campus, past the towering campanile gray and
green with age.  The Mulberry trees were being cut of branches, all their
new fingers sheared with scissors and cruel saws spiked with teeth.  The
trees have gnarled knuckles snarled branches and screams pockmarked on
bloated boles.  I passed by, averting my eyes, saddened by whips and fags
littering the red brick walkway.  There was no sound breaking the crisp
autumn air.  Nothing to crackle the sharpness and crystalline silence.
The students trudged on with their heavy loads and humpbacked steps.
Heads were bowed, expressions grim.  I saw no color, their bright slickers
had no hue.  The atomic reds, banana yellows, crayon greens and
superman blues were just a mirage.  Nothing but empty memories of carefree
childhood with alphabet blocks and Tonka toys.  
	The  next day I passed the grove, morbid, empty, and chill.  A
lonely trill trapped within my hearing drew my vision upwards.  I ignored
the flickering yellow hazard tape that encircled the perimeter and
uncrimped my neck to look towards the heavens.  There was a rosy sunset
with wisps of baby blue, jewel-like and pretty like a first communication.
But strangest sight of all,  sharp needles of darkened growth punctured
the sky like so many masts at Newport harbour.  It was sublime to see the
last line of trees, standing as so many sentries ready to fall.  Their
batons in the air, a ragged leaf waving in the wind, and the sunny-sunny
bright sun setting across the bay.  I wanted to capture the moment,
graphic and sharp and full of today's little tensions.  But I bowed my
head, resettled my backpack, and trudged on to class.



:)
M&m



PS  	Repetition is good--watch some Teletubbies....

miss heart wrote:
>inquiring minds want to know...
>
>1. what is a compressor?

its a device that squashes sound.  compacts it into a limited volume
range.  you set a threshold limit, and anything louder than that
gets clamped down. if you were standing at the mixer and lowering the fader
everytime a loud note hit you would be one.  whats cool is with really
low thresholds it makes everything sound like it is completely blown
fullblast even at low volumes.  as in all those trashy hiphop loops.

>3. is it possible to integrate an accoustic piano (real piano) into
>electro music or would you have to use the sampled sounds on a keyboard?
>or are there keyboards that have the touch sensitivity of a real piano?

sure why not, as long as you have a mic and a mixer.  i dont know anything
about mic'ing a piano, but you could probably get cool sounds by just
experimenting.  radio shack PZM mics sound miraculously good and theyre dirt
cheap.  otherwise, most old analogs arent touch sensitive, but almost all
new keyboards are.
hope that helps :)
marc

  ahh... i hear ya clear and loud.
  i detoxed from tv for a year and just recently started 
  vegetating on my couch again. today was the first
  day i watched jerry springer from beginning to end, 
  and the whole time i watched i was puking chunks
  of my sanity. 
  
  this show repulses me and i will never poison my
  brain with that brutal, button pushing, fist provoking
  crap. i'm sorry to all of you out there who enjoy 
  watching this show, but i will never ever change
   my strong feelings of anti respect for what this
   show represents. 

   todays beautiful happy topic was about men who are 
   playing two women. they brought out one woman who had
   a baby with this guy, who had a baby with another
   girl and she was nine months preggers. when the
   other girl came on stage, she immediately rushed
   her and tried to kick the crap out of her. now i am
   no medical specialist, but i have a feeling, call it
   intuition or maybe i'm psychic or something, that
   this isn't too healthy for a nine month pregger
   woman and her baby. 

   i understand that the topics that they so wonderfully
   explore is poop that happens in the real world. but there
   has got to be a better way of cleaning the poop than
   subjecting oneself to a show that promotes physical
   and verbal abuse. sure jerry brings in his deep 
   insightful caring comments and thoughts to try
   and bring peace and help to heal these poor poopy
   people, but its just not enough to positate a pregger
   woman having fists flown at her.

   am i the only one who doesn't like to watch jerry?

   -yasmin

   p.s. i no longer have cable and have to admit that i miss mtv
          the discovery channel, and a&e.

<messiahw@yahoo.com> writes:
>
>
>no, i didn't make it to notv at 1015 this week, though i've been
>before, and liked it.  actually, i'm just talking about not having a 
>tv.
>
>i don't own one, and neither do my roomates.  it's a personal choice
>we've all made, and one that we're all pretty happy with.  when you
>lose that fuckin box sitting in the living room, all sorts of neat
>activities spring up to fill the gaps.  talking for instance.  sure,
>we all like chatting with friends, but when the tv is around, it's all
>to easy to turn it on, and turn your friends (and yourself) off.  lose
>the tv, and suddenly you're forced to entertain each other.  and
>believe me, my roomies are _definitely_ funnier than any tv program
>out there.  well, except maybe for mst3k...
>
>we also play a lot of games: poker, backgammon, chess, scrabble,
>grass...  i never used to play most of those games, but i find i
>really enjoy them now.  they're like these little microcosms,
>miniature replicas of the game of life, or some facet of it.  i can
>feel my mind expanding, getting more limber, especially playing
>something challenging like chess.  learning little lessons that can be
>applied to the real world...
>
>granted, there have been times i've come home from work and found
>myself too tired to do a damn thing, even talk.  but on those rare
>occasions, i simply allow myself to "turn off" on the couch, as if i
>had a television, and just veg.  sure, i probably look sorta funny,
>but that's just cause everyone associates that vegetative state with
>watching tv.  i find i enjoy it better without, i just sit back, maybe
>roll one, listen to some tunes, and let my thoughts wander.
>
>tv is like this fucking drug, you turn it on and you just sit there,
>immobile, eyes glassy, staring at this one spot.  well, i've been in
>that state without the help of a television set, but the thing was, i
>was at least thinking my own thoughts.  if you're watching tv, you're
>silently absorbing all kinds of sick little messages:  i'm fat, i'm
>ugly, i need to diet, i need to eat some burgers, i need a new car,
>new clothes, i don't need it but it's on sale so i can save money by
>buying it...  it's not just the commercials, the commercials pay for
>every second of tv you see, and that's reflected in the programs,
>implicitly.  everybody lives in these dream apartments with furniture
>they couldn't afford if they really worked at a newspaper or whatever,
>and you just sit there and feel more and more inadequate, but
>subconsciously...
>
>ok, maybe that sounds a little paranoid, and perhaps it is.  and there
>are plenty of other socializing mechanisms in this culture to make you
>a little consumerclone, and i'm still vulnerable to some of them.  but
>honestly, i think that's what tv's all about, selling shit, and i
>wouldn't put it past the networks to find a thousand little ways to
>implant suggestions in your brain, all of them centered around your
>buying the sponsor's product.  certainly they would if they could,
>don't you think?
>
>anyway, i don't think i'm gonna go back to owning a tv anytime soon...
>
>
>-messiah

you know I grew up as a child pretty much without television by conscious
choice of my hippie parents.  i always kinda resented it then because i
would always feel left out at school when the kids started talking about
last night's cool episode of whatever show.  (and now today i really suck
at games like trivial pursuit with any tv references)  anyways, the first
time i moved into my own place one of my first purchases was the biggest
color tv i could afford and cable with ~all~ the channels.  for the next
three plus years i lived on the couch.  i stopped going out on the
weekends, i stopped reading books, i started eating nothing but tv dinners
and take out, friendships were lost with unanswered letters.  bleh, i could
go on and on.  my whole nonexistant life revolved the next episode of er or
seinfeld or hbo's saturday night new flick.  i'm quite embarassed when i
look back now.

so, about 9 months ago i realized what a horrible bore my life had become
because of television's hypnotic powers to suck you in and plant you
permanantly on the couch.  the very next day after realizing this fact i
called the cable company and had it turned off, all the channels.  now all
my television is good for is playing rented movies and you wouldn't believe
all that i've accomplished and how lively my social life has become.  i
have real live friends again! that i actually do stuff with.   you are
certainly right, messiah and so too i guess were my parents, tv is just
like a drug.  i know i feel like a recovering alcoholic sobering up from a
three year drunk.

now, if i could just get away from this computer. . .

j.

----Original Message Follows----

no, i didn't make it to notv at 1015 this week, though i've been
before, and liked it.  actually, i'm just talking about not having a tv.

i don't own one, and neither do my roomates.  it's a personal choice
we've all made, and one that we're all pretty happy with.  when you
lose that fuckin box sitting in the living room, all sorts of neat
activities spring up to fill the gaps.  talking for instance.  sure,
we all like chatting with friends, but when the tv is around, it's all
to easy to turn it on, and turn your friends (and yourself) off.  lose
the tv, and suddenly you're forced to entertain each other.  and
believe me, my roomies are _definitely_ funnier than any tv program
out there.  well, except maybe for mst3k...

we also play a lot of games: poker, backgammon, chess, scrabble,
grass...  i never used to play most of those games, but i find i
really enjoy them now.  they're like these little microcosms,
miniature replicas of the game of life, or some facet of it.  i can
feel my mind expanding, getting more limber, especially playing
something challenging like chess.  learning little lessons that can be
applied to the real world...

granted, there have been times i've come home from work and found
myself too tired to do a damn thing, even talk.  but on those rare
occasions, i simply allow myself to "turn off" on the couch, as if i
had a television, and just veg.  sure, i probably look sorta funny,
but that's just cause everyone associates that vegetative state with
watching tv.  i find i enjoy it better without, i just sit back, maybe
roll one, listen to some tunes, and let my thoughts wander.

tv is like this fucking drug, you turn it on and you just sit there,
immobile, eyes glassy, staring at this one spot.  well, i've been in
that state without the help of a television set, but the thing was, i
was at least thinking my own thoughts.  if you're watching tv, you're
silently absorbing all kinds of sick little messages:  i'm fat, i'm
ugly, i need to diet, i need to eat some burgers, i need a new car,
new clothes, i don't need it but it's on sale so i can save money by
buying it...  it's not just the commercials, the commercials pay for
every second of tv you see, and that's reflected in the programs,
implicitly.  everybody lives in these dream apartments with furniture
they couldn't afford if they really worked at a newspaper or whatever,
and you just sit there and feel more and more inadequate, but
subconsciously...

ok, maybe that sounds a little paranoid, and perhaps it is.  and there
are plenty of other socializing mechanisms in this culture to make you
a little consumerclone, and i'm still vulnerable to some of them.  but
honestly, i think that's what tv's all about, selling shit, and i
wouldn't put it past the networks to find a thousand little ways to
implant suggestions in your brain, all of them centered around your
buying the sponsor's product.  certainly they would if they could,
don't you think?

anyway, i don't think i'm gonna go back to owning a tv anytime soon...


-messiah

Subject: something funny that i found....

in Rob More's column in the examiner......

i thought that it was pretty funny....


"Overheard conversations, 

that's one of the things I like about San
Francisco. You don't hear the same kind of things you hear in Orlando,
things like "Is it an all-you-can-eat buffet?"

 The other night I was standing in line at a local nightclub.
Naturally, I was the oldest person there and felt bad about it until I
listened to the young woman behind me talk about her gum problems
caused by her new lip stud. I may be old, but I don't have gum problems.

 Then she started telling her friend about a rave she went to where
someone gave out a certain psychedelic, whose name or color I didn't
catch because of hearing loss caused by Doors concerts and Orange
Sunshine.

  "It was the big drug of the early '90s, but now it's cut with
speed," lisped Miss Lip Stud. "This was the real stuff, like you used
to get in the old days."

Sorry, I am not prepared for flashbacks to the good old days of five
years ago.

 Hey, kids, the early '90s was only two Middle Eastern buildups and six
  presidential sex scandals ago. My drug of choice back then in the
pre-Monica days was aspirin, same as now.

 Just say no to drug nostalgia. Ah, the early '90s: If you remember
them, you weren't there.
"

just thought i'd share some of the outside world....

=)
dan
