From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Mon Apr 13 06:40:56 1998
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 27797 invoked by uid 6000); 13 Apr 1998 06:40:55 -0000
Received: (qmail 27789 invoked from network); 13 Apr 1998 06:40:53 -0000
Received: from mailhub1.ncal.verio.com (204.247.247.38)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 13 Apr 1998 06:40:53 -0000
Received: from pegasus (paix-sds-gw4-32.ncal.verio.com [207.21.130.95])
	by mailhub1.ncal.verio.com (8.8.7/8.8.7) with SMTP id XAA25840
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Sun, 12 Apr 1998 23:40:51 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <199804130640.XAA25840@mailhub1.ncal.verio.com>
Reply-To: <rudir@aimnet.com>
From: "Rudi Rughoonundon" <rudir@aimnet.com>
To: "SFRaves" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: F8 in review ...
Date: Sun, 12 Apr 1998 23:38:07 -0700
X-Priority: 3 (Normal)
X-MSMail-Priority: Normal
X-Mailer: Microsoft Outlook 8.5, Build 4.71.2173.0
Importance: Normal
X-MimeOLE: Produced By Microsoft MimeOLE V4.72.2106.4
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

welp ... i am just now winding down my weekend so i figured it is about time
i reviewed Frequency-8 ... this saturday was a special occasion for me as i
was planning to take my crew from work to their first rave ... they had been
asking about that "rave thing" i do for a while and i had promised them that
i would have to find the right party before i brought them into the scene
...

this saturday felt right and at the beginning of the week i started planning
the event ... all the guys would be in town and "the gathering" was going on
in SF and from looking at the lineup i figured this was the party to take
them to ... haze had decided to go to Frequency-8 but given that i wasnt too
hot about Ethan and DRC i decided not to join her (i changed my mind about
that later ;-) ) ...

i wanted my buddies to hook up with some sfravers before we got to the party
so that the culture shock would not be too intense ... so around wednesday i
sent out an invite for a south bay pre-party dinner ... the response to the
dinner invite was lukewarm but some of the usual suspects replied back and i
was able to get a nice crew of 50% sfravers + 50% newbies for dinner on
saturday evening ...

saturday morning came around ... i had been out doing the bar scene the
night before and on a minimal amount of sleep i started saturday at 10am ...
i got the CD player in my car replaced as the one i had purchased the week
before sucked the big one (it was an alpine - the new one is a clarion and i
love it) ... some of you from the south bay have probably heard of the
depression i went through when my old CD player died on a sunday as i was
headed to Nick's bbq ... now that i have the new one, driving my car isnt as
traumatic anymore ... thank god ...

the installation shop happened to be right next to solid grooves and i
dropped by there to pick up the tix to the gathering and to get my weekly
fix of import CDs ... i got home to find email from haze urging me to
reconsider the gathering as i would be the only one going there and because
Mars & Mystre kick ass ... decisions, decisions ... i changed my mind a
couple of times on her but i finally agreed to go to F8 if i could get a
refund on my tix for the gathering ... the solid grooves boys had no
problems with giving me a refund and so the decision was made ...

i picked up haze and nico and we arrived at chilli's at around 7:30pm ... i
then took a quick drive by solid grooves and got the refund and i was back
at chilli's by 8pm ... my buddies were already there but most of the south
bay crew was a no show ... finally andrew and rick saved the day by showing
up and we got to sit down for dinner ... soon after that michael and marq
joined us and we all had a great little dinner together ...

rudi, is that review coming up anytime soon ? yup here we go ... ;-)

we headed for oakland at around 10pm and arrived at the location at around
11pm ... we walked into the party to some "hard core" trance by greg sandler
... the visual candy was just amazing inside the main room ... they had this
huge ass lazer which spanned the ceiling ... each room also had a huge
fluorescent pyramid hanging off the ceiling ... as i stepped into the main
room i realized that this was going to be a party to remember ... the party
had this "je ne sais quoi?" atmosphere that promised many marvelous
experiences to come ... you could just feel the vibe in the room seeping out
of the walls and from the people ...

my buddies were in shock to find out that no alcohol would be served and for
a while they were a little uncomfortable in the new environment ... mostly
they were just standing around checking out the visuals and the crowd and
getting accustomed to the loud music and to receiving hugs from strangers
... haze and I brought every sfraver we could find to meet with them and
slowly the uneasyness started to wear off ...

i couldnt help getting on the floor to shake my booty thing as the music was
so intense even though the evening was just starting ... i left my crew in
the very capable hands of haze and i took off for musical bliss ... DRC came
on fairly soon after we got there and she just tore the house up ... i had
heard her set at another party a while back and i really didnt like it but
she kicked some serious rudi booty with this set !!!! ... a couple of the
newbies soon got adventurous and decided to venture onto the dance floor to
my delight ... DRC's set was also fairly hard core but i was totally into it
... you could tell that she was into the music that she was spinning as she
danced to it and that she was connected to the crowd as she "communicated"
with us - you'd have to experience one of her sets to understand what i mean
by that ...

next came mystre ... he toned down the music a little bit by playing more
"melodic" trance which is my favorite type of trance (actually that is the
only type of trance that i like) ... the peaks and the valleys in what he
spun took me on a magical journey ... it was so intense that i would find
myself just standing there with my eyes closed sucking in the music ...
intense ... then the music came to a stop ...

next came the voice of mars (???) who thanked everybody for showing up and
urged us to keep the vibe alive ... and then the most intense moment of the
evening came for me as the music started again and the remix of underworld's
"dark and long" came on - it was so intense that i didnt know whether to
jump of joy or start crying ... i chose to jump of joy ... mars increased
the hard edge of the trance that he played through his set which was fine by
me ... he also had an excellent set totally living up to his reputation ...

finally Ethan came on ... he took the trance back to the "hard core" level
and so i didnt get into the set as much ... also i was starting to feel the
fatigue from 5 hours of non-stop dancing and very little sleep ... the
evening ended in an extra track thrown in there by Mars ...

after waiting for michael to find his car keys we left oakland ... as i was
listening to one of the CDs i picked up at solid grooves the day before i
discovered that i had the same track that Mars started his set with ... i
was ecstatic about that (no pun intended) ... i have been listening to that
track non-stop all day now and every time the music reaches its peak i go
back to the party and find myself surrounded by people who love music as
much as i do ... i believe the track is by Underworld and it is called "dark
and long (dark train mix)" - at least that is what the CD cover says ...

things turned out pretty good for my crew ... 3 of them will definitely join
us for a rave again soon :-) ... the two others will be left home as they
definitely cannot handle being up all night or dancing without being drunk
for that matter ...

i want to thank all the sfravers who hung out with us last night for
embracing my crew so warmly ... this definitely helped to enhance their
experience and make this an awesome first party for them ... even the ones
that couldnt handle the late night/dancing were impressed by the scene and
the party ... this is what raving should be about !!!!

i am not going to list everybody that i saw at the party last night ... i
would probably forget some of you and that would make me feel totally bad
... you all know who you are and i know what you look like ;) ... i love you
all - thank you for making my weekend ...

also much respect to the hazemeister for once again choosing the right party
for me to go to ... i'll try to trust your judgement a little bit better
next time gurl ... also thanks for taking care of my buddies and introducing
them to everybody ...

i got home at around 8:30am and i took a quick eye rest (that would be me
lying in bed with my eyes closed without sleeping) and then headed out to
golf with my crew ... i scored a 64 on a par 30 (9 holes) - i suck but i
enjoy playing no matter what ... also that was an improvement for me as i
scored a 69 last week :-) ...

after golf and a late lunch/early dinner i joined the south bay family at
DjNick's place for the bbq ... unfortunately the weather got threatening and
so we decided to shut it down early ... the gang that was there (once again
you know who you are and i am not naming any names to protect the guilty)
decided to have a south park viewing marathon as i was leaving ... i hope
you guys had fun ... it is now 11pm and i am still trying to get motivated
to do my taxes ...

all in all an awesome weekend brought about by the wonderful community of
ravers that we are blessed to have in the south bay !!! thank you all so
much !!!

if you've read all the way down to here i send you much respect and good

mail after the second paragraph ;) (obviously you wouldnt know that if you
didnt come all the way down to here) ...

until next time, peace and really loud music,

<< the sacramento scene is so diffrent....

someone who has lived here for just about all my life I have to say I agree
about our scene being different but we really aren't unfriendly, honest.  That
sucks that no one came up to ya but well it's like this everyone in sacramento

Hi all!  ]=}

 What a lotta fun!!  :) What I've always like about The Gathering events 
is the very diverse crowd they draw. I love gang-like kids and snotty 
socialites getting down on the floor together!  :)

 It was really nice to bust a move to Jeno (who was first up in the main 
room) with comfortable room on the floor!

 I was mostly in the "less thumps" room (I was working visuals and 
such). Nick Phillips was fun, Alex Patterson played some *very* 
interesting stuff but also some, ahm... unapproachable (for me) type 
stuff. He did keep things interesting but I felt his segues were a bit 
rough without smoothness. Loved dancing to some of it tho.

 Joe Rice was an interesting contrast and very enjoyable as I wound down 
getting ready to pack my gear at the end of the night.

 Maritime Hall was lacking a bit in TP and hand towels. If they are 
going to kick us out at 4 AM the least they can do is keep the bathrooms 
well stocked.

 There was some sort of Power Exchange/Fetish party in the basement and 
a few of those folks made their presence known on the dance floor.

 Great work by Martin and his crew!!!!!  Much love and respect to the 
The Gathering's crew!!  :)

mad hugz,

Ran D. Dreams

something of a celebrity down in l.a...

hmmmm...I guess this wasn't so bad...except for all those damn sfravers I
kept running into

HAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHAHA

This party KICKED ASS

	First of all, had I known I was going to enjoy the music so much, I would
not have worn my beetlejuice outfit.  Those friggin striped tights and
swishy skirt are so damn cool and my go go boots are kickin, but
hellllllllyyyyyun you don't want to be wearing them to dance 5 hours
straight!!!!  Sigh.  Oh well, I still danced til my toes hurt and next F8
party I will know better : )  
	Lacie-gurl got us to our spot and I went in with her to see a bunch of
sfravers already there.  We packed the place guys!!! It was tony-the-tiger
great. When Dina first came in we were just hanging and walking around a
bit....it was already hot in there and it did get MUCH HOTTER as the night
wore on.....I noticed there were so many people groovin already when I
first got there.  I didn't see hardly anyone standing around.  As I "hung"
I couldn't help bouncing around for two reasons:  the first set was really
cool for me because there was this tribal drum thing going on and I REALLY
have a thing for drums!! the other is that everyone was dancing and dancing
is contagious for me : )
	Dina, not being much of a dancer, wanted to find other sfravers so we went
on a little jaunt and found most everyone: Haze and Rudi and Co., Natasha,
Lacie, Josh, Scott, oh there were so many!!  I kept seeing people all night
and it felt really good almost like I knew everyone at the party.  The
music just kept happening and happening for me....I would dance and dance
and the crowd would just absolutely go wild (I especially noticed this when
DRC was spinning) and later when Mars and Mystere were doing their thing it
would totally happen again although I was almost in that "trance dance"
state by then and kind of unaware of much going on around me.  Except my
feet hurt.  That was a bit of a distraction dammit. 
	Later I got really tired and Dina was going back and forth because she
wasn't in dance mode that night (partly because she had a no-effect
experience), even though she loves trance more than anything, but she
didn't really want to leave to go back to reality. So we listened to music
for a while and it was cool....then we started to think about driving
home....and thought more....and then, well, I guess it was just time to go.

Love you all!  

Terri

WEll.. my spring break is off to a slow start.  I made it out to neither
theGathering or F-8, although I'm more bitter about missing the latter.  Glad
to hear it went so well.. I really wish I could have been there.  The only
thing I did this weekend (besides bum around with my ravah friends and start
turning my house into a hotel) was head down to Sanctuary.  Since I've never
gone down there before, I wasn't sure what really to expect,but it was fun.
It's laid back things like that that make the end of the weekend fun.  Just
wanted to say thanx to Nick for letting us use his
house/yard/tables/barbeque/phone  and for feeding us.  Oh!! and for pushing me
around the parking lot in a shopping cart.  And thanx to Mook for putting up
with my lovely trainwrecks on the turntables.  ANYONE who let's ravers have
free reign of their yard like that has to be cool.. and so this my thank you.
Ok.. heheh Hopefully next weekend will be more action packed and I'll see you
all soon!

hugs n'stuff,
trice the tekno diva

Hey kidz,

I need input. Heres the skinny. The turntables are
built into a stationary unit and everytime the place
starts jumping the needles start skipping. (We have
tried all types of needles by the way!) They are
resting on like three inch foam pads already and have
been for like 5 years (upstairs Sound Factory). Since
I can't get anyone off their asses to suspend them, I
thought I would ask for your ideas.

They are set in a wood enclosure and sunken so that
top of the table (not the platter) is even with the
top of the enclosure. (picture downstairs at 1015)
the edges aren't touching and its deffinately coming
from the floor moving whilepeople are jumping up and
down. I have tried like closing off three feet around
the front of the DJ Booth but nothing seems to be
working. 

Any ideas would be greatly appreciated. Please respond
privately as not to spam the list as a whole.

Thanks
Layne

There is a difference between seeing a rave and becoming part of the 
rave itself. I'm not referring to actually planning the party...but the 
subtle line between hearing the music and feeling the music..where the 
vibe picks you up sober and leaves you with a tranquil feeling as if 
this is enough in its self. 

Lisa is so right. There was a point where the whole crowd was going...no 
lurkers no watchers. a unity. Ahh! It was an amazing experience. I had a 
really great time.

DRC is a true definition of 'grl pwR'. That woman blows me away. And of 
course mars & mystre we amazing...ethan roked but I don't think I got to 
hear greg sandler (strike that reverse... maybe I heard greg and not 
ethan....hmmm....) anyhoot: I was in 'absorb everything mode' and just 
enjoyed the vibe and people. I once said I'd never party @ 2nd/jackson 
again (ok so I said it last week =0) but it really reminded me that its 
not the space that makes it groovy its the groovy people who make it!

OH & HI O::to all the kewl and funky people i got to party with and hi 
to all the new people i met and who's names I've inevitably forgotten! 
you rule! and hi to all the regular kydes & SLOTribe. y'all...it was one 
to remember.

**re mem mem re mem  mem member freqency 8 great time together lauphin 
and dancin doin whatever, we liked best what ever the weather** 
--->ok no more kamp songs :o) 

that's my re-VIEW ... so have a krazy mad day!

its a sparkleberry kind of day :o)

LaCie.

"Learn to enjoy every minute of your life.  Be happy now. Don't wait for 
something outside of yourself to make you happy in the future--Think how 
really precious is the time you have to spend, whether it's at work or 
with your family. Every minute should be enjoyed, savored."
Earl Nightingale

Robert Pointer wrote:
> 
> Gang,
> 
> I just got back from Denver last night (on business) but was able to sneak
> away for awhile to see what was going on in the land o' mile high stadium.
> I found this cool rekkid shop called synaptic records on one of the main
> strips (Broadway, go figure...).
> Picked up a couple of CD's from Submerge (Detroit Techno - which I was
> pleasantly surprised to see DJ-T1000 making an appearance here :) and
> picked up a few flyers. The city seemed pretty dead, but I really didn't
> have enough time to explore fully like I usually do.
> To my point: I found this mag called Activated, a free zine outta
> Baltimore. Reading the masthead it looks like it is distributed at
> Housewares in the city. Anyway, I like reading reviews of music, and there
> is this reviewer called Kenya that cracks me up. Let me write verbatim a
> coupla of his reviews:
> 
> "Double 99 Rip Groove (Logic Records)
> 
> SPEED GARAGE. It's here, Logic is selling. Pushing it on kids, cause
> really, it's the next big thing. I was late on the speed garage thing. I
> didn't catch it until i heard Feelgood at "Think". For all i feel, you can
> keep it. It all sounded like Sugar Daddy remixes and spin offs. This record
> is the same; it's okay for a house record but it just gets real tired real
> quick. House pattern and supposed "jungle basslines". I didn't know jungle
> had a certain bassline; I've heard thousands of them, but hey speed garage
> has it. I swear to god it all sounds like Sugar Daddy. Spin it if ya want.
> Rock on."
> 
> Fatboyslim The BeatBurger EP (Astralwerks)
> 
> "I always knew that a) the Chemical Brothers would in time influence a lot
> of people and that b) they would create many Chemical Brothers spawns. This
> EP sucks. When I got all these promos, weeks and weeks ago, i went to
> Flavor to drop them inna mix and just to see how people hangin out reacted.
> I swear to god people wouldn't stop laughing until i did a nasty rewind and
> yanked it off the table. This stuff is like pop rock meets candy raver
> meets DJ Dan meets the Chemical Brothers, (with) over burdened hiphop
> stolen beats with metal guitar riffs or cheesy samples and old stolen piano
> lines from people more talented. Sadly though in some places i bet this
> shit leaps off the 1200s and into the crowd at a rave they eat it up. Go
> Ravers. Rave on."
> 
> or....
> 
> Toxic 220 Subliminal Sewage (Sugar Spliff, US)
> 
> " Toxic 220 is part of the infamous Spiral Tribe. So delighted iwas to hear
> this. It's jungle, it's Sprial Tribe .. it's gonna be good. After all the
> Shite i have been reviewing this was it. WRONG. PLEASE COME AGAIN. THANK
> YOU. This is shit. Everyone is saying jump up is shit. No way. THis is
> shit. Darkside rocks, i have just discovered my darkside/techstep other
> half as a DJ. But with any form of music, too much is a bad thing. Two
> tracks, both dark. I like them both but then the programming just gets
> silly. Both tracks sound like they have 5 different rhythm pattterns...nice
> listening, but it doesn't communicate well on the dancefloor and either way
> it gives me a migrane."
> 
> THis is funny stuff considering most of the review you read these days are
> filled with non-meaningful words like "the sound is deep. This track is
> smooth." etc. Usually I'm a stickler for grammer, but this sounds like any
> conversation at a DJ store that could be had.
> 
> They have a web site:

From: Dan Capriles <micron1@rocketmail.com>
Subject: another strike against dancing...

something i found in the paper today...

 

             New loft residents target SoMa clubs 

             By Emily Gurnon
             and Tyche Hendricks
             OF THE EXAMINER STAFF 

             IT COULD BE called this year's version of "The Sound and
the Fury."

             Growing friction between South of Market residents and
area nightclub owners has prompted
             police to step up patrols in the 11th Street corridor and
try to shut down the popular VSF club.

             As more people have moved into live-work spaces and
condominiums in the neighborhood, the
             clubs and their customers have been the target of written
complaints, a lawsuit and crackdowns
             by police, club owners said.

             "We really don't have a problem with the Police
Department if we don't have housing," said
             Robin Reichert, owner of the Paradise Lounge and
Transmission Theatre.

             The 11th Street club corridor is the latest flash point
in the debate over The City's hottest
             development craze -- the explosion of loft housing,
called live-work by planners, taking place
             in the formerly industrial South of Market neighborhood.

             Club owners say the police presence is just the latest
sign that they are being edged out of their
             neighborhood by residents whose large real estate
investments make them unwilling to put up
             with the noise and rowdiness that the clubs sometimes
bring.

             To the residents, more patrols mean a better chance that
the rules will be enforced.

             "What we object to is one club in particular," the VSF,
said Gail Goedinghaus, who lives
             kitty-corner from the nightclub at 11th and Folsom
streets. "If he would only operate according
             to his permits, we wouldn't have a problem."

             Formerly the Oasis, the VSF has generated numerous
complaints from nearby residents, said
             police Capt. Dennis Martel.

             Other residents have complained about neighboring clubs.
But unlike the others, the VSF has a
             dance hall permit that allows it to operate beyond 2 a.m.

             What Goedinghaus and her neighbors hear is "a very loud
heavy bass beat that sounds like a
             'thump thump thump' coming out of this club," she said.
"It rattles the windows on the fourth
             floor of the building where I live, and these are
double-paned windows. If you can imagine,
             it's very hard to sleep. It's the kind of sound, it gets
into your brain. It penetrates everything."

             To her partner's 10-year-old daughter, "it sounds like a
T. rex or something walking down the
             street," Goedinghaus said.

             In the past 15 months, police have documented 21
different incidents -- ranging from assault to
             noise to drug possession -- that triggered a resident's
complaint or a visit by police, Martel
             said. The department will attempt within the next several
weeks to suspend or revoke VSF's
             permits, he said.

             $60,000 for soundproofing 

             Club owner Kevin Murphy said the VSF is a "pretty good
neighbor." He spent $60,000 last
             year to install more soundproofing. He also hires
homeless people to clean up outside every
             morning and tries to work with the residents and police
to address problems, he said. But he
             feels the cooperation is one-sided.

             "The way in which it's coming to me, it's more like a
witch hunt," Murphy said. "It's like,
             'You're causing noise; we're going to shut you down.'

             "OK, people want to sleep. We need to help here, but it
is an industrial area. I'd like to see
             some of the residents that have moved in here take some
amount of responsibility for the
             decision they've made. I didn't move into their
neighborhood. They moved into mine."

             The we-were-here-first argument is a common one South of
Market, where club owners feel
             increasingly threatened by their new neighbors.

             Several club owners wrote the city Board of Permit
Appeals, pleading for a reconsideration of
             the board's approval of a new 15-unit live-work space on
Harrison Street near 11th. The
             nightclubs lost; the project received the go-ahead.

             "It is unreasonable and unfair for businesses such as
ours, which have been established for
             longer than some of these tenants have been on Earth, to
have to constantly deal with a
             situation which should never have happened," wrote Bill
Herrmann, owner of the Holy Cow
             on Folsom. "It would be different if the area was
residential and the clubs moved in, but this is
             not the case."

             If more housing is allowed to move in, "We'll all go by
the end of next year," said Reichert,
             the Paradise Lounge owner.

             No new clubs allowed 

             The area is zoned for mixed use, meaning both housing and
light industrial development are
             allowed. Since a zoning change in 1990, new nightclubs
have not been allowed in the area, and
             the existing ones need to have all required police
permits to stay in business, planning officials
             said.

             Meanwhile, the number of lofts has mushroomed from 58
built in 1991 to 617 built or under
             construction in 1997. The housing boom in the mixed-use
area has caused much of the
             conflict, club owners and their supporters said.

             Problems that may have gone unnoticed by police in past
years, such as rowdy patrons, now
             attract the attention of residents. They, in turn, call
police.

             Clubgoers "get boozed up and they make a lot of noise and
they don't always have respect for
             the residents of the area," Martel said.

             "Not only do you have this music going on, but you have
all this street life that goes on until 4,
             5, 6 in the morning," said Felix Rodriguez, who lives on
11th Street between Folsom and
             Harrison.

             Rodriguez said the problems are limited to the VSF.

             "We're talking about violent fights in the street,
yelling," he said. "People who come here,
             their attitude is basically, anything goes here." On one
occasion, Rodriguez said he saw three
             or four men pull a parking meter out of the ground in
front of his building. Others urinate in
             doorways, throw beer bottles and rev their motorcycle
engines, he said.

             Police can enforce laws on public drunkenness, disturbing
the peace and traffic violations.
             They can force club owners to follow city laws and run
their establishments in an orderly
             fashion to avoid problems with the community, Martel said.

             Adapt to inner-city life 

             Many of the partyers themselves have little sympathy for
residents.

             "If you're moving into the inner-city area, then you have
to adapt to the inner-city life," said
             Tom Parsons, a New Zealander living temporarily in San
Francisco who stopped by the 20
             Tank Brewery on 11th Street last week.

             "People need to be a little more selective in where they
choose to live," said Paul Schuman,
             Parsons' roommate. "They need to research it before they
move in."

             Andrew Schmidt worked at 20 Tank three years ago and now
is a bartender in the Mission
             District. He is scornful of new residents who complain
about noise.

             "They were fools, I think (to move in here), because this
is South of Market," he said. "It's a
             hotbed for investment and that makes people make quick
decisions. They don't think. If you
             want quiet, live by the beach.

             "South of Market's history was always rowdy," Schmidt
continued. "People drag race
             motorcycles, there's bands, and there's lots of drinking.
And where there's drinking, there's
             noise."

             Musician Pauli Gray, who performed at an open mike at the
Paradise last week, said he feared
             the complaints could shut down clubs that make San
Francisco unique.

             "Then you wouldn't have the music scene happening. What's
going to happen then?" he said.
             "We're going to lose the special character of this city." 



                                             The Examiner

it doesn't matter what they dress like in denver.  dress how you want 
to.  be the individual that you are because that's the most beautiful 
thing about this scene - a group of individuals coming together to enjoy 
something that we all love, the music.  this is the tribe.

lovehugs&kisses,

amber

> Robert Pointer wrote:
> > 
> > Gang,
> > 
> > I just got back from Denver last night (on business) but was able to sneak
> > away for awhile to see what was going on in the land o' mile high stadium.
> > I found this cool rekkid shop called synaptic records on one of the main
> > strips (Broadway, go figure...).
> > Picked up a couple of CD's from Submerge (Detroit Techno - which I was
> > pleasantly surprised to see DJ-T1000 making an appearance here :) and
> > picked up a few flyers. The city seemed pretty dead, but I really didn't
> > have enough time to explore fully like I usually do.
> > To my point: I found this mag called Activated, a free zine outta
> > Baltimore. Reading the masthead it looks like it is distributed at
> > Housewares in the city. Anyway, I like reading reviews of music, and there
> > is this reviewer called Kenya that cracks me up. Let me write verbatim a
> > coupla of his reviews:
> > 
> > "Double 99 Rip Groove (Logic Records)
> > 
> > SPEED GARAGE. It's here, Logic is selling. Pushing it on kids, cause
> > really, it's the next big thing. I was late on the speed garage thing. I
> > didn't catch it until i heard Feelgood at "Think". For all i feel, you can
> > keep it. It all sounded like Sugar Daddy remixes and spin offs. This record
> > is the same; it's okay for a house record but it just gets real tired real
> > quick. House pattern and supposed "jungle basslines". I didn't know jungle
> > had a certain bassline; I've heard thousands of them, but hey speed garage
> > has it. I swear to god it all sounds like Sugar Daddy. Spin it if ya want.
> > Rock on."
> > 
> > Fatboyslim The BeatBurger EP (Astralwerks)
> > 
> > "I always knew that a) the Chemical Brothers would in time influence a lot
> > of people and that b) they would create many Chemical Brothers spawns. This
> > EP sucks. When I got all these promos, weeks and weeks ago, i went to
> > Flavor to drop them inna mix and just to see how people hangin out reacted.
> > I swear to god people wouldn't stop laughing until i did a nasty rewind and
> > yanked it off the table. This stuff is like pop rock meets candy raver
> > meets DJ Dan meets the Chemical Brothers, (with) over burdened hiphop
> > stolen beats with metal guitar riffs or cheesy samples and old stolen piano
> > lines from people more talented. Sadly though in some places i bet this
> > shit leaps off the 1200s and into the crowd at a rave they eat it up. Go
> > Ravers. Rave on."
> > 
> > or....
> > 
> > Toxic 220 Subliminal Sewage (Sugar Spliff, US)
> > 
> > " Toxic 220 is part of the infamous Spiral Tribe. So delighted iwas to hear
> > this. It's jungle, it's Sprial Tribe .. it's gonna be good. After all the
> > Shite i have been reviewing this was it. WRONG. PLEASE COME AGAIN. THANK
> > YOU. This is shit. Everyone is saying jump up is shit. No way. THis is
> > shit. Darkside rocks, i have just discovered my darkside/techstep other
> > half as a DJ. But with any form of music, too much is a bad thing. Two
> > tracks, both dark. I like them both but then the programming just gets
> > silly. Both tracks sound like they have 5 different rhythm pattterns...nice
> > listening, but it doesn't communicate well on the dancefloor and either way
> > it gives me a migrane."
> > 
> > THis is funny stuff considering most of the review you read these days are
> > filled with non-meaningful words like "the sound is deep. This track is
> > smooth." etc. Usually I'm a stickler for grammer, but this sounds like any
> > conversation at a DJ store that could be had.
> > 
> > They have a web site:
> > http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/studio/9391/active.htm
> > 
> > didn't test the link, however. maybe it works?
> > 
> > Anyway, props to this mag for printing the stuff raw w/o regard to status quo.
> >

broadcast is about an hour... i think i actually heard a sample i knew

yourself with about an hour's free time please check out the show at

Hmmmm....

I guess I've got a different review of that party...  so here's my .02 on the
whole dealio...  

Of the four peeps that went to the party, only 2 of us stayed longer than 2 or
3 hours... so since I had driven more than 2 hours just to get there (after
picking up some people) I wasn't about to let anything get in my way of having
a good time!!!  Most of the peeps I saw seemed either a little tight (as in
"wrapped too...") when I first got there, or were just (well... something else
then...) but as the party evolved, so did the vibe....  

My friend Steve and I both couldn't believe just how the party took off!  I
mean the whole thing did a 180!  I had people talking to me, and I saw so many
people having a good time that I think the Sac. scene definitely has
potential....  In short, I think I can  compare it to visiting "my cousin in
Omaha..."  (same name, same blood, same love, etc.  just different, thats
all...).  I really don't think it was worth 20 buckaroos... but I would
definitely go to another party there...!  

Peace. Out.
~Michael

Subject: Re: another strike against dancing...(LONG & URGENT)

Precedence: bulk

(Sunny using Molly's mail)

Thanks for posting this to the list.  We invited the media down last
Saturday night and had several TV stations and several print reporters
in the house.  We asked them (the media) to stand outside the club and
monitor the sound. In fact, one reporter standing outside VSF remarked
that he could hear The Paradise Lounge more so than VSF.  Mind you, he
was at VSF's front door.   We said just you wait.  Then almost like
clockwork the SFPD came careening around the corner and slammed on the
brakes right in front of us.  This cop gets out and briskly walks to our
front door to serve us with yet another sound violation.  Boy was he
surprised when all of these reporters said that they could hear the
clubs down the street more so than VSF.  Guess what, he didn't write the
club up. 

SOMA dance clubs are under attack.  First DV8 then The Trocadero, then
The Holy Cow and VSF last week. Big Heart City, 1015 Folsom & The Sound
Factory have been raided several times over the last few weeks and
received several write-ups from the ABC as well. Do you remember when SF
used to have raves then the police said no more and SF Raves stopped
over night? Ring a bell?  Welcome to the game.  

Besides promoting at VSF, I am also the owner of a bar in a totally
different neighborhood in SF. It's core clientele is 20 something's
young adults we have a DJ set-up in-house but close by 2AM.  I've owned
it for over 4 years now and we've never been raided by the ABC or the
police to date.  I asked my local station sergeant how come I was immune
while places like VSF & 1015 Folsom had to put up with these constant
raids.  He said, (off the record of course) The SFPD has decided that
after-hours clubs are a nuisance they attract the wrong crowd.  That
they (SFPD) think that most of the illicit activity in the city goes on
between those hours and if they can eradicate a businesses ability to
operate during those hours then no more problems. Bars are OK  they're
about "drinking."  Dance clubs attract a totally different element. 

But the Police are not the only problem.  The entire corridor is now
surrounded by lofts or live-work units.  In fact, the adjacent building
(shares a wall) to VSF was just converted from a storage warehouse to 4
premium loft units, each listed at $650,000.  No one has moved in yet
but it's a matter of time before someone does and can't sleep because
they share a wall with a nightclub and starts the whole process of
calling the police 10 times a night to stop the music.   VSF's owner has
owned the club for 15+ years now and he is quick to point out that the
clubs are not the only focus of the new loft owners.  2 blocks away a
family owned trucking company that has been in the neighborhood for 63
years is moving.  You see, they loaded their trucks between the hours of
2-6AM and were making too much noise for the loft units next door. 
While the police couldn't bust them for noise they could write them up
over and over for double parking.  That solved the noise problem
instantly.

The ownership and the promoters of VSF will obviously lose if they shut
the club but so will the local dance community.   Ask yourself if you've
ever enjoyed a night or day at any of the following parties: Stompy,
Spundae, Pablo's Sugar Shack, Sunshine Daydream, FTT's Ultra, Deep
Space, Bondage-A-GoGo, Raindance, Eye-Spy.   Who's next?

I just read the article again and especially enjoy the lady who says,
"What we object to is one club in particular, the VSF, said Gail
Goedinghaus, who lives kitty-corner from the nightclub at 11th and
Folsom
streets. If he would only operate according to his permits, we wouldn't
have a problem."  The reporter later writes,  "Other residents have
complained about neighboring clubs. But unlike the others, the VSF has a
dance hall permit that allows it to operate beyond 2 a.m."  

This same lady showed up at the front door a few weeks ago in her
bathrobe and slippers screaming to "shut the music off!" She kept
screaming "it's illegal to play music after 2AM!!!"  The owner
threatened to have her removed from the premises.  Turns out she had
just moved into the neighborhood 4 months earlier and says she didn't
even know that all of the clubs were clubs.  Duh. 

Thank you for letting me vent.

-Sunny
Promoter 
Dan Capriles wrote:
> 
> something i found in the paper today...
> 
> 
> 
>              New loft residents target SoMa clubs
> 
>              By Emily Gurnon
>              and Tyche Hendricks
>              OF THE EXAMINER STAFF
> 
>              IT COULD BE called this year's version of "The Sound and
> the Fury."
> 
>              Growing friction between South of Market residents and
> area nightclub owners has prompted
>              police to step up patrols in the 11th Street corridor and
> try to shut down the popular VSF club.
> 
>              As more people have moved into live-work spaces and
> condominiums in the neighborhood, the
>              clubs and their customers have been the target of written
> complaints, a lawsuit and crackdowns
>              by police, club owners said.
> 
>              "We really don't have a problem with the Police
> Department if we don't have housing," said
>              Robin Reichert, owner of the Paradise Lounge and
> Transmission Theatre.
> 
>              The 11th Street club corridor is the latest flash point
> in the debate over The City's hottest
>              development craze -- the explosion of loft housing,
> called live-work by planners, taking place
>              in the formerly industrial South of Market neighborhood.
> 
>              Club owners say the police presence is just the latest
> sign that they are being edged out of their
>              neighborhood by residents whose large real estate
> investments make them unwilling to put up
>              with the noise and rowdiness that the clubs sometimes
> bring.
> 
>              To the residents, more patrols mean a better chance that
> the rules will be enforced.
> 
>              "What we object to is one club in particular," the VSF,
> said Gail Goedinghaus, who lives
>              kitty-corner from the nightclub at 11th and Folsom
> streets. "If he would only operate according
>              to his permits, we wouldn't have a problem."
> 
>              Formerly the Oasis, the VSF has generated numerous
> complaints from nearby residents, said
>              police Capt. Dennis Martel.
> 
>              Other residents have complained about neighboring clubs.
> But unlike the others, the VSF has a
>              dance hall permit that allows it to operate beyond 2 a.m.
> 
>              What Goedinghaus and her neighbors hear is "a very loud
> heavy bass beat that sounds like a
>              'thump thump thump' coming out of this club," she said.
> "It rattles the windows on the fourth
>              floor of the building where I live, and these are
> double-paned windows. If you can imagine,
>              it's very hard to sleep. It's the kind of sound, it gets
> into your brain. It penetrates everything."
> 
>              To her partner's 10-year-old daughter, "it sounds like a
> T. rex or something walking down the
>              street," Goedinghaus said.
> 
>              In the past 15 months, police have documented 21
> different incidents -- ranging from assault to
>              noise to drug possession -- that triggered a resident's
> complaint or a visit by police, Martel
>              said. The department will attempt within the next several
> weeks to suspend or revoke VSF's
>              permits, he said.
> 
>              $60,000 for soundproofing
> 
>              Club owner Kevin Murphy said the VSF is a "pretty good
> neighbor." He spent $60,000 last
>              year to install more soundproofing. He also hires
> homeless people to clean up outside every
>              morning and tries to work with the residents and police
> to address problems, he said. But he
>              feels the cooperation is one-sided.
> 
>              "The way in which it's coming to me, it's more like a
> witch hunt," Murphy said. "It's like,
>              'You're causing noise; we're going to shut you down.'
> 
>              "OK, people want to sleep. We need to help here, but it
> is an industrial area. I'd like to see
>              some of the residents that have moved in here take some
> amount of responsibility for the
>              decision they've made. I didn't move into their
> neighborhood. They moved into mine."
> 
>              The we-were-here-first argument is a common one South of
> Market, where club owners feel
>              increasingly threatened by their new neighbors.
> 
>              Several club owners wrote the city Board of Permit
> Appeals, pleading for a reconsideration of
>              the board's approval of a new 15-unit live-work space on
> Harrison Street near 11th. The
>              nightclubs lost; the project received the go-ahead.
> 
>              "It is unreasonable and unfair for businesses such as
> ours, which have been established for
>              longer than some of these tenants have been on Earth, to
> have to constantly deal with a
>              situation which should never have happened," wrote Bill
> Herrmann, owner of the Holy Cow
>              on Folsom. "It would be different if the area was
> residential and the clubs moved in, but this is
>              not the case."
> 
>              If more housing is allowed to move in, "We'll all go by
> the end of next year," said Reichert,
>              the Paradise Lounge owner.
> 
>              No new clubs allowed
> 
>              The area is zoned for mixed use, meaning both housing and
> light industrial development are
>              allowed. Since a zoning change in 1990, new nightclubs
> have not been allowed in the area, and
>              the existing ones need to have all required police
> permits to stay in business, planning officials
>              said.
> 
>              Meanwhile, the number of lofts has mushroomed from 58
> built in 1991 to 617 built or under
>              construction in 1997. The housing boom in the mixed-use
> area has caused much of the
>              conflict, club owners and their supporters said.
> 
>              Problems that may have gone unnoticed by police in past
> years, such as rowdy patrons, now
>              attract the attention of residents. They, in turn, call
> police.
> 
>              Clubgoers "get boozed up and they make a lot of noise and
> they don't always have respect for
>              the residents of the area," Martel said.
> 
>              "Not only do you have this music going on, but you have
> all this street life that goes on until 4,
>              5, 6 in the morning," said Felix Rodriguez, who lives on
> 11th Street between Folsom and
>              Harrison.
> 
>              Rodriguez said the problems are limited to the VSF.
> 
>              "We're talking about violent fights in the street,
> yelling," he said. "People who come here,
>              their attitude is basically, anything goes here." On one
> occasion, Rodriguez said he saw three
>              or four men pull a parking meter out of the ground in
> front of his building. Others urinate in
>              doorways, throw beer bottles and rev their motorcycle
> engines, he said.
> 
>              Police can enforce laws on public drunkenness, disturbing
> the peace and traffic violations.
>              They can force club owners to follow city laws and run
> their establishments in an orderly
>              fashion to avoid problems with the community, Martel said.
> 
>              Adapt to inner-city life
> 
>              Many of the partyers themselves have little sympathy for
> residents.
> 
>              "If you're moving into the inner-city area, then you have
> to adapt to the inner-city life," said
>              Tom Parsons, a New Zealander living temporarily in San
> Francisco who stopped by the 20
>              Tank Brewery on 11th Street last week.
> 
>              "People need to be a little more selective in where they
> choose to live," said Paul Schuman,
>              Parsons' roommate. "They need to research it before they
> move in."
> 
>              Andrew Schmidt worked at 20 Tank three years ago and now
> is a bartender in the Mission
>              District. He is scornful of new residents who complain
> about noise.
> 
>              "They were fools, I think (to move in here), because this
> is South of Market," he said. "It's a
>              hotbed for investment and that makes people make quick
> decisions. They don't think. If you
>              want quiet, live by the beach.
> 
>              "South of Market's history was always rowdy," Schmidt
> continued. "People drag race
>              motorcycles, there's bands, and there's lots of drinking.
> And where there's drinking, there's
>              noise."
> 
>              Musician Pauli Gray, who performed at an open mike at the
> Paradise last week, said he feared
>              the complaints could shut down clubs that make San
> Francisco unique.
> 
>              "Then you wouldn't have the music scene happening. What's
> going to happen then?" he said.
>              "We're going to lose the special character of this city."
> 
>                                              The Examiner

Good good day.

Hooked up with Cole, at my house.  Then Pete came over and sold
me his kickin mixer!  Woo!  Eventually we got out of the house,
and headed for the Maritime Hall for tickets to the Gathering
before going to the Great American to see Trans Am.

Well, we needn't have gone to the Maritime, because there were
no ins and outs, as we deduced after much hassle and haggling,
so we went to the Great American, hoping we
hadn't missed Trans Am.  Fortunately, we only missed one song,
and tickets were only $8!  They were incredible!!!  Their drummer
(who also plays drums for Tortoise, I believe) was amazing!
Don't miss them if they come to your town -- trust me.

After the superduper Trans Am show, we had a pizza with extra
mushrooms (hold the pizza), and went back to the Maritime,
this time hoping we didn't miss Alex Patterson.  Unfortunately,
we had already missed a little, but still caught over an hour of
his set.  He was incredible!!!  And it was a good way to "digest"
our "pizza".  Alex waxed between IDM and ambient, all of which
was fantastic (if a little hard to keep up).

Then we went upstairs to the main room of Maritime, where the
bulk of the masses were.  It was crowded and hot and sweaty,
but the music was good, and the cool movies, posters, lasers,
lights, and all that made it worth braving the crowd.  But
not for long.  There was no room to shake it, so we went back
downstairs.

Joe Rice was on then, and he kept up the cool jams while people
lounged about on the floor, watched the acrobatics of the kids
in the dance circle (some of who were catching some serious air!),
dancing about in a more subdued fashion, or just standing about
watching the people.  I talked to some people (hey Ran D!), danced
some, and listened to the great choonz.  So so mellow and so so cool!!!

Unfortunately, the Maritime being what it is, they closed the
party down at 4am (there was an afterparty elsewhere, but we
decided to skip it), so we took off home.

But it was a great night of great music and I had a very mellow blast.

Steve.

>We invited the media down last
>Saturday night and had several TV stations and several print reporters
>in the house.  We asked them (the media) to stand outside the club and
>monitor the sound. In fact, one reporter standing outside VSF remarked
>that he could hear The Paradise Lounge more so than VSF.  Mind you, he
>was at VSF's front door.   We said just you wait.  Then almost like
>clockwork the SFPD came careening around the corner and slammed on the
>brakes right in front of us.  This cop gets out and briskly walks to our
>front door to serve us with yet another sound violation.  Boy was he
>surprised when all of these reporters said that they could hear the
>clubs down the street more so than VSF.  Guess what, he didn't write the
>club up.

My housemates and I used to have a music studio in our garage when we were
living in the suburbs.  We took care to keep the level low enough so that
someone standing in the street couldn't hear the music.  But then our
neighbor across the street complained to us (at midnight on a weeknight)
that the bass was making his walls vibrate.  Sound travels more easily
through solids than through air.  What was happening was that even though
the sound didn't travel through the air out to the street, it was
travelling through the earth across the street and making our neighbor's
walls vibrate.

In the case of VSF... If you are standing outside the club and cannot hear
the music, it is still very likely that the sound is travelling through the
ground and up through the walls of the neighboring buildings, causing their
windows to rattle.  Someone who is trying to sleep in one of those
buildings could conceivably be awakened by the vibrations that are
travelling through the walls in their apartment.

Yeah but this is like the person who moves into a neighborhood a few blocks
from the airport and complians that the planes are making too much noise. If
the source of the noise was there first then it's your own fault for moving
into an uncomfortable environment. What these people are doing is the
equivelent of the airport tenants going to the airport and asking them not
to fly the planes late at night cuz they need to sleep. Ludicrous! If you
can't handle the noise, don't move into a noisy neighborhood.

>From my view, this is one of the best things to happen in a long time.  I
guess one need just wait long enough until the chickens come home to roost.
I personally hate VSF, so if they go *I* won't miss it at all.

This also goes to show how when people band together (in this case the loft
owners), anything is possible.  If the rave community, and the people who
threw parties weren't so disorganized, and so concerned with self, this
might be able to be stopped.  However considering the long history, I am
would put my money with the loft owners.

That club does no service to the dance community.  The security is quite
overzealous (grabbing ladies out of line because of thier use of, er, lip
balm?), and the people who are a part of the club (not necessarily the
promoters) are , to say the least, underhanded.

Oh well.  At least there is still (for now), 1015, Townsend.  Perhpas VSF
will survive.  But they will do so without my help.

Good riddance.

At 11:22 AM -0700 4/13/98, Dan Capriles wrote:
>something i found in the paper today...
>
>
>
>             New loft residents target SoMa clubs
>
>             By Emily Gurnon
>             and Tyche Hendricks
>             OF THE EXAMINER STAFF
>
>             IT COULD BE called this year's version of "The Sound and
>the Fury."
>
>             Growing friction between South of Market residents and
>area nightclub owners has prompted
>             police to step up patrols in the 11th Street corridor and
>try to shut down the popular VSF club.

:)

>
>             As more people have moved into live-work spaces and
>condominiums in the neighborhood, the
>             clubs and their customers have been the target of written
>complaints, a lawsuit and crackdowns
>             by police, club owners said.
>
>             "We really don't have a problem with the Police
>Department if we don't have housing," said
>             Robin Reichert, owner of the Paradise Lounge and
>Transmission Theatre.
>
>             The 11th Street club corridor is the latest flash point
>in the debate over The City's hottest
>             development craze -- the explosion of loft housing,
>called live-work by planners, taking place
>             in the formerly industrial South of Market neighborhood.
>
>             Club owners say the police presence is just the latest
>sign that they are being edged out of their
>             neighborhood by residents whose large real estate
>investments make them unwilling to put up
>             with the noise and rowdiness that the clubs sometimes
>bring.

Well maybe if you treated your patrons better (VSF), you might garner some
sympathy.  Unfortunately there are still other places that are just as good
to have a aprty at.


>
>             To the residents, more patrols mean a better chance that
>the rules will be enforced.
>
>             "What we object to is one club in particular," the VSF,
>said Gail Goedinghaus, who lives
>             kitty-corner from the nightclub at 11th and Folsom
>streets. "If he would only operate according
>             to his permits, we wouldn't have a problem."

:)

>
>             Formerly the Oasis, the VSF has generated numerous
>complaints from nearby residents, said
>             police Capt. Dennis Martel.

And from disgrunteld clubbers alike I'm sure.

>
>             Other residents have complained about neighboring clubs.
>But unlike the others, the VSF has a
>             dance hall permit that allows it to operate beyond 2 a.m.
>
>             What Goedinghaus and her neighbors hear is "a very loud
>heavy bass beat that sounds like a
>             'thump thump thump' coming out of this club," she said.
>"It rattles the windows on the fourth
>             floor of the building where I live, and these are
>double-paned windows. If you can imagine,
>             it's very hard to sleep. It's the kind of sound, it gets
>into your brain. It penetrates everything."

Time to close the roof on the sucka.  Like 1015 before ye, you too must
enclose the noise, I mean beat.  It now becomes just another hot ass club.

>
>             To her partner's 10-year-old daughter, "it sounds like a
>T. rex or something walking down the
>             street," Goedinghaus said.
>
>             In the past 15 months, police have documented 21
>different incidents -- ranging from assault to
>             noise to drug possession -- that triggered a resident's
>complaint or a visit by police, Martel
>             said. The department will attempt within the next several
>weeks to suspend or revoke VSF's
>             permits, he said.
>
>             $60,000 for soundproofing
>
>             Club owner Kevin Murphy said the VSF is a "pretty good
>neighbor." He spent $60,000 last
>             year to install more soundproofing. He also hires
>homeless people to clean up outside every
>             morning and tries to work with the residents and police
>to address problems, he said. But he
>             feels the cooperation is one-sided.
>
>             "The way in which it's coming to me, it's more like a
>witch hunt," Murphy said. "It's like,
>             'You're causing noise; we're going to shut you down.'
>
>             "OK, people want to sleep. We need to help here, but it
>is an industrial area. I'd like to see
>             some of the residents that have moved in here take some
>amount of responsibility for the
>             decision they've made. I didn't move into their
>neighborhood. They moved into mine."
>
>             The we-were-here-first argument is a common one South of
>Market, where club owners feel
>             increasingly threatened by their new neighbors.
>
>             Several club owners wrote the city Board of Permit
>Appeals, pleading for a reconsideration of
>             the board's approval of a new 15-unit live-work space on
>Harrison Street near 11th. The
>             nightclubs lost; the project received the go-ahead.
>
>             "It is unreasonable and unfair for businesses such as
>ours, which have been established for
>             longer than some of these tenants have been on Earth, to
>have to constantly deal with a
>             situation which should never have happened," wrote Bill
>Herrmann, owner of the Holy Cow
>             on Folsom. "It would be different if the area was
>residential and the clubs moved in, but this is
>             not the case."
>
>             If more housing is allowed to move in, "We'll all go by
>the end of next year," said Reichert,
>             the Paradise Lounge owner.
>
>             No new clubs allowed
>
>             The area is zoned for mixed use, meaning both housing and
>light industrial development are
>             allowed. Since a zoning change in 1990, new nightclubs
>have not been allowed in the area, and
>             the existing ones need to have all required police
>permits to stay in business, planning officials
>             said.
>
>             Meanwhile, the number of lofts has mushroomed from 58
>built in 1991 to 617 built or under
>             construction in 1997. The housing boom in the mixed-use
>area has caused much of the
>             conflict, club owners and their supporters said.
>
>             Problems that may have gone unnoticed by police in past
>years, such as rowdy patrons, now
>             attract the attention of residents. They, in turn, call
>police.
>
>             Clubgoers "get boozed up and they make a lot of noise and
>they don't always have respect for
>             the residents of the area," Martel said.
>
>             "Not only do you have this music going on, but you have
>all this street life that goes on until 4,
>             5, 6 in the morning," said Felix Rodriguez, who lives on
>11th Street between Folsom and
>             Harrison.
>
>             Rodriguez said the problems are limited to the VSF.
>
>             "We're talking about violent fights in the street,
>yelling," he said. "People who come here,
>             their attitude is basically, anything goes here." On one
>occasion, Rodriguez said he saw three
>             or four men pull a parking meter out of the ground in
>front of his building. Others urinate in
>             doorways, throw beer bottles and rev their motorcycle
>engines, he said.
>
>             Police can enforce laws on public drunkenness, disturbing
>the peace and traffic violations.
>             They can force club owners to follow city laws and run
>their establishments in an orderly
>             fashion to avoid problems with the community, Martel said.
>
>             Adapt to inner-city life
>
>             Many of the partyers themselves have little sympathy for
>residents.
>
>             "If you're moving into the inner-city area, then you have
>to adapt to the inner-city life," said
>             Tom Parsons, a New Zealander living temporarily in San
>Francisco who stopped by the 20
>             Tank Brewery on 11th Street last week.
>
>             "People need to be a little more selective in where they
>choose to live," said Paul Schuman,
>             Parsons' roommate. "They need to research it before they
>move in."
>
>             Andrew Schmidt worked at 20 Tank three years ago and now
>is a bartender in the Mission
>             District. He is scornful of new residents who complain
>about noise.
>
>             "They were fools, I think (to move in here), because this
>is South of Market," he said. "It's a
>             hotbed for investment and that makes people make quick
>decisions. They don't think. If you
>             want quiet, live by the beach.
>
>             "South of Market's history was always rowdy," Schmidt
>continued. "People drag race
>             motorcycles, there's bands, and there's lots of drinking.
>And where there's drinking, there's
>             noise."
>
>             Musician Pauli Gray, who performed at an open mike at the
>Paradise last week, said he feared
>             the complaints could shut down clubs that make San
>Francisco unique.
>
>             "Then you wouldn't have the music scene happening. What's
>going to happen then?" he said.
>             "We're going to lose the special character of this city."

It was lost a long time ago.  There are only a few clubs with after hours
permits, the cab laws suck, and the clubowners could care less about
clubgoers and are in it for one thing: $$$'s (the drinks at VSF are some of
the highest in SOMA).

Anyway...this will be interesting if nothing else.

>
>
>
>                                             The Examiner

At 1:12 PM -0700 4/13/98, Dan Capriles wrote:
>i REALLY think that we should start a letter (or e-mail) writing
>campaign to the board of supervisors and the mayor.  This is ludicrous
>and should not be allowed to continue.
>
>does anyone have the contact info for the above??
>
>=)
>dan

Dan,

On the for real, you have got to be kidding. If we can't even get together
for a vietnamese dinner what makes anyone think this loose band of ravers
can get together to do anything other than party.

The real issue for raver action is this:  What do you have to offer the
City?  You are not involved in the economic development , you do not own
property and are not (other than partying) contributing the the city's
coffers in a significant fashion.  You don't even vote!  Money talks, and
da Mayor listens to those with deep pockets.  Especially property owners
buying $350,000 lofts!

If I could count the times I wrote letters to the various Mayors about
after hours parties.  In any case, I doubt there will be any collective
action.  there are other clubs and other venues and other places (the East
Bay), to get a groove on.  Usually people will only move when their backs
are pressed against the wall and there is nowhere to go!  Dancing is
usually not enough to make people do anything other than look for the next
party at the next place.  Unfortunate but true.

In general ravers are a lazy lot, and not really motivasted by politics.
As Miss Kitty pointed out there have been other clubs (DV8 & The Oasis),
that havene;t survived, and you heard not a peep from the community.  Same
will happen to toher clubs as development interest with long dollars gobble
up every space in sight (until the next earthquake).

I hope that unlike myself and others you can motivate people to act
(although I do wish it was for some other club than VSF) and you can turn
the tide of history.  If that does happen and thier is a victory I hope VSF
does everyone a service and treats it's patrons like human beings, instead
of cattle to be pushed around.  If they do win they would do well to lower
the price of drinks at the bar, and tell thier overzealous security to ease
up and let people have some fun.

Good luck.

(I still hate VSF).

peace,
John

"Everyday above ground is a good day." - Mel Bernstein, Chief Detective
Narcotics

 A little Tuesday Morning Humor:


 this is stupid, but cute...
  ----------

A chicken and an egg are lying in bed.
The chicken is smoking a cigarette with a satisfied smile on its
face and the egg is frowning and looking a bit pissed off.
The egg mutters, to no one in particular,
 "Well, I guess we answered THATquestion!"

Precedence: bulk

(SUNNY on Molly's account)

I hear John.  The management & security @ VSF *DO* suck.  But in over 8
years of promoting I haven't met a club owner that I could actually call
anything more than a sour business acquaintance, much less a friend. 
The issue here is simple.  There's an agenda at work.

The chronicle ceased to write about the 11 ABC (Alcohol Beverage Control
Board) raids in the last 4 months!  These agents walk right through the
entire establishment and make everybody show their IDs.  One night they
even fanned out onto the dancefloor and stopped the dancing @ VSF. 
There have been undercover cops in the house every Friday & Saturday for
as long as I can remember.  Believe me, the security wouldn't be so
damned on edge if they didn't have the police all over them every
night.  If they don't react to something illegal & a cop sees it then
the club DOES lose it license.  It's a catch-22.

I can't argue what happened to John.  I wasn't there & that's been
hashed to the Nth degree on this list.  My argument right now is
simple.  THE SFPD IS TRYING TO STOP AFTERHOURS DANCING.  Like VSF or
not, a club that you DO like WILL be next.  If you could only hear some
of the shit that the police have said to us.  I mean, one time last
summer I lost my shit when a police officer told me that I didn't have
to worry because my party brought in the *right* crowd.  But they were
having a problem with the club's *Wednesday* hip-hop night.  That night
brought in the wrong crowd. Oh yeah, and the "tweaker freaks" on Sunday
nights.  This is *YOUR* police department.  

San Francisco will not issue anymore after-hours dance permits. So every
time one club leaves that's one fewer venue in which to hold a party. I
have some of the fondest memories of Spundae's @ DV8.  I can remember
several killer WICKED's @ The Trocadero.  The word is that King Street &
Townsend are next after the 11th Street Corridor.  Take a look
Townsend/King Street's location, just across the street from the new
ball park with lofts sprouting up around the place like mushrooms. Where
are we going to hold "dance parties?"

Somewhere along the line we were forced to transfer a lot of the medium
that we call raving into club venues.  In other cities the dance scene
exists only in clubs. When there cease to be any afterhours dance clubs,
well what then?

-SUNNY
Promoter

More reading...

SOMA WARS

URL:
http://www.sfgate.com/cgi-bin/article.cgi?file=/chronicle/archive/1998/04/14/DD82609.DTL

---Dan Capriles <micron1@rocketmail.com> wrote:

> Personally i don't go to clubs but maybe twice a
>year, but i will not

While I am much more of a "Club Kid" than say a "raver"
I think Dan has a big point. This is my thing and
I maybe hit raves up once or twice a year. So its sort
of opposite, but we all stand for the same principle. 
The freedom to express ourselves through song and
dance.

> stand by and let this f*cked up city shut down
dance >venues to please
> wealthy developers.

Its not just clubs either! My good friend was on
the channel four news the other night because her
wedding store (its been in SOMA 15 years) is being
run out because of these high cost work/live lofts
going up. She has spent her lifes savings and all
her time and energy on this store. They are running
people out of their leases so they can build more
expensive lofts and they just find ways to run you
out. With the new Baseball field going up your going
to find that this will be happening all over SOMA and
its going to affect people you know.

 
> First VSF, then 1015, then what..the
maritime....and >any other spaces
> that could possibly be used for a party.

Exactly! Its not whether VSF is run properly John,
thats not the point I think we are making. Its that
folks are being run out of they're lively hood so
someone else can profit. Personally I think it sucks.

LL

Dan Capriles wrote:

> this isn't really about VSF, but about ALL of the SOMA clubs and all
> of the clubs/spaces left in SF.
>
> First VSF, then 1015, then what..the maritime....and any other spaces
> that could possibly be used for a party.

The maritime hall has 'MAJOR' problems with all the lofts that they just
built across the street from them.   all the complaints from them severely
limit the activities at the maritime hall.   And now more are being built.

The maritime has been petitioning for a special permit that will allow them
to go till 6 am, but with all these residents complaints, they are now more
worried about keeping their 4 am permit.

At Feel Good Friday (last friday), we used the back side outdoor area as a
small chill space and had it all covered up, this was not alowed, but as a
personal favor, we were able to do it.  And in the middle of the nights,
some old rechity bitch from one of the lofts across the street came over and
nagged about how this was not allowed, and that it was noisy, and
disruptive.   She had a real nasty mouth on her.   Obviously she was rather
irritated by all the commotion that the maritime, sound factory, and street
traffic with the bay bridge off ramp.   its does get rather noisy at that
intersection.   The manager came out and kissed her ass like she was Donald
Trump or something like that.   It was rather embarrassing, cause I was
going at it with her at the time about how she shouldn't have moved in here
if she didn't like the noise, and that this isn't going to change, so she
had better get used to it, and change her attitude, or get a night job.    I
didn't care about her self centered, egotistical bitching, but the
management at the maritime sure did.

These residents have all the club owners on the run.   There running in
circles trying to do and say whatever it takes to appease these idiot
wanabee yuppie fuck ups.

I was told, that at large events, they even pay for hotel rooms for some of
the very irritating neighbors, just to ge them out of their hair for the
night.  Can you believe that shit?

Keep it real..   Vlad

> > >             in the formerly industrial South of Market neighborhood.

> > >different incidents -- ranging from assault to

> > >complaint or a visit by police, Martel

> > >neighbor." He spent $60,000 last
> > >             year to install more soundproofing. He also hires
> > >homeless people to clean up outside every
> > >             morning and tries to work with the residents and police
> > >to address problems, he said. But he
> > >             feels the cooperation is one-sided.
> > >
> > >             "The way in which it's coming to me, it's more like a
> > >witch hunt," Murphy said. "It's like,
> > >             'You're causing noise; we're going to shut you down.'
> > >
> > >             "OK, people want to sleep. We need to help here, but it
> > >is an industrial area. I'd like to see
> > >             some of the residents that have moved in here take some
> > >amount of responsibility for the
> > >             decision they've made. I didn't move into their
> > >neighborhood. They moved into mine."
> > >
> > >             The we-were-here-first argument is a common one South of
> > >Market, where club owners feel
> > >             increasingly threatened by their new neighbors.
> > >
> > >             Several club owners wrote the city Board of Permit
> > >Appeals, pleading for a reconsideration of
> > >             the board's approval of a new 15-unit live-work space on
> > >Harrison Street near 11th. The
> > >             nightclubs lost; the project received the go-ahead.
> > >
> > >             "It is unreasonable and unfair for businesses such as
> > >ours, which have been established for
> > >             longer than some of these tenants have been on Earth, to
> > >have to constantly deal with a
> > >             situation which should never have happened," wrote Bill
> > >Herrmann, owner of the Holy Cow
> > >             on Folsom. "It would be different if the area was
> > >residential and the clubs moved in, but this is
> > >             not the case."
> > >
> > >             If more housing is allowed to move in, "We'll all go by
> > >the end of next year," said Reichert,
> > >             the Paradise Lounge owner.
> > >
> > >             No new clubs allowed
> > >
> > >             The area is zoned for mixed use, meaning both housing
> and
> > >light industrial development are
> > >             allowed. Since a zoning change in 1990, new nightclubs
> > >have not been allowed in the area, and
> > >             the existing ones need to have all required police
> > >permits to stay in business, planning officials
> > >             said.
> > >
> > >             Meanwhile, the number of lofts has mushroomed from 58
> > >built in 1991 to 617 built or under
> > >             construction in 1997. The housing boom in the mixed-use
> > >area has caused much of the
> > >             conflict, club owners and their supporters said.
> > >
> > >             Problems that may have gone unnoticed by police in past
> > >years, such as rowdy patrons, now
> > >             attract the attention of residents. They, in turn, call
> > >police.
> > >
> > >             Clubgoers "get boozed up and they make a lot of noise
> and
> > >they don't always have respect for
> > >             the residents of the area," Martel said.
> > >
> > >             "Not only do you have this music going on, but you have
> > >all this street life that goes on until 4,
> > >             5, 6 in the morning," said Felix Rodriguez, who lives on
> > >11th Street between Folsom and

I know the people who comprise Sweet Trip.  They are very pleasant folks. 
Viet, the bass player & the gent who occassionally posts to sfraves, was
key in getting me my live gig at the Justice League as part of Glad Hand
#2 back in January. The other two are Valerie (vocals/guitar) and Roberto
(vocals/guitar/programming, also produces **EXCELLENT** drum'n'bass under
the moniker Busheeloop--very sincerely highly recommended--can't say
enough about this guy's stuff).

ST just released their first full-length album on Darla
Records..."halica/bliss out v.11" is the title. Again, very highly
recommended...gives you the sonic depth that often doesn't come across
fully in a live setting.

These people rock, because they are fully into this for the love of the
music, no pretentions or BS...not to mention the fact that the music is
excellent.

Highly recommended.

-jimg

(As always these are words are not completely from me persay, by from
something I represent...  from a deeper place... and they are from my own perceptive... 
and I don't want you to believe what I say if it doesn't feel right...
just take it for what it is.... )

Urban Legend... Messiah Wannabe.... he wasn't Kryogenicized... (sp?) I've
done some research into the topic and that is one of the first things they
state. His flesh was burried at Forrest Lake in LA. Also, he could have
been convertly dressing/acting to society like what you've mentioned, but don't 
you think it'd be necessary for his *Magic* to flow through society?? If
you're going to hang with the romans, you have to act like the romans.. :) 
Everyone in one way or another does this... acts like they want to be
percevied... to move forward their purpose and message.... Jesus was a
carpenter as the story goes.... but do you think his mental compacity was
that of a carpenter? Not to put down carpenters at all, because I think
carpenters are very intelligent. But the consciousness of Jesus was far
beyond any comprehensible Earth job.. and he had to take a career
change of sorts... :) 

___*Everything*___ in life is a metaphor or paradym of something spiritual
that we represent, must learn from, must give to, etc... Jesus, one of the
most notable enlightened beings possessed a link to the pool of knowledge that
is and he could have conquered the world and destroyed it if that was his 
purpose... .. .   .    .     . A carpenter in Jesus' time was a
Sr.+++***** Level Architect of electronic commerce.... 

Lets focus on the *good* as apposed to the *bad* for good vibes.... 
For us to think of *this*, is for *this* to *be*. Seek and ye shall
find.... seek negativity and negativity will come... seek happiness and
love, it will come... the negative thoughts are what sink into this
reality and taint it... and the worst part is that we know it's our
fault.... to give in to the negative energy given off by others..
dominoing from the beginning of time....

and I am not nutsy cookoo.... .... ... just a free thinker and obtainer...

poof! ;)


*BYRONi....... .   .     .     .     .     .     .     .     .     .    !

At 10:29 PM 4/13/98 -0800, John S. Lee wrote:
>In general ravers are a lazy lot, and not really motivasted by politics.
>As Miss Kitty pointed out there have been other clubs (DV8 & The Oasis),
>that havene;t survived, and you heard not a peep from the community.  Same
>will happen to toher clubs as development interest with long dollars gobble
>up every space in sight (until the next earthquake).
>

and then the scene will have no direction to go in except...

...UNDERGROUND...

I can't wait!  Map points leading to map points!  No steroid-amped
security!  DJs booked because of their skill, not because of their name!
Festivals in the wilderness lasting several days!  Negative pressure from
authorities shaping ravers into a powerful force for good!

and most of all, an end to this nasty schism between the 21-and-overs and
those who ain't.

and if tomorrow ever comes:
"We'll know how small we really are.

Mime-Version: 1.0
