well, i just called the trance & jungle factory in berkeley to find out
until when presale tix for viberation would be available and they told me
they arent even selling tickets

im not going to make it into the city until saturday morning and i
absolutely must get into this party at all costs. anybody know where
presales are available for sure and for how long?

by the way, i was just up there for f-8 this past saturday and had the most
wonderful time. was feeling a little bit burnt out on raving and this party
gave me back faith. the energy was consistent throughout and spread across
the entire room. i havent felt anything like that in much too long. thank
you to all the people that were there and made it such a great time. i
didnt meet any sfravers because im so damned shy and i dont know who
anybody is, but i understand they were all over the place. i met rudi near
the end though, but i dont think he remembers me. i was the skinny asian
guy with buzzed hair wearing a blue t-shirt that said: onE and sporting big
green cargo pants. i brought a bunch of glowsticks with me and gave them
all out. what a nice feeling that pieces of me were spread all across the
room (id danced with each pair of glowsticks for a little bit before giving
them away)

the music: god, i dont even know how to describe it. hopefully that will be
enough to convey my enjoyment of it. drc blew my mind, so did mystre, mars
i didnt like all that much (very pretty tracks, but i didnt feel he had
much of a sense of building a set, or maybe i was just really tired by
then), who was the last guy, was that ethan? whoever it was kicked ass.
sounded like really minimal but hard trance. the first guy was wonderful
too, greg sandler?

this is an experience i will always remember. i hope whoever of you guys
was there also enjoyed it. looking forward to being up there for vibe this
again this saturday

joe

Speaking of stars, and disney....on paulina taylor's tape smile, it starts out
with "its a small world" and then....goes off into...(hum along if ya know
it:):)....so if you see the stars tonight, then tell me what they say, and let
me know how bright they are and i will always pray, that one day you'll come
down to me, my angel from above, the one i've always dreamed of , the one i'll
always love........
and also........i wanna see a rainbow high in the sky, i wanna see you and me
on a bird flying away, and then i hope to see your smile every nite and day,
i wanna make love to you, lead you to tomorrow, i wanna feel the sunshine and
the rain, we can reach out for the sky, no more pain and no more sorrow, for
you i am the one that i could never be..........
i know, happy harcore cheesy stuff........but its just so  happy and lovey i
don't understand how you could not like it.......you really have to hear the
beat to feel the words, but just take my word on it.........:)

---Cara4527 <Cara4527@aol.com> wrote:
>
> Speaking of stars, and disney....on paulina taylor's tape smile, it
starts out
> with "its a small world" and then....


a friend of mine grew up in orlando, right near both nasa and disney. 
anyway, he always had season passes to disneyworld, so he spent a lot
of time there, exploring the seedy underbelly of the disney empire.

one time he was on the "it's a small world" ride, when the floats
broke, and everybody was stuck in the middle of the ride.  now i don't
know if y'all have ever been on "it's a small world", but basically
you have all these mechanized puppets singing the same two lines over
and over, in different languages, depending on where your little boat
is sailing past.  anyway they were stuck there for a really long time,
so they wound up having to listen to those two lines being sung over
and over again for about an hour and a half, in eskimo, by inane
little puppets endlessly repeating the same goofy mechanical actions
that weren't really all that cool the first time you saw them. 
eventually one woman started screaming uncontrolably till her face
turned purple.  another guy decided he just couldn't take it any more,
and got badly shocked trying to wade out of the ride...

well that's what he told me, anyway.  and thus another urban legend is
born...



-messiah wannabe

Granted I would have gone banana's if I'd got stuck on the ride too, but I
don't agree with your comment on the not so great looking puppets.(Not a
flame just a tangent) If your between the ages of 4-10 those puppets are
awesome. My memories of Theme parks when I was a little kid are magical and
the rides were amazing. When ever I've gone back "as an adult" I notice the
cheap trinkets and dolls that once looked so real are really beat up and
fake looking. At first I felt ripped off and upset but then I decided to
ignore it and have fun and the same energy and excitement that was there
when I was a kid was there again.
I guess my point is that with a little imagination and enthusiasm you can
have a blast anywhere anytime. ;D

MooK<><

Hi Rave Friends,

        The following is a letter written in response to the "Dear Abby"
column in the March 31 San Francisco Chronicle.  I thought I would post it
in light of the renewed SFR discussion of drug use...


Dear Abby,
Universal Press Syndicate,
P.O. Box 69440,
Los Angeles, CA  90069

Dear Abby:

        This is in response to the letter you printed from "Older, Wiser
And Clean," the 18-year-old college student whose negative experiences led
her to believe that no one should "experiment" with "drugs" (presumably
meaning those drugs banned by our government).

        Her story has something in common with numerous other similar
stories I've heard and witnessed -- a lack of moderation.  First there is
the binge -- a reckless use of substances, coupled with strong denial that
there is a problem, leading one's life into a downward spiral.  Then there
is the purge -- total sobriety, coupled with an extremely intolerant
attitude toward the illicit drug use of others.  Some people go through one
binge/purge cycle, while others repeat the pattern over and over.

        I am 27 years old.  I first smoked marijuana when I was 20, and
since then have tried MDMA, LSD, crystal meth, magic mushrooms, 2CB, and
GHB.    There are others I have stayed away from, including heroin,
cocaine, and PCP, because they don't seem to offer much value, but I can
say unequivocally that drugs have been a positive influence in my life.
They have not kept me from holding professional jobs, serving in the
military, being happily married, or maintaining a high level of physical
fitness.  The only regret I have about these substances is that I was so
brainwashed in my youth that an irrational fear of addiction and
"destroying my life" kept me from broadening my horizons sooner.  The
desire to be "cool" was never a factor.  I tried illicit drugs because I
saw happy, well-adjusted people whom I admired and respected using these
substances, and my curiosity overcame my fear.

        If you find you can't take a particular substance responsibly, the
smart thing to do is stop taking it, but the too-much-or-nothing mind set
with regard to "illegal" substances is just plain stupid.  ("Illegal" is in
quotes because the prohibition of marijuana and other drugs is clearly
unconstitutional.  The U.S. Constitution was temporarily amended to allow
the prohibition of alcohol in 1919, but there has never been a provision
allowing the government to prohibit any other drugs.)  I have learned
first-hand that the infrequent hit of Ecstasy or 'shrooms, like the
occasional glass of wine, can be good for your total mind-body health.
It's easy to tell the difference between life and death, but it's harder to
measure quality of life.  If you never strap on a pair of skis, you'll
never die by skiing into a tree, but you'll also never experience the
beauty, the joy, the exhilaration, of flying down a snowy mountainside with
strips of fiberglass under your feet.

        Both skiing and drugs have provided me not only some incredibly
pleasurable moments, but a heightened sense of spirituality, of
understanding and appreciating what life is about.  I don't expect that you
will ever print a letter like mine which portrays drug use in a balanced,
reasonable light.  But if by some pang of conscience you do, I hope
everyone reading this will think long and hard about whether they want to
limit their experiences in life based on the irresponsible behavior
patterns or moral prejudices of others.

Signed,

Experimenting & Satisfied in San Francisco

Isn't life a BITCH!!!     This is such crap.   I know many of the owners
and managers of the clubs in that area, and They have bent over backwards
to work out the situation in the neighborhood, but it's only getting worse
for them.    This is a typical case of selective enforcement that makes our
country the money oriented cesspool that it is.   Rich developers utilizing
the voices of disgruntled tenants so they can force the clubs out of
business and pick up the club property for new development.   It's such
bullshit that it makes me sick to my stomach.    Who do these people think
they are?   They are like a virus... a disease that needs eradication
before it grows and consumes itself, and everything around it.
They idiots chose to live next to the clubs, and If they don't like it then
move the hell out, and let someone that wants to life in that environment
move in.   It's amazing how self centered and egotistical these residents
are... that they don't even realize how irrational their demand are to have
an existing neighborhood remodeled to their liking, just because they now
live there.   If you have allergies, then you don't live in the outdoors...
and if you don't like noise, then don't live next to a nightclub.    It's
reality check time.

Keep it real...   Vlad

Dan Capriles wrote:

> something i found in the paper today...
>
>
>
>              New loft residents target SoMa clubs
>
>              By Emily Gurnon
>              and Tyche Hendricks
>              OF THE EXAMINER STAFF
>
>              IT COULD BE called this year's version of "The Sound and
> the Fury."
>
>              Growing friction between South of Market residents and
> area nightclub owners has prompted
>              police to step up patrols in the 11th Street corridor and
> try to shut down the popular VSF club.
>
>              As more people have moved into live-work spaces and
> condominiums in the neighborhood, the
>              clubs and their customers have been the target of written
> complaints, a lawsuit and crackdowns
>              by police, club owners said.
>
>              "We really don't have a problem with the Police
> Department if we don't have housing," said
>              Robin Reichert, owner of the Paradise Lounge and
> Transmission Theatre.
>
>              The 11th Street club corridor is the latest flash point
> in the debate over The City's hottest
>              development craze -- the explosion of loft housing,
> called live-work by planners, taking place
>              in the formerly industrial South of Market neighborhood.
>
>              Club owners say the police presence is just the latest
> sign that they are being edged out of their
>              neighborhood by residents whose large real estate
> investments make them unwilling to put up
>              with the noise and rowdiness that the clubs sometimes
> bring.
>
>              To the residents, more patrols mean a better chance that
> the rules will be enforced.
>
>              "What we object to is one club in particular," the VSF,
> said Gail Goedinghaus, who lives
>              kitty-corner from the nightclub at 11th and Folsom
> streets. "If he would only operate according
>              to his permits, we wouldn't have a problem."
>
>              Formerly the Oasis, the VSF has generated numerous
> complaints from nearby residents, said
>              police Capt. Dennis Martel.
>
>              Other residents have complained about neighboring clubs.
> But unlike the others, the VSF has a
>              dance hall permit that allows it to operate beyond 2 a.m.
>
>              What Goedinghaus and her neighbors hear is "a very loud
> heavy bass beat that sounds like a
>              'thump thump thump' coming out of this club," she said.
> "It rattles the windows on the fourth
>              floor of the building where I live, and these are
> double-paned windows. If you can imagine,
>              it's very hard to sleep. It's the kind of sound, it gets
> into your brain. It penetrates everything."
>
>              To her partner's 10-year-old daughter, "it sounds like a
> T. rex or something walking down the
>              street," Goedinghaus said.
>
>              In the past 15 months, police have documented 21
> different incidents -- ranging from assault to
>              noise to drug possession -- that triggered a resident's
> complaint or a visit by police, Martel
>              said. The department will attempt within the next several
> weeks to suspend or revoke VSF's
>              permits, he said.
>
>              $60,000 for soundproofing
>
>              Club owner Kevin Murphy said the VSF is a "pretty good
> neighbor." He spent $60,000 last
>              year to install more soundproofing. He also hires
> homeless people to clean up outside every
>              morning and tries to work with the residents and police
> to address problems, he said. But he
>              feels the cooperation is one-sided.
>
>              "The way in which it's coming to me, it's more like a
> witch hunt," Murphy said. "It's like,
>              'You're causing noise; we're going to shut you down.'
>
>              "OK, people want to sleep. We need to help here, but it
> is an industrial area. I'd like to see
>              some of the residents that have moved in here take some
> amount of responsibility for the
>              decision they've made. I didn't move into their
> neighborhood. They moved into mine."
>
>              The we-were-here-first argument is a common one South of
> Market, where club owners feel
>              increasingly threatened by their new neighbors.
>
>              Several club owners wrote the city Board of Permit
> Appeals, pleading for a reconsideration of
>              the board's approval of a new 15-unit live-work space on
> Harrison Street near 11th. The
>              nightclubs lost; the project received the go-ahead.
>
>              "It is unreasonable and unfair for businesses such as
> ours, which have been established for
>              longer than some of these tenants have been on Earth, to
> have to constantly deal with a
>              situation which should never have happened," wrote Bill
> Herrmann, owner of the Holy Cow
>              on Folsom. "It would be different if the area was
> residential and the clubs moved in, but this is
>              not the case."
>
>              If more housing is allowed to move in, "We'll all go by
> the end of next year," said Reichert,
>              the Paradise Lounge owner.
>
>              No new clubs allowed
>
>              The area is zoned for mixed use, meaning both housing and
> light industrial development are
>              allowed. Since a zoning change in 1990, new nightclubs
> have not been allowed in the area, and
>              the existing ones need to have all required police
> permits to stay in business, planning officials
>              said.
>
>              Meanwhile, the number of lofts has mushroomed from 58
> built in 1991 to 617 built or under
>              construction in 1997. The housing boom in the mixed-use
> area has caused much of the
>              conflict, club owners and their supporters said.
>
>              Problems that may have gone unnoticed by police in past
> years, such as rowdy patrons, now
>              attract the attention of residents. They, in turn, call
> police.
>
>              Clubgoers "get boozed up and they make a lot of noise and
> they don't always have respect for
>              the residents of the area," Martel said.
>
>              "Not only do you have this music going on, but you have
> all this street life that goes on until 4,
>              5, 6 in the morning," said Felix Rodriguez, who lives on
> 11th Street between Folsom and
>              Harrison.
>
>              Rodriguez said the problems are limited to the VSF.
>
>              "We're talking about violent fights in the street,
> yelling," he said. "People who come here,
>              their attitude is basically, anything goes here." On one
> occasion, Rodriguez said he saw three
>              or four men pull a parking meter out of the ground in
> front of his building. Others urinate in
>              doorways, throw beer bottles and rev their motorcycle
> engines, he said.
>
>              Police can enforce laws on public drunkenness, disturbing
> the peace and traffic violations.
>              They can force club owners to follow city laws and run
> their establishments in an orderly
>              fashion to avoid problems with the community, Martel said.
>
>              Adapt to inner-city life
>
>              Many of the partyers themselves have little sympathy for
> residents.
>
>              "If you're moving into the inner-city area, then you have
> to adapt to the inner-city life," said
>              Tom Parsons, a New Zealander living temporarily in San
> Francisco who stopped by the 20
>              Tank Brewery on 11th Street last week.
>
>              "People need to be a little more selective in where they
> choose to live," said Paul Schuman,
>              Parsons' roommate. "They need to research it before they
> move in."
>
>              Andrew Schmidt worked at 20 Tank three years ago and now
> is a bartender in the Mission
>              District. He is scornful of new residents who complain
> about noise.
>
>              "They were fools, I think (to move in here), because this
> is South of Market," he said. "It's a
>              hotbed for investment and that makes people make quick
> decisions. They don't think. If you
>              want quiet, live by the beach.
>
>              "South of Market's history was always rowdy," Schmidt
> continued. "People drag race
>              motorcycles, there's bands, and there's lots of drinking.
> And where there's drinking, there's
>              noise."
>
>              Musician Pauli Gray, who performed at an open mike at the
> Paradise last week, said he feared
>              the complaints could shut down clubs that make San
> Francisco unique.
>
>              "Then you wouldn't have the music scene happening. What's
> going to happen then?" he said.
>              "We're going to lose the special character of this city."
>
>                                              The Examiner

What's up all you out there.  Thanks for checking yet another post of mine. (=

This round:  DJ's Noel and Abstract (two of the mighty Phunckateck Crew) are
heading out to the East Coast for a tour in June.   Don't sleep on this
opportunity to have two of the originators of the drum n' bass gig your
club, bar, store, etc.  

Not only do they destroy the decks but they produce their own music as well.
You know, taking it to that other level.  New trax are out on Green Label,
I'm sure you've all checked the XLR8R Big Shots CD, they have a new mix tape
is out as well called Cold Fusion.  Cheggit out.

- dial up www.betalounge.com and pull up last weeks antics.  While you are
there surf this web site, it is amazing.

The way I look at it, it seems it doesn't matter what type of club or how
they treat people.  It's not a matter of the right kind of club, just that
one is being shut down (potentially), no matter how crappy they treat
people?  I don't know if that is a good enough reason or not.  Anyway to
me, they would garner plenty of support from people if they indded treated
people well.  That aside I think you have to deal with a reality that this
scene is going up against big, and I mean big money.

You also have to come to a reality that one persons livelyhood is another
nuisance in this case.  Both sides have very valid points!

Approaching this as big money against a poorly organized and temporal group
of partyers the odds are squarely against ravers.  What needs to happen if
ANYONE is really serious about this is:
-Club owners, partyers, and promoters need to present a unified front.
-Promoters & club owners, whose livelihood is at stake, should be the ones
financing this, with some money pitched in from the public (partygoers).
-promoters & club Owners should solicit signatures from people who vote in
the City and County of SF allowing them to have thier place , un harassed.
-Promoters, club owners, and partyers from all over should start a letter
campaign (e-mail ain't it, real letters, with real signatures) to:
	-Da Mayor
	-dept of permits
	-police dept.
	-fire marshall
	-sf chron
	-sf examiner
	-guardian
	-sf weekly
	-sj merc
	-la times ???
	-board of supes
	-all of the local gay papers & orgs.
-Club owners should sponsor free events in the park promoting music and the
dance culture.
-People should attend any public meetings that may result from the ruckus.
What should happen is that more and more people should show up each time.
If you can go to sefveral parties a month, there should be no problem in a
continued and increasing presence at meeting relevant to your cause.
-Protest in the streets @ or on SOMA near the clubs.  Peaceful, with music!

Look if you and others care so much, this is the ONLY way to fight this
thing.  So either get ready for a long protracted battle, or lose the
nightlife everyone feels is threatened.

The hardest thing will be in getting the various factions of  flighty
clubbers, club oweners, and the ever so flighty promoters together, put
aside all of the ego rubbish, and get this thing done.  Anything less is
doomed to failure.

As a famous pracher once said, "If you see a good fight, jump in it!".

Peace & good luck to those with the guts,
John

P.S.  More strategy:  You're looking into the future and after some massive
meetings and some grass roots organizing you're ready to execute.  Do you
have a plan that the city can live with?  Let's say you're going to lose
the SF turf war, what next?  Treasure Isalnd, that's what!  Willie wants to
make that place a big night club so why not propose that as an alternative?
How about the city aloow, and even finance clubs in SOMA moving there, and
allowing some percentage of them, permits for after hours?  Willie said he
wants that, all you have to do is make a counter proposal, a solution to
the overall problem of "Where is the nightlife of SF!".

Just some thoughts from one who has done battle before.

"For those about to die, we salute you!" - A line from Spartacus.


"Everyday above ground is a good day." - Mel Bernstein, Chief Detective
Narcotics

Date: Tue, 14 Apr 1998 20:51:52 -0700
X-Priority: 3
MIME-Version: 1.0

	charset="iso-8859-1"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I see the points in the posts below from John Lee and Jen.  This is just
the order of things and not necessarily a bad one.  Hear me out before
you get all twisted.  The "haves" always move and spread to the areas
imposing on the "have nots" or the "have not as much."  If you're down
for the love of the party then you know that clubs close down and open
up again.  It's their business, like any thing else, there is a certain
amount of risk serving as folly to the current sign of the times.  S.F.
seems to be in that conservative let's beat on the downtrodden sort of
mode and mess things up.  

Hey, I empathize with the club owners since I'm a patron just like the
next person.  John is right in saying that history is against us (and I
do mean us as in all party people, and please don't glorify it as some
kind of movement because all I can say is that I'll wait to see what
you're doing ten years from now).  Our scene is the underground and then
it gets discovered in all its layers so then is mainstream all over the
place.  

Look at it as a cycle, sometimes you got to go outlaw and back
underground to build the love up again to explode unknowingly in
people's lives to show them the light.  The clubs and business owners
related to our scene are suffering to no end and it sucks, no doubt.  I
take it that their sacrifice will dictate the party be taken somewhere
else, na'mean.  It's a party folks, it lives on and if you don't
know...well, you know the saying.  

Movements come and go, but the party lives on.  If you're looking to be
a white knight, understand the uphill battle you will fight and weigh
the pros and cons.  If the club stays open, it's not like you can just
totally relax as if the SFPD is not going to hold a grudge.

IMHO, better to work toward making a better party location where you
might not get hassled.  Fighting for your rights has its pitfalls
alright.  I've just been one of the type who looks forward.  You've got
to lull them to sleep into thinking they have you.  It's no different to
the slave days (sorry John, just trying to get you worked up, you my
homey doh), when dance was practiced as a form of fighting.  You've got
to get'em thinking one thing when all the time you're still right there
getting your groove on.  I mean if it's the party you love, don't worry.
Selfish?  Maybe, but for a club owner/promoter to think that it's a
hassle free world and that something is forever or will last as close to
it is naive.  Either that or they ain't greasin' the right palms, fact
of life.  It's the same wherever you go.  Money talks, bullshit walks.
Power of the people and all that is great for real human issues.  As far
as this topic, you've got to see that even if you win, you lose.  Livin'
in a fishbowl ain't pretty.

I haven't forgotten the more evolved party people who just like the
dependability of clubs because they've paid their "dues" with
underground sets.  What can I tell ya, shit changes, deal.  By that, I
mean assess, plan, react.  Let's do this like a nudist
buddhist...where's the next party?

outta change,
moki
sending virtual sunshine

guilty of it myself in living where i live. not that i'm keeping ppl's
livelihood away, but that i'm contributing to the gentrification of
the tenderloin.

> >> === message truncated ===

> people?  I don't know if that is a good enough reason or not. 
snip

one point i'd like to make here is that this might be a case in which
one would support somethning that they disagree with in order to
support the rights of ppl they do agree with. to me, i don't give a
shit whether vsf lives or dies. i don't much care for clubs and all
the spandex they hail period. i just like the fact that they have
running water when raves do not. other than that, i def. prefer a
party. :)

another
> nuisance in this case.  Both sides have very valid points!

agreed - i can see both sides. i do see more tho that these yuppies
moved into an area that is known for its nightlife. what did they
expect? guess i just don't care for the yuppies coz they're making
what *used* to be affordable housing for artists into an expensive
trend.

snip

hurts) a lot of ppl talk, and a lot of ppl talk shit. period. welcome
to raver land. :)

i don't think anyone will lose anything. so what - vsf might get shut
down. if sf is like any other city another club will open soon to take
its place. perhaps with the same  owners, perhaps in the same venue.
it's amazing how these things work out. anyway aren't there zoning
laws to protect these guys? (sorry if this has been pointed out - i
read only a few of the posts on the subject)

sorry - i'm in a foul mood. and this irks me more that these ppl are

club is so much more important....

nighty night!

Well i think we should have a party
in the middle of the street. No music or noise of any kind
a night of meditative silence. We have a mime dj spin
imaginary decks of silence ...listen to the internal music
form the cosmos amd we dance a silent dance till sunrise,
in the middle of the street.

after the residents have watched this strange bizzare
behavior for a few nights we end our little party as the 
sun rises and they crawl out of their unenjoyed
beds on the way to starbucks...we hand them flyers
that say we do this because there's something in the local
water that causes this strange behavior...they will be moving
imediately...i betcha...=)

Hello everyone

    Just wanted to let you know that the 420 spring celebration will be
happining this year!
First off, many thanx to all that came out last year (420/sunset in
marin) and also to everyone
who has supported us these last 4 years : )

Here is a small recap of the past events, Were u there?

Sean Murray
John Mac

djs

Mark e Quark
Andre Lucero
Quantum 23(Static)
Sean Murray

The free party is on a Monday afternoon, April 20th - 12pm to sunset -
We could of done it on Sunday or even Saturday
But we have always stayed true ( It just isn't the same if it ain't on
THE DAY) So, hopefully some of you can get the
day off, play sick, etc. A limited number of $5 after party (to recoup
van & generator costs) tickets will be sold at 420 during the day, and
also at the Sunset Boat Party the day before. (just look for the
stressed out sound guy, Sean) We are also working on a presale locale
that will most likely be in marin. Please call for more info:
415-838-0454

Once again, Thanks to all!
and we hope to see you there.
Renegade Soundsystem

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 15 06:38:07 1998

Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 15 Apr 1998 06:38:05 -0000
Received: (from mook007@juno.com)
 by m2.boston.juno.com (queuemail) id CYR00431; Wed, 15 Apr 1998 02:35:20 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Date: Tue, 14 Apr 1998 23:33:20 -0700
Subject: Spring Break Review (Dayz 8,9 & 10 of 10)
Message-ID: <19980414.233321.12110.1.mook007@juno.com>
X-Mailer: Juno 1.49
X-Juno-Line-Breaks: 0-2,15-17,38-40,45-48,55-59
From: mook007@juno.com (I MooK I)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

And now for the long awaited exciting conclusion......

Day 8:
I guess it was the lack of sleep all week that did it. I dunno but I was
feelin adventurous. The road trip plans for driving to So-Cal for E-3
fell through when word was that E-3 was postponed. I had promised a
friend down there that I'd spend the weekend with her, and when I make a
promise I keep it. Well I didn't wan to go down there and party with
people I didn'tknow so I left work at 12 noon and drove to Northrodge
picked her up and drove straight to Berkeley and was just in time for the
T&J Favtory party. This party was dope. The music was mind blowing, the
people were so friendly and I had an awesome time. The girl I brought
(Denise) had a blast and totally wants to come back and party up here
again. Only bad part of the night was some dudes stole a bunch of stuff
from the store including a turntable a few tshirts a few hundred dollars
in quarters from a coin jar and various other items.

Day 9:
Left the T&J Party with the intention of driving Denise back to So-Cal
but some very cool people(Lacie, TOny) rufused to let that happen (in
case I'd fall asleep on the way back and die in a car accident )and
pitched in to buy her a plane ticket back home. I luv you guyz. =) Well
me and some folks(BBong, Lacie) wandered around the bay wasting time and
after picking up tix in Solid Grooves for Bionic (I had a wierd feeling
that we should be buying tix for the Rbel ALiance party but a bunch of
our frenz were already going to be at Bionic) and then we headed up to
people park to catch the tale end of Ethan's set (beautiful) Minh allowed
us(Michael, Tony, Lacie, and ME ;D) to Crash at his place. So after two
hours of sleep we woke up and went to Bionic. Bionic was overcrowded,
hot, and too smokeee. I tolerate people smoking but I really had a hard
time breathing. I went out side and met some cool people. Went back
inside to find D(Natasha426) and the SLOTribe(Geoff Adam and Ray) needin
air too. The music sucked so we went outside and it was real cold so we
went back to the car and Listened to the Man- Geoff Herbst's new mix tape
(Auditory oragsma WoW!) Really deep spiritually uplifting epic trance
stuff. It's a must listen for anybody who likes that kinda stuff. After
about 4 hours of deep meaningful conversations the rest of the raving
party returned and we headed back to D's place to crash and hang for a
lil while.

Day 10:
Go home and crash for a few hours bringing weekend sleep totals to about
4.5 hrs. Listened to Micron's new tape (I still have to write a review
for that but it's coming soon)  and Watched Lost in Space. The rest of
the day was spent hangin with my frend Joel and with Family. Very dull
day which after that spring break week I really needed.


Note:
The only night this entire week that I partook of mind altering
substances was Tuesday night when I drank a few Beer's during the Bar
Hopping. And most of the time I outlasted my Cracked out frenz on the
dance floor. Just a reminder that it is possible and definitely still fun
to party sober. It'll be a while before I'll be at a party again (end of
May) because of skewl  so I'll be expectin review's galore of all the
Great parties I'll be missin.

luv'n'hugz' to thoze who know they deserve it

MooK<><

messiah wannabe wrote:
> 
> i like dancing at clubs.  what can i do to help?  bomb the live/work
> highrises?  maybe put a dog turd in a paper bag, douse it in kerosene,
> light it on an obnoxious resident's front doorstep, then ring the
> doorbell and run away?
> 
> that's about the best i could come up with, but perhaps you have some
> suggestions about ways we could help - i have no idea how this city
> hall stuff works.  maybe there's someone i could bribe? 
> seriously,
> messiah

You know the sorry thing is that I don't know what to do and it's tough
to make suggestions when you haven't a clue yourself.  At yesterday's
SOMA meeting the South Station Captain Martel said that we needed a
powerful & respected voice to speak on behalf of the SOMA clubs because
the developers had such a person working on their behalf.  But the fact
remains if you are a Real Estate developer who can turn a 5 story
warehouse into 35 Loft units that will sell for $350-$450K/loft, you're
probably already pretty connected in the city governement.
Unfortunately, the club owners aren't held in as high regard.

Oh yeah, in response to all of the complaints and the "general feeling
on the part of the public that the clubs are operating unchecked,"
Captain Martel also announced yesterday the formation of a new 5 officer
night
patrol, (actually 4 officers & 1 sargeant) dedicated solely to policing
the South of Market club scene.  Joy.

-Molly
Pablo's S.S.

Precedence: bulk

HOW TO CLEAN YOUR MOUSE             
                          
This memo is from an unnamed computer company.  It went to 
all field engineers about a computer peripheral problem.  The author 
of this memo was quite serious.  The engineers rolled on the floor.

Mouse balls are now available as FRU (Field Replacement Unit).
Therefore, if a mouse fails to operate or should it perform 
erratically, it may need a ball replacement.  Because of the delicate 
nature of this procedure, replacement of mouse balls should only be 
attempted by properly trained personnel.

Before proceeding, determine the type of mouse balls by examining
the underside of the mouse.  Domestic balls will be larger and harder 
than foreign balls.  Ball removal procedures differ depending upon 
the manufacturer of the mouse.  Foreign balls can be replaced using 
the pop-off method.  Domestic balls are replaced by using the twist-off 
method. Mouse balls are not usually static sensitive. However, excessive
handling can result in sudden discharge.

Upon completion of ball replacement, the mouse may be used
immediately. It is recommended that each replacer have a pair of
spare balls for maintaining optimum customer satisfaction.  Any
customer missing his balls should suspect local personnel of 
removing these necessary items."

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

Candyland by the Bay.  He couldn't book me because of the obvious lineup
conflicts, but then this morning, i got this goofy lightbulb that it would
be really funny if i opened up the night in the hardcore room, busting out
the Brian Eno & Enya records, then Ron D Core came on after me..
BOOMBOOMBOOMBOOM!!BOOMBOOMBOOMBOOM!!

off, so I'mma get there early & give him a wet willy.

>front for freedom to dance.  Who's got the PR connections to make the
>contacts.  How would you get the word out to the media?

media is the easiest part.  if stipe & Madonna will be there, so will the
media--ya just have to call them.  the hard part is writing well- worded,
convincing letters to the publicity agents.

> >
> >> You know the sorry thing is that I don't know what to do and it's tough
> >> to make suggestions when you haven't a clue yourself.  At yesterday's

> >> powerful & respected voice to speak on behalf of the SOMA clubs because
> >> the developers had such a person working on their behalf.
> >
> >The only thing you can fight money with if you don't have any yourself is
> >celebrities. Know any?
>
> madonna.  someone get her publicity agent on the horn!

Actually, as weird as this may be, Madonna, may be able to help out.   9
months ago her organization bought the old Stone Night Club on Broadway, and
it is in the process of being renovated.   It's going to be one hell of a hot
spot in town once it's completed.

How knows, she may either be sympathetic and try to help out her fellow club
owners, to eliminate any possibility that the same thing may effect her, or
just see it as less competition, and not give a crap.   Or she may be behind
the whole conspiracy of it all.    ?????   Who knows now days.

Keep it real...   Vlad

CHICAGO
            Tuesday, April 14,1998 - 05:13 PM ET


            (AP) Bad reactions to prescription and over-the-counter
            medicines kill more than 100,000 Americans and seriously
            injure an additional 2.1 million every year, far more than
most
            people realize, researchers say.

            Such reactions, which do not include prescribing errors or
            drug abuse, rank at least sixth among U.S. causes of death
            behind heart disease, cancer, lung disease, strokes and
            accidents, says a report based on an analysis of existing
            studies.

            "We're not saying, 'Don't take drugs.' They have
            wonderful benefits," said Dr. Bruce H. Pomeranz, principal
            investigator and a neuroscience professor at the University
of
            Toronto.

---"Thomas, Cassandra" <cthomas@kmd-arch.com> wrote:

> > press release ---the owners of the clubs in quesion NEED
> > to prepare one if they are serious in getting people enlisted...

...

Once this announcement exists, it should be easy to get it read and
discussed by djs on KZSU, KPFA, (KSJS?), Radio Free Berkeley, etc. -
especially since many of these djs subscribe to this mailing list!  It
might not help that much in reaching the general public, but it would
get the word out to the interested people in the scene - the more
people who hear about this static, the better.

Plus if several bay area stations are running public service
announcement about organizing public opposition to license
revocations, we would have a start towards making this a 'news item'
that other local media would report on.  I'm sure that local media is
a small community, and word of mouth would count for a lot.

Hey, if we get 2 cents from everybody, we might have a couple bucks!
Matt.

I think this thread, and many of the comments I've read in regards to it, is
highly ironic.

Mainly though, it's ironic that when this music and culture is recieving more
attention in this country than ever before, that it is also seemingly being
threatened more than ever.

That fact is a signal to me that it may be time to return all of this to its
essence, where it originated in the first place. We may not have a choice; the
decision may be made for us.

From: Robert Pointer <rwpointer@citiscape.com>
Subject: Re: another strike against dancing...stratego!
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

To all involved in the conversation,

Has anyone thought to present the DJ as an artist and the venue/stage is
the club by which they perform? In this light, maybe some of the artist
groups in the city who champion SF as a cultural city might jump in on the
bandwagon to protect important music venues such as clubs for electronic
music artists.
The problem with getting the club owners involved is that the city
percieves the issue as being a pure money issue. Dollars vs. dollars... the
one with the most almost always wins and is seen as the beneficiary of good
things.
If you position the argument as one that lists these problems as
potentially reducing the cultural significance of SF, then maybe you can
phrase your greivance in a way that speaks to the inherent pride SF'ers
have w/ their city.
No Venues. No musical artistry for the next age. Certainly SF can take
itself off the map of significance for this type of important development.
(hmmmm, this might play well with the New Media/SOMA groups as well.)

Its a stretch, but the idea here should be to reposition the argument that
allows us to define the solution in a way that takes money directly out of
the equation and makes the city planners, law enforcement, look at it as a
cultural issue.

Anyway, just writing out loud.


Robert Pointer
Executive Producer
CITISCAPE Media Design, LLC
http://www.citiscape.com
(916) 922-3353

1401 El Camino Avenue, Suite 520
Sacramento, CA 95815

Subject: Poetry @ TouchBass
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII

X-Mailer: AOL 3.0 16-bit for Windows sub 38

  Hey everyone! I was at TouchBass last night and Chris wrote this dope poem
that he read.  He designed it to get the attention of those people
disrespecting the poetry readers and it really worked.  But I really liked it
and it was so true I just had to share it with you all....

Dare I?
Dare I front on your
Unholy Trinity?
Polo, Hilfigger, Nautica?
Dare I proclaim your 3 striped
emporer: Naked?
Damn straight!!
We laugh at the plurred out
antics of day-glo candy ravers
30-inch panel pants
soaking up every drop of
7-in-the-morning Folsum Street scum.
Quit gnawing on that
goddamn pacifier!
Lips sticky blue
from Blo-pop mastication.
There should be recycling centers
for burnt-out glo-stix.
Hey, girl, you actually put records
in that record bag?
Word, B-boy!
You gonna go jogging in that suit?
Before or after that blunt?
"Oh, you're so sensitive!
I'm only saying simple sentences
You act as though they are venemous.
They are though."
Cuz folks, this is you, me,
and everybody in this place
at one time or another.
And anyone who thinks
they got points over the next kid
needs to go back to square one
like cro-magnon.
and I mean anyone!!
D.J., Breaker, M.C., Writer,
Designer, Promoter, Dealer.....
cuz we are all
emporers and emporesses
and... is there a draft in here or is it just me?
Sylables from grampa crusty
over & out.


Yes... that was so hillarious at the time.. I hope some of you still find the
humor in it.  See you all at Viberations!!

hugs n'stuff,
trice (pronounced TREESE for those of you that wonder) the tekno diva


=================
Raving is my Religion
The DJ is my shaman
Dancing is my Prayer

At 04:02 PM 4/15/98 -0700, Dina Alemagna wrote:
>got kicked off for two daze, just got my confirmation back now (pheew).   

Just to clarify - I don't kick people off arbitrary, when mail starts
bouncing back with a somewhat authoritative tone I remove them (e.g. "User
Unknown")... when it bounces back with something more temporary I wait for
a few days ("Full Mailbox", etc).

I read this on excite news, thought I'd pass this on...

here's the url also
http://my.excite.com/news/r/980415/16/odd-drugs



Ecstasy seized at Channel Tunnel

LILLE, France (Reuters) - A record 357,900 ecstasy tablets were seized
at the
Channel Tunnel terminal in the French port of Calais, police said
Wednesday.

The haul was discovered at the end of last month aboard a Belgian
registered truck as
it was about to join a train heading for Britain. The Belgian driver,
who has not been
named, was arrested and is being held in custody.

Some 10 kg (22 lb) of cocaine was also found on the truck.

A police spokesman said the ecstasy find represented more than double
the total of
all ecstasy seizures in France last year. He added that the famous
tongue logo of the
British rock group the Rolling Stones had been printed on the tablets.


....thats 7,158,000$ worth of E



Wait, there's more....
http://my.excite.com/news/r/980415/16/odd-hearse



They smuggled marijuana in hearse

BOGOTA (Reuters) - Six men were arrested in Colombia on charges of
transporting more than 1,320 pounds (600 kg) of marijuana in a hearse,
police said
on Wednesday.

The alleged smugglers, all clad in black, aroused suspicion because they
were
riding in the hearse and another vehicle in a mock funeral procession
down a
deserted stretch of highway at 2 a.m. Tuesday.

The hearse, a 1977 blue Ford, was stopped just outside Medellin, capital
of the
northwestern province of Antioquia, police spokesmen said.

Instead of a coffin or a corpse, they said, the hearse was found to
contain large
packets of marijuana.

The drugs were seized and the men were jailed.

At 12:22 PM -0700 4/13/98, Ray Vonie wrote:
>Isn't life a BITCH!!!

A struggle indeed.

>     This is such crap.   I know many of the owners
>and managers of the clubs in that area, and They have bent over backwards
>to work out the situation in the neighborhood, but it's only getting worse
>for them.    This is a typical case of selective enforcement that makes our
>country the money oriented cesspool that it is.   Rich developers utilizing
>the voices of disgruntled tenants so they can force the clubs out of
>business and pick up the club property for new development.   It's such
>bullshit that it makes me sick to my stomach.    Who do these people think
>they are?

People with a vested interest in the city and how it's run.  He who has the
money has the power.  It may suck but it is a reality you must deal with if
indeed you are going to go into battle.

>   They are like a virus... a disease that needs eradication
>before it grows and consumes itself, and everything around it.

Like humanity itself.  Ever growing, making species extinct, and ever moving.


>They idiots chose to live next to the clubs, and If they don't like it then
>move the hell out, and let someone that wants to life in that environment
>move in.

Naive.  People always change their environs when they move in.  You build a
house, and change it to your liking.  You buy land and push every living
thing out to make a foundation.  We mimick nature to the extreme.  We all
do the same thing to a greater or lesser extent.  Understanding this will
allow you to attack a problem, or the problem, with more clarity.

>   It's amazing how self centered and egotistical these residents
>are...

The property owners think of ravers as "self centered and egotistical".
Witht he backing of thier money their gripes are heard loudest and first.

> that they don't even realize how irrational their demand are to have
>an existing neighborhood remodeled to their liking, just because they now
>live there.

What you don;t realize is how irrational you look to them.  The fact is
they do live there and have every right to create a neighborhood of their
choosing.  This is called gentrification people, sf stylee.

>   If you have allergies, then you don't live in the outdoors...

Remove the plants to you liking is also another choice when you're a human.

>and if you don't like noise, then don't live next to a nightclub.

Or remove the nightclub to your liking.

>    It's
>reality check time.

Who's?  And who's reality will ultimately win?  My moneyu is on the people
with the best organization, the best funded, and those with the greatest
perseverance.  So far land owners 1, ravers 0.

>
>Keep it real...   Vlad
>

Indeed.

Peace,
John

and has four wheels.

Hello All,

I've been getting quite a few e-mails forwarded to me in regards to the
escalation of ongoing problems...I have a suggestion.

You'd be surprised how many people you can find through the internet.  Try
doing a search on "celebrity white pages" and there is a myriad of resources
for you to chose from.  I have had much luck getting into contact with
people this way...that is not to say that we should inundate them with
unwanted requests, but a few keenly worded e-mails might do the trick.  I
would say really refine a search, only to whom you think would be most
responsive to this issue.  

I already have some wheels turning myself on this one...good luck!



miragirl

Reminds me of that time in London...

So there I was, hanging out in Leicester Square, waiting on Nigel and
Beanbag to show up.  I was broke and hungry and cold, and to make matters
worse, my drawers were soaking wet from the rain.

Nigel had told me to meet him at the pub because he had some information
about a kid named Truffles who was in the tank in Holland.  Truffles was
busted for some passport problem, and he'd left 20,000 E's in a locker at
the ferry terminal in Rotterdam.

Nigel had the scoop on the locker number, and he was going to tell me how
to pop the door open and pinch the pills before Truffles got out of the
tank.

So it was pouring rain when Nigel and Beanbag show up, and we go inside the
pub for a warmer and to talk about the crime.

"Please don't go along with this stupid plan, Boomerang!"  Beanbag tried to
tell me.  "Truffles never did anything to hurt you.  Why should you go all
the way to Holland to pinch a bunch of E's from someone who's never done
anything to you?"

Beanbag wasn't too hip on the idea, she had all these wonderful things to
say about karma and respect and what she's learned on the rave circuit.
But me and Nigel, we're incoorigible hooligans, right nasty bastards when
you think about it.  Besides, we both know that raves aren't about nothing
but scoring money and maybe a bird to bring home to the sack.

So when Beanbag started putting up a fuss, Nigel told her to cram it and
sent her up to the bar for 3 pints.  While she was gone we got down to
business:   Truffles had left Amsterdam with 20,000 E's, and stuffed them
in a locker at the ferry port in Rotterdam, just to keep it cool while he
was waiting for the boat back home.  Well, he ran into some trouble with
the coppers, and when his passport didn't check out,  they stuck him in the
can for a couple of weeks. He'd called home for help, and pretty soon word
got around about the treasure in locker number 715.

Since I was broke, Nigel told me to beat it on down to the dockyards and
get to gabbing with one of the sailors, see if I could swing a ride across
the Channel to Rotterdam in the hold of a boat.

Nigel, nasty poof that he is, didn't have the decency to lend me 10 quid
for carfare down to the docks, so I had to nick a motorbike from Covent
Garden, which I properly rolled into the Thames when I was finished with
it.

Down at the docks, I got to chatting with a lad named Bill,  he was a
rugged old meathead, teeth all rotten from snorting too much nitrate.  The
old lunk worked on one of the boats, said he could stow me in the hold and
take me across the Channel to Rotterdam.  All he wanted in return, he said,
was was a little bit of company now and again.

Well, it wasn't until my first night in the hold that I figured out what he
meant by "company".  I'd got to thinking he wanted to guff it up about
football scores and such, but on no, my friends.  Bill showed up in the
hold that night, eyelids a-fluttering and ready for company.  I put up my
dukes and was ready to fight my way through hell and high water, but old
Bill threatened to yell for the captain if I didn't loosen up.

Let me tell you, friends, I went through five days of hell, being tossed
about by the waves during the day, and tossed about by old Bill at night.
The man was a frightful savage, committing the most uncivilised acts
imaginable on my poor body.  I'm not much of a softy, but by my third day,
I was in tears at the very thought of my next visit from Bill.  Sometimes
got to thinking I should have listened to Beanbag when she warned me about
karma and all that happy bollocks.

My only consolation was the promise of those 20,000 E's in locker #715.
20,000  could last me quite a long time,  and thinking about ripping off
that poor sucker Truffles made my suffering manageable.

On the fifth night in the hold of the rusty old vomit-bucket, the door
swung open and I braced myself from another onslaught from sailor Bill.
Instead, there in the door, was the Captain himself.

"Keeping company for that scalawag Bill, are ya, lad?"

"Please, sir,"  I begged.  "Don't send me back to London.  I need to get to
Holland by the end of the week.  I have important business there, and Bill
promised me a ride."

"Holland, eh?  Ahh, that old pirate!"  the captain cried.  "I supposed he
neglected to mention that this here vessel is a charter barge running up
and down the River Thames!"



~b))merang








>LILLE, France (Reuters) - A record 357,900 ecstasy tablets were seized
>at the
>Channel Tunnel terminal in the French port of Calais, police said
>Wednesday.
>
>The haul was discovered at the end of last month aboard a Belgian
>registered truck as
>it was about to join a train heading for Britain. The Belgian driver,
>who has not been
>named, was arrested and is being held in custody.
>
>Some 10 kg (22 lb) of cocaine was also found on the truck.
>
>A police spokesman said the ecstasy find represented more than double
>the total of
>all ecstasy seizures in France last year. He added that the famous
>tongue logo of the
>British rock group the Rolling Stones had been printed on the tablets.
>
>
>....thats 7,158,000$ worth of E
>
>
>
>Wait, there's more....
>http://my.excite.com/news/r/980415/16/odd-hearse
>
>
>
>They smuggled marijuana in hearse
>
>BOGOTA (Reuters) - Six men were arrested in Colombia on charges of
>transporting more than 1,320 pounds (600 kg) of marijuana in a hearse,
>police said
>on Wednesday.
>
>The alleged smugglers, all clad in black, aroused suspicion because they
>were
>riding in the hearse and another vehicle in a mock funeral procession
>down a
>deserted stretch of highway at 2 a.m. Tuesday.
>
>The hearse, a 1977 blue Ford, was stopped just outside Medellin, capital
>of the
>northwestern province of Antioquia, police spokesmen said.
>
>Instead of a coffin or a corpse, they said, the hearse was found to
>contain large
>packets of marijuana.
>
>The drugs were seized and the men were jailed.

To continue this thread, another angle would be how much money are these
clubs bringing into this city directly and indirectly.  From peninsula
residents driving up on the weekend  to foreigners flying in to enjoy
that famous San Francisco nightlife,  will they still come with their
money if that nightlife is damaged.  I would recommend those involved
with the clubs start coming up with some figures and a lawyer.

Cassandra

Thomas, Cassandra wrote:
> 
> To continue this thread, another angle would be how much money are these
> clubs bringing into this city directly and indirectly.  From peninsula
> residents driving up on the weekend  to foreigners flying in to enjoy
> that famous San Francisco nightlife,  will they still come with their

> with the clubs start coming up with some figures and a lawyer.

Interesting.  When you fly into SFO on Air France or Continental there
is a quick video that runs as you're landing that features highlights of
the city.  VSF was approached as was 1015 last summer to let the video
company tape a night. The result was approximately a minute of NIKITA
footage and a minute of PABLO'S SUGAR SHACK footage showing DJs Garth &
Taj.  This is all spliced together with shots of Fisherman's Warf, Cable
Cars etc.  We get a ton of foreigners who wander in asking if this is
the Sugar Shack that's on the air plane.  Strange to serve as a
"representative" of the same city that's trying to shut us down. 
-Molly

come from around the WORLD to check out the SF music
scene.  Few come from around the globe to look at the
bitchin live/work loft spaces in soma.

Robert Pointer wrote:
> 
> To all involved in the conversation,
> 
> Has anyone thought to present the DJ as an artist and the venue/stage is
> the club by which they perform? In this light, maybe some of the artist
> groups in the city who champion SF as a cultural city might jump in on the
> bandwagon to protect important music venues such as clubs for electronic
> music artists.
> The problem with getting the club owners involved is that the city
> percieves the issue as being a pure money issue. Dollars vs. dollars... the
> one with the most almost always wins and is seen as the beneficiary of good
> things.
> If you position the argument as one that lists these problems as
> potentially reducing the cultural significance of SF, then maybe you can
> phrase your greivance in a way that speaks to the inherent pride SF'ers
> have w/ their city.
> No Venues. No musical artistry for the next age. Certainly SF can take
> itself off the map of significance for this type of important development.
> (hmmmm, this might play well with the New Media/SOMA groups as well.)
> 
> Its a stretch, but the idea here should be to reposition the argument that
> allows us to define the solution in a way that takes money directly out of
> the equation and makes the city planners, law enforcement, look at it as a
> cultural issue.

Received: from [206.170.26.204] by web1; Thu, 16 Apr 1998 12:33:02 PDT
Date: Thu, 16 Apr 1998 12:33:02 -0700 (PDT)
From: tabitha hanrion <bewitched@rocketmail.com>
Subject: Worth the price of my impound fee and then some!(SABATOGE/Astral Matrix)
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


So all day Wednesday I'm giddy at work, real excited like because I'm
going to see Astral Matrix that night.  On my ride up to the big city
everything was fine and dandy.  No major delays on the 17 at all.  To
quote Jake, or maybe it was Elwood, I was on a mission from God.

And I didn't even have to parallel park!

Get inside VERY early.  Found my little special spot right by one of
the padded tables and waited to be wowed.  Didn't take long.  Andrew
was getting me smiling just doing a sound check.

Stood around trading Tellytubbie stories for a bit at the bar then the
heavens opened and Astral Matrix went on.  Or something like that.  In
my heaven, this boy is going to provide the Musak! Danced around and
goofy grinned for most of his set.  The music was incredible but god,
the people out dancing were just as amazing.  It went beyond people
being nice to each other, but to the point where people were actually
just bonding with eachother.  You really meant it when you smiled at
someone.  And best of all, you REALLLLLLY meant it when you let out
this scream of approval.


So yeah, I guess you could say it was an okay shin-dig.


BUT THEN......
Go to drop off Steve and park somewhere I shouldn't have even though
HUNDREDS of people have done it before me, and I get my car towed.  
And the only thing I can think is, "Hmmm, $150 dollars to get my car
out of the impound lot, and know what, it was worth it."

Happy Birthday Andrew!  THANK YOU!


tabitha

...uh huh....

Z-Trip played that classic beat last night at Double Dutch (thx Mark).
Z-Trip (Bombshelter DJ, AZ.) is the illest on the dex.  I am always blown
away by his tune selection, he has got to be given props.

~~First of all, hello to all.  Your weekly SF update is here~~

I would like to apologize to all those who were not able to get into
Eklektic (jungle flava) last week.  The club only holds 300 people and fire
codes were the issue.  I know, I heard the line went down the block, and
some people were turned away.  It only took about a half hour before
everyone was filtered in.  Once again Dara was blown away by the energy at
the club, thank you for making his night so exciting.  I am blown away by
the constant support of the heads and the true intensity of the vibe.
Thanks to everyone that make it so special.

Tonight when you come down to Eklektic, try to crawl out of the house before
11:PM,  I promise room to dance (=    I also promise:  SWINGSETT.  Yes our
yin residents Stareyes and Sage along side Ubiquity and Sirkus recording
artist from NYC, Swingsett.  

The **all new** Eklektic line-up.   Hosting proper talented crews from
California.  We want to give recognition for all their hard work.  Props to
UFO! for the mad art, number three, in our flier art series.  If anyone is
interested in receiving a flier to check out his art please send a self
addressed stamped envelope to Ground Score, 647 Cole Street, SF,CA 94117
e-addy: eklektic@hotmail.com

April23 - JUNGLE LOVE CREW (Sifu, Honey B, Madame Butterfly)
April 30 - PHUNCKATECK BOYZ (Abstract, UFO!, Noel, Jason Mouse)
May 7 - HOME INVASION TOUR (R.A.W., Oscar da Grouch)
May 14 - STEP 2K (PUSH, Gamekat)
May 21 - B.A.S.S. KRU (Flux, Rinse, Stareyes) *Stareyes' last date in SF for
a few*
May 28 - UMOJA SOUNDSYSTEM (Jun, tomas, MC Cokni O' Dire) *don't miss it*

Expect crazy antics, dubplates, and note the unity between artists that is
found only when crews come together and play with/off/and around each other.  

Did you know that Future Breaks (jungle radio KUSF, Sat. 4-5PM) was the
first radio show in the nation to debut the Reinforced Crew?  Congrats to
them!  Big Up's to Rita Johnson for putting the 6 date Reinforced Tour
together.  

Friday Night Sessions, another KUSF radio show is now being underwritten by
Eklektic.  We are proud to be fortunate enough to have been asked to do this
and also to have the funds to do it.  The hosts of the show are Andrew
Jervis (Bugs) and tomas (Umoja Soundsystem), two people we highly respect.
Check it, 90.3 FM, Friday nights 8-11.  

Dieselboy will be at Audio Impact this Monday, which means the club will be
jumpin off of the hook.  It is an exclusive booking, please call the BASS
Kru/Eklektic hotline at 415.332.5800 X797for info.  Audio Impact is the ONLY
18+ drum n' bass weekly in the city.  (touchbase may also be 18+, it resides
at the 11 11 cafe, they do not serve alcohol)

So, did you know, KRAFTWERK is comming to SF.  June 7th, the Warfield.  Do
not sleep on this one, I won't.  Thanks to FTT for yet again bringing in the
propper talent that most of us can't afford to.  I love it!

All you in So. Cal.  Keep an eye out for tomas of Umoja Soundsystem (former
LA resident), he will be giggin in LA for  the week of May 10 - 15th.  I'll
forward exact dates and locations in my next post.

New kids in town, from NYC.  They call themselves S.F. Hardstepaz, and they
will be throwing a drum n' bass weekly at Club 181 on Wednesday's.  Let's
see what these heads have for us SF locals.  I dig the one tape I have
heard, by Sub-G, it starts out with this Slayer sounding rock riff and then
drops into heavy bass tones.  They also have rolling papers for their
fliers, I had always wanted to do that....

Aceyalone has arrived....well not yet but on 4.20 Aceyalone, Abstract (tribe
unique), L*Roneous, Peanut Butter Wolf, Fat Jack and Raw B (beatsauce) will
be kickin up the flava on the Hip Hop side at the DNA.  

++BIG Up's to:
++Michelle Lolli for all the assistance with URB.
++Mudfoot for keepin it real at all times and NEVER giving up.
++Jeffe for the Synergy opportunities
++3D for the mad props
++Andrea for writing her senior thesis on women in the underground
++XLR8R for taking the Ca$h Money review and for the ad space
++SINC for Everything!
++Michelle Nicoli from Vancouver, for comming to town, hooking up, and
diggin' our vibe
++Monty Luke for his constant communication
++DJ Stef for the years of hard work running the Vinyl Exchange
++Chris W. & Plinko for all their inspiration
++Control Dek for trying, sorry about the shop shut down  )=
++Noel, Stareyes, Abstract and Push for representing the d n' b @ the SF
AIDS DANCE A THON 
++Jon at Lotus for the deadline extension

on the kick out - remember - for SF bookings - contact Ground Score at
415.332.5800 or groundscore@yahoo.com

peas...

dmarie - Ground Score
Miss E - Future Breaks
Q - BASS Kru web master
"three Buffallo Girls goin' 'round the outside"

Bay Area Kiddies: 
Tonight, there's a get-to-gether which you all are invited, this is 
tended more towards the South Bay- I mentioned this get. about a month 
ago and it got canceled, but it's happening for sure this time. 
If your big on the age thing, the party heads will be around 17-20, 
possibly a few younger and a few older. A friend of ours will be 
spinning, he's a SJ local DJ, " Mystic Mike", just a bunch partiers/bud 
smokers/and drinkers will be there.  If you do want to drink, I 
recommend bringing your own drinks, or bringing money to put in on 
drinks, someone will probablly do a few runs here and there-

Directions: 
Take Stevens Creek(coming from Bascom), and make a right on SanTomas, 
and make a left on El Camino , a right on  kiely, and a right on 
Warburton. It's at the very very end of Warburton. The addy is 2467-

If you get lost you can page me at 
9328831 or call the 
house where it's at
244-7122

PeaceOut
Liz

Precedence: bulk



well, we all know raving is for "the kidz", 18 and under only please
;)  but for the few of us who refuse to grow up, get religious, have
kids and move to suburbia...

messiah wannabe's raverdrinks
-----------------------------

yes that's right, when you're a jet-setting, rave-hopin, bikelight
socialite 20-something like myself, an evening out isn't an evening
out without a sophisticated mixed drink or three.  sure "wanna
backrub?" gets the job done, but "can i mix you a drink?" sounds so
much better.  just pack the ingredients for one or two of these into
an "alcoholic's briefcase" and sneak it in to your party of choice. 
if you get caught just slip the security a ten-spot and tell em it's
ghb...



rocketfuel - two parts redbull to one part vodka 
----------   
c@weasel gave me the secret formula for this one, it's stunning in
it's simplicity and ease of covert mixing.  plus the buzz is...
unique...


the aging candyraver - gin, blowpop
--------------------   
like many of our finest technologies and styles of music, this was
invented entirely by accident.  fill a glass with as much gin as you
can stand to drink.  then add another ounce or two (important!). 
unwrap the blowpop and place it, bulb down, in the glass. let it sit
till the color of the blowpop has permeated the drink, then serve. 
you get a subtly sugared hard drink, available in a variety of colors
and flavors.  the blowpop acts as both stirrer and chaser...

the jetson - two parts white rum, three parts "obitz"
----------   (any flavor), two or more "space age"
             lookin glasses

the hardest part is finding a gas station that still sells orbitz -
you know, that weird looking drink with the little collored globs
floating in it.  well, i wouldn't drink it on it's own either, but
it's actually quite tasty once you mix in some hard liquor.  to do
this right you really must have a couple of groovy lookin coctail
glasses though - just check out the "housewarez" section of your fave
thriftstore.  think "star trek - the old generation" (if you can't
remember william shatner ordering one too many andruvian boilermakers
before hitting on the green bellydancer from alpha centuri, you're
probably too young to be reading this...)
             

and finally...  i gotta tell the story behind this one before i reveal
it's name...

me, pjfuzzy and our friend bradford were driving around manhattan one
night, just enjoying the ride, watching all the streetpartys and mob
scenes after the yankees won the world series.  anyway i had thrown a
party at my parents house the weekend before, and i had all these
not-quite-empty bottles of exotic liquors to get rid of.  so we were
trying to come up with drinkable combinations out of these various
bottles, and when we'd come up with a good one, we'd give it a
suitable name.  finally bradford handed up a really tasty one to me
and pj from the back of the car...

"i like this, what's in it?"
"oh, coca cola, cherry liquor, and everclear to taste..."
"this is sorta a girl drink, tastes like cherry coke.  i cant taste
the everclear at all!"
"well there's plenty in there.  give a couple of these to your high
school sweetheart and she'll have all the excuse she needs to give it
up..."
"brad, you're satan.  besides, my girlfriend graduated from high
school like two years ago..."
"he's right though.  plus, it's great for a car date - with the cap on
it's impossible to spill..."
"ok, this is a keeper.  what's it called?"
"'cherry buzz bomb'?  nah..."
"ummmm...  'high-school sweetheart'?"
"no, that's cheesey.  how about 'new coke'."
"already taken.  we invented it in a car, so it oughtta have a
car-related name.  'the drink and drive'?" 

finally brad pipes up from the behind us.  "well, i invented it, so
i'm gonna name it.  it's called... 'cherry in a back seat'..."


ok, so maybe you had to be there...


-messiah wannabe

At a Special Olympics track meet, a young girl had just won the 50-yard 
dash
and was jumping up and down all excited.

She yelled out to her parents, "Look, Mom and Dad, I won."

Her parents burst into tears.

At the awards ceremony the young girl proudly stood there as the medal 
was
placed around her neck.

Then she ran over to her parents, who were crying now even more than 
before.

The three of them hugged ... as the parents kept on crying.

A Special Olympics official who had watched this whole scene became
concerned and went over to the parents and said, "Excuse me, is there
anything wrong?".

Through their tears, the mother said, No, nothing's wrong.  Everything's
right....We just heard our daughter speak for the first time."

>From Bits & Pieces

supposed to be pretty good(which he wasn't), and he showed up around

> record the sound from whatever channel was piping
through it over the
> original soundtrack of the tape.  or if you plugged
in a microphone,
> whatever the mike picked up.
> 
> we would stay up all night, recording random
snippets of late-night tv
> into bizzare cut and paste pastiches.  then, we'd
rewind the tape, and
> record strange industrial soundscapes over them,
using guitars,
> walkie-talkies, phazed spoken word rants, fans with
tinfoil,  electric
> organs, xylophones, and whatever else was handy...
> 
> -messiah wannabe
> 
> 
> 
> 
> ---Jonas Edgeworth <jonas@nit.AirTouch.COM> wrote:
> >
> > 
> > > HOW TO KILL THE TELEVISION MONSTER WITHOUT
UNPLUGGING IT
> > > 
> > > 1. turn off the sound on your TV
> > > 
> > > 2. turn on two different stereo systems--one
with your choice of
> wordless
> > > music, the other with either AM radio or some
spoken word stuff.
> > > 
> > > 3. sit back and enjoy!  or take control by
changing channels as
> the music
> > > changes!
> > 
> > 
> > Trip out! My friends and I used to do this back
in middle school
> when I was a 
> > little skater. We would put on some cheese soap
opera and mute it,
> and then
> > blare some hardcore ala Minor Threat, the
Decendents, MDC, etc.
> There would be 
> > these occasional moments of briliance where the
actors and actresses
> were 
> > synched up with the music and appeared to be
singing along to 'John
> Wayne was a 
> > nazi', 'I'm not a loser' or other similar love
songs. 
> > 
> > Back in the day,
> > 
> > JoNaS
> > 
> 
> 
>

A benefit for the Leukemia Society:  LOVEHELPS

The LoveWorks Organisation is volunteering it's efforts with Maida Stupski and
the Leukemia Society Team in Training, to raise funds in a dance environment.

Saturday, April 18th, 1998  (yes, tomorrow!)
111 Minna Street Gallery (2nd & Mission), San Francisco
Festivities begin at 7:00pm with hors d'ouvres

7pm Acid Lounge with:   	Mauricio (Corazon & Backflip)   
9pm LoveWorks dancing:	Matt Valenz & Dani

A $10.00 donation will be asked for the Leukemia Society

(LoveWorks, Madia Stupski, sfstation.com, & Charlotte Ng, along with family
members & friends are donating all their time, effort & money for this event)

For advance tickets and donations:  http://sfstation.com/clubs/loveworks.htm

Voice info:  415.646.0744

LoveHelps is a LoveWorks platform for non-profits...and with this effort, we
ask you to make an effort and come down, donate & be a part the love that will
help to find a cure.

From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: Re: another strike against dancing...
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Rave Friends,

        I'd like to point out that if we lived in a society that respected
property rights, people who moved into a neighborhood with noisy late-night
clubs and then tried to get them shut down would be laughed out of the
police department.

        But since we operate under a system where your neighbors get nearly
as much say about how you run your business and what you do on your own
property as you do, and it's all up to the arbitrary whim of a bunch of
government bureaucrats, inevitably those outside the mainstream (aka those
with less money and clout) are going to get shafted.

        I'm not so cynical to say that there's nothing we can do about it,
but I think we'll be more effective in creating positive change when we
recognize the true nature of the problem and address it.

Power to the people,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

Hi Steve,

        The reason I asked is that I don't think Willie Brown has done shit
for our scene, yet there seem to be continuing unsubstantiated rumors to
the contrary.  Not only do I see no evidence of him helping protect raves
or clubs, he appears to be working against the "little people" in general.


        Under Brown's regime, the SFPD appears to be spending *more* time
than before cracking down on victimless "crimes" such as living in your
vehicle (recent article on a Vehicular Residents' Association man's hunger
strike in the SF Bay Guardian), prostitution (check the front page of the
most recent SF Independent), marijuana use (a friend of mine was recently
arrested for "selling" pot to a homeless woman; in fact he had given her a
small amount for personal use, and considering that a search turned up only
$.62 between them, the idea that he was selling is ridiculous, not to
mention a complete waste of police resources even if a sale had been
involved), traffic violations (recent stories in the Chronicle about
Brown's crusade against double parkers, jaywalkers, etc.), and the homeless
(the number of arrests now is greater than it was under Frank Jordan's
hated Matrix program, according to homeless advocates).

        Since this was a private communication between us, I won't post
this to the list without your permission, but if you're cool with it,
please forward it to SFRaves for me.

Much love,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

On Fri, 17 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:

> Hi Rave Friends,
> 
>         I'd like to point out that if we lived in a society that respected
> property rights, people who moved into a neighborhood with noisy late-night
> clubs and then tried to get them shut down would be laughed out of the
> police department.

Well, you could point that out but you would be sadly mistaken. Tenants of
a property have the right to "quiet enjoyment" of their property
regardless of who was there first. I found this great book at a thrift
store called "You and the Law" and it goes in to all sorts of issues,
tenant rights being one of them. 

Sorry folks, but both money and the law are on the side of the tenants,
like it or not.

ahhh, a lazy day today.  i love working on fridays, it's almost better
than having the day off - cause you get paid even though you're not
working...

well, ok, sometimes i gotta actually get something done on friday. 
but not today, looks like.  nothing to do but check my email...

nope, nothing...




damn, still nothing....







geez, yall are a bunch a quiet ravers out there today, whats up with
that?  well, i'm bored, and the list is awfully slow today, so if
anyone wants to chat feel free to drop me a line, i'll probably be
bored at work till 7 or later...


course an open invitation to chat is sorta hard to follow up on, i
usually get more responses if i say something interesting or
controversial.  so i guess i'll just throw some ice-breakers out to
you guys, see if anyone bites...


i've had telepathic experiences before, mostly on hallucinogens.

it's hard to plan falling in love, but i think if i ever get married
again i'd like to marry someone of a different race.

most californians don't like woody allen movies.  why is that?  i
think he's fuckin hillarious.

lately i've been noticing that there's this sort of attitude that guys
in the city cultivate, espicially in clubs and bars - it seems to
mostly express itself as a facial expression.  sort of a permanent
sarcastic scowl that says "i'm better than you".  it used to sort of
intimidate me, but the more i meet people who do it, the more i
realize it's just an act.

1015 is the nicest, friendliest, most laid-back meat market i've ever
been to.  course that's not saying much...

who do you think is the biggest asshole on this list?  if you think
it's me, i'd be glad to discuss it with you...

the village people were great.  imagine, they got a whole nation of
straight people to sing along with radio to songs about having casual
sex with other men at the young men's christian association.

god i need a massage.  anyone out there know a good massage therapist
in the city?



anyone?  anyone?



maybe i'll just take off a little early today...

see y'all at vibe this saturday!

-messiahw

Hey everyone, I'm back from No (Wo)man's Land and soooo excited about the
the scene right now, especially here in Sac (sorry if this is stuff you've
all heard before, but I've been unsubbed):

1.  There's a Jungle weekly in Sac now!  And it's _good_!  Jungle here has
often been quite horrible, but the resident DJ (dunno his name) is good &
they're booking some nice talent (Star Eyes was here this week).

2.  Who put this party (see below) together?  Whoever you (all) are, I
worship you!
   Saturday, May 30th - Fuz-E presents May Daze
   Omar Santana, Kelly Reverb, Jesse Brooks, Slim, Rockit, Catilist
   (live), Dennis, Ethan Miller, Micado, Andy W, Greg Sanders, Stillwind,
   Dre, Rinse, Flux, Noel, UFO, Sage, Star eyes, Simon Apex.
   916.484.4040

3.  Looking at the calendar, it seems as if hardcore is invading the bay . .
. woohoo!

4.  It's getting warmer . . . outdoor parties!!!  Are there any campouts
coming up?

5.  Hey, on April 19th I will have been raving for exactly 1 year . . . am I
still a newbie?  I sure feel like one . . . everything seems fresh & new
since I took a break from partying.

6.  I missed you guys . . . especially when Madonna's new album came out.  I
knew the list would be buzzing . . . was it?


xoxo--Miccaela
