        Black Adder shared:

>On Fri, 17 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:
>
>> Hi Rave Friends,
>>
>>         I'd like to point out that if we lived in a society that respected
>> property rights, people who moved into a neighborhood with noisy late-night
>> clubs and then tried to get them shut down would be laughed out of the
>> police department.
>
>Well, you could point that out but you would be sadly mistaken. Tenants of
>a property have the right to "quiet enjoyment" of their property
>regardless of who was there first. I found this great book at a thrift
>store called "You and the Law" and it goes in to all sorts of issues,
>tenant rights being one of them.
>
>Sorry folks, but both money and the law are on the side of the tenants,
>like it or not.

        I wasn't talking about the current state of the law, rather *if* we
lived in a society that respected property rights.  When it comes to
current law, Adder is clearly right.

On Fri, 17 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:

> >Well, you could point that out but you would be sadly mistaken. Tenants of
> >a property have the right to "quiet enjoyment" of their property
> >regardless of who was there first. I found this great book at a thrift
> >store called "You and the Law" and it goes in to all sorts of issues,
> >tenant rights being one of them.
> >
> >Sorry folks, but both money and the law are on the side of the tenants,
> >like it or not.
> 
>         I wasn't talking about the current state of the law, rather *if* we
> lived in a society that respected property rights.  When it comes to
> current law, Adder is clearly right.
> 
> Peace, love & liberty,

Starchild, 

Perhaps you could explain to me how the current law does not respect
property rights. Am I not entitled as a tenant of a space that has been
zoned for dwelling, to receive "quiet enjoyment" of that property? Not
legally mind you, but "morally." How is that disrespectful of property
rights? If I am apartment hunting is it my duty to go to a prospective
apartment at 3 a.m. to ensure that someone isn't making a lot of noise?

Laying blame on the tenants of these properties is highly inappropriate.

To: dreamer@ziplink.net, blkadder@value.net
Subject: Re: another strike against dancing...
Cc: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Content-Md5: BJfdmUynacFfq6DiqnqUPA==
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


> If I am apartment hunting is it my duty to go to a prospective
> apartment at 3 a.m. to ensure that someone isn't making a lot of noise?
> 

Uh, I actually do this. I'll spend a weekend night outside my prospective
apartment to make sure that "problems" don't arise so that I am completely
informed of the environment that I may be moving into. Its just one more factor 
in the opportunity costs of renting/purchasing a given place. 

This may not be your's or anyone else's "duty" when moving into a place in the 
city, but for a person moving into an urban environment, (especially those that 
are BUYING their place of residence) it is almost essential to do this, in terms 
of saving one's self hours of grief fighting whatever inconvience exists in the 
area you are moving into.

Its a case of responsibility. Yes, you are correct that these people "should"
have the moral right to "quiet enjoyment", but they also have the responsibility
of investigating their environment. Imagine a lone person moving into the middle 
of an industrial area and he or she starts complaining about the noise and 
saying, "I didn't know it would was like this!". Although that person has the 
moral right to "quiet enjoyment", most people would just roll their eyes and say 
"you should have known better". 

Now the arguments about SOMA/VSF are more blurred due to the number of people on 
each side of the issue and with the money in the hands of the tenants, the 
tenants' argument at this juncture has more clout.


> Laying blame on the tenants of these properties is highly inappropriate. 


To say the tenants are blameless is way too strong of a statement to make.
It IS appropriate to attribute some blame to these individuals' ingorance.
Obviously, they are not fully to blame: there are the developers who bought up 
the area and built these units with no regard to the surrounding environment. We 
can also blame the city for allowing the zoning of all these live/work spaces. 
We can blame the police and public official's for being paid off by the 
developer's (did you know that 10% of a building's cost go toward paying off 
inspectors/official's/etc.) We can blame ourselves for not taking enough action
to help perserve these clubs. We can point fingers all we want, but what good
does that do. 

God, I am ram-bel-ling, its time to go.

Being way to didactic,

JoNaS

I saw Mojo Nixon in concert a couple of years ago and he told us about a
drink he makes.  Just so ya know, Mojo Nixon is an maniac redneck
rocknroller.  You  buy a 2 liter bottle of Mt. Dew and a bottle of Gin. 
Dump half the Mt. Dew down the sink, and add the gin.  Shake until foamy.  

Something /very/ funny begins to happen. The chemical reaction between the
juniper berries in the gin, and the caffeine in the Mt Dew make you act
like a load, boasting, maniacal redneck.   Just like Mojo!

I call the drink Mojo Mixin'.

yeee, haw indeed.   :o)

> ----------   
> c@weasel gave me the secret formula for this one, it's stunning in
> it's simplicity and ease of covert mixing.  plus the buzz is...
> unique...
> 
> 
> the aging candyraver - gin, blowpop
> --------------------   
> like many of our finest technologies and styles of music, this was
> invented entirely by accident.  fill a glass with as much gin as you
> can stand to drink.  then add another ounce or two (important!). 
> unwrap the blowpop and place it, bulb down, in the glass. let it sit
> till the color of the blowpop has permeated the drink, then serve. 
> you get a subtly sugared hard drink, available in a variety of colors
> and flavors.  the blowpop acts as both stirrer and chaser...
> 
> the jetson - two parts white rum, three parts "obitz"
> ----------   (any flavor), two or more "space age"
>              lookin glasses
> 
> the hardest part is finding a gas station that still sells orbitz -
> you know, that weird looking drink with the little collored globs
> floating in it.  well, i wouldn't drink it on it's own either, but
> it's actually quite tasty once you mix in some hard liquor.  to do
> this right you really must have a couple of groovy lookin coctail
> glasses though - just check out the "housewarez" section of your fave
> thriftstore.  think "star trek - the old generation" (if you can't
> remember william shatner ordering one too many andruvian boilermakers
> before hitting on the green bellydancer from alpha centuri, you're
> probably too young to be reading this...)
>              
> 
> and finally...  i gotta tell the story behind this one before i reveal
> it's name...
> 
> me, pjfuzzy and our friend bradford were driving around manhattan one
> night, just enjoying the ride, watching all the streetpartys and mob
> scenes after the yankees won the world series.  anyway i had thrown a
> party at my parents house the weekend before, and i had all these
> not-quite-empty bottles of exotic liquors to get rid of.  so we were
> trying to come up with drinkable combinations out of these various
> bottles, and when we'd come up with a good one, we'd give it a
> suitable name.  finally bradford handed up a really tasty one to me
> and pj from the back of the car...
> 
> "i like this, what's in it?"
> "oh, coca cola, cherry liquor, and everclear to taste..."
> "this is sorta a girl drink, tastes like cherry coke.  i cant taste
> the everclear at all!"
> "well there's plenty in there.  give a couple of these to your high
> school sweetheart and she'll have all the excuse she needs to give it
> up..."
> "brad, you're satan.  besides, my girlfriend graduated from high
> school like two years ago..."
> "he's right though.  plus, it's great for a car date - with the cap on
> it's impossible to spill..."
> "ok, this is a keeper.  what's it called?"
> "'cherry buzz bomb'?  nah..."
> "ummmm...  'high-school sweetheart'?"
> "no, that's cheesey.  how about 'new coke'."
> "already taken.  we invented it in a car, so it oughtta have a
> car-related name.  'the drink and drive'?" 
> 
> finally brad pipes up from the behind us.  "well, i invented it, so
> i'm gonna name it.  it's called... 'cherry in a back seat'..."
> 
> 
> ok, so maybe you had to be there...
> 
> 
> -messiah wannabe
> 
> 
> 
> 
> 
>

note: forwarded msg attached.
Not once in my entire message did I say anything about drugz
or entheogenz being bad. My end quote iz The most violent
element in society iz Ignorance.

I'm sorry paul, and I apologize that you are too ignorant
to see that I just want to  point out that Drugz are
not bad, people make drugz bad by not educating themselvez
about them prior to uzing them. I thought that by perhaps
calling attention to the Binge/Purge cycle that every other 
raver seemz to fall into, we might take steps az a community
of raverz and help each other avoid the addiction pitfall.
Perhaps someday you will open your mind and heart az 
totally az you believe it iz opened now...
-AlwayzSpun-
P.S. I know all there iz to know about shroomz...Am willing
to be taught about DMT, Ayahuasca, 2-CB, or Ketamine though (^_^)

> In the 20'z we had the Flapperz and Anti-Prohibition
> Gang warz...
> In the 40'z, we had the Zoot Suiterz, and the Lindy Hopperz.
> In the 60'z,Woodstock waz the most spectacular display
> of human love and affection ever witnessed at one gathering
> any where on the face of the planet. Oh yeah, the funky
> concept of tie-dye waz invented at this point by the cool
> ass hippy'z.
> In the 80'z, we were still reeling from the effects of the
> disco dancin John Travolta and the one and only Soul Train.
> This said era waz dominated by such comical characterz az
> 'Boy' George and Cindi Lauper. I don't know what to call
> them, and let's not forget about Madonna'z rize to fame with
> hits like Border line and Jimmy Jimmy.
>     Now entering the New Millenium, a new breed haz arizen.
> Enter the Party Kidz. Underaged Adolescents staying
> out way past every1'z curfew and cramming every conceivable
> illicit substance down their throats and just trying to get
> az fucked up az they can.
> While we all have had our share of spending a whole night
> drooling in the corner spun out of our mindz while attending
> a phat party, most of us had the common sense to realize
> that this waz not acceptable behaviour to carry out on a
> weekly basis. But not the Rave Baby. Party Kidz are nothing
> more than Rave Babiez who grew out of the habit of getting
> az aced out of reality az they could only after they had
> hit rock bottom(getting strung out, lozing everything, and
> only then realizing addiction to whatever poizon they had
> picked).
>     Okay, so while some of us continued to get wasted, and
> otherz realized that wasted wazn't where it waz at, we still
> have a new wave of party goerz entering the scene every month.
> What impression are the newcomerz supposed to get about the
> now clouded and confuzed scene?
> Even in the magic mushroom dayz of the hippiez and the mystic
> mescaline dayz of Heavy Metal viewerz, in the dayz before
> LSD waz banned, people were not getting az fucked up az the
> Rave Babiez. Oddz are that any new gen-Xer entering the scene
> now will partake of more controlled substancez within a
> month than the freelovin' swingin' sex-pressive hippiez of
> the 60'z did in 2 or more months.
>     However, with the help and aid of an experiened guide,
> the guiding hand of an experienced party goer, new rave
> babiez won't have to learn the true meaning of a rave the
> hard way. I mean yeah sure,everyone wants to get a little
> blasted and high az fuck, therez no problem with that. Ya
> wanna hippy flip, cool... Candy flip, go right ahead, MX Missle,
> Fire away, Coco puffs, I'm cuckoo, parachuting your thing,
> feel free to do so.
> What I'm saying iz that there iz no need to try out 4
> different drugz at the same sitting. And I feel that this
> point iz not made clear for most first time raverz, who get
> the obvious yet wrong impression about the type of thing to
> do at a good party by nitro sucking shroom swallowing smoked
> out speed snorting e-kid laying in hiz own puddlez of urine
> and multicolored vomit... Get what I'm sayin?
>     Misunderstand me not, I've been more than my fair share
> of high before, but I've never been incoherent and I've never
> not known what I've just put in my body. I've also never put
> hellacious amounts of entheogenz in my body.
> I've heard of people taking 4-5 hits of E within the same
> 2 hourz trying to 'Get Off' az best they can. Ten hits of
> acid disappear down the same manz throat. Half an ounce of
> shroomz 'tween teo people... Or how bout the first timer
> with their paycheck in their pocket on Friday night answering
> to every call of 'X' and 'Fry', az well az getting taken by
> the venderz and people selling other shit. Why not make
> it clear from the beginning of the party that you're not
> suppozed to get all fucked up beyond belief. I've recently
> seen a flier that stated right on the front that G would not
> be tolerated within its doorz. Its not much by itself, but,
> its a great start for what it's worth. There iz nothing
> wrong with getting your high on, but be selective when
> wasting the limited grey matter. You only have so much of
> it and you can only get so high at one time... No matter
> how much pot you smoke, you'll only get so stoned. No matter
> how many hits of E you take, you're gonna get spun. There iz
> no need to take more than two hits of acid, you're gonna fry.
> You don't need to eat more than two eigths of shroomz cuz
> you're still gonna get off. This iz the Point that so many
> have difficulty understanding, sillly az that might be. I
> guess some assume that 20 hits of Fry will make you see more
> than 2-3 hits will. Might be true, but you'll be just az
> fuckin incapacitated so what doez it really matter? Sure
> you will relive the sinking of the Titanic after 1/2 oz. of
> shroomz, but you'll be so fuckin shroomed out that you won't remember
> shit about sinling anyway. So maybe it will feel
> 8 timez az good to drop 4 hits of X instead of 1 or 1-1/2.
> Who carez if you're E'n so hard that your teeth grind and
> no one can understand a fuckin word your sayin...
>      I guess this iz nothing more than a warning early
> Easter 98 mornin for the purpose of lettin y'all know some
> one iz concerned with the posterity of the scene, and I do wish
> to keep all my party peops alive until we're old and decrepit
> haz been fart knockerz doin dancez in front of our kidz
> like our parents do in front of us... But if we keep destroyin
> ourselvez, by not watching out for each other, where will
> we be in the near future. What will we have in the near future.
> Sure I can down 40 geltabz and not sweat it, but can I
> eazily and clearly what I waz doin exactly what I waz doin
> 1 year ago?
>     If reading this made you scratch your head or set off
> a warning light somewhere in the back of that partied out
> teenage brain of yourz, Take a sec to look at your involvement
> in the scene... How involved are you really? How much are
> you doing really? What do you spend on drugz really? How many
> different 1'z are you on at your partiez?
> I'm exhausted and can no longer continue, so pleaze feel
> free to get back to me any time you pleaze...
>     Only cuz I care...
> -AlwayzSpun-
> 
> "The most violent element in Society iz Ignorance"
> 
> -source unknown-
> 
> ==
> The Cali 1 who'z AlwayzSpun,
> livin life and havin fun...
> Gettin high late at night,
> Alwayz rollin through hiz life
> Not knowin what to do or where to go
> Eatin shroomz and snortin blow...

I am very sorry that you haven't realized the positive portion of the
psychedelic experience. Maybe one day you will.

Yeah, they had a massive WW party in LA . . . but it's still a cool idea.
I'm mean, how many parties have been named "CandyLand" or "ToonTown" or
"Fantasia" or whatever?  So I'm sure there could be one more "Willy Wonka &
the Chocolate Factory."

But the problem w/ parties named after movies and other such stuff is that
they never seem to live up to the name.  You think you're going to this
super-happy party with all these cool visuals and blah blah and you just end
up at another ol party like any other ol party and you put all that glitter
on for nothing.  Kinda sucks.

xoxo--Miccaela

after standing there for half an hour in my cold arse adidas outfit
waiting that hopefully Michael would come out... I feel at my lowest
ever because I messed up and now in my part I need to pay Michael back
the 30 bucks he spent on tickets that I never picked up because of my
own stupidity : ( I'm sorry Michael for not being there when I said I
would... Didn't get there till round 11:45pm and I feel hella bad : (

All I can say is Wow.

It had been a while since I'd been to a party.  My [non-raving] boyfriend
wanted to go  "It's those DJs you've been talking about..."  And indeed - the
lineup was stellar.  It didn't take much to talk me into going.

When I arrived, Li and J-bot [?] were up.  Talk about starting my evening
right.  I hardly ever get to see Li spin anymore.  I picked a spot in front of
the decks upstairs and barely left the rest of the party.

Ethan went on next.  A seriously wicked hard 2 hour set.  Got the crowd moving
and screaming in a hurry.  Bustin a move behind the decks.  Ethan is my idol.
 =)

Not to be outdone, AndyW and C@weasel pushed techno to one of my personal
favorites, minimal.  I'd never seen the c@ spin before and lemme tell ya what a
treat.  I knew he must be something because I'd seem him booked at parties not
too long after he arrived from the UK.  Their styles went together really well.

Up last, Micron just stole the show though.  Playing harder than usual for him.
 Like some killa, killa techno... moving into some really nice bouncy trance.

I also got to see a bunch of my original raving crew.  That was a special
treat.

Supa special thanks to Dan, Terri, Andy, Li, Science and all yous Viberation
kinda people out there.  Truly a party of epic proportions.

Love,

Beth

Just to remenis a bit...   Sometime back in '93...   There was a party here in SF
called 'willie wanka's chocolate factory'   It was put on by some of my friends.
The guys from Juice (Mike, and Josh) and Sara Lee.   It was a cool party.  The
flyer looked like a 3 by 4 gold chocolate wrapper.   and there was even small bite
size hershey candy bars handed out that were preprinted with the info and the
party name.   it was a good promotion, but the party ended up to be at the Mission
Rock, and was kinda booty.    Lots of BS with sf spaces at that time.   But the
candy sure was good, I think I personally ate like 50 of those flyers :)    But
even though it has already been done, doesn't mean anything, cause it can
definitely be done better.      Follow your vision :)

Keep it real...   Vlad

PureUtoPia wrote:

> Hey I was wonder If any one had ever thought of having a rave that the theme
> was Willie Wonka and the Chocolate Factory? Maybe this had already been done.
> Has it? Well anyways i thought about it and gawd it would be so rad. For
> visuals you could use like computer generated scenes from the movie or
> anything like that. And then for decorations there could be those big colorful
> flowers and anything else bright and colorful from the movie. Well what does
> everyone think?

Cc: *Rave Friends* <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Black Adder,

        Assuming that the zoning near the clubs was changed to allow
residential units *after* the clubs had been operating, this action was
effectively violating their property rights by creating (as you point out)
a reasonable expectation of new tenants moving into a space zoned for
dwelling, of "quiet enjoyment" of their property at 3am.  (Although there
is a very strong argument to be made that someone moving into an apartment
near, say, 11th and Folsom should have known what to expect.)

        My view is that zoning is a violation of rights to begin with,
because it is telling you what you can or cannot do on your own land.  The
only thing that makes it remotely excusable is that it is already so built
into the system that people have made all kinds of economic decisions based
on existing zoning designations.

        Ideally, there would be no zoning, and I do believe it should be
the responsibility of prospective tenants to investigate the neighborhood
adequately before moving in.  This needn't involve going there at 3am to
see if somebody's making noise, just asking a few neighbors.

Much love,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

You shared:

>Starchild,
>
>Perhaps you could explain to me how the current law does not respect
>property rights. Am I not entitled as a tenant of a space that has been
>zoned for dwelling, to receive "quiet enjoyment" of that property? Not
>legally mind you, but "morally." How is that disrespectful of property
>rights? If I am apartment hunting is it my duty to go to a prospective
>apartment at 3 a.m. to ensure that someone isn't making a lot of noise?
>
>Laying blame on the tenants of these properties is highly inappropriate.
>
>
>On Fri, 17 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:
>
>> >Well, you could point that out but you would be sadly mistaken. Tenants of
>> >a property have the right to "quiet enjoyment" of their property
>> >regardless of who was there first. I found this great book at a thrift
>> >store called "You and the Law" and it goes in to all sorts of issues,
>> >tenant rights being one of them.
>> >
>> >Sorry folks, but both money and the law are on the side of the tenants,
>> >like it or not.
>>
>>         I wasn't talking about the current state of the law, rather *if* we
>> lived in a society that respected property rights.  When it comes to
>> current law, Adder is clearly right.
>>
>> Peace, love & liberty,

  Thought this was another forward that could be applied as an alogorical
  to our scene... -LM
---

"Time..... a Fable"

Once upon a time, there was an island where all the 
feelings lived: Happiness, Sadness, Knowledge, and 
all of the others, including Love. 

However, one day it was announced to everybody that 
the island would sink, so all prepared their boats and left.

Love was the only one who stayed.  Love wanted to stay 
until it started sinking.  When Love was almost sinking, 
he decided to ask for help. 

Richness was passing by Love in a beautiful boat. 
Love said, "Richness, can you take me with you?"
Richness answered, 
"No, I can't. There is a lot of gold and silver in my 
boat.  There is no place here for you."

Love decided to ask Vanity who was also passing by, 
"Vanity, please help me!"
"I can't help you Love.  You are all wet and can probably 
damage my boat," Vanity answered.

Sadness was close by so Love asked for help, 
"Sadness, let me go with you." 
"Oh... Love, I am so sad that I prefer to go alone!"

Happiness passed by Love too, but she was so happy 
that she did not listen when Love called her!

Suddenly, there was a voice, 
"Come Love, I will take you."  It was an elderly person.

Love became very happy that he even forgot to ask the 
name of the elderly person.  When they arrived to the other 
side, Love asked Knowledge who the elderly person was.

"It was Time."

"Time? But why did Time help me?"

"Because only Time is capable of understanding such 
a great Love."

P.S:  Time is capable of solving anything.  Things today 
may not have a solution but tomorrow you will find one!  
The time has come for us to stop tuning separate 
instruments and, together, to create a symphony.

WOoHoo!! Can We say DOPE DOPE DOPE DOPE DOPE DOPE DOPE?!?!?!?!

I LOVED THIS PARTY!! !YESSS!! Ok... So a bunch of my newbie friends I was
supposed to take flaked on me, and I ended up going alone, although I was
later joined by my friend Paige, who's visiting from Orange County.  It was
her first SF party and let me just say... SHE WAS IMPRESSED!! I was too... she
is now convinced that So-Cal doesn't even compare to our scene.  hehe
ANyways.. thanx for making her feel at home, although with Paige, I doubt
that's hard.

ANYWAYz.. I'm getting sidetracked.  I liked the set-up for this location.
I've always wanted to go to a party at that house, and I wasn't dissapointed.
OH YES!!! The Jungle room was so Phat with the cargo nets and blacklight art
and all the couches so you could just chill.  The dining hall (sorry.. main
room) had a nice set-up too, except the visual screens kept showing what the
computers were doing to change the visuals.  Was that on purpose??? WHo
cares.. It was all good!!  

   FREE WATER. FREE FRUIT.  Yeah.. you're making Trice happy already.  I also
like how you have the outdoor space the keeps the party from getting too hot
and has a dope ass view of the bay bridge leading over to the city with the
Berkely campus in front of you.  Hey, if anyone else got pictures of the
sunrise from the roof could you send them to me?? Mine didn't come out.

So Ah.. my two favorite sets of the night had to have been #1 ~~> Siphon for
OH MY GOSH!! DRopping that "rock the funky beats" track that my friends and I
have had stuck in our heads for over a month.  We'd been singing it everyday,
and when he threw it down we just had to go off.  Oh, and of course call for a
rewind!! YES!! that's the first rewind I've ever called in my life, and he
played it over too!! oh oh oh!! That just made my night.  #2 ~~~> goes out to
Micron for his INTENSE morning set... It was so beautiful and upliting..
especially since i love morning sets.  he had everyone going off so strong
that the party ran over I heard like an hour and 45 minutes???  yes.. and all
the other music was Phat too!

So this marked my one full year of actually raving and partying and i got to
reflect on it all and how much I've changed, and i couldn't have picked a
better party to do it at.  I had wonderful conversations with so many people (
you all know who you are) and learned so much about the people I party with.
It was a HUGE SFR turnout and I met a lot of new faces.  (I'm not even going
to TRY to remember them all)  I just want to say hi and thank everyone for
making it a beautiful party.  

I saw Mad good vibes going off from everyone and people taking care of each
other.  and I am proud to say our scene can produce a party like this one.
WHEW!! but seeing as how I haven't slept in 39 hours and 40 minutes, I'd
better go to bed so I'm all rested for school tomorrow on 420.  Hope everyone
had a happy weekend!!!

     hugs n'stuff,
trice the tekno diva


===============
Raving is my religion.
The DJ is my shaman.
Dancing is my prayer.

Hello all......

The end...... by the time you all get this I might be kicked out of my
house and living on the streets so this might be the last time you hear
from me..... I'm at the lowest point in my life that I've ever been
before. I might not even be raving anymore because I might decide to
dissapear..... I don't even see why I'm telling you all this because
this isn't the place to talk about this.... Maybe I'll live.. maybe I
won't.... I don't really care and don't feel like dealing with my messed
up body anymore.... Or how much acid does it take to kill someone ?? I
mean in doses ?? Maybe I'll go to my last rave and do that.... Maybe
some of you will say you care and don't want me to dissapear... but most
of you have never met me and don't know about my messed up body or
life.... Sorry if I worry any of you..... especially Michael because
he's the only one on this list that knows anything about me... I'll get
you your 30 dollars soon Michael before I'm gone..... Maybe I'll be here
tomorrow and be ok.... and maybe I won't.... time will tell......

Farewell?...

Ryan

Come One Come All!!!!!

if you didn't know about SFRaves IRC chat room, you can now consider
youself informed.

WHAT IS IRC? Internet Relay Chat (chances are, if you have an internet
service provider you can get irc)
PURPOSE OF SFRAVES CHATROOM (talk to people on SFRaves without having
to  solely rely on the e-mails)
HOW TO IRC...
Specs: If you have a web browser you can download IRC from the WEB at NO
COST TO YOU...
first go to <a href="http://www.mircx.com/">an Mirc WebSite</a> and
download it (if you have a PC, download "mIRC" and if you have a
Macintosh download "Ircle")
follow directions as listed, and next thing you know, YOU'RE ON!!!!
ONCE YOU'VE LOADED YOUR IRC CLIENT:
open the program.... they'll give you a list of options... read the
directions..... and you'll be on in not time...
REMEMBER THAT THE SFRAVES IS ON AN EFNET server.... (you'll know
whatthat means later)
and the channel name is "#sfraves" (yes, the pound sign included)
keep working on it...
if you're on AOL your special server is irc02.irc.aol.com USE IT!!!!!!

ok, well I hope to see you peeps there soon.
it can get fun and your added participation can make a phat conversation
forum for those with "Partying on the brain"
if you have any questions....
e-mail <a href="mailto:NavySatan@aol.com">NavySatan@aol.com</a>
or e-mail me here...
hope to see you there...

I don't even begin to know you, but sweetheart please don't feel so sad.
There is a quote which gets repeated all over the place, so you have
probably heard it before: "this too shall pass"  I know it is trite as
shit, but it does have a truth to it.  The beautiful thing about life is
that it is never stagnant; change is the only constant.  If you can just
hang on for a little while I am so sure that things will look up.  I don't
know *your* life at all, but I have a confidence in the universe that for
every valley there is a peak. It can just be a hard climb back up that
slope.  Sometimes however, you just have to own the depressed times, and
accept that is who you are and how you are feeling right now.  But at least
it is yours.  My last thought is that there is no shame in wallowing in
self-pity every once in a while.  It can be really good for the soul.

absynthe

I know where you're coming from, I was there about 2 years ago.  
Life sucked the big donkey and I was thinking about turning to 
the darkside of the force, but instead, I sought an inward source
for help.  During the retrospection and reflection on my life, the 
only thing that could help me, was myself.  I got off my fatass,
went down and applied for a job, I went in, got an interview and
they practically begged me to work for them, they hired me on
the spot.  But life was still hard from then on, but you can only
deal with what is given to you.  While right now my life could be
better, I deal with what I can, and make the most of what I have.
It's all in what you do with it.  Make it so, Number One!

Your Jedi Bitch,
Jedi666Boy

Don't get me started!  >=?
Andrew and I headed for the T&J factory pretty damn late but we 
figured hey!  it's a party so it'll go until real late.  So if we get there
about 1 or so, it should be coO.  WRONG!  We got there and there
were some directions to a party about 5 miles away at some guys
house.  We banged on the door for about 20 minutes.  The lights 
were on, the pooter was on, and the gates were closed and locked.
So we figured that they were still there.  I really wanted to go to this
party.  There were some directions on the door, which we followed
but were very confusing and we got lost but I eventually got there.
We get there and things are looking OK, but then we walk up and 
look around, and some little cutie asks me if I know where this party 
is and hands me a flyer...  for VIBE THIS!!  FUCK!  FUCK FUCK FUCK!
So we get in the car all bummed out because I know this party was going 
to kick my ass for weeks, and headed to get something to eat.  Then
we went home and played Tekken 3 for about an hour before I went to
sleep.  Can't get enough of the Tekken Ball mode!  Yeah, let's stop
fighting and play beach ball!  =)  but that doesn't make up for the fact that 
I missed such a bombass party!  

guess I'll see you guys at afterglo tonight.  

>And why didn't I see you at Vibe This?

Your Jedi Bitch,

Many of us have been thru some incredibly difficult times,
and many of us have been to the point of suicide. It seems
everyone always offers to listen which is nice but if you're
like me sometimes talking just doesnt help much.
So i think we should organize a new raver FUNd to help out
our fellow raver that might be having a bad time.
Im going to call it barf...Bay Area Relief FUNd.

We can use it to buy a sad raver something to cheer them up
or maybe take then to a good party to revive their spirit.

So next time you see someone passing around a B.A.R.F. bag
please make a contribution.

ps to drakonis...if you do get booted from your house and need
a place to come get a shower or set up a hotmail account for your
email,etc, let me know...anyone else too.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

hello.
so I went on my first boat party yesterday and I must
say it rocked, both to and fro.

I made sure to get some photos to send back east to
make my friends jealous enough to come out and visit
me(where else are they gonna party while on a boat
enjoying the beautiful views that we take for granted
in San Francisco).

I loved the accessories that some of the people wore
to the party especially the girl who wore water wings
and another who wore scuba gear, I'll know to get
more creative next time I go.

This is why I love theme parties more than your
average just go and dance party.  You get the feeling
that everyone is one the same wavelength, and makes
you feel almost conspiratorial, like if only the rest
of the world knew how much fun we were having.

I was sad when we pulled in the dock at 12:00 pm, I
could have gone for another 2 hours but was spent
enough to call it a day.

If any of you went drop me a line and tell me what
you thought of it.  I got to work on a new sfraves
laminate, one that you can see under club lighting.

pjf

victoria,

i responded to you privately because you wrote me (a not so nice e-mail) 
privatly, but i think my opinions are just as important as yours & as 
everyone else's so i'm writing this to the whole list.  i don't think any 
one had any intention of insulting or offending you when they responded 
to your post.  it's cool if you want to go to denver & know how they 
dress/how they dance/what the parties are like, but the best thing anyone 
could ever do at a party is be THEMSELVES!  the greatest thing about this 
scene is that it supports inividuality.  yes, there is this whole deal 
with kids dressing alike (thw little adidas whores running around in 
baggy pants - i'm at school in the south right now & that's the biggest 
style right now) but if you bring your individuality, your own style of 
dress, your own style of dance, it's going to make the scene a much 
better place - and poeple are goinbg to think you're the shit for doing 
that.  i don't see where your nasty attidtue is coming from, especially 
since no one has acted rudly towards you.  before you say that it's 
poeple like ME who are making others leave this list maybe you should sit 
back and take a look at yourself, because it seems to me that you are one 
who is spreading a bad vibe.

amber "i've got nothing more to say about this so don't bother bitching at 
me" mcquown

ryan!

life may "look" ruf, but it's only an appearance.  beleive me, i may not 
know exactly what you're going through but i do know something similar.  
(i'm going to put my heart on my sleave for a little bit here.)  i've 
been the kind of kid who has always been driven, done well in school, 
gotten straight A's, known where i've wanted to go in life.  i went to 
marin academy, graduated with a 3.9, got sent off to DUKE, worked my butt 
off here, and only recently i've realized i have no clue where i want to 
go in life, what i want to do withmyself.  i had no moitvation to do 
anything. i came back from christmas break feeling so depressed.  i 
wanted to transfer to berekely so i could be in cali (i miss home so damn 
much)  i wanted to change my major to something easier (i don't know what 
i'll do with a math & econ major but who cares!)  i was so depressed i 
would just lie in bed & cry.  i didn't go to classes.  i slacked off with 
everything.  i stopped doing stuff in my sorority.  i stopped competing 
on the ski team (this is all stuff i was very active in before.)  my drug 
use went WAY up.  even though i am a weekend user, it would get to the 
point where i would be at friends houses after parties & just yell out 
what i wanted: COKE! CRYSTAL!  PILLS! and it would come, and i would do 
more.  of course ythis never helpoed my depression.  i felt unloved, even 
though i had so many wonderful friends around me.  i never really told 
them what was going on until recently.  i didn't feel i could talk to 
them, but i found out i could.  i told then EVERYTHING.  i talked to 
myself.  i figured things out, what i wanted what i needed.  i found out 
i really didn't love myself.  you can't expect any one to love you if you 
don't love yourself.  
what i'm trying to get at is even though i felt like i had no direction, 
that i was just fucking my body up (my body is perfectly fine by the way) 
it all got better.  i've pulled my grades up (thank god!), i've learned 
that i am a beautiful, wonderful, exiting person that everyone (including 
myself) should feel lucky to have around.  i've learned it's ok to not 
know what the future will bring - that it's more fun to watch it unfold 
and see all the surprises that come.  i've learned that life is always 
going to bring to bags full of shit, but you have to take them with a 
grain of salt & keep moving ahead.  i've also learned that there are 
poeple out there who love me & will always be there for me.  so if you 
decide to keep on keepin on, please call me (i'm long distance so you can 
call collect if you want or i'll call you back).  my number is 
919.613.0649.  i'll be back in marin in 3 weeks so you can get in touch 
with me at 415.388.7313 or page at 1.800.5.SPRINT, pin # 315.0414 anytime 
you want.  you do have people that love youy and care about you even 
though they haven't met you.  please think about that.

lovehugs&kisses,

amber

but you know when you are at the lowest point in your life, there is no

Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk



WOW eh?

The music was just incredible but so were the people!  It took me
about an hour to finally make it upstairs from outside.  From the
minute Nick and I got inside I just kept bumping into folks I'd either
seen 2 days ago or 2 years ago. It was just incredible.  Nothing like
gabbing over FREE water!

I caught Joe Rice set downstairs and he was amazing.  Great waiting in
line for the bathroom music indeed.  Oh and just in case I didn't
point it out to you Sat. night, I was the one who put the toilet paper
roll on the spinner dealie so all the raver kids didn't have to grab
it off the floor.  No really, you don't need to thank me.  Any Martha
Stewart wannabe would have done the same.

Upstairs just took my breath away. Took me forever to finally make it
up there, and it was worth it.  Just beautiful and best of all, it
never got too hot no matter how many people were packed in there
dancing to the music.  And the view from the balcony, WOWZERS!  I'm
sure the Fuji Disposable camera won't do it justice, but hey, we can't
all have the good Kodak kind right Elena?

Andy and c@weasel were incredible. It was great to just stop for a
minute and look at the crowd.  Everyone had a smile going.  Some folks
were getting down but others just closed their eyes and went with it. 
I can't believe how quickly their set was over.  Seemed like they were
only on for 10 min. but yes time flies when you're having fun.
Was only able to stay for the beginning of Microns set, damn shame I
know.

Oh, and Lacie, it was,
"Go eat poo. Okay?" ;)
Did anyone else notice that great graffiti by the bathroom stairs
besides Tony and I?

Tabitha

Two stories off the wire today about a substance many of you enjoy...

    JERUSALEM, April 20 (Reuters) - Israeli police found dozens of marijuana
plants in a flower-filled traffic island on a major highway in Jerusalem on
Monday.
    Police said they had no clue who planted the marijuana in the carpet of
flowers laid down by the Jerusalem municipality.
    Israel Television showed two plainclothes detectives weeding out the
illegal
seedlings as cars drove by on the busy highway. A police spokesman said they
would hunt for more marijuana on Tuesday.

    DETROIT, April 20 (Reuters) - A pilot flying a plane loaded
with marijuana apparently ran out of gas and was trying to find
a place to land when he was killed in a crash Sunday in a
Detroit school playground, police said Monday.
    Customs agents who were trailing the plane videotaped it as
it flipped over while trying to make an emergency landing in
Detroit.
    The pilot was identified as Douglas Dufresne, 66, of
Indialantic, Florida. Officials found 400 pounds (185 kg) of
marijuana in the wreckage.
    Three planes from the U.S. Customs Service in Texas had
tracked the single engine craft since early Sunday morning
after a park ranger in Big Bend National Park spotted it
crossing the border from Mexico.
    Police said Dufresne apparently ran out of gas after a
1,400-mile (2,240 kilometre) journey. He appeared to have been
looking for a place to land when he clipped trees and plowed
into the grass between baseball fields in back of the Noble
Middle School on the west side of Detroit.
    Witnesses at the scene said two people took bags full of
pot and cash before police arrived.
    Customs agents said they do not know where Dufresne was
headed but they had received clearance from Canadian officials
to continue the pursuit into Canada.

All I can keep saying to myself is WOW! 
That had to be the best party I 'we been to in the Bay Area by far. That
location was soooooo sweet. The combination of outside decks, sofas, cool
decorations/visuals, black lights etc., two different rooms and it lasted
ALL NIGHT LONG! The vibe was thick. My only possible suggestion might have
been the line at the bathroom and maybe a request for a house record now and
then. Hey, call me a house fairy. Yes , I was the tweaker you saw dancing
like a phreek in the total white long sleeve shirt black hat always bumping
into you and speaker humping like always hehehe. The people throwing this
one sure had an incredible location and thanks very much to that crew! I
loved meeting all you sfravers and hope we can do it again real soon.

Take care everybody,
-Josh

--=_ORCL_19876651_0r0

thank you! thank you! thank you! thank you! thank you! thank you!

Thanks to everyone who made it out to "Vibe This!" last Saturday!

We are so *overwhelmed* by the show of support and good vibes!

Special thanks to:

- Our special guest DJs: Ethan, Cloud, C@weasel,Roman, and Joe RIce

- The hardworking and devoted crew who threw down like nobody's business!

- Gateway Systems, for bustin' out the thumpin' blue sound system last minute!

- Tony, Blake, and Scott for putting together the live webcast

- Most importantly...*all of you*! You made the party, and you all are the
reason that we put our heart and souls into every event we do.

I'm sorry for those of you that didn't get in, we sold out pretty early.
We'll get presale tix out earlier next time I promise.

As for us, it's back to the drawing board once again to see what new ideas
we can come with for next time. And as always, we love to hear your
questions, comments, suggestions, and concerns...our email addy is
viberation@saturn5.com

See you at Harmony's 5 Year Anniversary!

much love and energy,

The Viberation Crew

P.S. I still have a handful of Viberation T-Shirts, contact me if you want one.

http://www.saturn5.com/viberation

It may seem odd to see "No on E" posted to a rave mailing list, but if you
are a renter in San Francisco, you will definitely want to read this...

>From: Graham Potter <graham@meadowbase.com>
>
>Hi all,
>
>As you know, I'm totally psyched to have such a wonderful warm pleasant
>home here in the coolest city in the world. As you may not know, my home --
>and possibly yours -- is coming under a serious threat this June. There is
>a ballot measure on the June ballot, buried among Gubernatorial primary
>candidates and bond measures, that would effectively remove rent control in
>San Francisco. My landlord, and possibly yours too, would have the legal
>right to DOUBLE or TRIPLE RENT on the DAY AFTER ELECTION DAY, if this
>measure passes.
>
>  That's why I'm asking you to join me and vote NO on E this June.
>
>Your vote makes a difference. Local measures like this often make it or
>break it on the basis of one or two votes per precinct. This measure has
>the potential to directly harm our quality of life in our community, in a
>drastic and severe way. Please vote. Please pass this information along to
>others who are eligible to vote in San Francisco.
>
>  NOT REGISTERED?   I WILL SEND YOU REGISTRATION MATERIALS.
>
>If you have never registered to vote in the place where you're living now,
>you must register before May 2 to be eligible to vote in the primary. Email
>me your name and snailmail address, and I will send you the form. (Send
>email to graham@meadowbase.com). Just fill it out and mail it in.
>If you've been putting off registering to vote in your current location,
>now is a great chance to register.
>
>  TOO BUSY TO VOTE?   VOTE ABSENTEE.
>
>When you get your voter packet, there will be instructions on absentee
>voting. All you have to do is fill out a form and mail it in. You don't
>have to go to the ballot box on election day, if you plan ahead.
>
>  NOT SURE WHO TO CHOOSE FOR GOVERNOR?   VOTE ON PROP E ANYWAY.
>
>You don't have to vote on issues that you don't feel comfortable about, or
>for people in races where everyone's a slime. Vote NO ON E and leave the
>other issues blank, if you want. Even if voting isn't usually your thing,
>please consider the importance of this issue and it's effect on your life
>and my life. It only takes a couple of minutes. There's a building movement
>of opposition to the measure, but the other side has lots more money.
>
>  KNOW SOMEONE ELSE WHO MIGHT BE INTERESTED?   SEND ME THEIR EMAIL ADDRESS.
>
>I'm keeping an informal email list of people who want to be kept posted
>about Prop E as the election approaches. (No more than one message every
>two weeks, I promise.) If you want to be removed from my list, let me know.
>If you know someone who wants to be added, also let me know. Thanks!
>
>
>------------------------------------------------------------
>                        MeadowBase
>          Software for Growing Organizations
>
>                       Graham Potter
>
>graham@meadowbase.com                    2336 Market St #138
>(415) 643 9005                  San Francisco, CA 94114-1521
>------------------------------------------------------------

Well, I havn't posted in a while due to massive panic/stress/fatigue overload.
I'm preparing to test for my 3rd dan Black belt, and it's killing me.
(literally)

So, today, I had just finished training for six hours straight, when I left to
find that sombody had hit my car, and drove off without a word.  Well, I was
so tired that I didn't have the energy to get angry, but was too frustrated to
go to sleep.  So I drank way too much coffee and headed to afterglo.

And as soon as I heard Lori's phat beats, and met Elenas eternal smile(thanks
girl), all my problems just seemed to melt away.  Haaaa... a short escape from
reality makes everything so much easier to bear.

Hippity hoppity frogboix kickin to the moon.

Crystal Nitrous
Fox Interactive makes good on promise to sign major techno band for shooter

Talk about name brands! When Fox Interactive debuted its impressive 3D shooter 
N2O: Nitrous Oxide earlier this year, its visuals were fantastic, but the music 
was -- well, placeholder. The reason for the temporary music was the fact that 
Fox Interactive was in the process of signing on major music talent to compose 
the soundtrack.

That major music talent is Crystal Method, the hot new Bay Area-based techno 
band, whose tunes have shown up in everything from dance clubs to car 
commercials. Crystal Method will be providing 10 original and remixed tunes, 
including "Busy Child," "Keep Hope Alive," "Now is the Time," "Trip Like I Do," 
"Vapor Trail," "She's My Pusher," "Cherry Twist," and "Comin' Back."

Next, Crystal Method will appear on a wall in Peoria and be instantly hailed as 
saints.

On Sun, 19 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:

> Hi Black Adder,
> 
>         Assuming that the zoning near the clubs was changed to allow
> residential units *after* the clubs had been operating, this action was
> effectively violating their property rights by creating (as you point out)
> a reasonable expectation of new tenants moving into a space zoned for
> dwelling, of "quiet enjoyment" of their property at 3am.  

Yay! We agree on something. :-)

> (Although there is a very strong argument to be made that someone moving
> into an apartment near, say, 11th and Folsom should have known what to
> expect.)

Perhaps they didn't. Perhaps they couldn't afford or find anything else.
Been apartment hunting lately? It is neither easy nor cheap. We could
engage in speculation all day, however I don't think that it is really the
issue. 

>         My view is that zoning is a violation of rights to begin with,
> because it is telling you what you can or cannot do on your own land.  The
> only thing that makes it remotely excusable is that it is already so built
> into the system that people have made all kinds of economic decisions based
> on existing zoning designations.
> 
>         Ideally, there would be no zoning, and I do believe it should be
> the responsibility of prospective tenants to investigate the neighborhood
> adequately before moving in.  This needn't involve going there at 3am to
> see if somebody's making noise, just asking a few neighbors.

Let's examine that line of reasoning for a second. By having no zoning, I
could open a concrete factory that ran 24 hours a day, or how about 
a garbage dump right next to your property and that would be ok with you
since it is after all my property?

Zoning laws, right or wrong(or however misapplied) exist for a reason, and
sometimes they are good reasons. I also feel that if many of you who are
railing about your rights to dance would quickly change your opinion if
you found yourselves unable to sleep at 3 a.m. due to noise.

hello folks

i just wanted to say thanks to everyone for this awesome wonderful time i
had at this party saturday night. sheesh, ive never partied in a dorm room
before, very weird

i dont know if i met many sfravers, i know i met a handful. who was that
guy that was chilling with me and adam on the roof waiting for the sunrise?
with the goatee, is he an sfraver? but i met very many cool people, sfraver
or not. all you guys are very very awesome

are your parties normally this good? i felt like a virgin raver again,
meeting all these new people and hearing all these different djs, put
together with that kick-ass vibe. i havent felt a party like this in a long
long time. ive been so lucky, everytime i come up to the city, i experience
a damned good party. usually its also when i start burning out on the la
scene, sf events always renew my faith in raving and make me feel a part of
a global raving family. you guys have such a tight scene, i hope you
realize that too and enjoy it just as much as i do

the music was freakin (damn, im running out of decent adjectives
here-insert one of your choosing). i especially loved the variety. and id
never seen a 2x4 on techno before, wow! i loved that video game that kept
playing on the visuals screens every once in a while, the one with two
characters battling each other with their dancing stylees. i thought it was
tekken or something, but then i noticed they were dancing instead of
whipping out combos at each other, it cracked me up! what is that game, is
it on playstation? i want it! someone please help me out and tell me

ethan kicked ass and was my favorite of the night. i heard that guy for the
first time last week at f-8 and i was hooked. so glad i got to hear him
again. andyw vs. c@weasel (is that who that was?) rocked. so did siphon.
and so did micron, most definitely. thats all the dj names i remember, but
i loved every bit of the music that entire night

man, i dont know what else to say. i have such love towards you guys and
your scene, i cant even describe it. im so lucky to have been a part of it
for that one night

the viberation crew had such heart in this event, you could tell, it made
the good time that much better. if only more crews had such great intents

i dont know when i can come back up, i think not till july for the harmony
5-year. i cant believe you guys got adam beyer to come, holy fuck! but i
cant wait until i can party with the sf kidz again. is anyone coming down
for elevation and dune here in socal? ill definitely be at those, hopefully
i can meet you there

anyway, have a good week everyone and i look forward to seeing you soon

joe

ps
i especially wanted to say thanks to micron who helped make sure that i got
in. i was really worried i wouldnt and i didnt want to travel 400 miles to
find id missed the party. and also my friend diane, but i dont think shes
on this list. oh well

> << 1015 is the nicest, friendliest, most laid-back meat market i've
ever 
> been to....>>

you

> seen, followed by a few drinks on your blouse by some other
cheezeball, 
> with some snide sexist remarks on the side to even out the whole

> day...just gimmie some slimy conversation with that Don Juan over
there 
> and enjoy the disco music at 1015, right?? :))

"and the messiah opens up with a sharp left jab" -> i've been on this
list for a long time, and recollection serves me, you post a lot of
reviews of nikita, which is at 1015, on friday night, right?  heck,
that's when the unsavory element is at it's peak.  does that mean you
secretly like such behavior?  i mean, you keep going back, if you
don't want to get hit on go to a rave instead...

just kidding, i don't want to pick a fight, really.  truth is, i don't
deny the slime element at 1015.  plus i know it's kinda different to
go there being a guy, women have told me they get pounced on pretty
bad.  i think it has a lot to do with what night you go, sundays,
mondays and wednesdays are _way_ more laid back than fridays and
saturdays.  plus, it also depends what room you're in, the front room
especially, and the main room to an extent, seem to be where most of
the ribbed t-shirt and gold chain types congregate.  i meet much
cooler people in the little side rooms.

i can understand your position, really.  you go cause you like the
music, but work too hard during the week to go on a tuesday night
instead of friday, right?  and to get to the cool rooms you have to
walk through massive crowds of scummy guido's.  believe me, i've
noticed their presence too, though for the most part they just ignore
me, for obvious reasons...

i guess what i was trying to say was, considering it's a meat market,
which it is, there does seem to be an element of pretty cool folx
there, even if they too are all trying to get laid...


-messiah

That game everyone keeps talking about is called Bust-a-Move: Rhythm and Dance.
Not that retarded Bubble-Bobble game.  It's called Bust-a-Move here but it's 
been
Bubble-Bobble in the arcades as well as in Japan.  DON'T CONFUSE THEM!
Anyway, it's a game that involves play mechanics similar to Parappa the Rapper,
where by pushing certain button combinations, your character puts out a dance 
move
instead of a phrase, a la Parappa.  Push buttons and joypad combinations to
execute dance moves.  Good stuff, huh?  If you're diggin' on that J-Pop dealio.
But from what I hear through these news sensitive holes, is that the company,
Enix, is looking to sign some big name techno bands for the American release.
There are about 10-15 characters, each with their own look, dance moves and 
music.
Secret characters are revealed after completing the game in certain ways and 
with
certain characters.

I should be able to get myself a copy soon, so those of that are interested, 
invite me
over so we can get down and funky.  I'll post the list once I get it.

Your Jedi Bitch,
Jedi666Boy

<<  you post a lot of reviews of nikita, which is at 1015, on friday 
night, right?  heck, that's when the unsavory element is at it's peak.

*actually*....I haven't been to nikita in over three or four months.. if 
that, and  I don't think i've posted more than 1 or two reviews....to be 
honest, YES, it's for the music, but it's still pretty slimy and i'd 
*MUCH* rather goto a rave than be in the element of "wanna-get-laid" 
slimyboys....;)  And, if my memory serves me correctly, fridays at 
nikita are *way* different from Saturdays...don't get me wrong -- both 
nites are very "clubby" and i have *nothing* against clubs per se, but 
it seems to me that the "slime factor" might be wee bit worse on 
Saturdays :)  

and just for the record, no, i don't secretly enjoy such behavior... 
sorry to disappoint :)  And no, i don't keep going back , either....like 
i said, i haven't been there in months and prolly won't return unless 
like Paul Van dyk is there or somethin; :)  Nothing against the club

arrested at work- handcuffed and taken down to INS.  They tried to deport him
yesterday without even getting the chance to go home and get any of his
things.

in Oakland waiting deportation (probably not until tomorrow)

housemate is ludicrous. does he have his green card? there must be
more to the situation than what you've written. i've been given hell
from the ins as has my husband, but he has never been carted off to
jail. if he got his green card and went through the proper channels
when he got married he ought to have the necessary documentation to
get himself out. however if he hasn't played by bureaucracy's rules,
he might have some problems. one thing i've learned is to save
everything - all paper work - everything. have documentation of every
step of the way and they can't touch you. anyway i can get you the
name of a lawyer if you need one - it sounds like you might.

>don't want to get hit on go to a rave instead...

>go there being a guy, women have told me they get pounced on pretty
>bad.  i think it has a lot to do with what night you go, sundays,
>mondays and wednesdays are _way_ more laid back than fridays and
>saturdays.  plus, it also depends what room you're in, the front room
>especially, and the main room to an extent, seem to be where most of
>the ribbed t-shirt and gold chain types congregate.  i meet much
>cooler people in the little side rooms.
>
>i can understand your position, really.  you go cause you like the
>music, but work too hard during the week to go on a tuesday night
>instead of friday, right?  and to get to the cool rooms you have to
>walk through massive crowds of scummy guido's.  believe me, i've
>noticed their presence too, though for the most part they just ignore
>me, for obvious reasons...
>

Rick wrote:

> That game everyone keeps talking about is called Bust-a-Move: Rhythm and Dance.
> Not that retarded Bubble-Bobble game.  It's called Bust-a-Move here but it's
> been
> Bubble-Bobble in the arcades as well as in Japan.  DON'T CONFUSE THEM!
> Anyway, it's a game that involves play mechanics similar to Parappa the Rapper,
> where by pushing certain button combinations, your character puts out a dance
> move
> instead of a phrase, a la Parappa.  Push buttons and joypad combinations to
> execute dance moves.  Good stuff, huh?  If you're diggin' on that J-Pop dealio.
> But from what I hear through these news sensitive holes, is that the company,
> Enix, is looking to sign some big name techno bands for the American release.
> There are about 10-15 characters, each with their own look, dance moves and
> music.
> Secret characters are revealed after completing the game in certain ways and
> with
> certain characters.
>
> I should be able to get myself a copy soon, so those of that are interested,
> invite me
> over so we can get down and funky.  I'll post the list once I get it.

There were four people named Everybody, Somebody,
Anybody, and Nobody.  There was an important job that 
had to be done and Everybody was asked to do it.
Everybody was sure Somebody would do it.  Anybody
could have done it, but Nobody did it.  Somebody got
angry about that, because it was Everybody's job.  
Everybody thought that Anybody could do it but Nobody
realized that Everybody wouldn't do it.  It ended up that
Everybody blamed Somebody when Nobody did what
Anybody could have done.


Man, doesn't it suck when that happens.  Hope ya'll had a good day.

Drekster

unknown.

hello everyone,

i'm sending this out in hopes that some altruistic, musical soul will
answer my call for help...

i need a DJ who is willing to volunteer their time and sound equipment
this friday, april 24, for a very good cause.

i have been volunteering to organize a volunteer appreciation party for
the bay area chapter of the NAMES Project for the AIDS memorial quilt to
be held this friday.  it's an event to appreciate its volunteers during
volunteer appreciation week.  its a smallish affair, more of a social
mixer, and it's being held at the Foundation offices on townsend; about
75-80 people are expected, max.

i have everything is set to go, except that the person i had lined to
DJ,
just flaked on me. i could scream! (in fact, i think i did, but it's all
a
blur...:) 

so, if anybody knows of someone who is willing to donate their DJ
services and sound equipment, i would be one very happy, thankful and
relieved puppy. it's for a good cause and it's only for 3 hours. 

not feeling altruistic? well, you get free food, a free bottle of clos
du
bois,and you can get a tax write-off for the value of the services
donated
to the event. also, you could make lots of friends! (some of the
volunteers are very cute....;) 

i'd greatly appreciate any help and/or leads.

crossing her nail-bitten fingers,
lilia.

-->Hello everybody...it's me again,

	Directions to mi casa are as follows: Take all alternate routes to
the 580 WEST...since many of you will be heading north from say berkeley
or oakland or from the peninsula, just go as if you were going to a sunset
at Pointe Molate.  You want to stay on the left two lanes to get to the
580-W heading towards SAN RAFAEL; there is construction at the 580/80
interchange so be careful not to miss it. You want to take the MARINA BAY
PARKWAY/ South 23rd street exit...they switch names, but the exit before
mine is Regatta Blvd so keep an eye out. You want to make a left from the
offramp, which will put you on Marina Bay Parkway.  You will pass three
signals (you will cross Railroad tracks...if there is a train you will
have to wait for it to pass; I know of no alternate route to my complex). 
When you see the sign "The Beach" slow down; MY COMPLEX IS "THE SHORES"
which is after "The Beach". Turn right into "The Shores" which will place
you onto SHORELINE COURT...make an immediate left.  Call me at 071 at the
box and I will buzz open the gate. The road will curve right and my apt.
is #62 on the second floor on the right hand side at the first curve. 
Apparently there are two #62's in proximity, but open your ears...you
should be able to hear the music. Park in any UNCOVERED parking space
available. It's not that complicated, but I don't want anyone to get lost.
My address is:

62 Shoreline Court
Richmond, CA 94804
(510) 234-9038


	The party will start at 3PM and there will be DJ's...not sure who
yet; it's open tables so SURPRISE! :) It's a mellow party but it will go
on rain or shine; if the BBQ gets flooded I have a fireplace and
marshmallows at your service :O


See you Friday!
:)
M&m


PS	In case you end up at a different #62, I have a green astroturf
doormat with a white plastic daisy on it :) Kitsch baby!



From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 22 07:06:12 1998
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 1831 invoked by uid 6000); 22 Apr 1998 07:06:11 -0000
Received: (qmail 1818 invoked from network); 22 Apr 1998 07:06:09 -0000
Received: from relay-0.ziplink.net (HELO ziplink.net) (206.15.168.49)
  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 22 Apr 1998 07:06:09 -0000
Received: from [208.196.121.73] (sf-ip-2-10.ziplink.net [208.196.121.10])
	by ziplink.net (8.8.7/8.8.7) with SMTP id DAA05523;
	Wed, 22 Apr 1998 03:05:59 -0400 (EDT)
X-Sender: dreamer@pop3.ziplink.net
Message-Id: <v01530504b163452e9caa@[208.196.121.73]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 22 Apr 1998 00:12:53 -0800
To: <blkadder@value.net>
From: dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild)
Subject: NRR: zoning, etc. (was: Another strike against dancing)
Cc: *Rave Friends* <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Adder,

Our conversation to date, interspersed with new commentary by yours truly:

>On Sun, 19 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:
>
>> Hi Black Adder,
>>
>>         Assuming that the zoning near the clubs was changed to allow
>> residential units *after* the clubs had been operating, this action was
>> effectively violating their property rights by creating (as you point out)
>> a reasonable expectation of new tenants moving into a space zoned for
>> dwelling, of "quiet enjoyment" of their property at 3am.
>
>Yay! We agree on something. :-)

        Ah, come on Adder, I often agree with you, if only to avoid the
poignant sting of your oft-indulged sarcasm, wit, and dismissive remarks.
8)

>> (Although there is a very strong argument to be made that someone moving
>> into an apartment near, say, 11th and Folsom should have known what to
>> expect.)
>
>Perhaps they didn't. Perhaps they couldn't afford or find anything else.
>Been apartment hunting lately? It is neither easy nor cheap. We could
>engage in speculation all day, however I don't think that it is really the
>issue.
>
>>         My view is that zoning is a violation of rights to begin with,
>> because it is telling you what you can or cannot do on your own land.  The
>> only thing that makes it remotely excusable is that it is already so built
>> into the system that people have made all kinds of economic decisions based
>> on existing zoning designations.
>>
>>         Ideally, there would be no zoning, and I do believe it should be
>> the responsibility of prospective tenants to investigate the neighborhood
>> adequately before moving in.  This needn't involve going there at 3am to
>> see if somebody's making noise, just asking a few neighbors.
>
>Let's examine that line of reasoning for a second. By having no zoning, I
>could open a concrete factory that ran 24 hours a day, or how about
>a garbage dump right next to your property and that would be ok with you
>since it is after all my property?

        There is an alternative to zoning; it is called common sense.  If
you're opening a business, you don't want to piss off all your neighbors,
and you're going to try to reach reasonable accomodations with people.
Furthermore, your examples are quite extreme.  I would venture to say that
99% of what people want to do with their property that is prohibited by
zoning would have less of a negative impact on their neighbors than opening
a garbage dump or concrete factory in a residential area.

        In the few cases where someone actually went ahead and did
something like this, they could always be taken to court.  Subjecting you
to regular doses of loud noise or foul stench that did not exist when you
moved into your property could definitely be considered a violation of your
property rights, and I think most judges and juries would be inclined to
look favorably on the plaintiff in such a case.

>Zoning laws, right or wrong(or however misapplied) exist for a reason, and
>sometimes they are good reasons.

        There is almost always a good intention behind every additional
measure of power and control exerted by government.  Very often new laws
are invoked as necessary to correct problems caused by previous state
interventions!  You say that housing in San Francisco is scarce and
expensive, therefore people cannot be expected to turn down decent living
places just because of a little late-night noise.  Instead, you seem to
imply, they should move in and then pretend they weren't aware of the
problem beforehand in order to press neighborhood businesses to change in
order to accomodate them.

        While I don't agree with this as a justification either for zoning
or for shutting down existing clubs, I admit that housing here is indeed
pricey and hard to find.  Yet scarce and unaffordable housing is itself a
problem created by other laws!  Homes have become increasingly unaffordable
over the past few decades, and it's largely due to developments such as
increased rent control, building permits, building codes, taxes and fees on
new development, etc.

        To simplify the model:  The more laws you have, the more fucked up
things get, and the more laws you "need" to fix things and make them right
again.

I also feel that if many of you who are
>railing about your rights to dance would quickly change your opinion if
>you found yourselves unable to sleep at 3 a.m. due to noise.

        Usually when I'm unable to sleep it's because of emergency
vehicles, car alarms, and public works crews who seem to enjoy tearing up
the pavement near my apartment with jackhammers before 8 o'clock in the
morning.  I've found these to be much worse insomniants (wordcheck?) than
the steady, low pitch thud-thud-thud of a sound system.

        Certainly emergency vehicles, if not the other items are recognized
as a necessary public good.  But why cannot raves be similarly recognized?
Surely the amount of happiness that is created is worth something to the
community.  I don't believe the few should be sacrificed for the good of
the many, but in a moral grey area such as we seem to have with the SOMA
neighbors-club dispute, the happiness of hundreds ought to count for at
least as much as the undisturbed sleep of one or two, wouldn't you say?

Much love,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Wed, 22 Apr 1998 01:15:29 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID: <353E4FEB.8B31F47B@geocities.com>

From: Paul Hayden <goodvibe@geocities.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.04 [en]C-DIAL  (Win95; U)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: THE GREAT EXPERIMENT

Here's the Question:

Can millions of people, focusing their minds on inner and world peace,
heal the world in an instant?

Can we, through scientific and quantifiable means, prove that we are
indeed the creators of the world we perceive, and that by changing our
perception, the world itself changes?


             This is "The Great Experiment."


It's time we prove scientifically what the saints and sages have
always told us- that we are powerful spiritual beings with the ability
to create a world based on the laws of love, instead of the rules of
fear. 

Two months ago, James Twyman, author of the bestselling book,
"Emissary of Light," was invited by the government of Iraq to perform
his "Peace concert" in Baghdad. The situation seemed desparate war
seemed almost inevitable and diplomatic efforts seemed to have failed.

"I was being used by the Iraqi government," Twyman said. "But we had
the same goal: to avoid this terrible war. I was given permission to
sing the Muslim prayer for peace to Saddam Hussein and I wanted the
world to join us in this prayer. Hundreds of thousands of people over
the world participated, and when it was complete, I felt a profound
shift in the energy of that whole region. Three days later, a peace
agreement was signed, something which seemed impossible before the
prayer vigil began."


             But The Story Continues . . .


"A week later, I was invited by the government of Northern Ireland to
sing at Stormout Castle in Belfast - the building where the peace talks
were being held. For days, bombs were exploding all around that area.
Many people were trying to interrupt the peace process and it seemed
like the talks might fall apart. Once again, thousands around the
world joined us in prayer, and three days later there was a
breakthrough in the talks. April 12, 1998, a peace accord was reached.

The evidence is there - we do have the power within us to change the
world. Scientists have measured the statistically significant effect
that focused meditations and events have upon the earth's energy
field. These effects were measured during the GaiaMind Meditation and
during Princess Diana's funeral. The studies show that the greatest
effects occur when groups synchronize their focus. During "The Great
Experiment," we will meditate upon specific affirmations in unison to
achieve the power of a singular group focus.

                 NOW IT IS TIME TO PUT INTO PRACTICE 
                   WHAT WE ALREADY KNOW TO BE TRUE:

"If enough people join their minds and hearts for peace, we can heal
the world."

"The Great Experiment" will take place on April 23rd at 6:30 PM
Eastern Daylight Savings Time ( This would be 10:30 PM GMT ) Please
mark your calendars now, and tell everyone that you know to join with
us.

James Twyman has been invited to sing the peace prayers from the
twelve major religions at the United Nations building in New York on
April 23rd. This presents an unparalleled opportunity for us all. Dr.
Doreen Virtue, best-selling author of The Lightworker's Way, and Gregg
Braden, geologist and author of Awakening to Zero Point and Walking
Between the Worlds, join James in conducting this incredible
experiment. Authors, entertainers, and other celebrities, will
participate by sharing their vision of "a world transformed by love."

Here's how you can participate:

1. Tell everyone you know. Share this with everyone on your mailing
list so that everyone can participate. Feel free to print this out and
make copies. The goal is to get as many people as possible focused on
this meditation.

2. Begin preparing your spirit and mind for the event by spending a
few moments in silence everyday. This will help build the energy.

3. Join at least one other person for the vigil on April 23rd. This is
an experience to share. "Where two or more are gathered."

The Format of the Meditation:

1. Opening:

Begin with this affirmation, said with great power and committment:

     I am an Emissary of Light. I extend this Light to all beings, in
compassion and love, knowing that they are one within me. this
moment the world is healed - and I along with it. I will it - and
it is so.

2. Then spend five minutes creating a sound (such as "Om") to carry
the spiritual energy and vibration. This can be done with a single
tone or by singing a song such as "Amazing Grace."

3. Spend five minutes in silence allowing your spirit to receive the
light and love which you yourself extended to the world.

4. End with this prayer:

     "It is done! I am one with all - and all is healed. Let love
reign where fear once was. I accept this for myself and for the
world. I am an Emissary of Light now and always. Amen"

Then, with reverence, bow your head and thank God for this grand
opportunity. The universe gives thanks to you for being part of this
great experiment.

If you have any questions regarding this Great Experiment, 
please write:       TheGreatExperiment@CreatePeace.com

Also please visit the website for the latest
updates:                          
                 http://www.CreatePeace.com

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 22 08:32:31 1998
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
