	by imo11.mx.aol.com (IMOv14.1) id IFGa018926
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Wed, 22 Apr 1998 04:31:56 -0400 (EDT)
From: Just a K1D <JustaK1D@aol.com>
Message-ID: <138e6649.353daafe@aol.com>
Date: Wed, 22 Apr 1998 04:31:56 EDT
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Mime-Version: 1.0
Subject: NRR: a warning to people who enjoy camping
Content-type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-transfer-encoding: 7bit
X-Mailer: AOL 3.0 16-bit for Windows sub 41
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, so, where would be the MOST perfect place to celebrate 420??  Well me
and some of my friends decided that we would like to go out to the woods and
camp all night at some beautiful spot, celbrate all night, and play some drums
and guitars and just mellow back with some beers (& tequila & goldschlager &
jegermeister &etc.) & of course, pot.  So we got there at this gorgeous spot,
a camping ground in the Santa Clara county, around 2 in the afternoon.  we set
our tents and just chilled waitng for that magical time.  When it arrived, we
hiked to Ga(ru)nja Falls and had a great minute.  Anyway.  Back to the WARNING
<> WARNING <> WARNING!!!  We told Mr. RAnger dude that we were kicken it all
night, not sure how many cars were going to be there, but fully intending to
pay for all those that showed up.  We had the camping grounds to ourselves.
Absolutely noone was on the camp grounds but us.  It was hell of cool.

Well, a few hours later, more cars showed up.  4 to be exact, there were 11 of
us kicken.  The Ranger dude shows up at 9:30 pm.  He says:  I smell alcohol.
Is anyone here over 21?  <we all stared dumbly at him> Okay :he says: I'll be
back in a minute <we all scramble to hide out liquer and beer>  He comes back
and tells us we are busted, makes us all give him our ID's, he runs us through
the scanner and all that BS.  comes back again and says: you all are in
serious trouble, you are all underage.  You are lucky noone here was over 21
becasue he/she would have been arrested for contributing to the delinquency of
minors.  I have backup coming up here, they will be here in a minute.  Get all
yoour alcohol out and gather it right here.  <so we all scramble, gather the
alcohol, hide the pot and pipes and bongs and such>  Mr Ranger dude #2 shows
up.  He says: Is anyone here sober enough to drive?  me and this (16 year old)
boy (who just got his liscence which is still a piece of paper) step up and
say we are.  SO I have to take a breathalizer test.  Damn! I almost ran outta
breath!  So, 4 cars, 2 sober drivers, 11 people.  Hmm.....  So we broke down
camp (by force) and packed up with me and the 16 yr old driving.  

Mr Ranger dude #1 & #2 made us have a nice long talk at the entrance.  They
said we are lucky.  We were the first people of the season to get caught
drinking illegally on the premesis so we would get let go with a warning.
But!!!  Because he had all our ID's, if we get caught again doing something
wrong in a county park we will get arrested and our liscences taken away.
Ranger dude #2 said he can write us a ticket anytime in the next YEAR period
of time for what we did that night. He told us to tell evryone we new what was
up.  They said they weren't going to let anyone else go.

<Then I had to drive back to town, call people who were sober and bring them
back to the campt site so we could get everyone and there cars home.>  that's
how my story ends.

so the warnings go as such...

1. Do not drink in a county park unless you are over 21, and everyone with you
is over 21.

2. Make sure you have enough sober drivers for cars.

3. Do not exceed the number of cars per site (we were only supposed to have 2
per site, but we were going to go back and get another site. no, really!)

4.  If you choose to drink, make sure you scout out good places to hide you
stash BEFORE the rangers come up to fuck with you.

Hope you all had a HAPPY 420 DAY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!

Ms. K1dd

Please READ this!!! It is VERY IMPORTANT!!!
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here's the Question:

Can millions of people, focusing their minds on inner and world peace,
heal the world in an instant?

Can we, through scientific and quantifiable means, prove that we are
indeed the creators of the world we perceive, and that by changing our
perception, the world itself changes?


             This is "The Great Experiment."


It's time we prove scientifically what the saints and sages have
always told us- that we are powerful spiritual beings with the ability
to create a world based on the laws of love, instead of the rules of
fear. 

Two months ago, James Twyman, author of the bestselling book,
"Emissary of Light," was invited by the government of Iraq to perform
his "Peace concert" in Baghdad. The situation seemed desparate war
seemed almost inevitable and diplomatic efforts seemed to have failed.

"I was being used by the Iraqi government," Twyman said. "But we had
the same goal: to avoid this terrible war. I was given permission to
sing the Muslim prayer for peace to Saddam Hussein and I wanted the
world to join us in this prayer. Hundreds of thousands of people over
the world participated, and when it was complete, I felt a profound

prayer vigil began."

"A week later, I was invited by the government of Northern Ireland to
sing at Stormout Castle in Belfast - the building where the peace talks
were being held. For days, bombs were exploding all around that area.
Many people were trying to interrupt the peace process and it seemed
like the talks might fall apart. Once again, thousands around the

The evidence is there - we do have the power within us to change the

                 NOW IT IS TIME TO PUT INTO PRACTICE 
                   WHAT WE ALREADY KNOW TO BE TRUE:

the world."

Eastern Daylight Savings Time ( This would be 10:30 PM GMT ) Please
mark your calendars now, and tell everyone that you know to join with
us.

James Twyman has been invited to sing the peace prayers from the
twelve major religions at the United Nations building in New York on
April 23rd. This presents an unparalleled opportunity for us all. Dr.
Doreen Virtue, best-selling author of The Lightworker's Way, and Gregg
Braden, geologist and author of Awakening to Zero Point and Walking
Between the Worlds, join James in conducting this incredible
experiment. Authors, entertainers, and other celebrities, will
participate by sharing their vision of "a world transformed by love."

Here's how you can participate:

1. Tell everyone you know. Share this with everyone on your mailing
list so that everyone can participate. Feel free to print this out and
make copies. The goal is to get as many people as possible focused on
this meditation.

2. Begin preparing your spirit and mind for the event by spending a
few moments in silence everyday. This will help build the energy.

3. Join at least one other person for the vigil on April 23rd. This is
an experience to share. "Where two or more are gathered."

The Format of the Meditation:

1. Opening:

Begin with this affirmation, said with great power and committment:

     I am an Emissary of Light. I extend this Light to all beings, in
compassion and love, knowing that they are one within me. this
moment the world is healed - and I along with it. I will it - and
it is so.

2. Then spend five minutes creating a sound (such as "Om") to carry
the spiritual energy and vibration. This can be done with a single
tone or by singing a song such as "Amazing Grace."

3. Spend five minutes in silence allowing your spirit to receive the
light and love which you yourself extended to the world.

4. End with this prayer:

     "It is done! I am one with all - and all is healed. Let love
reign where fear once was. I accept this for myself and for the
world. I am an Emissary of Light now and always. Amen"

Then, with reverence, bow your head and thank God for this grand
opportunity. The universe gives thanks to you for being part of this
great experiment.

If you have any questions regarding this Great Experiment, 
please write:       TheGreatExperiment@CreatePeace.com

Also please visit the website for the latest
updates:                          
                 http://www.CreatePeace.com

I've been reading a lot about how the mind works recently, especially
about a neat model of the mind called NLP. I just finished a very good
NLP book tonight which had a section on how to re-experience drug states.
the book basically gave step-by-step instructions for how to bring back
any previously experienced drug state.

so I tried it. BAM. I was high. then I just turned it off and I wasn't
high anymore. it was unbelievable. for one thing, just being high was fun.
(I mean, it usually is.) but also, if you've ever had one of those
mind-expanding experiences where you notice new possibilities, you might
know what it felt like. you just experience a really exciting sense of
possibility doing this, because you realize your high is completely up to
you.

now, here's the thing. I want to get good at this stuff. teaching people
how to do it themselves is one way to get good, so I'm wondering: would
anyone be interested in learning how to do this? If you are, grab me at a
party if I'm there (I have a green A's hat which is practically glued to
my head, I wear it so often) or e-mail me offlist. (I get the digest, and
I don't always read the whole thing 'cause the volume's so high.)

                                                      { bowkettdotcom
                                                      {
                                                      { ooh, mama
                                                      {

Here's one for ya. I got busted for mountain biking in Alum Rock Park
(not even real bikin- I was just bored). I got the cops and the whole bit.
They didn't post when the park was going to reopen and it had been like
2 and a half weeks. The sign said closed due to storm damage. There were
even people walkin down there. Did they get busted no.

The "law" is subjective. Civil disobedience was in order. From
my experinces climbing for 10 years. I've gotten to know a few park
rangers from Joshua Tree to American Fork (Salt Lake). They're serious
dudeskis/dudedalas with nothing else to do. In your case, you're definately
lucky. I've seen em cuff and stuff people. Let the baseheads steal shit and let's
harass all the climbers... it seems to be their fav theme. But I shouldn't bag on
em too much cause they helped me rescue this one girl who was really badly
injured in an isolated area (due to her own stupidity). So they are okay some...
(as was the case with you) but most are just silly. I guess sitting out in an
isolated
area can do that to a person. Oh well...

N

Just a K1D wrote:

> Well, so, where would be the MOST perfect place to celebrate 420??  Well me
> and some of my friends decided that we would like to go out to the woods and
> camp all night at some beautiful spot, celbrate all night, and play some drums
> and guitars and just mellow back with some beers (& tequila & goldschlager &
> jegermeister &etc.) & of course, pot.  So we got there at this gorgeous spot,
> a camping ground in the Santa Clara county, around 2 in the afternoon.  we set
> our tents and just chilled waitng for that magical time.  When it arrived, we
> hiked to Ga(ru)nja Falls and had a great minute.  Anyway.  Back to the WARNING
> <> WARNING <> WARNING!!!  We told Mr. RAnger dude that we were kicken it all
> night, not sure how many cars were going to be there, but fully intending to
> pay for all those that showed up.  We had the camping grounds to ourselves.
> Absolutely noone was on the camp grounds but us.  It was hell of cool.
>
> Well, a few hours later, more cars showed up.  4 to be exact, there were 11 of
> us kicken.  The Ranger dude shows up at 9:30 pm.  He says:  I smell alcohol.
> Is anyone here over 21?  <we all stared dumbly at him> Okay :he says: I'll be
> back in a minute <we all scramble to hide out liquer and beer>  He comes back
> and tells us we are busted, makes us all give him our ID's, he runs us through
> the scanner and all that BS.  comes back again and says: you all are in
> serious trouble, you are all underage.  You are lucky noone here was over 21
> becasue he/she would have been arrested for contributing to the delinquency of
> minors.  I have backup coming up here, they will be here in a minute.  Get all
> yoour alcohol out and gather it right here.  <so we all scramble, gather the
> alcohol, hide the pot and pipes and bongs and such>  Mr Ranger dude #2 shows
> up.  He says: Is anyone here sober enough to drive?  me and this (16 year old)
> boy (who just got his liscence which is still a piece of paper) step up and
> say we are.  SO I have to take a breathalizer test.  Damn! I almost ran outta
> breath!  So, 4 cars, 2 sober drivers, 11 people.  Hmm.....  So we broke down
> camp (by force) and packed up with me and the 16 yr old driving.
>
> Mr Ranger dude #1 & #2 made us have a nice long talk at the entrance.  They
> said we are lucky.  We were the first people of the season to get caught
> drinking illegally on the premesis so we would get let go with a warning.
> But!!!  Because he had all our ID's, if we get caught again doing something
> wrong in a county park we will get arrested and our liscences taken away.
> Ranger dude #2 said he can write us a ticket anytime in the next YEAR period
> of time for what we did that night. He told us to tell evryone we new what was
> up.  They said they weren't going to let anyone else go.
>
> <Then I had to drive back to town, call people who were sober and bring them
> back to the campt site so we could get everyone and there cars home.>  that's
> how my story ends.
>
> so the warnings go as such...
>
> 1. Do not drink in a county park unless you are over 21, and everyone with you
> is over 21.
>
> 2. Make sure you have enough sober drivers for cars.
>
> 3. Do not exceed the number of cars per site (we were only supposed to have 2
> per site, but we were going to go back and get another site. no, really!)
>
> 4.  If you choose to drink, make sure you scout out good places to hide you
> stash BEFORE the rangers come up to fuck with you.
>
> Hope you all had a HAPPY 420 DAY!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
>
> Ms. K1dd

Just a quick word on zoning...

The reason zoning ever existed is because of the health crises and
overcrowding of  modern cities. Without it, people lived in overcrowded
conditons, near garbage dumps, etc., etc. New York City's government
finally in the late 1890's-early part of theis century (my dates are
probably wrong-i can not entirely wrong) had to impose zoning to force
developers to stop forcing people like rats in a lab experiment in
unsafe tenements in unsafe areas.  Yes, zoning is frequently used today
to protect other experiment but to say people won't build bad housing
because of common sense is forgetting the power of people's greed.  Go
to a city that grew fast without zoning like Houston  and you will see
huge skyscrapers on lots smack in the middle of a small residential
neighborood with nothing else around it to support the office poeple in
them and of course, they are frequently empty but the people around them
have to live it.  Zoning is a good practical thing and like everything,
it can be turned into a politcal tool.  But for all intents and
purposes, it does more good then harm.  

my 1.00 (adjusted for inflation),

Cassandra

> for

> >
> >Yay! We agree on something. :-)
> 
>         Ah, come on Adder, I often agree with you, if only to avoid
> the
> poignant sting of your oft-indulged sarcasm, wit, and dismissive
> remarks.
> 8)
> 
> >> (Although there is a very strong argument to be made that someone
> moving
> >> into an apartment near, say, 11th and Folsom should have known what
> to
> >> expect.)
> >
> >Perhaps they didn't. Perhaps they couldn't afford or find anything
> else.
> >Been apartment hunting lately? It is neither easy nor cheap. We could
> >engage in speculation all day, however I don't think that it is
> really the
> >issue.
> >
> >>         My view is that zoning is a violation of rights to begin
> with,
> >> because it is telling you what you can or cannot do on your own
> land.  The
> >> only thing that makes it remotely excusable is that it is already
> so built
> >> into the system that people have made all kinds of economic
> decisions based
> >> on existing zoning designations.
> >>
> >>         Ideally, there would be no zoning, and I do believe it
> should be
> >> the responsibility of prospective tenants to investigate the
> neighborhood
> >> adequately before moving in.  This needn't involve going there at
> 3am to
> >> see if somebody's making noise, just asking a few neighbors.
> >
> >Let's examine that line of reasoning for a second. By having no
> zoning, I
> >could open a concrete factory that ran 24 hours a day, or how about
> >a garbage dump right next to your property and that would be ok with
> you
> >since it is after all my property?
> 
>         There is an alternative to zoning; it is called common sense.
> If
> you're opening a business, you don't want to piss off all your
> neighbors,
> and you're going to try to reach reasonable accomodations with people.
> Furthermore, your examples are quite extreme.  I would venture to say
> that
> 99% of what people want to do with their property that is prohibited
> by
> zoning would have less of a negative impact on their neighbors than
> opening
> a garbage dump or concrete factory in a residential area.
> 
>         In the few cases where someone actually went ahead and did
> something like this, they could always be taken to court.  Subjecting
> you
> to regular doses of loud noise or foul stench that did not exist when
> you
> moved into your property could definitely be considered a violation of
> your
> property rights, and I think most judges and juries would be inclined
> to
> look favorably on the plaintiff in such a case.
> 
> >Zoning laws, right or wrong(or however misapplied) exist for a
> reason, and
> >sometimes they are good reasons.
> 
>         There is almost always a good intention behind every
> additional
> measure of power and control exerted by government.  Very often new
> laws
> are invoked as necessary to correct problems caused by previous state
> interventions!  You say that housing in San Francisco is scarce and
> expensive, therefore people cannot be expected to turn down decent
> living
> places just because of a little late-night noise.  Instead, you seem
> to
> imply, they should move in and then pretend they weren't aware of the
> problem beforehand in order to press neighborhood businesses to change
> in
> order to accomodate them.
> 
>         While I don't agree with this as a justification either for
> zoning
> or for shutting down existing clubs, I admit that housing here is
> indeed
> pricey and hard to find.  Yet scarce and unaffordable housing is
> itself a
> problem created by other laws!  Homes have become increasingly
> unaffordable
> over the past few decades, and it's largely due to developments such
> as
> increased rent control, building permits, building codes, taxes and
> fees on
> new development, etc.
> 
>         To simplify the model:  The more laws you have, the more
> fucked up
> things get, and the more laws you "need" to fix things and make them
> right
> again.
> 
> I also feel that if many of you who are
> >railing about your rights to dance would quickly change your opinion
> if
> >you found yourselves unable to sleep at 3 a.m. due to noise.
> 
>         Usually when I'm unable to sleep it's because of emergency
> vehicles, car alarms, and public works crews who seem to enjoy tearing
> up
> the pavement near my apartment with jackhammers before 8 o'clock in
> the
> morning.  I've found these to be much worse insomniants (wordcheck?)
> than
> the steady, low pitch thud-thud-thud of a sound system.
> 
>         Certainly emergency vehicles, if not the other items are
> recognized
> as a necessary public good.  But why cannot raves be similarly
> recognized?
> Surely the amount of happiness that is created is worth something to
> the
> community.  I don't believe the few should be sacrificed for the good
> of
> the many, but in a moral grey area such as we seem to have with the
> SOMA
> neighbors-club dispute, the happiness of hundreds ought to count for
> at
> least as much as the undisturbed sleep of one or two, wouldn't you
> say?
> 
> Much love,
>                                 <<< Starchild >>>
> 
>

have a really groovacios Kamp.

hospital- got it?  just look for a group of funky lookin' people

freeway, then make a left on Kiely, it's like the second light,
and follow Kiely down until you see the park on the left, i believe.

see you there!

heres another helpful story since we are passing out good advice
today:


A foursome was on the last hole and when the last golfer drove off
the tee he hooked into a cow pasture. He advised his friends to play
through and he would meet them at the clubhouse. They followed the
plan and waited for their friend.

After a considerable time he appeared disheveled, bloody, and
badly beaten up. They all wanted to know what happened.

He explained that he went over to the cow pasture but could not find
his ball. He noticed a cow wringing her tail in obvious pain. He went
over and lifted her tail and saw a golf ball solidly embedded. It was
a yellow ball so he knew it was not his.

A woman comes out of the bushes apparently searching for her lost
golf ball. The helpful male golfer lifted the cow's tail and asked,
"Does this look like yours?"

That was the last thing he could remember.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

Burning Man Beach Burn 

                    Saturday, April 25th, 8pm 

 Join us every last Saturday of the month as we build up to the desert
burn.
  Bring drums, instruments, yourself and something for the fire.
Location,
    Ocean Beach, San Francisco. For exact stairwell tune into the Jack
           Rabbit, or email the firegoddess: Crimson Rose. 

  If you are interested in tending the fire at Burning Man 1998, joining
the performers for our Saturday night event, or leading the procession
to the Man on Sunday please see Crimson at the beach burn or if unable
to attend, contact: Crimson Rose. 

          Become a member of THE NEBULOUS ENTITY!

more helpful advice when dealing with police and how to raise
funds if you dont have enough money for that party.:

>A woman gets pulled over for speeding by a California Highway Patrol
>motorcycle officer. When he walked up to her window and opened his
>ticket book she said, "I bet you're going to sell me tickets to the
>Highway Patrol Ball. He replied, "No, highway patrolmen don't have
>balls." There followed a moment of  silence while she smiled and he
>realized what he had said. He then closed his book, got back on his
>motorcycle and left.
>**********
>A police officer had a perfect hiding place for watching speeders. But
>one day, everyone was under the speed limit, and the officer found the
>reason for it. A ten year old boy was standing on the side of the road
>with a huge hand painted sign which said: "RADAR TRAP AHEAD."  A little
>more investigation work led the officer to the boy's accomplice. Another

>ten year old boy about 100 yards beyond the radar trap with sign
>reading:"TIPS" and a bucket at his feet, full of change.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

It's taking me all day to get the body work done and deal with the car
insurance boneheads.

Talk about bad car karma, now my horn honks whenever I make a left turn!!!!!
And for the past week, my damn turn signal goes on whenever I put on the
breaks!!!!

Oh god!!!!  this is getting so redicilous that it's funny.  Ofcourse,
everything in my life is like that.
I guesss this is what I get for buying a 67 squareback.

Hey Elena, sorry if my car karma rubbed off on you at afterglo.  You can have
my Ferrari liscence plate cover to make up for it.

I think I'm going to go hook kick some of my student's heads off to relieve
some frustration.

Hipity Hoppity Frogboix missing his afternoon meal :-(

ok just have to pipe in-
maybe its just me but seems the size and attitude of the police have
changed over
last few yrs.
it used to be 'alright you kids, poor those drinks out and get the hell
out of there, this is private property' etc.  and that was it.  it didnt
seem like
their *goal* was to make a bust, just to sorta keep things in order.  i
dont know
how many parties, campingtrips, nights out, etc., would have landed us all
in jail
if cops  had the attitude they do today.  the attitude used to be 'yeah i was
young once, i like to have fun too, you just cant do it HERE, or if I get
another complaint.., etc.
Now its like a contest or a hunt 'hey look here Mel, caught me real good one!'
there are still resonable cops, but in some cities, san jose for instance, i
dont know if they were over-funded or what, but there are simmply too many cops
and not enough crime to go around between them, so you end up with bored cops
looking for bust. and if you look different/wierd, forget it.  in sf ill
see someone
driving wrong way down 1way street at night with lights off and nothing happens.
in san jose, you double-park for 30sec while your friend grabs a tape for
you (this happened to me) and 3 cars swoop on the scene ready to arrest you.
'is this, uh your vehicle, are you sure??? ever been arrested?'  the best was
few weeks back, we were pulled over due to 'the illegal ornament hanging from
rear-view mirror'.  it was a plaque.  i got full drunk test + breathalizer
and passed,
yet they still didnt want me to drive the remaining 3 blocks to my house.
yikes...
marc

>Here's one for ya. I got busted for mountain biking in Alum Rock Park
>(not even real bikin- I was just bored). I got the cops and the whole bit.
>They didn't post when the park was going to reopen and it had been like
>2 and a half weeks. The sign said closed due to storm damage. There were
>even people walkin down there. Did they get busted no.>
>
>The "law" is subjective. Civil disobedience was in order. From
>my experinces climbing for 10 years. I've gotten to know a few park
>rangers from Joshua Tree to American Fork (Salt Lake). They're serious
>dudeskis/dudedalas with nothing else to do. In your case, you're definately
>lucky. I've seen em cuff and stuff people. Let the baseheads steal shit
>and let's
>harass all the climbers... it seems to be their fav theme. But I shouldn't
>bag on
>em too much cause they helped me rescue this one girl who was really badly
>injured in an isolated area (due to her own stupidity). So they are okay
>some...
>(as was the case with you) but most are just silly. I guess sitting out in an
>isolated
>area can do that to a person. Oh well...

N

Booyah motherfuckah!!!! 

Matt just put it right on target.  When I first heard them on that
glorious radio station       LIVE 105......j/k.....I totally thought it
was a Chemical Brother's track. Nope, it was just another average techno
group that was jumping on the Chemical Brother bandwagon at the time.  I
listened to more and more of the tracks from that point and have to say
it's not necessarily worth the attention they're receiving.  Maybe it's
the name.  You know how mainstream society likes groups that affiliate
their names with something bad and corrupt in their own eyes.  I mean,
mainstream society obviously isn't for the use of crystal meth, but in
their good hypocrytic fashion, they want to embalm themselves in
something that they are against already.  

I don't know.  Don't mind cynical ol' me.

Drekster

Fact: Its "The Crystal Method" not jes "Crystal Method" and it has
nuttin to do about the drug, it has to do about this female bus/truck
driver they met awhile back who had this odd way of doin somethin and
she called it "The Crystal Method", and thats how the 2 artist got their
name. They thought it was funny that it sounds a whole lot like Crystal
Meth.
Another Fact: TCM are great artists, and has their own sound. 
thats whats i think anyhow.

Besides everyone should respect Tekno artists who makes the beatz we
rave to and oh so love!
and thats TCM!
and thats the Chemical Brothers!
take it E-Z, keep it real, and pump dem BEATZ up!  =]

-Groovy Child

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 22 23:15:16 1998
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 22 Apr 1998 23:15:13 -0000
Received: from geocities.com (sjx-ca72-22.ix.netcom.com [207.92.177.150])
	by geocities.com (8.8.5/8.8.5) with ESMTP id QAA04422
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Wed, 22 Apr 1998 16:15:08 -0700 (PDT)
Message-ID: <353F22D2.C9CEC25C@geocities.com>
Date: Thu, 23 Apr 1998 04:15:30 -0700
From: Paul Hayden <goodvibe@geocities.com>
X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.04 [en]C-DIAL  (Win95; U)
MIME-Version: 1.0
To: SFRaves <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: READTHIS!It happens Today!!!
X-Priority: 1 (Highest)
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Please READ this!!! It is VERY IMPORTANT!!!
------------------------------------------------------------------------

Here's the Question:

Can millions of people, focusing their minds on inner and world peace,
heal the world in an instant?

Can we, through scientific and quantifiable means, prove that we are
indeed the creators of the world we perceive, and that by changing our
perception, the world itself changes?


             This is "The Great Experiment."


It's time we prove scientifically what the saints and sages have
always told us- that we are powerful spiritual beings with the ability
to create a world based on the laws of love, instead of the rules of
fear. 

Two months ago, James Twyman, author of the bestselling book,
"Emissary of Light," was invited by the government of Iraq to perform
his "Peace concert" in Baghdad. The situation seemed desparate war
seemed almost inevitable and diplomatic efforts seemed to have failed.

"I was being used by the Iraqi government," Twyman said. "But we had
the same goal: to avoid this terrible war. I was given permission to
sing the Muslim prayer for peace to Saddam Hussein and I wanted the
world to join us in this prayer. Hundreds of thousands of people over
the world participated, and when it was complete, I felt a profound
shift in the energy of that whole region. Three days later, a peace
agreement was signed, something which seemed impossible before the
prayer vigil began."


             But The Story Continues . . .


"A week later, I was invited by the government of Northern Ireland to
sing at Stormout Castle in Belfast - the building where the peace talks
were being held. For days, bombs were exploding all around that area.
Many people were trying to interrupt the peace process and it seemed
like the talks might fall apart. Once again, thousands around the
world joined us in prayer, and three days later there was a
breakthrough in the talks. April 12, 1998, a peace accord was reached.

The evidence is there - we do have the power within us to change the
world. Scientists have measured the statistically significant effect
that focused meditations and events have upon the earth's energy
field. These effects were measured during the GaiaMind Meditation and
during Princess Diana's funeral. The studies show that the greatest
effects occur when groups synchronize their focus. During "The Great
Experiment," we will meditate upon specific affirmations in unison to
achieve the power of a singular group focus.

                 NOW IT IS TIME TO PUT INTO PRACTICE 
                   WHAT WE ALREADY KNOW TO BE TRUE:

"If enough people join their minds and hearts for peace, we can heal
the world."

"The Great Experiment" will take place on April 23rd at 6:30 PM
Eastern Daylight Savings Time ( This would be 10:30 PM GMT ) Please
mark your calendars now, and tell everyone that you know to join with
us.

James Twyman has been invited to sing the peace prayers from the
twelve major religions at the United Nations building in New York on
April 23rd. This presents an unparalleled opportunity for us all. Dr.
Doreen Virtue, best-selling author of The Lightworker's Way, and Gregg
Braden, geologist and author of Awakening to Zero Point and Walking
Between the Worlds, join James in conducting this incredible
experiment. Authors, entertainers, and other celebrities, will
participate by sharing their vision of "a world transformed by love."

Here's how you can participate:

1. Tell everyone you know. Share this with everyone on your mailing
list so that everyone can participate. Feel free to print this out and
make copies. The goal is to get as many people as possible focused on
this meditation.

2. Begin preparing your spirit and mind for the event by spending a
few moments in silence everyday. This will help build the energy.

3. Join at least one other person for the vigil on April 23rd. This is
an experience to share. "Where two or more are gathered."

The Format of the Meditation:

1. Opening:

Begin with this affirmation, said with great power and committment:

     I am an Emissary of Light. I extend this Light to all beings, in
compassion and love, knowing that they are one within me. this
moment the world is healed - and I along with it. I will it - and
it is so.

2. Then spend five minutes creating a sound (such as "Om") to carry
the spiritual energy and vibration. This can be done with a single
tone or by singing a song such as "Amazing Grace."

3. Spend five minutes in silence allowing your spirit to receive the
light and love which you yourself extended to the world.

4. End with this prayer:

     "It is done! I am one with all - and all is healed. Let love
reign where fear once was. I accept this for myself and for the
world. I am an Emissary of Light now and always. Amen"

Then, with reverence, bow your head and thank God for this grand
opportunity. The universe gives thanks to you for being part of this
great experiment.

If you have any questions regarding this Great Experiment, 
please write:       TheGreatExperiment@CreatePeace.com

Also please visit the website for the latest
updates:                          
                 http://www.CreatePeace.com

Yeah... Nuke Them Damn Spamming Hippies Tabitha!!!!

Everyday should be peace day folks... do we really need to go "Ohm" 
together to understand that the world might be a better place without
weapons of mass destruction?  Let's put it this way... we live in a
country that has tons of nasty weapons and two political parties...
violent Republicans and violent Democrats (and don't forget about all
those Police actions to "insure peace" we're involved in...).

If we all took five minutes to write a letter to a politician rather than
do a chant, or make up with a long term enemy that you swear you'd
punch if you saw, maybe it would get more done?

Peace,
AndyW

Paul Hayden wrote:

> Please READ this!!! It is VERY IMPORTANT!!!
> ------------------------------------------------------------------------
>
> Here's the Question:
>
> Can millions of people, focusing their minds on inner and world peace,
> heal the world in an instant?
>
> Can we, through scientific and quantifiable means, prove that we are
> indeed the creators of the world we perceive, and that by changing our
> perception, the world itself changes?
>
>              This is "The Great Experiment."
>
> It's time we prove scientifically what the saints and sages have
> always told us- that we are powerful spiritual beings with the ability
> to create a world based on the laws of love, instead of the rules of
> fear.
>
> Two months ago, James Twyman, author of the bestselling book,
> "Emissary of Light," was invited by the government of Iraq to perform
> his "Peace concert" in Baghdad. The situation seemed desparate war
> seemed almost inevitable and diplomatic efforts seemed to have failed.
>
> "I was being used by the Iraqi government," Twyman said. "But we had
> the same goal: to avoid this terrible war. I was given permission to
> sing the Muslim prayer for peace to Saddam Hussein and I wanted the
> world to join us in this prayer. Hundreds of thousands of people over
> the world participated, and when it was complete, I felt a profound
> shift in the energy of that whole region. Three days later, a peace
> agreement was signed, something which seemed impossible before the
> prayer vigil began."
>
>              But The Story Continues . . .
>
> "A week later, I was invited by the government of Northern Ireland to
> sing at Stormout Castle in Belfast - the building where the peace talks
> were being held. For days, bombs were exploding all around that area.
> Many people were trying to interrupt the peace process and it seemed
> like the talks might fall apart. Once again, thousands around the
> world joined us in prayer, and three days later there was a
> breakthrough in the talks. April 12, 1998, a peace accord was reached.
>
> The evidence is there - we do have the power within us to change the
> world. Scientists have measured the statistically significant effect
> that focused meditations and events have upon the earth's energy
> field. These effects were measured during the GaiaMind Meditation and
> during Princess Diana's funeral. The studies show that the greatest
> effects occur when groups synchronize their focus. During "The Great
> Experiment," we will meditate upon specific affirmations in unison to
> achieve the power of a singular group focus.
>
>                  NOW IT IS TIME TO PUT INTO PRACTICE
>                    WHAT WE ALREADY KNOW TO BE TRUE:
>
> "If enough people join their minds and hearts for peace, we can heal
> the world."
>
> "The Great Experiment" will take place on April 23rd at 6:30 PM
> Eastern Daylight Savings Time ( This would be 10:30 PM GMT ) Please
> mark your calendars now, and tell everyone that you know to join with
> us.
>
> James Twyman has been invited to sing the peace prayers from the
> twelve major religions at the United Nations building in New York on
> April 23rd. This presents an unparalleled opportunity for us all. Dr.
> Doreen Virtue, best-selling author of The Lightworker's Way, and Gregg
> Braden, geologist and author of Awakening to Zero Point and Walking
> Between the Worlds, join James in conducting this incredible
> experiment. Authors, entertainers, and other celebrities, will
> participate by sharing their vision of "a world transformed by love."
>
> Here's how you can participate:
>
> 1. Tell everyone you know. Share this with everyone on your mailing
> list so that everyone can participate. Feel free to print this out and
> make copies. The goal is to get as many people as possible focused on
> this meditation.
>
> 2. Begin preparing your spirit and mind for the event by spending a
> few moments in silence everyday. This will help build the energy.
>
> 3. Join at least one other person for the vigil on April 23rd. This is
> an experience to share. "Where two or more are gathered."
>
> The Format of the Meditation:
>
> 1. Opening:
>
> Begin with this affirmation, said with great power and committment:
>
>      I am an Emissary of Light. I extend this Light to all beings, in
> compassion and love, knowing that they are one within me. this
> moment the world is healed - and I along with it. I will it - and
> it is so.
>
> 2. Then spend five minutes creating a sound (such as "Om") to carry
> the spiritual energy and vibration. This can be done with a single
> tone or by singing a song such as "Amazing Grace."
>
> 3. Spend five minutes in silence allowing your spirit to receive the
> light and love which you yourself extended to the world.
>
> 4. End with this prayer:
>
>      "It is done! I am one with all - and all is healed. Let love
> reign where fear once was. I accept this for myself and for the
> world. I am an Emissary of Light now and always. Amen"
>
> Then, with reverence, bow your head and thank God for this grand
> opportunity. The universe gives thanks to you for being part of this
> great experiment.
>
> If you have any questions regarding this Great Experiment,
> please write:       TheGreatExperiment@CreatePeace.com
>
> Also please visit the website for the latest
> updates:
>                  http://www.CreatePeace.com

curly and lucious the way you all love it! (=@!... smirk...

grandparents are so important.... we can learn so much from them and they
can learn so much from us.... I love the way I make her smile... and the
way she makes me smile.... --->> =)*(=

listening to Q-Burns from the Winter Music Conference in Miami... GOD!...
aaaaah.... soooo sweet it is... =) =) =)

Religion, Sir?
HOUSE!

See, spams make you smile... at magical, mystical, sick and twisted life
forms like me!

And if you're annoyed you have no reason to be. Because this is all
good vibes... no negativity.... maybe a couple kbits of extra data across
some routers... but what's it really about? Increasing the warmth.... and
I feel I've done that with this post.. unles you're a cranky spazz and
don't know how to be happy.... but to know how not to be happy is to know
how to be happy, because you're so good at strategic planning to
counter act good vibes... making yourself upset... (= Be happy.... *you
deserve it*...and if you're not happy, relax and sift through the things
that are making you upset... and think of each one... as they cannot be
anything worth making you that upset... because you're here... and there
are still people who care about you..... see.. I don't have to post
this... but I want to... and feel good doing it. Otherwise I'd e-mail
myself...  and that would be scary.... :)

Have a great Wednesday.

ok i'm in a predicament...i have this math problem i need to solve for 
extra credit..and i need the extra credit, ya know what i mean?
so here it is..

How many seven digit numbers using only the digits 1 through 9 in 
which exactly two digits are alike are there?

this means that 0 is not a digit.  
and ONLY two digits can be the same, every other digit must be 
distinct.

um..email me personally if you have it mastered, or if you have any 
suggestions on how to solve it.  oh yeah, here's one hint: the answer 
is over 10,000.  thats all i know.
thanks in advance :)

doreen

-*-Written today during my day at work... looking out into the deep blue..
with the white fluffies tickling the skyline...  thinking of you guys-*-

See of Think

I glide through the think plane infinitely in my own liking
Distant citadels and sky beams interact to create spectrums into the 
point of infinence above distant astral lands
Around me is that which I choose
I swim freely as I once had in a different time and place, a different
setting entirely, one of water and collective harmonix, yet it is all the 
same
Metaphors and paradyms sweep through me and bring a smile to my lips, 
spinning forever off the lips of others as reflections of love
My eyes close as I spin in every direction expanding the energy within        
Life forms are around me enjoying my expressions, feeling more comfortable
expressing their own, as we are no longer alone, and never have been
Moments like this remind us of this, and make us forget the invisible
shackles that we create for ourselves
Doubt is non-existent and progressive thought fills the vast expanse   
of spectracreaminess as we all become one, once more, in our own choosing  
The universal tourist faked into believing this self-sustained reality
that is the material world, is set free and returned to a view point that
is much more familiar 
The warm seat of consciousness is fitting to you in every way from your   
nosey nose to your tosey toes                               
Casio and rolex are out of business as time dissipates and pure emotion   
emerges and flows from the meridian banks
This is the gift to ourselves from ourselves for ourselves  
It's just a matter of time until that secret santa climbs up your chimney 
and you receive the greatest gift of all; life unrestrained and unrefined 
Ride the waves and swim underneath them, deep within in them, to the
depths of love and joy
For this is all within you, me, them, in *us*
We simply have to remember and allow ourselves this great gift of life

Don't question what life is, know what life is
Questions are for those who require the answers of others,
to replace their own answers that are overshadowed by self-created doubt.
So who is making the answers? 
I believe it is those who believe in and follow their heart. 
If it is warm and fuzzy it cannot be wrong. 
As this is our direct link to the greatness we are bound to and ultimately
apart of. 

Swim deep and play nice with the other fish in the see.

-me

*Byroni....... .   .     .     .     .     .     .     .     .     .    !

	by igc3.igc.apc.org (8.8.8/8.8.8) with SMTP id OAA09990
	for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Tue, 21 Apr 1998 14:10:12 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Tue, 21 Apr 1998 14:10:12 -0700 (PDT)
Message-Id: <2.2.16.19980421141441.409752b2@pop.igc.org>
X-Sender: laurenb@pop.igc.org
X-Mailer: Windows Eudora Pro Version 2.2 (16)
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Lauren Giniger <laurenb@igc.apc.org>
Subject: Sunset Boat Cruise review
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

7pm:  300 or so people gathered at the pier looking like a low grade bad
dream hipster hallucination to the random lost tourist wandering by.....
The vibe is already grand and promising and we haven't even left the dock
yet.  Took off around 8pm just as the sun dipped behind the GG headlands to
whistles, applause, cheers...cruised under bridges, around islands, Alcatraz
taken over by gulls, water tranquil and air warm in the Bay's inner reaches,
the water rough and the boat is shaking, tippy as we head to the GG bridge,
disoriented it's hard to tell what's really tipping, the dancefloor just
cheers and goes with it, it's just another motion another rhythm another
beat the cheerful tippiness.....sparkling views of the SF skyline, phat
laser light show projected unto unknown dark islands as screens,....two
dance floors packed the whole night........the music  downtempo hip-hop
shades into driving jungle as the night wears on upstairs...while downstairs
started with pounding progressive house....shading into funky slower-tempo
house as the night ended.  what an unbelievably beautiful party and night.
Completely memorable.

Lauren

****************************************************************************
*************
Real generosity toward the future lies in giving all to the present --
Albert Camus

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 23 Apr 1998 17:43:34 -0000

From: <blkadder@value.net>

cc: *Rave Friends* <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: Re: NRR: zoning, etc. (was: Another strike against dancing)
In-Reply-To: <v01530504b163452e9caa@[208.196.121.73]>
Message-ID: <Pine.BSI.3.95.980423101945.2491A-100000@value.net>

On Wed, 22 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:

> >Let's examine that line of reasoning for a second. By having no zoning, I
> >could open a concrete factory that ran 24 hours a day, or how about
> >a garbage dump right next to your property and that would be ok with you
> >since it is after all my property?
> 
>         There is an alternative to zoning; it is called common sense.  If
> you're opening a business, you don't want to piss off all your neighbors,
> and you're going to try to reach reasonable accomodations with people.

Not in the U.S. If something is not implicitly illegal(and sometimes even 
when it is...) then people *will* do it. 

> Furthermore, your examples are quite extreme.  

However they are completely valid.

> I would venture to say that 99% of what people want to do with their
> property that is prohibited by zoning would have less of a negative
> impact on their neighbors than opening a garbage dump or concrete
> factory in a residential area.

Did you know the 86.5% of all statistics are made up? Really, all one can
do is guess. Zoning takes out much of that guesswork. 

>         In the few cases where someone actually went ahead and did
> something like this, they could always be taken to court.  Subjecting you
> to regular doses of loud noise or foul stench that did not exist when you
> moved into your property could definitely be considered a violation of your
> property rights, and I think most judges and juries would be inclined to
> look favorably on the plaintiff in such a case.

And without a standard set of applicable laws, decisions would likely be
reached in an even more haphazard and conflicting fashion than they are
now. 

> >Zoning laws, right or wrong(or however misapplied) exist for a reason, and
> >sometimes they are good reasons.
> 
>         There is almost always a good intention behind every additional
> measure of power and control exerted by government.  Very often new laws
> are invoked as necessary to correct problems caused by previous state
> interventions!  You say that housing in San Francisco is scarce and
> expensive, therefore people cannot be expected to turn down decent living
> places just because of a little late-night noise.  Instead, you seem to
> imply, they should move in and then pretend they weren't aware of the
> problem beforehand in order to press neighborhood businesses to change in
> order to accomodate them.

Please, don't attempt to put words in my mouth. What I stated is that when
a person moves in to a dwelling is that they have the right (legally and
"morally") to receive "quiet enjoyment" of that property. 

If there is blame to be laid it is with the person(s) making the zoning
decisions. 

What I find in the attitude expressed by you and others is myopia. It is
the inherient inability to see things from any other perspective but your
own. It is what leads to the constant "us vs. them" syndrome that so much
of this society enjoys.  

> I also feel that if many of you who are
> >railing about your rights to dance would quickly change your opinion if
> >you found yourselves unable to sleep at 3 a.m. due to noise.
> 
>         Usually when I'm unable to sleep it's because of emergency
> vehicles, car alarms, and public works crews who seem to enjoy tearing up
> the pavement near my apartment with jackhammers before 8 o'clock in the
> morning.  I've found these to be much worse insomniants (wordcheck?) than
> the steady, low pitch thud-thud-thud of a sound system.

Do you live right next to a club? Could you at all entertain the
possibility that hearing that thud-thud-thud night after night after night
might begin to bother you after a while?

>         Certainly emergency vehicles, if not the other items are recognized
> as a necessary public good.  But why cannot raves be similarly recognized?

Please. As a person that enjoys music, and has gone to a couple of clubs
in my life time, if I had to make a decision as to which was more
important me shaking my ass at 3 a.m. or the ability for someone to sleep
so they can get up and live their life, I would side with the person
needing sleep. 

> Surely the amount of happiness that is created is worth something to the
> community.  I don't believe the few should be sacrificed for the good of
> the many, but in a moral grey area such as we seem to have with the SOMA
> neighbors-club dispute, the happiness of hundreds ought to count for at
> least as much as the undisturbed sleep of one or two, wouldn't you say?

No. And being to give a yes and no answer is the crux of the issue. Common
ground must be found for there to be hope of everyone being happy....

Subject: Re:Crystal Method....& live shows
In-Reply-To: <v04003a02b165171677fe@[206.40.4.17]>
Message-ID: <Pine.GSO.3.96.980423101239.24495D-100000@atari>

Okay, I get opinionated about this stuff... here goes.

On Thu, 23 Apr 1998, Robert Pointer wrote:

&e>Underworld, however, knows how to tear it up on wax, but their live
&e>shows blow. 

Eh... I take it you missed Organic, the first year when they had Orbital,
Underworld, Loop Guru (I thinks... I kinda lost some of the evening),
Chemical Brothers, Electric Skychurch, Orb...

Underworld kicked some serious ass in the live department there... hopping
around, playing perfect stuff for their time slot... as did Electric
Skychurch with their early daytime performance, and Orb with a set that
had me pass out two or three times from dancing too hard at altitude (it
WAS at a ski resort at a fairly good altitude, but I was feeling a tad
elevated in my own right). 

As for Crystal Method... I don't care how they claim they got their name,
that's a strike against them in my book.  They play from the same formula
as the more recent Prodigy and Chemical Bros which is a sound that's just
plain going flat to my ears (I call it macho breaks)... I also saw them
live, and to be honest, they sucked compared to the other acts at the
Warfield that night.  I really hate it when you see them playing a certain
part on the keys and then they stop playing it and the part keeps going... 
why bother? The CM were all about a light show... and my final pet peeve,
everytime the music peaked, like 2000 dataflashes went off in everybody's
face (strobes when overused are ugly painful).  Sounded like a lot of
breakbeat cliches sequenced together.

Fatboy Slim does deserve props as well as Propellerheads (and who was that
other guy who spun bigbeat stuff?) for delivering solid big beat with a
lot of class that night... not too big a fan of the genre and the magazine
hype surrounding it, but those guys had talent at least (and you can tell
they were actually playing, fixing mixes, having fun, a pleasure to watch
and listen to really). The Crystal Method were the headliners and I guess
it's all a matter of taste, but I think any other act on the bill at that
show deserved it more... the other acts seemed to pack more style,
creativity, personality and talent.

I think I just pissed off half the list...
AndyW

On Thu, 23 Apr 1998, Robert Pointer wrote:

> 
> Underworld, however, knows how to tear it up on wax, but their live shows blow.
> 

I really have to disagree here.  =)  When I was in England a little over a
year ago, I got to see Underworld perform twice. And let me tell you,
those were two of the most energy packed performances I have seen in my
life. Of course, maybe it had something to do with the crowds. One show
was at the Redding Festival, in the 'other' tent with everyone cramed
together... lights swirling, people jumping up and down... the securty
gaurds throwing water at the crowd to keep 'em cool. I got to see them
again at a Universe party. Image a HUGE tent that appeared to be bigger
than the inside of the Richmond Civic center. With at least 5,000+!
people. Talk about a spiritual feeling. Sooo many people gettin' down to
the music. Especially that Rez/Cowgirl mix they do, and Born Slippy which
seemed to be the anthem of the summer.... mmmmmmmmmmmmmm....

I also got to see Darren Emerson spin some vinyl at Mr. C's club, and
wasn't particularly impressed. I was really looking forward to hearing
him play out, but the music he played was kind of boring... Oh well...

Of course, we are all entitled to our own opinions...  =)

-matt (aka mc^2)

Subject: Sixth Sense -- OH MY GOD!!!!
Date: Thu, 23 Apr 1998 12:56:13 -0700

Note: This message was originally posted to nw-raves.  I'm from Seattle, and
have heard about the Goa Vibe Crew and the boys from Sixth Sense through the
grapevine.  I finally mustered the free time to go down and was NOT
disappointed.

Also, DJ Meri, I think I'm in love with you.  Got your tape from Prem and
Ray, and
my tape deck in my car bites my hand every time I try to eject it!!!!

---------------------------------------------------------

"Trance is at the pinnacle of modern electronic music.  Its rhythms so
hypnotic and driving that I have seen people climb into a speaker baffle in
an attempt to become one with the music."

You know, I had always heard that the Israeli goa was the shit, but before
now, I had no idea.  Allow me to recap...

I, my beautiful darling Karen, and Carlo, (the original dawn panic
guerrilla) arrived at LAX on a warm Friday night.  Karen, having never
visited LA, was immediately consumed by its vastness.  My recollections were
vague, having lived there over 10 years ago.  Because of the heavy rains,
the city had received a rare boost, and the vegetation was growing wild,
flowers blossoming from every nook and cranny.  Even the freeways were
bedecked with pink and white, rare dessert flowers claiming supremacy over
the concrete and dust.

We chilled at the Cat and Fiddle, enjoying a few beers and the freedom to
smoke at one of the few remaining bars in LA to provide refuge.  LA has
banned smoking, even in bars, but the Cat and Fiddle's main area is an open
air courtyard.  Underneath the propane lamps and 10 foot fica trees we
finally relaxed from our flight.

The next day, we went shopping.  As the rains had tormented the city for
weeks, the first break of sun brought out people by the millions.  Rodeo
Drive, Vermont, and Melrose were filled with throngs of beautiful people,
the fashions were raw and refined, and groover chic was KING.  The most
interesting stuff I've seen in a long time.

Then, around 11:00, we headed off to the Spanish Kitchen Studios, a suite of
sound stages that were usually used for filming, and were designed for
acoustic perfection.  The main room housed around 250 people perfectly, and
was driven by an impressive sound system.  The back chill room was an open
air courtyard, with one brick wall covered by blooming wisteria and a
flowering tree of some kind -- enormous big red blossoms.

The chill room was delicious, a spiritual refuge, where ambient DJs soothed
the weary groover with sounds of whales and nature, a little slow trance,
and even some Cocteau Twins (Victoria Land).  The main room, however, was
madness...

After peaking, I rambled into the main room, and was immediately charmed by
the most incredible flouro garb I had ever seen, groovers galloping around
like stallions around a may-pole, bright psyche-patterns blurring with
glowing eyes and bright smiles.  The music was twisted, with DJ Kavandi and
his ten
year old son, DJ Christ taking the crowd for a journey.

Then Amnon took over around 12:00 and didn't let up until 4:00.  Amnon, my
friends is from Israel, and had the most incredible shit I have ever heard.
You can't find what he has in ANY record store.  His collection was all on
CD, and he crafted his magic with a dual CD player with pitch control.  Yes,
say what you will about the touch and feel of vinyl.  But, remember, the
important thing here is the music.   His bytes were hot off the synthesizer.
Psychic Deli and others have made special mixes for the masterful Amnon, and
he bore down on the crowd with such ferocity as to make grown men whimper
for mercy.  I looked at his set list, and it was all written in Hebrew.  I
asked him if he could translate the list for my own copy, so I could at
least drop the titles to my good buds in Seattle, and he simply shook his
head and smiled like a gargoyle, perched atop his magic box.

These Israelis were unstoppable, galloping around the dance floor, whipping
the crowd to a level of hypnosis I've never seen before.

I realized that there was there was only one thing to do.  I'm going to
bring them here to Seattle, and I'm going to promote a few shows this
summer.  I'll announce the dates and locations once I have that ironed out.
Seattle must know this kind of passion.

Also, I found out that Tsuyoshi is coming to the states and will be doing a
gig in the coming months.  The date has been confirmed, but I don't have the
info here.  I'll announce that as soon as I get the information.

Love,

Julian Klappenbach
"Better living through code"

okay, ive never done this because i dont own a dat but i read an 
interview with oliver leib and he said what he likes to do when he sees 
a live show is bring the remote to his dat and start aiming it at the 
stage pushing all kinds of buttons and stuff...anyway if the act is 
playing off dat you can really mess them up...unless they cover up the 
little sensor on theirs... 

>
>
>Okay, I get opinionated about this stuff... here goes.
>
>On Thu, 23 Apr 1998, Robert Pointer wrote:
>
>&e>Underworld, however, knows how to tear it up on wax, but their live
>&e>shows blow. 
>
>Eh... I take it you missed Organic, the first year when they had 
Orbital,
>Underworld, Loop Guru (I thinks... I kinda lost some of the evening),
>Chemical Brothers, Electric Skychurch, Orb...
>
>Underworld kicked some serious ass in the live department there... 
hopping
>around, playing perfect stuff for their time slot... as did Electric
>Skychurch with their early daytime performance, and Orb with a set that
>had me pass out two or three times from dancing too hard at altitude 
(it
>WAS at a ski resort at a fairly good altitude, but I was feeling a tad
>elevated in my own right). 
>
>As for Crystal Method... I don't care how they claim they got their 
name,
>that's a strike against them in my book.  They play from the same 
formula
>as the more recent Prodigy and Chemical Bros which is a sound that's 
just
>plain going flat to my ears (I call it macho breaks)... I also saw them
>live, and to be honest, they sucked compared to the other acts at the
>Warfield that night.  I really hate it when you see them playing a 
certain
>part on the keys and then they stop playing it and the part keeps 
going... 
>why bother? The CM were all about a light show... and my final pet 
peeve,
>everytime the music peaked, like 2000 dataflashes went off in 
everybody's
>face (strobes when overused are ugly painful).  Sounded like a lot of
>breakbeat cliches sequenced together.
>
>Fatboy Slim does deserve props as well as Propellerheads (and who was 
that
>other guy who spun bigbeat stuff?) for delivering solid big beat with a
>lot of class that night... not too big a fan of the genre and the 
magazine
>hype surrounding it, but those guys had talent at least (and you can 
tell
>they were actually playing, fixing mixes, having fun, a pleasure to 
watch
>and listen to really). The Crystal Method were the headliners and I 
guess
>it's all a matter of taste, but I think any other act on the bill at 
that
>show deserved it more... the other acts seemed to pack more style,
>creativity, personality and talent.
>
>I think I just pissed off half the list...
>AndyW

On Sun, 19 Apr 1998, Elizabeth Traver wrote:

. And did anyone go to the 
> free party which most of the Choclate Factory kids were spinning???

yeah, i was walking to the bathroom by the Organ Pavilian in Golden Gate
Park last Saturday when i stumbled across that free out-of-sight party.
high noon, a park full of bass, and not a soul on the dance floor. you
gotta love this city. 

GGP parties have been pretty spontanious as of late. the last one that i
remember was the Jeno & DJDan Organic that was on the same day as the Last
Sunset of '97 ((as if people in this city aren't spoiled enough they had
to choose between 2 free parties on the same day))and this one was thrown
together just the night before. no flyers, not on the calender, no posts
on SFraves, just a number. 437-4462.

i love outdoor parties, that's the future right there. people are cool to
me in clubs and all, but it's just something about the structure of walls
and sofas that can make it socially exceptable for these player guys to
plant thier shoulders in your face and zone out. with outdoor parties it's
just you, your space, and what you're able to do with it. it takes a
pretty bold dance to survive in broad daylight without any strobes or
lasers to hind behind. this is where i get a lot of my inspiration from.

a good number of raver superheros showed up. i think that if you were to
strip it down, the san fransisco scene really only consists of about 47
people. at any given time about half of them are on active duty, the rest
being semi-retired, or working on a real life, real girlfriend, or just
growing up.   

Work parties *hard*. it's gotten to be that i see that guy like 4 times a
week. 1015 on a wendsday: there's Work. kiddie rave on a saturday :
there's Work. spun out at sunset : there's Work. taking the 71 home on
Monday afternoon : there's Work, walking his dog on lower Haight. that
guy's like an ambasador of good karma. 

so yeah, Mr. San Diego, Mark E Quark, rocked the park on saturday, and the
free arter party at the Food Not Bombs 30 Minna flat with the Chocale
factory people was fun too. Soupstock should be interesting this saturday,
I don't see myself rocking out as much with that crowd, but it's worth
taking in. check it out,  i just got word that The Man is gonna be erected
in front of city hall for a week or so some time in July before being
hauled out to Black Rock. That should be pretty fucking surrreal. crazy
town -

"So I sez to charlie, I sez, 'Charlie, ya gotta gimme a little sumthin ta
go on here.  I'm prolly goin' ta New York dis summer ta work.'

"Charlie laughs and pokes at me, goin', 'Yeah, like any o' dem fancy
stuck-up publishers gonna hire your hack ass.  Whatcha gonna do for a real
job, huh, sell smack to dem luscious little high-stocking private school
chickadees?'"

"I gets real mad, seein' red like and sez, 'Now Charlie, you know I'm in it
for da music.  So tell me, wazz it like dere?  Do ya gotta watch yer step?
Do ya gotta be stylin'?  Wearin' yer Polo and yer Hilfugger?  Snort dat K?
Cut dat midrange drop dat bass?'"

"Charlie screws up his face, seemin' ta give me da evil eye and shakes his
head, sayin, 'Joshie ma boy, I is only a colorful fictional character and I
can't offer yuz no advice.  Mebbe you oughts ta ask da SFRaves kids about
what da Big Apple rave scene is all about, eh?'"

Eh?

Precedence: bulk


Robert Pointer sez (about Fatboy Slim):
>It's very commercial and not very interesting. Guitars over looping
>breakbeats...They sound real predictable to me.

I _love_ Fatboy Slim--and his music does seem pretty mainstream but actually
it's not.  I say that because I don't think most (I repeat most) mainstream
people get it.  Like I when I went to The Rage one night and the dj played
"Song for Lindy," no one really knew what to do.  They were all waiting for
that ChumbaWumba remix to come on.

What I'm saying is that he's no Armand Van Helden or Daft Punk and therefore
the only people who think he's mainstream are people who use words like
"mainstream" and "commercial."  Like us!

And is commercial music necessarily bad music?  Am I not allowed to like the
Chemical Brothers anymore?  And hey, "Little Fluffly Clouds" (The Orb) was
on a VW Bug commercial--does that mean it sucks too?

I'm not necessarily dissin Robert (no way man), but I'm calling into
question the use of the word "commercial" as a negative adjective.

>Underworld, however, knows how to tear it up on wax, but their live shows
blow.
This is just my opinion, but most live tekno shows blow.  Everyone's looking
at the stage like their @ a rock concert and all you see is somebody running
around twisting knobs and pressing buttons.  It sucks.  People should treat
a live act like a dj--look at the visuals, not the stage.

The other problem with live shows is that you don't get the variety in
music/sound etc. that you get from a dj.  A DJ plays a bunch of records by
different artists w/ different sounds & styles during his/her set, but w/
live acts you have only one sound, one style.  Bleah.

An example of a live act that wasn't much to watch or listen to:  The
Crystal Method.

The only live acts that are ever entertaining are musicians who are also
djs, and spin their music and other people's too--musicians like the
Chemical Brothers and, hey, Fatboy Slim.  I guess the only exception to this
rule that I've seen is Moby--oops, I got the words "asinine" & "ridiculous"
mixed up with "entertaining."

xoxo--Miccaela

Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

> 
> what happens if you throw an outdoor party in The City & the police come?
>   do they tell you to leave, threaten arrest if they have to come back?

Often times they will just flash their lights and talk over their PA
and not even get out of their car.  Often times they will ticket
all cars parked near the party.  In rare cases they will start
towing the cars.

>   beat you over the head?

unlikely.

>   arrest you & confiscate equipment?

arresting you is very unlikely.  Confiscating equipment is unlikely, but
it has happened.  It depends on where you are.  If you have broken
into private property, or doing something *very* illegal, they might
confisacte equipment.  If you are just out on some random, public beach,
its is unlikely they will arrest you or confiscate equipment.  Its
all a matter of how illegal your party is.

>   extort donuts?

keep a dozen around just in case.... and coffee.  I know from expereince
that park rangers like chai...

> anyone have any horror stories?  how recently?

I was involved with "oystergate"... a party near the oakland airport
that got busted and all 40 or so people got slapped with a 250 dollar
fine.  We collectively got a lawer... who managed to reduce our tickets
to 50 dollars each, plus 50 dollars each to pay for the lawer.  This
was several years ago.

-troy

http://www.saturn5.com/tsheets/            <- Instant Content
troys-list@schwa.eng.sun.com               <- Inquire Within

   It's another huge weekend coming up...  Last night I stopped by at
   the Top for the Vinyl Treetment, the beats and the crowd were
   totally fonky.  Any good weekly that's within walking distance from
   my house is enough to make me a regular!

   I like Crewsade for tomorrow, and Bohemian Lounge; Trance Force 
   of course if you want trance, and Magic + its afterparty has
   a great lineup.  Saturday has too much goin' on to sort out, but
   check out Soupstock in the afternoon. 

   I was in a good mood this week and unsubscribed a couple of people
   who sent me mail asking for that, but usually I ignore those 
   messages since the instructions for unsubscribing are at the bottom...

           http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

   marcus miller, positive p, kit clayton, guests. reopens April 1st.
   10pm-2am, 21+, $3. Il Pirata, 16th St @ Potrero, SF.
   http://www.egatobas.com/
   
   Good Housekeeping - house, techno w/DJs John Howard, Mark E Quark, Don
   Crisp. every 2nd, 3rd and 4th Wed of the month starting in February.
   21+, $5. Jelly's, Pier 50, SF.
   
   Cybertrance 8000 - trance, techno w/DJs Mystre, Mars, DRC, weekly
   guests. 21+, $3. Club Boomerang, 1840 Haight St @ Stanyan, SF.
   415.541.5019
   
   Seance - trip hop, downtempo, drum'n'bass w/DJ local guests weekly.
   Tarot readers, belly dancers, henna tattoo artists and authentic
   egyptian tapestries. 21+, $5. Backflip, 601 Eddy @ Larkin, SF.
   http://sfstation.com/clubs/seance.htm 415.281.0823
   
   Trax Cafe - techno w/DJs Chris Jackson, Mark Johns, Lucas, special
   guests. 21+, $3. free before 11.. basement of the Agenda, SJ.
   
   Phased - various and sundry DJs. 2 rooms, downtempo upstairs, uptempo
   downstairs. $5. Bahia Cabana, 1600 Market St, SF. 415.339.7875
   
   Telefunken - house, jungle w/DJ guests weekly. every other
   Wednesday...alternating jungle and house. 9p-2a, 21+. low cover!. 107
   4th St, Santa Rosa. 707.526.1230
     _________________________________________________________________

                             Radio/TV/Net Shows
                                      
     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Monday night 9:30pm-midnight - "The Autobahn" w/dj Sutekh. Man and
       machine made music. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 11:30pm-1:30am - "Conscious Groove" -
       ambientdowntempojunglehousetrancedrumnbasstriphop spun by weekly
       guest DJs. Hosted by Stephanie aka Miss fat slice. Free Radio
       Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
       [4.21.98 - Steven Tune]
       [4.28.98 - Ethan (Friends & Family)]
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 5am-7am - A postmodern Garrison Keillor on crack,
       DJ Boomerang Fidget spins hilarious tales of backwoods meth labs,
       urban decay and redneck ravers; all with a social conscience.
       Also, ambient & techno. Free Radio Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 7pm-11pm - The Beta Lounge - Live on the net - electronic
       music and culture, worldwide. http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Thursday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Friday 10am-3pm - weekly DJ netcasts. x-radio.
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.

       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.

       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).

                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

hehehehe well last summer ian and meeks and i (under the name *grumpy
kidz*) tried to throw an outdoor evening/night jungle gig... 
	it woulda went OFFFFFFFFF had everything gone fine, people couldnt
even hear/see us, we were soo far back..
	but some fucked up arsonist decided to fuck with the area
and set a dock on fire..

we had no choice but to call the fire dept, scared we'd be blamed for it
if they just happened to stumble upon it themselves..

the lazyass cops didnt wanna walk the halfmile/mile wer had set up far
awy, so they waitd til one of us went up there.. alex and i had taken a
nap and when he tried to get back to the party, a cop was siitting around
all the parked cars and told us we couldnt go in.. turns out the first cop
was a little nice about it, tellin us to get the hell out..
	so i run off to find another location, there was an outdoor
detroit tecchno gig going on down the street and i was gonna ask em if we
could share the space, if the sound didn't interfere with one another. 
	when i come back, our sound system's still down in the area, coz
our friend's truck is down there, and these cops are tellin ian and alex
that if we don't get off the property they'll take our sound system and
have us arrested, and if we're found throwing a party around that area
that night we'd be busted HARDCORE.. they were totally harassing ian and
alex, to the point that we decided it was safest to just call it quits and
go home for the night :( the second group of cops were total DICKHEADS and
were makin fun of us, the way we talked and shit.. whatever! so...
	i've known people who've thrown parties outdoors and had their
entire equipment taken away, i've known people who just get warnings, i've
been to parties down in santa cruz when the cops just come, get bought off
and/or sweettalked, and they just turn their heads and drive off..

i guess it's all in luck, and how good you are at talking to cops ;)
xo
lara
p.s. looks like we're gonna be st00pid and try to throw a few more
all-jungle outdoor gigs so look out for my BSP's! :):) peace
