Note: This message was originally posted to nw-raves.  I'm from Seattle, =
and
have heard about the Goa Vibe Crew and the boys from Sixth Sense through =
the
grapevine.  I finally mustered the free time to go down and was NOT
disappointed.

Also, DJ Meri, I think I'm in love with you.  Got your tape from Prem and
Ray, and
my tape deck in my car bites my hand every time I try to eject it!!!!

---------------------------------------------------------

"Trance is at the pinnacle of modern electronic music.  Its rhythms so
hypnotic and driving that I have seen people climb into a speaker baffle =
in
an attempt to become one with the music."

You know, I had always heard that the Israeli goa was the shit, but befor=
e
now, I had no idea.  Allow me to recap...

I, my beautiful darling Karen, and Carlo, (the original dawn panic
guerrilla) arrived at LAX on a warm Friday night.  Karen, having never
visited LA, was immediately consumed by its vastness.  My recollections w=
ere
vague, having lived there over 10 years ago.  Because of the heavy rains,
the city had received a rare boost, and the vegetation was growing wild,
flowers blossoming from every nook and cranny.  Even the freeways were
bedecked with pink and white, rare dessert flowers claiming supremacy ove=
r
the concrete and dust.

We chilled at the Cat and Fiddle, enjoying a few beers and the freedom to
smoke at one of the few remaining bars in LA to provide refuge.  LA has
banned smoking, even in bars, but the Cat and Fiddle's main area is an op=
en
air courtyard.  Underneath the propane lamps and 10 foot fica trees we
finally relaxed from our flight.

The next day, we went shopping.  As the rains had tormented the city for
weeks, the first break of sun brought out people by the millions.  Rodeo
Drive, Vermont, and Melrose were filled with throngs of beautiful people,
the fashions were raw and refined, and groover chic was KING.  The most
interesting stuff I've seen in a long time.

Then, around 11:00, we headed off to the Spanish Kitchen Studios, a suite=
 of
sound stages that were usually used for filming, and were designed for
acoustic perfection.  The main room housed around 250 people perfectly, a=
nd
was driven by an impressive sound system.  The back chill room was an ope=
n
air courtyard, with one brick wall covered by blooming wisteria and a
flowering tree of some kind -- enormous big red blossoms.

The chill room was delicious, a spiritual refuge, where ambient DJs sooth=
ed
the weary groover with sounds of whales and nature, a little slow trance,
and even some Cocteau Twins (Victoria Land).  The main room, however, was
madness...

After peaking, I rambled into the main room, and was immediately charmed =
by
the most incredible flouro garb I had ever seen, groovers galloping aroun=
d
like stallions around a may-pole, bright psyche-patterns blurring with
glowing eyes and bright smiles.  The music was twisted, with DJ Kavandi a=
nd
his ten
year old son, DJ Christ taking the crowd for a journey.

Then Amnon took over around 12:00 and didn't let up until 4:00.  Amnon, m=
y
friends is from Israel, and had the most incredible shit I have ever hear=
d.
You can't find what he has in ANY record store.  His collection was all o=
n
CD, and he crafted his magic with a dual CD player with pitch control.  Y=
es,
say what you will about the touch and feel of vinyl.  But, remember, the
important thing here is the music.   His bytes were hot off the synthesiz=
er.
Psychic Deli and others have made special mixes for the masterful Amnon, =
and
he bore down on the crowd with such ferocity as to make grown men whimper
for mercy.  I looked at his set list, and it was all written in Hebrew.  =
I
asked him if he could translate the list for my own copy, so I could at
least drop the titles to my good buds in Seattle, and he simply shook his
head and smiled like a gargoyle, perched atop his magic box.

These Israelis were unstoppable, galloping around the dance floor, whippi=
ng
the crowd to a level of hypnosis I've never seen before.

I realized that there was there was only one thing to do.  I'm going to
bring them here to Seattle, and I'm going to promote a few shows this
summer.  I'll announce the dates and locations once I have that ironed ou=
t.
Seattle must know this kind of passion.

Also, I found out that Tsuyoshi is coming to the states and will be doing=
 a
gig in the coming months.  The date has been confirmed, but I don't have =
the
info here.  I'll announce that as soon as I get the information.

Love,

Julian Klappenbach
"Better living through code"



--part0_893381527_boundary--

good feeling of the old days........:)

Well unfortunately that pretty much is an unfixable problem.. the color tube
is messed and you'll have to send it in for a replacement if you can........
I've had that problem but all the blue left my screen then eventually about
2-3 weeks later the monitor started dying and then about a week later it faded
to black never to come on again : ) Hopefully you can get a new one from the
peoples who made it.... Just speaking from experience here.... I had to call
NEC and ship them my broken monitor in and wait for a week for a refurbished
(sp.) one.... I went through computer withdrawls I tell ya : ) Well if I had a
spare monitor it would be at your house in a minute..... but just to warn
you...... if it's the same problem I had you only have about a month from when
it started tweaking to get a new one or you will have a pictureless
monitor.....

Good luck,
Drakonis

---------- Forwarded message ----------
Date: Wed, 22 Apr 1998 00:02:40 -0700 (PDT)
From: "Minh Q. Le" <mlowdrma@ocf.Berkeley.EDU>
To: SFRAVES <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
Subject: M&m's party directions 





-->Hello everybody...it's me again,

	Directions to mi casa are as follows: Take all alternate routes to
the 580 WEST...since many of you will be heading north from say berkeley
or oakland or from the peninsula, just go as if you were going to a sunset
at Pointe Molate.  You want to stay on the left two lanes to get to the
580-W heading towards SAN RAFAEL; there is construction at the 580/80
interchange so be careful not to miss it. You want to take the MARINA BAY
PARKWAY/ South 23rd street exit...they switch names, but the exit before
mine is Regatta Blvd so keep an eye out. You want to make a left from the
offramp, which will put you on Marina Bay Parkway.  You will pass three
signals (you will cross Railroad tracks...if there is a train you will
have to wait for it to pass; I know of no alternate route to my complex). 
When you see the sign "The Beach" slow down; MY COMPLEX IS "THE SHORES"
which is after "The Beach". Turn right into "The Shores" which will place
you onto SHORELINE COURT...make an immediate left.  Call me at 071 at the
box and I will buzz open the gate. The road will curve right and my apt.
is #62 on the second floor on the right hand side at the first curve. 
Apparently there are two #62's in proximity, but open your ears...you
should be able to hear the music. Park in any UNCOVERED parking space
available. It's not that complicated, but I don't want anyone to get lost.
My address is:

62 Shoreline Court
Richmond, CA 94804
(510) 234-9038


	The party will start at 3PM and there will be DJ's...not sure who
yet; it's open tables so SURPRISE! :) It's a mellow party but it will go
on rain or shine; if the BBQ gets flooded I have a fireplace and
marshmallows at your service :O


See you Friday!
:)
M&m


PS	In case you end up at a different #62, I have a green astroturf
doormat with a white plastic daisy on it :) Kitsch baby!

 Hola amigos and amigas, 
 
 Today (Friday) is the SFRLunch, Downtown Edition.  Have your mommy pack 
your bologna sandwhich into your metal "Disco" lunch box, and come join 
us.
 
Anyhoo, the location is Sydney Walton Square, which
is between Davis and Front at Jackson St.  Commonly, this park is also 
called MacArthur Park, as the MacArthur Park restaurant is on the 
corner.  It's a nice park, with a fountain in the middle.  Pick up the
foodstuff of your choice and meet at the fountain at 1:00.  There are 
several large square stones there on which to sit.  To help you find us, 
we've set up a sumo ring, where Boy George will be wrestling with George 
Michael (we posted his bail after his little *incident*).
 
There is a safeway deli as well as a health food sandwich store directly 
across the street-- due south-- of the park, and there is a Yank Sing 
takeout dim sum, Oishii takeout sushii, Uno's, World Wraps, all that 
shtuff-- in the walkable vicinity.
 
If you're still confused where this place is, go to
www.mapquest.com. Go to the MAPS section.  Type in 94111 in the zip code 
section, hit enter. Click on the button, 'center and zoom in', then 
click on the red star on the map.  You're smart, you'll figger it out.

All are welcome, especially contagious lepers. We'll see you there....if 
you don't come, we'll talk about you,giving you that annoying 'ears are 
burning' sensation. 
  
 Nathan
 
ALSO!!:  It's liz's (emenon) 21st birthday today, so come say hi or let 
her buy you a drink-- she's legal now! ALSO!! Infamous SF DJ and animal 
porn peddler Joe Rice is rumored to be coming!  ALSO!! Listmaster Brian 
Behlendorff occasionally makes noise that he may come!  Will he show?  
Or is there even such a person?  Is BRIAN really just an acronym for 
Binomial Random Internet Activity Network, an IBM-sponsored 
supercomputer that runs the whole show, much like the wizard in the 
Wizard of OZ? Find out, today at SFRLunch!

Well if you can get a amplified music permit then everything is ok ,
unless laws are being broken
ie... alcohol/drug consumption, or not respecting peoples property
(parking,graffiti)
First they will ask you to turn off the music and go home.
If you don't they will FINE you and/or confiscate the equipment.

Uhhhh...

The police can never confiscate your gear. They can impound it...which
is a pain in the ass...but they have no legal right to keep it....When
this happens, the legal owner has to go down to the police station to
pick up their property....The funny side of this would be getting the
police to carry your gear off the beach for you, so that you could pick
it up from them later.

If anyone is worried about getting their gear impounded from an outdoor
party, then write up a rental receipt...thus guaranteeing that someone
will be able to re-claim their confiscated gear. It also is proof to the
police that the confiscated gear has something to do with a persons
livelihood. This forces the police to return the gear in a timely
mannner, as holding it would cause the renter to loose revenue.

Peace,

ES

Ummm...the police can do what ever the rich want then to do.
The tenderloin in sf got its name from the quite common practice
of taking your local police man to dinner and buying him 
a big juicy tenderloin stake in exchange for a 'little favor"

Case in point is the sherif being forced to shut down the cannibas club.
He wants to obey the law but dan lungren and other people with the
money refuse to allow the law or the will of the people to be enforced.

	><{{{">  <"}}}><

		foolish fish

From: Catweasel <cat.weasel@usa.net>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Eklektic
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

I was pretty skeptical about jungle club nights in SF, expecting cheesy lightweight drum n bass white suburban trash rubbish (a la LTJ Bukem/Goldie etc) so it was with great trepidation that I ended my techno only moratorium and me n the messiah hit Eklektic last night.
Walked in at midnight and the place was rammed with people, music was full on jump-up and techstep jungle through a sweet soundsystem and people were going for it bigstyle on the dancefloor. Completely wikked. Big up the Eklektic massive, Bo!
What was that track with the dog bark sample? Ace.
Thoroughly recommended night.
So I've now got Tuesdays at Static, Wed at Sabotage and now Thurs at Eklektic every week, there must be something to fill Monday nights and my week is complete. What's No TV like?
Cheerz
K@wzl



-----------------------------------------------------
http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Underground/5185
-----------------------------------------------------

 Hola amigos and amigas, 
 
 Today (Friday) is the SFRLunch, Downtown Edition.  Have your mommy pack 
your bologna sandwhich into your metal "Disco" lunch box, and come join 
us.
 
Anyhoo, the location is Sydney Walton Square, which
is between Davis and Front at Jackson St.  Commonly, this park is also 
called MacArthur Park, as the MacArthur Park restaurant is on the 
corner.  It's a nice park, with a fountain in the middle.  Pick up the
foodstuff of your choice and meet at the fountain at 1:00.  There are 
several large square stones there on which to sit.  To help you find us, 
we've set up a sumo ring, where Boy George will be wrestling with George 
Michael (we posted his bail after his little *incident*).
 
There is a safeway deli as well as a health food sandwich store directly 
across the street-- due south-- of the park, and there is a Yank Sing 
takeout dim sum, Oishii takeout sushii, Uno's, World Wraps, all that 
shtuff-- in the walkable vicinity.
 
If you're still confused where this place is, go to
www.mapquest.com. Go to the MAPS section.  Type in 94111 in the zip code 
section, hit enter. Click on the button, 'center and zoom in', then 
click on the red star on the map.  You're smart, you'll figger it out.

All are welcome, especially contagious lepers. We'll see you there....if 
you don't come, we'll talk about you,giving you that annoying 'ears are 
burning' sensation. 
  
 Nathan
 
ALSO!!:  It's liz's (emenon) 21st birthday today, so come say hi or let 
her buy you a drink-- she's legal now! ALSO!! Infamous SF DJ and animal 
porn peddler Joe Rice is rumored to be coming!  ALSO!! Listmaster Brian 
Behlendorff occasionally makes noise that he may come!  Will he show?  
Or is there even such a person?  Is BRIAN really just an acronym for 
Binomial Random Internet Activity Network, an IBM-sponsored 
supercomputer that runs the whole show, much like the wizard in the 
Wizard of OZ? Find out, today at SFRLunch!

Hmmm... I wonder what LTJ and Goldie would think of your categorization of 
their music as cheesy lightweight drum n bass white suburban trash 
rubbish, especially since neither of them are white or suburban. Not to 
mention, both have made immense contributions to drum n bass... without 
them and the producers they have fostered and the scenes that they 
helped build, I doubt you would even know what jungle is.

show a little respect,

-radon

it's nice to see people are taking the next evolution. but i don't see
why it should be such a surprise to folks when they find themselves
thoroughly entertained at a night such as (and specifically) eklektic. i
would say that i haven't seen a single bad review of that party in the
many i've read... (though that wouldn't be exactly true, however if
memory serves the author promptly recanted after dina removed her boot
from his bum). 

the jungle scene in SF is alive, live and off the hook. i'm torn between
the impulse to tell everyone i know and not tell a sole so that i have
more dancin' room to myself. but either way, the shit is good. like i
said, c@weasle and mw, i'm glad y'all took a chance on a sure thing, but
damn, when will people stop saying shit like "you can't dance to drum
and bass?"

moving on; goldie & LTJ  = "cheesy lightweight drum n bass white
suburban trash rubbish" ? i'd say you're full of shit and you don't know
from what you speak of, but rather than incite a flame war, how about
you just check goldie @ digital in 2 weeks. see what you have to say
after that... 

i missed LTJ @ ultra last year, but i didn't hear anyone use the words
"cheesy lightweight drum n bass white suburban trash rubbish " then
either.  ;-)

see ya @ eklektic next week then,

jdw

K@weasel:

I'm not in any way the world's jungle expert - but I do know "cheezy
lightweight drum n bass" when I hear it, (maybe commercial coffee-table
jungle would be a better way to put it) and Goldie is it. Compare
anything he has produced to what you hear on London's pirates and you'll
see it immediately. If you don't live in london check out interface
pirate radio on the 'net - www.pirate-radio.co.uk - it's ace!

LTJ - havn't heard him in a while. His last tape that I have is from a
hardcore rave circa '92/93, and is brilliant. It's a shit recording, but
the music has soooo much energy and warmth, chopping and changing at an
amazing pace.

Pity I missed Eklektic - c u next week, looking forward to it.

l8r

Simon

http://simon.sublime.org

Subject: Goldie and LTJ/ Eklektic 
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Well, thanks for all the lovely comments on the club.  We love making you
all happy, we do this drum n bass club for you all, not for our pocketbooks.  

So great having room to dance lately, agreed?  Sifu and Honey B fucked it up
last night!

One thing for all who dig d n' b to understand:  There is so much history
behind the music, there is a  much deeper meaning behind d n' b than most
think.  A lot of the junglists out there have only been turned on for 2
years or lass, this shit dates way back!  Think of reggae or ragga music,
how about Dub, the original Konkrete Jungle in Jamaica, the slums, and the
drums in the jungle, keeping the rhythm solid throughout the hellish living
conditions.  This is where jungle music came from:  Poverty, and opression.  

If you think someone is "lame" for being of a certain color or lifestyle, or
for having mixed a track on a soundtrack or for doing a sprite commercial,
just put it into perspective.  At least they are making paps ($) doing what
they like to do, diggin the vibe they dig and exposing a culture to thier
love of drum n bass (or whatever kind of) music.  On top of all that, these
artists that some slander as sellouts are simply "doing their job".  Any of
us in the music biz that have come from the underground or below ground and
now reside slightly above ground understand where Goldie and LTJ are coming
from, and it is time that those who are not involved in the biz, (perhaps
the listeners, purchasers, and clubbers) understand and educate themselves a
bit, as to not be slandering BIG NAMES out of ignorance.  

So again, I love the Eklektic reviews.  I am so glad the one gent is off the
techno only train and that he has found a love at Eklektic, but before
anyone SLAMS pioneers of a musical genre, pioneers that are so INTENSE,
please do your homework, figure your history out, etc.  If you had thought
of that I'll bet the words "white-trash" and Goldie and LTJ would not have
been in the same sentance.  (=
A much more appropriate thing to say woulod have been "Yeah - they are
played out - or yeah, they are superstars",. but RESPECT to them for all
they have done to pave the way for us to do what we pleasure doing, which is
diggin the drum and the bass.

Ciao and I look forward to seeing you ALL next Thursday for the Phunckateck
exhibition at Eklektic!

dmarie
Ground Score.

What exactly is Cheez??... lets think of this...

Cheese:

Free flowing, creamy, soothing, warm, fulfilling

like fluid... like human emotion....  

so what is BAD about CHEEZ?... nothing. It's good.. and people are afraid
to admit that we're all one and flow...     like cheeze... through
emotions...

I know there is music that lacks depth and lacks automatic reaction...
(soul tickling) ... but music that makes you feel *good* and is not
chaotic is not bad music.... it's simply a different style that you may
not like..

and like LTJ's Essential Mix tape (whatup Steve!) states... "Tell me one
guy that knows anything about music, just one guy.... no one knows
anything about music, *it's all a matter of opinion*".

It's Friday people.... it's going to be a fat weekend...

HEYYYY OOOOO it's that TIME AGAIN FOLKS! 

MAY 9th are ya'all READY??!?!?! :)

readin straight off the flyer to get the point across (coz i couldn't pt
it any better way)...
(scroll down for the REAL info')
Happy kidz,
	I have been inspired to do whatever possible to influence all the
folks I care about (that's all y'all) to come experience the WHole Earth
Festival in Davis, California. Every year this cozy little town transforms
and comes to life creating, celebrating and sharing that powerful warm
vibe that we hold sacred in our underground dance scene. Solar powered,
rump-shakin grooves rangin from funky jazz to melodic trance to feed the
soul throughout the weekend, not to mention the FATTEST tribal drum
circles you';ll ever see. There's also grubbin ass organic food, hemp
goods and lotsa other goodies.
	 Most importantly, everybody there seems
connected. People toss friendly smiles left and right -- *just because*.
Worlds that we create like this, even if just for the weekend, are
important to our happiness and progress as human beings. So come and share
your own shining spirit with us at this gathering to celebrate and
appreciate our mother earth.
	Then when the smilin' sun sets, we'll continue our craziness into
the night at a good ol' Happy Kidz shindig up the road a piece. It'll be a
weekend getaway well worth the commute.
Love ya kidz! 
	(happykid marty wrote that, ain't he SWEET!)

and the INFO you all want n need:

** FREAKS ON FOUR TECHNICS **
mars vs. mystre
happykid marty vs happykid ian
crappykid elias vs dribblebib dyloot
jeyson vs brian flipp

>lightweight drum n bass" when I hear it, (maybe commercial coffee-table
>jungle would be a better way to put it) and Goldie is it. Compare
>anything he has produced to what you hear on London's pirates and you'll
>see it immediately. If you don't live in london check out interface
>pirate radio on the 'net - www.pirate-radio.co.uk - it's ace!

i'm just posting a quick note here on my way out the door (a 2630 mile
drive i might add).  i just -needed- to thank sfraves for the absolutely
-amazing- time i had in califonia these past four months!  you guys are
the best!

i had a fantastic time, met some of the greatest people i've ever met in
my life, and went to some of the best parties i may ever go to: ever!
there are so many people i want.. no, NEED to thank right now, but i just
don't have time to do it!  don't worry, i'll be sending you all personal
messages to keep in touch--you'll just have to wait until i'm back in
toronto (around tuesday).

i got asked so many times for this the past week or two, so here it is, my
contact info! :) :

my email address is jason@slaughter.com, although this email addy
(jason@vfive.com) will still be active, i just won't check it as often.
my addy @actel.com WILL NOT work, so DON'T email me there! :)

59 hazelden grove
london, ON
N6H 5A1
CANADA

#ice or #sfraves as 'isosceles' ...

oh yeah, and one more thing:  i know i said i'd talk to everybody
personally, i just -have- to publicize my hella thanks to GUYTROPIX!  this
guy is the nicest guy i've ever met!  he drove me -everywhere-, he
introduced me to -everybody- and on top of all that, he told me some great
stories :).. big props to GUY!  thanks, i owe you one bigtime! :)

anyhow, that's it, i've -really- got to get driving!  thanks again
everybody, I LOVE YOU GUYS!  for all you who didn't meet me, i was the kid

ever near toronto!

- jason :)

Hiya SFR folks!

Well I guess I'm back. Although I never really left at all, that 
addiction is begining to kreep back into my veins. Scary enough, I've 
even started buying records again! 

Anyway, for those of you who have tried to get in touch with me through 
thorfio@hotmail.com I'm truely sorry. When I started my new job in 
februaury my life became really chaotic and I was sooo busy and 
scattered that I hadn't checked my e-mail in like three weeks. When, I 
finally did, every computer that tried to upload the 1000 plus messages 
in my hotmail account got frozen dead in it's tracks. So I gave up and 
started this new one...so please, if you have anything important that 
you had e-mailed me over the last month could you send it to this 
address? I don't want to break any lose ties. And from now on I'm making 
it a point to check my e-mail every night, so I'll definately get 
anything you send me.

Anywayz...it was really aswome to see all of my old raver friends at the 
last two parties I was at...I definately miss you guys a lot. Hope to 
see yas soon.!

Stay Cool!

Matt

it would be nice to have magicians at raves. 
Long ago when you went to a spiritual temple there
was always a magician to remind us of the magic in life
and open our minds to the possibilities of magic.
All magic had a spiritual meaning like the cutting
of someone in half and putting them back together again
represented death and rebirth or reincarnation.

I know how to make ravers levitate, disappear, walk thru walls
escape chains, cut them into piece,etc, etc...
someday i would like to do a magic
show at a rave.

>Uhhhh...
>
>The police can never confiscate your gear. They can impound it...which
>is a pain in the ass...but they have no legal right to keep it....When
>this happens, the legal owner has to go down to the police station to
>pick up their property....The funny side of this would be getting the
>police to carry your gear off the beach for you, so that you could 
>pick
>it up from them later.
>
>If anyone is worried about getting their gear impounded from an 
>outdoor
>party, then write up a rental receipt...thus guaranteeing that someone
>will be able to re-claim their confiscated gear. It also is proof to 
>the
>police that the confiscated gear has something to do with a persons
>livelihood. This forces the police to return the gear in a timely
>mannner, as holding it would cause the renter to loose revenue.
>
>Peace,

At 12:58 AM 4/27/98 -0700, James Miller wrote:
>I am hoping someone can enlighten me as to what "trance" is generally
>associated with.  I had always thought of it as more ambient
>sounding'ish but from the other day I seem to be mistaken.  I know I
>have liked all the D&B I have ever heard.  Also are D&B and Jungle
>equivelent nonclementure?  As I every hear them, they sound to be so.
>
>

TRANCE is a 4/4 bass kick laid over a march.  all the different trance
subtypes just have different styles of melody lines.  the march element
(which also sounds like galloping horses) is the reason why it "entrances"
you--they use the same thing in basic training.  not that i'm about to turn
in my Aum Shivaya shirt and phat pants for a crisply pressed pair of olive
fatigues.

lotsa times people consider DRUMNBASS and JUNGLE to be identical but any
true junglist (wazzup lara) can tell you that drum n' bass focuses more on
intricate cut-up drum loops, hip-hop and such, whereas jungle goes more for
a stripped-down rhythm line and lets the growly analog-sounding synths do
the talking.  

preach on, my patch-cabled oscillatin' prophets, preach on.

I have a 50 gallon cybertroppix fishtank.... it's fishless but is for sale
I might *ad*.. $250 including all accessories, a nice black stand, and a
groovy guy to set it up.... ;)

I love fish.... they're very relaxing. As for eating the fish food... :)
well it depends on the fish you get... I had fish that I used to feed goldfish...
and I'm not too keen on munching on crunchy, slimy, goldfish.... as for
the flakes, well thats yet to be desired... and the blood worms... :/
well....   I'll stick to my tofu and rice..

I think the flaky fish food is a bunch of *stuff* pressend and packed...
kinda like our food...

Date: Mon, 27 Apr 1998 09:39:08 -0700
Subject: Weeken' Review
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=us-ascii
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


'ello folx,
     Adam here (or Anakin to some of you...) just tryin' to let the 411
down on the hap's of last weekends' events.  Got the dirt on some and the
word on others...  So here's what I gathered.

FRIDAY:
     A majority of the evening was spent doing mappoint for _TranceForce_.
This event was sorta significant in many ways- it was in SF (mission
dist.), scheduled to go till daybreak, verymuchso on the UG tip
(bustability factor was up there), oh yeah, I was supposed to spin there
too.
     Mappoints can be fun, and they can also D.R..A...G....  (for a looong
time).   Fourtunatlly Friday was the former.  After many mappiont
misadventures (those stories could be a email initself) the point closed,
and off to _Trance Force_.


The location itself wasn't new, however, it's been so long since I've been
there last (oh, about 2 yrs. ago) it felt like raving in a virgin space.
The sound was nice, the vibes were flowing on the positive side and DRC was
stirring things up when I got there.  A good people count of about 300+
were in attendence which added to the vibe and the vibe surfers merrrily
pounding on the floor to Ms. D's Big Beats.   Afta cutting the rug for a
bit I stepped off the floor and chatted w/my fellow scensters.  Talking to
several other promoters about the BIG events in the summer :

     -" Yeah, I think I'll check out Frankie Bones next month..."

     -"Serious? Christoper Lawrence in June?"

     -"No way he'll spin in SF, when he gets here in the summer, Chris
(Liberator) will be spinning in the Oakland warehouses..."

     -"So he'll be doing his first U.S.A. apperance in the Bay Area?  Are
you sure Commander Tom's never spun in the U.S. before?"
  But enough of the gossip....

After DRC, Mr. Dutch did his Psi-Trance thang and handed the mind set for
Mari who contuned the Goa-ish beats running on till...

                              ... the lights turned on...

People sober enough to understand thier watches noticed it was only 5AM.
Tsk.  Add to the fact that, oh, about 30-50 ppl. from _Bionic_ (@ Maritme)
has just got there to at least party till 6 or 7. (from what I heard
_Bionic_ didn't make thier numbers so they cancelled thier 'free'
afterparty) Tsk, tsk...  A slight discomfort to myself since my slot was
from 5-6AM.  Tsk, tsk tsk.  But mainly, I guess it shows that a party still
CAN NOT go on till daybreak in The City.
                         Mad props to the SFPD.

The unoffical word was that the propritors of the location, "were tired,"
and, "needed some rest."  thus giving the boot to 100 or so partygores to
tweak in the the streets of the Mission... (Please take note to all you
other promoters considering that space...).

Trance Force Rating:  Vibe- 8smiles,  Sound- 7Smiles (it kept getting
turned up...turned down...turned up... turned down...), Lights and Decor-
7smiles, Chill space- 9 smiles (plenty-o-room to relax).  Overall : 7.75
C+.

Hey but that was only night!  SATURDAY it started up all over again:

Sat. was a slight repeat of Friday since I spent the majority of the
evening Mappointing _Foot Print_ till 1:30AM.  Then off, to _Diverese City_
to checkout the haps.  Mars and Mystre were up on the decks tossing down
trance jam after trance jam...  Nice grooves to make you move, but, for me,
sitting in a trance store for 11+ hours,  I guess being indoors was too
much to handle...  So, despite a decent Drumm and Bass set by Noel, the
call of the Sea beckoned me...

I arrived around 3:30ish with some Diverse-City Kitties to _Footprint_.
Suprisingly the cover was still in effect (talking to one of the promoters,
he indicated that after mappoint closed it was to be a 'free' party).
Sonic was spinning an "experimental" set to about the dozen or so people
dancing.  The other 40 or so were piled up close to the fire or wandering
about the beach and ajoining trees...  Chatting a bit I found that the
numbers didn't quite crack 100 but the fact that people trickling in and
out the way they do the numbers of ravers never dipped below 40 either.  Me
and my 'pals' stuck around till about 5:30 or so, Mainly I spent most my
time dancing barefoot in the sand (that alone brought back fond
memories)...  And then drove of to RavensWood (another secret 'smoke spot')
to watch the sunrise.

Diverse City Rating: Sound System- 8smiles (typical club sound), Lights-
8smiles (Typical club lights), Space- 5.5smiles (been there, done that AND
chekin' I.D.'s @ the door AND only till 4). DJ's-N/A (I was only there for
1-to-1 1/2 hrs.). Overall: 7.17 C

FootPrint Rating:  Sound System- 6smiles (2 15's -eeeeh... this is a 5$
party?), Cover- 6smiles (hey guy's outdoors, renegade, shoulda been free
and request for donations),  Music- 8smiles, Location- since it was the
first allnight outdoor in 98 for me,  _Foot print_ gets a coveted 10
(Awesome Space).  So despite the subpar smiles Overall: 7.5 Solid C.


Allthough I heard of _DiverseCity_ afterparty in the Berk Marina and a few
other Sunday daytime events The RAS crew got a bit envious about all the
outdoor parties in planning and happening.  So, Sunday was the serious
Plan-Session for _Casseopiea_ Rebel Alliance Sound's First outdoor event
set for May.  Brining together Trance, Goa,  Acid Techno, Drum and bass and
Hardcore/speedcore/gabber DJ's and Live acts...  (pretty spiffy, huh?).
Local Dj's and artists from the bay contenuing the spirit of the UG in 98.


But since no one's been confirmed and we still have to develop concepts of
decor, flyer design and other trivalities.  More concrete info will be out
soon.
And on the subject of things... An Anakin Spring 98' UG mixtape is floating
about in the scene called _Intrinsic Juncture_.  It's free, get a copy from
a friend (not me, I allready gave out 20 copies).

Well that's about it.   Hope that the society that puts you down dosen't
affect your spirits, and c-ya...
     ... in the void.

-AnAkIn

OK, so I don't like commercial drum n bass. There, I said it. I was 
commenting that Eklektic plays the kind of jungle I like, as opposed 
to drumnbass that I don't like. Fine, if you want to go to a drumnbass
night, go ahead. I'm not stopping you or saying it's wrong to do so, I 
was commenting that I don't like this kind of music, what's wrong with
that ferchrissake?

> btw i loved your set w/ Andy W at ((Vibe This)), your t~shirt was
> hilarious it said "Fuck Goa Trance" although i luv Goa, i do have a
> sense of humor ;)
> you obviously do too, i just prefer to not make humor out of racial
> issues, but who am i 100% *eurotrash* Spain/Czech baby! it's true that 
> sometimes humor doesn't manifest too well on email posts...

Is it wrong to not believe in PLUR on this list? Is it a prerequisite
for membership? Do people who aren't PLURry get kicked off?
Glad you liked Viberation, me n Andy were having a ball up there jumping around and cutting it up.

Radon wrote:
> > > Hmmm... I wonder what LTJ and Goldie would think of your
categorization of
> > > their music as cheesy lightweight drum n bass white suburban
trash
> > > rubbish, especially since neither of them are white or suburban.

Yeah, but their market is white suburban people. You wouldn't get the
Brixton massive listening to their stuff.

 Not to
> > > mention, both have made immense contributions to drum n bass...
without
> > > them and the producers they have fostered and the scenes that
they
> > > helped build, I doubt you would even know what jungle is.
> > >
> > > show a little respect,

Hmm. gotta take you to task on this one. I don't know what jungle is 
eh? Well, trust me, I've seen one hell of a lot more jungle than you, 
coming from London and all. I saw LTJ for the first time in 94 in 
Switzerland, I saw Goldie live in 95. And its the cheesy commercial 
watering down of the jungle scene by people like the aforementioned 
artists that really annoys me. Its taking something that was raw and
energetic and came from the rough council estates and watering it down
to sell to suburban people who don't want the rawness of true jungle.
That's why I dissed their styles. The comment about white eurotrash 
applies to me too (I'm white and european, I don't consider myself 
trash but some people would), it was a comment about a certain feel of
music - music can feel black (detroit, jungle) or white (goa trance,
drumnbass). Its a funk thing. It has nothing to do with race or colour
of skin, its about feel of the music. White people can make black
music (e.g. jungle being the best example) and vice-versa. Why are
people over here always actively searching for any comment to be 
vaguely construed as non-PC, it gets on my tits sometimes (is that a
non-PC comment as I don't have tits?). I dunno. 

I think y'all wanna chill out a bit and stop jumping on people for
disliking things. If you don't like the music I like, I won't get 
offended if you dis it, more power to you for saying how you feel. If 
you get offended by my personal dislikes, then that's your problem, 
its not going to stop me speaking my mind about it.

Anyway, we ought to meet up at this goldie thing to discuss it over a
bowl. I'll be with the guy doing the dancing man visuals.

L8Rs

K@wzl

Hey C@,

First off, I'd like to say that the tone of my post came off more 
indignant than I intended. Sorry 'bout that.

> Radon wrote:
> > > > Hmmm... I wonder what LTJ and Goldie would think of your
> categorization of
> > > > their music as cheesy lightweight drum n bass white suburban
> trash
> > > > rubbish, especially since neither of them are white or suburban.
> 
> Yeah, but their market is white suburban people. You wouldn't get the
> Brixton massive listening to their stuff.

Good point, although I doubt they intentionally market to white suburban 
people, and they would probably argue that their intent is just to bring 
drum n bass to as many people as possible. 

I've always resisted drumnbass/jungle elitism, because I feel that some 
of it's musical innovations (focus on irregular percussion, 
revolutionary bass lines, aggressive tempo, use of "half-time" feel, 
etc.) and it's relationship to hip-hop (as a portal to hip hop music and 
culture for some, as a continuation/branch of hip hop for others) make 
it an extremely important development in 20th century music. 

I think there's drum'n'bass out there for everyone, there'll always be 
"hardcore" stuff that's less accessible, and stuff like LTJ's that's 
more accessible. LTJ's music is important because it has and will 
continue to bring important musical/cultural ideas to new ears. Not to 
mention, IMO, that much of his stuff is very good.

> Hmm. gotta take you to task on this one. I don't know what jungle is 
> eh? 

Basically, I should have said that without LTJ, Goldie, the scenes they 
fostered/contributed to, and the producers that they schooled, most 
Americans wouldn't know what Jungle is. I definitely didn't intend to 
accuse you of not knowing what jungle is.

> And its the cheesy commercial 
> watering down of the jungle scene by people like the aforementioned 
> artists that really annoys me. Its taking something that was raw and
> energetic and came from the rough council estates and watering it down
> to sell to suburban people who don't want the rawness of true jungle.
> That's why I dissed their styles. 

I can see where you're coming from, but as you can probably judge from 
my comments above, I think that LTJ and Goldie's contribution to the 
scene far exceeds any watering down they've done. If you'll forgive me 
for speaking for them, they believe that the music should be spread far 
and wide, that getting drum'n'bass/jungle heard is a good thing for the 
scene. 

That's a belief I agree with, but even if you don't, their music 
is an important part of drum'n'bass/jungle history, and to dismiss 
everything they've done as rubbish seems... overzealous?

On the other hand, this thread has become way too serious (mostly my 
fault). In person, if you made a reference to lightweight Bukem-esque 
rubbish, I would have smiled knowingly. *shrug*. SO...

> Anyway, we ought to meet up at this goldie thing to discuss it over a
> bowl. I'll be with the guy doing the dancing man visuals.

That is a great suggestion. I love talking about this shit.  I'll try to 
find a "My name is..." sticker to put on myself, see you there...

-radon

Subject: white n black music
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Catweasel sez:
> it was a comment about a certain feel of music - music can feel black
> (detroit, jungle) or white (goa trance, drumnbass). Its a funk thing. It has
> nothing to do with race or colour of skin, its about feel of the music.
White
> people can make black music (e.g. jungle being the best example) and
vice-versa.

oh, you read that article too, eh? i remember awhiles back, there was some
article in a newspaper or magazine or something about black music vs. white
music. that black music is more something that seeps into you, more like
body-sensitive sorta music whereas white music is more of a
head/intellectual thingamabobber. then it went along to talk about how much
popular music was in fact invented by black people and was more of a funk
think like c@weasel says, then white folk picked up on it and made it
digestable for the white masses, like elvis presley, or vanilla ice, or the
beastie boys

it made an interesting comparison between tricky and dj spooky (outta nyc).
tricky's big criticism concerning spooky is that spooky thinks too much
about his music and intellectualizes it too much when, in tricky's opinion,
real music is more instinctual, that you just kinda know it when you know
it and theres no other way of knowing it. both tricky and spooky are black
too, if that has any bearing on anything whatsoever

i dunno, i personally try to avoid this whole polarity between keepin it
real and music for the (white?) masses. sometimes i feel the need for music
that just plain gets me going, othertimes, i like music that i can wrap my
mind around, that sorta fills in the spaces. when it comes jungle (i dont
care about this whole dnb thing, i just call it all jungle), i find i keep
toggling between the different kinds, depends on my mood

joe
-man of many moods

	Mon, 27 Apr 1998 14:37:16 PDT
X-Originating-IP: [207.217.146.73]
From: "Natasha 426" <natasha426@hotmail.com>
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: TranceForce + Swadeshi reviews! :)
Content-Type: text/plain
Date: Mon, 27 Apr 1998 14:37:16 PDT
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

	Damn! What a weekend!  First, it was TranceForce Fryday nite...it was 
at the trippiest location -- this funky space in SF with an upstairs, a 
downstairs...*invisible* stairs... (yes, for those of you who are 
wondering, there was this little dinky corner stair that I  consistently 
kept missing EVERY time I descended into the dancing area...verrry 
tricky :)  Very kewl artwork and twisty windy hallways....and the MUSIC 
was incredible!  Nice hard trance, melodic trance (mars), psy trance 
(Dutch for a while...), angry trance (ala DRC :) wierd trance (some dude 
toward the end, don't remember his name)....who cares, it was ALL good 
:)  And it was SO SO SO nice to hang with Steve (finally!!!), Tony, 
Stephen, Mackdaddio, Derek ...and to meet lara, alex...who am i 
forgetting?  ...All in all, a totally kewl party!

Saturday nite was Swadeshi...again at the neatest space (I had never 
been there before, tho there've apparently been lotsa parties at this 
space)....a little warehouse/loft/apartment whatever with an upstairs 
where the dj was spinning in the kitchen!! Gotta love it :))
Music was a lotta mixed stuff that was out of my realm of Trancedom 
:)...but definitely lotsa energie and kewl peeps!!  It was great to meet 
amy, marco, sara, craig, gabbergirl, alex #2 ;> and Guy, and naturally 
to hang with stephen, michael (the VibeMan!) and josh!! You guys ROCK!! 
The party lasted all nite and well into the mornin' and had one of those 
home-grown-rave-vibes that ya just can't find at massives ...(like 
Bionic,blech!)  This made missing the huge goa/psy-festival thingy in 
the desert truly worthwhile (forgive me, G!!)...two great parties in the 
same weekend -- is it a full moon or somethin'??  ;)

I am now recharged and ready for my Week of Hell!!  (insert pouty face 
here)  But inside I am *still* smiling... =)

sending happy Monday vibes!!
:>  natasha

my friend asked me to make a CD-R copy of a tape he wants to preserve
for posterity called "John Howard Live at Sunset"... it is indeed a
very good tape, and I happened to make myself an extra CD-R copy while
I was at it. It sound killer, esp. after a little remastering and
re-eqing with my Finalizer (digital sound processing swiss army knife).

John Howard is god.

So... anybody know when this appearance was taped?

Also, the tape was clearly DATed (i heard a dat mistrack on side 1) and
i'm wondering if anybody has a copy of the DAT of this?

Oh, and if anybody has any good live DJ sets on DAT, I'll be happy to
make a CD for you as long as you let me keep a copy for myself. by
good, i mean preferably house, prog. house, chicago house, garage,
speed garage, interseting non-booyaka-booyaka non-harder-than-thou
jungle (i.e. wimpy white-suburban-jewish-momma's-boy-that-wears-normal-pants
intelligent drum and bass :-)).

catweasel said:

>> I don't consider myself trash but some people would), it was a comment
>> about a certain feel of music - music can feel black (detroit, jungle)
>> or white (goa trance, drumnbass).

How can you say what *Black Music* feels like? You can only say what
Catweasel music feels like.... and if you're going to bring race into it,
I would assume that you'd be able to feel *white* music, using your own
catergorizing...

I'm African American/Swedish and I take a bit of offense of people
catergorizing music... especially music that touches me deeply... LTJ is a
Shamen and he delivers.... (i'm going to skip the commercialism, as
Dina Alemagna has stated my claim on this... by any means necessary) it's
about his sound... which can only be catergorized as, "Ltj Bukem Style"... 
end of story....  individualism.

Everyone's perception is different... let us meet at the points of our
common interests and leave it at that.... lets no put lines between
ourselves... isn't that what raving is about??.. moving *above* and beyond
*this*... and being *one* once more...

I'm outtie 420 G!

*Byroni....... .   .     .     .     .     .     .     .     .     .    !
*____/\__(!/~***#:dj:h798:m:19847:e:242`1r4g`21:rid:g4hj`2g4j:ian:[sf][s)

> > sense of humor ;)

> > issues, but who am i 100% *eurotrash* Spain/Czech baby! it's true that 
> > sometimes humor doesn't manifest too well on email posts...
> > *huggies absorb more plur*
> 
> Is it wrong to not believe in PLUR on this list? Is it a prerequisite
> for membership? Do people who aren't PLURry get kicked off?
> Glad you liked Viberation, me n Andy were having a ball up there jumping around and cutting it up.
> 
> Radon wrote:
> > > > Hmmm... I wonder what LTJ and Goldie would think of your
> categorization of
> > > > their music as cheesy lightweight drum n bass white suburban
> trash
> > > > rubbish, especially since neither of them are white or suburban.
> 
> Yeah, but their market is white suburban people. You wouldn't get the
> Brixton massive listening to their stuff.
> 
>  Not to
> > > > mention, both have made immense contributions to drum n bass...
> without
> > > > them and the producers they have fostered and the scenes that
> they
> > > > helped build, I doubt you would even know what jungle is.
> > > >
> > > > show a little respect,
> 
> Hmm. gotta take you to task on this one. I don't know what jungle is 
> eh? Well, trust me, I've seen one hell of a lot more jungle than you, 
> coming from London and all. I saw LTJ for the first time in 94 in 
> Switzerland, I saw Goldie live in 95. And its the cheesy commercial 
> watering down of the jungle scene by people like the aforementioned 
> artists that really annoys me. Its taking something that was raw and
> energetic and came from the rough council estates and watering it down
> to sell to suburban people who don't want the rawness of true jungle.
> That's why I dissed their styles. The comment about white eurotrash 
> applies to me too (I'm white and european, I don't consider myself 
> trash but some people would), it was a comment about a certain feel of
> music - music can feel black (detroit, jungle) or white (goa trance,
> drumnbass). Its a funk thing. It has nothing to do with race or colour
> of skin, its about feel of the music. White people can make black
> music (e.g. jungle being the best example) and vice-versa. Why are
> people over here always actively searching for any comment to be 
> vaguely construed as non-PC, it gets on my tits sometimes (is that a
> non-PC comment as I don't have tits?). I dunno. 
> 
> I think y'all wanna chill out a bit and stop jumping on people for
> disliking things. If you don't like the music I like, I won't get 
> offended if you dis it, more power to you for saying how you feel. If 
> you get offended by my personal dislikes, then that's your problem, 
> its not going to stop me speaking my mind about it.
> 
> Anyway, we ought to meet up at this goldie thing to discuss it over a
> bowl. I'll be with the guy doing the dancing man visuals.
> 
> L8Rs

> K@wzl

Diamond) and DJ Andrew of Bugs/Ubiquity.  Ground Score ruling there!  What a

> vice-versa.
> 
> oh, you read that article too, eh? i remember awhiles back, there was
> some
> article in a newspaper or magazine or something about black music vs.
> white
> music. that black music is more something that seeps into you, more
> like
> body-sensitive sorta music whereas white music is more of a
> head/intellectual thingamabobber. then it went along to talk about how
> much
> popular music was in fact invented by black people and was more of a
> funk
> think like c@weasel says, then white folk picked up on it and made it
> digestable for the white masses, like elvis presley, or vanilla ice,
> or the
> beastie boys
> 
> it made an interesting comparison between tricky and dj spooky (outta
> nyc).
> tricky's big criticism concerning spooky is that spooky thinks too
> much
> about his music and intellectualizes it too much when, in tricky's
> opinion,
> real music is more instinctual, that you just kinda know it when you
> know
> it and theres no other way of knowing it. both tricky and spooky are
> black
> too, if that has any bearing on anything whatsoever
> 
> i dunno, i personally try to avoid this whole polarity between keepin
> it
> real and music for the (white?) masses. sometimes i feel the need for
> music
> that just plain gets me going, othertimes, i like music that i can
> wrap my
> mind around, that sorta fills in the spaces. when it comes jungle (i
> dont
> care about this whole dnb thing, i just call it all jungle), i find i
> keep
> toggling between the different kinds, depends on my mood
> 
> joe
> -man of many moods
> 
	[Moki]  Is it only me or does anyone else see that to even
intellectualize the discussion of the merits of black music v. white
music and the vibe that accompanies both genres makes my lower jaw hang
and I almost want to puke.

	There is music, created by people.  Ethnic background will
certainly contribute to their musical perspective as will a number of
other traits.  I speak up because I think that this discussioin, or
rather the validation of this discussion perpetuates the stereotypical
differences of what "black" or "white" music does to you.

	If it moves you, great.  But I think the authors of that article
trying to describe the color of music are idiots.  There was an African
drummer in the early part of this century who was renowned historically
as the best drummer able to communicate people's vibe and feelings
better than anyone.  He was known to people as the Mozart or Beethoven
of their time.  True story?  Not really, but it certainly is another
point of view you may never have heard of right?  The point is, which
point of view are you bandwagonning?  

	Music is like water, there are different types but it all flows.
If you can picture yourself flowing with it then it's music to you.  The
color of music is too abstract to quantify, IMHO.  If you insist on
believing in the "black" or "white" thing, then what about other ethnic
groups, what color would their music be, e.g., northern scandinavian
folk music, chinese opera music, middle eastern desert tribes music,
etc.  Ran outta change, gotta go...

	Aloha,
	Moki
	sending virtual sunshine...

> Catweasel wrote:

	[Moki]  Techno was born in Detroit with Derrick May (he's
black).  It's the grittier side of life and eschewed the bleakness
surrounding the motor city at the time.  Though it may have been adopted
by more whites as a form of music.  The creation of the genre by a
person of color is incidental as I think had it been by some "white" guy
then it's just as redundant.  

	I disagree with you that techno is a white version of
newyork/chicago house.  House music is just that.  Techno has an
entirely different vibe and pattern.  At least I think it does anyway
but maybe you've heard some mixes that were so borderline, it questioned
your definition of both styles.

My fish Turlock is about 4  and 1/2 inches long and about and inch and a half
tall.  He is a good fish.  I just feed him the normal, Tetra Fin flakes.  As

raised since he was a youngen.  If you are a fish lover, don't ever watch
turtles eat, i mean tear apart, fish.  Rather discusting......Right Jil??!

radon@kzsu.Stanford.EDU wrote:
> First off, I'd like to say that the tone of my post came off more 
> indignant than I intended. Sorry 'bout that.

Nuff respect for not letting this degenerate into a flame war - half expected to come back to an inbox full of flames after everyone bashed me for not liking drumnbass.

> > Yeah, but their market is white suburban people. You wouldn't get the
> > Brixton massive listening to their stuff.
> 
> Good point, although I doubt they intentionally market to white suburban 
> people, and they would probably argue that their intent is just to bring 
> drum n bass to as many people as possible. 

Yeah, bringing it to as many people as possible also has this side effect of getting very rich and powerful. Strange things happen when money becomes involved in people's motives...

> I can see where you're coming from, but as you can probably judge from 
> my comments above, I think that LTJ and Goldie's contribution to the 
> scene far exceeds any watering down they've done. If you'll forgive me 
> for speaking for them, they believe that the music should be spread far 
> and wide, that getting drum'n'bass/jungle heard is a good thing for the 
> scene. 
> That's a belief I agree with, but even if you don't, their music 
> is an important part of drum'n'bass/jungle history, and to dismiss 
> everything they've done as rubbish seems... overzealous?

What this waters down to is the age old problem of underground vs commercialism. It's been hacked out time and time again on mailing lists forever. It comes down to whether you believe that getting into a scene will change people for the better, or whether you believe that getting people into the scene will degrade the scene.
Based on my experience of Europe, I stand FIRMLY in the latter camp. What happened there will happen here soon, and I guess there's no way of stopping it - you have to learn the lessons yourself. The powers of commercial mass appeal involve money, and money is a more powerful force of change than music in this world, sad but true.
And I don't for a second believe that the outer appeal of goldie and LTJ and crowd is their real persona, they know the score of how money and power work. anyone who has got that far in the music biz will attest to that. They ain't innocent artists any more.
Overnout
K@wzl

http://www.geocities.com/SunsetStrip/Underground/5185
-----------------------------------------------------

At 01:03 PM 4/27/98 -0700, Sharif Torpis wrote:

>...music is music...like it for what it is not for who listens to it

music is not *just* music and who gets to define what it is?   it's much
more complex....it's much more political too in a sense, and layered with
meaning and people bring their own valid experiences in deciding on their
own choices and preferences.....and sometimes those preferences arise from
conflicting and multiple reasons e.g. I"m white and urban female and I grew
up in a city and sometimes I"m angry so maybe more aggressive jungle speaks
to that experience but I lived in a sleepy surf town so more mellow music
like trip-hop speaks to that experience too....and so what it is to one
person maybe a totally different thing than "what it is" to another
person....there are no single or simple right definitions of "what it is."

anywaze c@ actually you're choice in music is a political choice....whether
it's politically correct or not is up to some other judge to decide : -P and
you and AndyW did look awfully cute bouncing and cutting up at Vibe This.

Lauren

hey moki

i dont think you read my post all too carefully or even catweasel's
original one because catweasel (in his) says specifically that labelling
music black or white has nothing to do with race or color of skin but with
a feeling evoked by the music, he called it funk, this is how i understand
it. i brought up color of skin on people in relation to music because i
was alluding to the article which explicitly brought that into the
discussion

essentially, i was paraphrasing this article id read some year or two ago
that catweasel seemed to be paralleling in his post. if youd read the last
coupla lines of my own post, you wouldve seen that for my personal
classificational purposes, i prefer to avoid such polarities but classify
music by the way it affects me, because the different kinds affect me in
different ways

now, sofar as my detroit post goes, i based it on the system of logic
catweasel set forth in his original post: black music has a sense of funk,
white music doesnt. now, when you read that last line, remove all previous
connotations you may personally associate with either the word "black" or
the word "white", especially ones that are related to color of skin.

according to my skewed understanding of things, new york/chicago house has
a sense of funk, because it literally makes me want to shake my butt, must
be the way the bass is arranged, it kinda has that swing to it. therefore,
according to this system of logic that is set up in the last paragraph, i
would call that black music, because its funky. so far as detroit techno
goes, it doesnt seem quite so funky to me, seems to have less of it, if
any at all. it doesnt instinctively make me shake my butt, but moreso stop
and listen to the way the sounds and percussion fall into place
rhythmically and interact with each other. since it dont seem so funky, id
call it white music. so far, this discussion has nothing whatsoever to do
with color of skin

finally, i did mention in parentheses that the detroit trinity were black.
my point in doing so was to stress that this classification has nothing to
do with color of skin since, according to my understanding, the detroit
techno they made i would consider white music (i.e. w/out funk)

ok, i hope this clears things up a little. i have no intention of
offending anyone, i am trying my utmost to avoid it. if i am, and if my
logic fails somewhere in this post, i would honestly appreciate having it
pointed out to me so that i may be set right

joe
-suddenly feeling a little defensive

Mime-Version: 1.0

Date: Mon, 27 Apr 1998 18:31:53 -0800
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org, Curious George <gchan@best.com>
From: peter@niles.com (Peter Sandifer)
Subject: Curious George & the alpineheads (tahoe review)
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

So Jam Master Jamie, boomerang, Vertigo, Pengo, Pete T. & his gal pushed up
into the frosty nosebleed levels to cool it with Curious George & the
Alpineheads.  Pengo's cabin was a bust but Curious George opened his rustic
digs to the SanFran Fam, so with 2 sound systems,  30 candles, a box of
glowsticks & a half-dozen vinyl crates we slid sideways over the snowy peak
and into the valley below.

Saturday the rest of the SF kids showed up & we spread out the gear,
squabbling over cables & cursing at mixers as words buzzed through town
about the SF technoheads in the cabin up on Rocky Point Road.  By sundown
the alpineheads-- snowboarders, skiers, townie drunks--  started to roll
in, searching for kegs & finding nuclear glowstick trails instead.  Most of
these cats, I catch, had their eardrums rattled by the techno machine for
the very first time.    The ravers in the house spread the fire until the
rafters shook.   Vertigo stank up the room real sweet, but I'm getting a
bit yawny of all the wet mixes;  i'd fancy it green if the kid would throw
the sneakers in the dryer once in awhile just to let us know he ain't a
calculator.

Pete T. kicked out smooth but cracked the fatal whoopsie of dropping the
volume on a beerflow dancefloor.  Ravers digs the speakers clean & clear,
but the snowjacks & alpinebunnies needed noise to filter the buzz.  Smooth
programming from what I heard, though.

Ryan Newell dropped a pleasant surprise with some wet mixes & friendly
vinyl,  & kept Jam Master Jamie hopping the drunkboy hurdles.

Pengo too popped out some pretty funk, jigged it something fancy after only
4 months at the helm.  One of those "Lemme Scratch Your Record"
drunkspotters made a wreck of Pengo's groove & Boomerang almost laid a
stomping to his soul, but  Jam Master Jamie buried the Boomerang with juicy
lips & made it all peace.

Then someone dropped the 20-Megaton Rubberleg Bomb on the house and things
got mighty butterfly as the beerheads shuffled off to their wheels.  The
rafters shook til 3 or so and the groove stayed nice.

I catch it most of the alpineheads were dropjawed with the vibe.  Mad love
to Curious George for the invitation and the warm hospitality!    :o)

--b))merang

Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


  Many years ago a famous jazz trumpet player, Roy Eldridge, was
discussing this very issue with jazz critic Leonard Feather. Eldridge
insisted he could always tell the race of the musician by the style of his
playing. So Feather assembled a number of records by obscure performers
(since you could easily tell the identity of the famous ones), and played
them for Eldridge without telling him whether the musicians were black or 
white.
  Eldridge guessed the race right 55% of the time.

roots to the colors found in a standard box of crayolas. however, if

meanings having *nothing* to do with race. lets not get into the
history of language as we've been there before on this list and i
haven't been subbed all *that* long. must people always search for
something to bicker about? hasn't this gone just a bit too far? the
sun is yellow. does that mean that i'm making a derogatory reference
to asians? if icall something red, am i making rreference to it being
hot or a derogatory remark about native americans? sorry - i just

> hey moki
> 
> i dont think you read my post all too carefully or even catweasel's
> original one because catweasel (in his) says specifically that
> labelling
> music black or white has nothing to do with race or color of skin but
> with
> a feeling evoked by the music, he called it funk, this is how i
> understand
> it. i brought up color of skin on people in relation to music because
> i
> was alluding to the article which explicitly brought that into the
> discussion
	[Moki]  My point is that to use labels associated with the color
of skin in general evokes racial parallels.  I mean, if jazz has a blue
tone, would it be different if people started saying that there's white
jazz and black jazz?  As I'm sure people already say that, but for the
purposes of our discussion, you can see that using white and black to
describe music denotes too many negative connotations.  I do see your
point but I view it as a non-ethnic point of view, not to cast
aspersions on your remarks mind you.   

> essentially, i was paraphrasing this article id read some year or two
> ago
> that catweasel seemed to be paralleling in his post. if youd read the
> last
> coupla lines of my own post, you wouldve seen that for my personal
> classificational purposes, i prefer to avoid such polarities but
> classify
> music by the way it affects me, because the different kinds affect me
> in
> different ways
	[Moki]  I realize that my reaction may have been written a
little too strongly.  I apologize for any discomfort caused to you and
C@t.  It's your personal opinion and you're certainly entitled to it.
You avoid polarities you say and yet it is generally understood that
white is the complete opposite of black.  Furthermore, when you say
music relates to black and funk, well I don't agree that white music or
the vibe of it is devoid of funk.  I think Beethoven's 9th is pretty
damn funky, weird?  Dunno, just do.

> now, sofar as my detroit post goes, i based it on the system of logic
> catweasel set forth in his original post: black music has a sense of
> funk,
> white music doesnt. now, when you read that last line, remove all
> previous
> connotations you may personally associate with either the word "black"
> or
> the word "white", especially ones that are related to color of skin.
	[Moki]  I can't, and I challenge everyone else to act in the way
you suggest to see if they indeed can discount all historical
connotations with white and black.  And why would you use those terms if
you weren't predisposed to do so by influences of our times?  It's
bordering on ridiculous but why can't you use blue or red?  A gang
thing?  How about brown or yellow?  Oh, another ethnic quandary.  Do you
see the pitfalls of using terms with so much excess baggage and then
merely tossing it aside as a trivial coincidence?  As far as funk, I
think that's the deepest of vibes and if the music moves you no matter
what genre then it's got the funk.

> according to my skewed understanding of things, 
	[Moki]  Don't self-deprecate, you don't need to.  I view your
opinions as one made by an intelligent person, it just happens to be
different and therefore unique.

> new york/chicago house has
> a sense of funk, because it literally makes me want to shake my butt,
> must
> be the way the bass is arranged, it kinda has that swing to it.
> therefore,
> according to this system of logic that is set up in the last
> paragraph, i
> would call that black music, because its funky. so far as detroit
> techno
> goes, it doesnt seem quite so funky to me, seems to have less of it,
> if
> any at all. it doesnt instinctively make me shake my butt, but moreso
> stop
> and listen to the way the sounds and percussion fall into place
> rhythmically and interact with each other. since it dont seem so
> funky, id
> call it white music. so far, this discussion has nothing whatsoever to
> do
> with color of skin
	[Moki]  So you're into the funkier side of dance music, that's
great, so am I.  I think that desensitizing the music with a black or
white label brings the importance of that music down.  I guess I'm
trying to influence you through my own ideas of why continuing to think
of various forms of music as black or white can only lead to confusion.
I mean you always get the "boozies from the burbs" who wanna be down and
all of a sudden after a big rave, they know all about jungle/d&b, house,
trip-hop, etc.  I just think that another term(s) would be better.  I
only reply because there are so many people on this list and I thought
there was another side that needed voicing.

> finally, i did mention in parentheses that the detroit trinity were
> black.
> my point in doing so was to stress that this classification has
> nothing to
> do with color of skin since, according to my understanding, the
> detroit
> techno they made i would consider white music (i.e. w/out funk)
	[Moki]  I disagree, there's funk in it, it just ain't as funky
na'mean?

> ok, i hope this clears things up a little. i have no intention of
> offending anyone, i am trying my utmost to avoid it. if i am, and if
> my
> logic fails somewhere in this post, i would honestly appreciate having
> it
> pointed out to me so that i may be set right
	[Moki]  We're having a discussion, not an offensive argument at
all so no worries.  IMHO, your logic fails in that you insist on calling
funky music black and non-funky music white.  I think the effects are so
wide ranging that you would be better served if you simply referred to
music that makes you want to shake your butt as funky and the other kind
as not funky, period.  Using white or black only lends itself to heated
debates and perhaps confusion on your intent. 

> joe
> -suddenly feeling a little defensive
	[Moki]  Not meaning for you to feel that way, you have your
thoughts and I have mine.  Both were represented and I understand what
you are trying to say.  I equate our discussion with explaining to
people when they ask me if I'm flip because I look part Filipino.  I
say, "No, actually I'm mostly spic with a little nigger."  A friendly
term to them that was entirely misunderstood.  Hence, my motivation to
reply to your posts.  BTW, apologies to those of Spanish or
African-American heritage but I do use those terms to make an example.
I'm actually Spanish and Filipino, though it certainly doesn't give me
license to use such derogatory terms, I don't give a fuck so sue me.
Hey, just kidding, I don't need another lawsuit but I really don't give
a flyin' rat's ass about the other stuff.  Please feel free to voice
your opinion if you have one.   

	Hey, you got any phat house tapes?  Maybe you wanna trade, I
need some dopalicious new grooves to dance to.  Let me know.  I'm
out...peace be with you...

	aloha,
	moki
	sending virtual sunshine...

YIkes hide your pets...nick is looking for food for his bbq.
Dont do it nick...even if you're really hungry...dont eat
your pet fish or their food.

Ive always liked fish but sometimes feel sorry for them
in that little glass box eating that dehydrated rice cake
stuff day after day.

fishes daily diary...

sun:   ate, swam around tank
mon:   ate, swam around tank
tue:   ate, swam around tank
wed:   ate, swam around tank
thu:   ate, swam around tank
fri: dang human went out dancing and forgot to feed me so 
 i swam around tank
sat: human brought home cute raver girl who kept starring at me
 but didnt know how to feed me, so i swam around tank.

Anyone know what kind of music your pets like?
I find fish like ambient and trance altho if it gets too
loud they get annoyed as fish are pretty sensitive.

Just wanted to drop a quick thanks to all those of you involved in helping
with and being at/with Alice in Wonderland; I had the time of my life, and
the return trip was nothing short of mystical.  In fact, the spirit threw
me into an amazing Sunday as well... it threw off a lot of my (east coast)
jadedness, and was a wonderful welcome to the Bay Area.  I'm glad to see
that the vibe is alive and strong, and that there's a group of people
dedicated to keeping it that way.  Awesome job!

<mike>

1st rule of peeling away fictions:  Throw away the history books and the
newspapers - your senses provide all the data you need.

-->Hellow everybody,

	I had a great time and I know that all the peeps that made it over
to my place on Friday had a good time too!!!  Major props to DjNick for
sharing a beautiful sound system, as well as laying down some phat beats,
and I wanted to thank Michael Standish (aka Ulrich) for carrying on the
vibe, as well as Derek and Mark (mook) for touching the vinyl. Big *Hugs*
to Elena, Lisa, Mickey, Lacie, Tony, Josh W., Starchild, and all my other
fine feathered friends for flying from far for five fun filled fabulously
decadent hours of merriment...now all I have to do is get rid of  the
empty bottles :) I hope I didn't forget anybody's name, but I just had a
wonderful time seeing all my friends from different worlds getting along
so well and mingling amiably; but then again, there was all that wine :)
It was amazing that the neighbors didn't complain, but that just shows
what a perfect evening should be about.


This lidda BuddahFlye is feeling all so very warm and fuzzy inside :)

M&m

Catweasel wrote:

> What this waters down to is the age old problem of underground vs commercialism. It's been hacked out time and time again on mailing lists forever. It comes down to whether you believe that getting into a scene will change people for the better, or whether you believe that getting people into the scene will degrade the scene.
> Based on my experience of Europe, I stand FIRMLY in the latter camp. What happened there will happen here soon, and I guess there's no way of stopping it - you have to learn the lessons yourself. The powers of commercial mass appeal involve money, and money is a more powerful force of change than music in this world, sad but true.
> And I don't for a second believe that the outer appeal of goldie and LTJ and crowd is their real persona, they know the score of how money and power work. anyone who has got that far in the music biz will attest to that. They ain't innocent artists any more.
> Overnout
> K@wzl
> 


I think its amusing that you feel that just because someone is involved
in an underground scene, they are supposed to be a better person  I
operated under this same mistaken notion when I was into the
diy-hardcore-punk scene.  Later I realized that just because people
superficially espoused radical beliefs they were not any better people. 
The scene I was in believed in being drug-free, vegan, and fighting for
animal rights, but people who slipped out of the scene became addicts
just like the rest of society, and many of the less relevant scenesters
never even embraced vegetarianism.  The event that finally shook my
belief was when a friend of mine was date-raped by another of my
"friends" who was also a major scenester.  Most rave scenes I've
experienced have at least as many problems as society, if not more.  So
please let go of the belief that you are changing the world for the
better just by listening to music.

I believe that any attempt to embrace the mainstream ends up watering
down the heart of a scene, isn't it enough to let the world know that
the scene exists and let the people with an interest learn to like the
music?


summary/addendum: underground is in no way inherently better than
commercial music, it can only be better by choosing a less destructive
distribution channel and by maintaining artistic control.


sorry for soapboxing on my first mail to sfraves....


anthony aka salsa

message.  Read the full text of Title 47 Sec 227 at 
http://www.law.cornell.edu/uscode/47/227.html

is anyone out there listening?

i'm posting this little gig- because the last show that i went to
confirmed my admiration for the band!
if you like slow, trippy, spacey, beautifully melodic music w/ a lush
undertone of vocals...  you'll want to check out these bands!  
i can only speak for sweet trip and andalusia... but if the other two
are half as good as these bands-  you're instore for an incredible
night of dreamy live music!

_trust me on this people!_ 
i've got no connection to either of the bands, yet i'm preaching about
them!
(sort of my remedy to a withdrawl from the band slowdive!)
hope to see lots of you there!!!
parkings a bitch in northbeach...  but that night i might just have to
splurge on a cab!

but don't miss analusia!)

I used sonic images for my first tape, and if you do under 250, there is a charge.  and the set up fee was DOUBLE what i paid at DAVKORE for my 2nd tape.  sorry i don't have the #, but info will.  it's worth checking out, and i know they do j-cards, but not sure on the pricing, i did my own.....
