news from the east coast....

-------

'Raver' dies of overdose

By CHRISTINE MAGNOTTA
Pocono Record Writers
cmagnotta@poconorecord.com

EAST STROUDSBURG - A 20-year old Virginia man who came to the
Poconos for an all-night dance party died of a drug overdose
Monday at Pocono Medical Center.

An official at Mount Airy Lodge, the resort that hosted the
event, said Monday it is unlikely similar dance parties,
called "raves," would be held.

Jason Robert Williamson of Virginia Beach died of
"multi-system failure" at 1:36 p.m. after being unconscious
for more than 15 hours at the medical center, Monroe County
Coroner Dave Thomas said.

A second drug overdose victim from California is in critical
condition at the hospital.

"I think the death of any person any time is tragic," said
Alfred Heim, managing director at Mount Airy Lodge. "I'd like
to separate that from the event. I'm a father and can
sympathize with the family of the child. Our sympathies go to
the family."

The 14-hour party, which drew about 8,500 teen-agers and young
adults from several states, "was of a magnitude where I doubt
the owner would allow such a large event to take place again
at the hotel." The rave lasted from 6 p.m. Saturday to 8 a.m.
Sunday.

"I can't see us doing it again," said Heim, who emphasized
that he was not responsible for booking the event. "We're
still recovering from the weekend."

PMVB chief lashes out

In a rare display of anger at a resort, Robert Uguccioni,
executive director of the Pocono Mountains Vacation Bureau,
said no more raves should be held in the region.

"We would strongly, strongly encourage Mount Airy never to
book this kind of a group. Ever. No matter what the rationale,
no matter what the numbers. We are not supportive of this kind
of an enterprise in our area," Uguccioni said. "The Pocono
Mountains Vacation Bureau is not supportive of Mount Airy or
other resorts holding similar events in the Poconos. Period.
Period. Period."

Heim said he would meet with other resort officials today to
assess the aftermath of the rave.

"My predecessor booked it," he said. "I don't think he was
fully aware how it would evolve."

Mount Airy hosted a similar event in September, though that
attracted about 2,500 youths. There were several arrests but
no deaths at that rave.

Police are unsure if Williamson came here alone or if he had
planned on joining others to stay at Mount Airy or its sister
resort, Strickland's Mountain Inn.

Thomas said Williamson's kidneys failed and the victim had to
be put on a dialysis machine at the hospital.

Toxicology reports will reveal what drugs Williamson ingested,
inhaled, or injected, Thoma said.

Family `heartbroken'

Williamson's uncle and grandmother described the victim to one
of the ambulance crew members as a straight A college student.

"They were heartbroken," Leah Murray, an emergency medical
technician with the Tannersville-based volunteer Central
Pocono Ambulance team, said of the family. She drove the
ambulance that brought Williamson to the hospital and then
called the family.

The parents drove up from Virginia, she said.

Murray described the rave, officially billed as an
"International Music Conference," as wild, with throngs of
teen-agers slamming into each other as a live band pelted out
alternative music. She and her crew treated four overdose
patients.

"They made a really big nice mess," she said, adding that the
temperature in the Sports Palace "was about 100 degrees."

Drug arrests

As Williamson lay dying in Pocono Medical Center, state police
from Swiftwater were charging three young adults with
possession with the intent to deliver after they found more
than 100 hits of LSD in a black pouch that was left at the
Ramada Inn at Delaware Water Gap. The drugs were hidden in
chewing gum wrappers.

Darlla Lindaw, 20, of Pasadena, Md., Pascal B. Halabi, 18, of
Falls Church Va., and James E. Martin, 18, of Stonewood, W.
Va., had about $1,000 worth of a horse tranquilizer known as
"Special K," LSD, Ecstasy and methamphetamine. Police expect
to release the details of all of the confiscated drugs
Tuesday.

Some of the pills were in a bag tucked into Lindlaw's bra.

In all, there were 22 drug arrests, police said.

The partiers each paid $25 to attend the event. That money
went to the event organizer, Local 13, of Philadelphia, Heim
said. The organization is a business and is not affiliated
with a union, he said.

"We leased the hall to them," he said. He refused to say how
much Mount Airy received for leasing the space to Local 13.

Heim referred inquiries to a Philadelphia man affiliated with
Local 13. Repeated calls to his home Monday were met with busy
signals. There is no phone listing for Local 13.

Extra coverage

State police scheduled an additional 40 troopers to patrol the
area during the rave.

"From our point of view it ran smoothly," said Sergeant Donald
Fernbach, supervisor of the crime section of the Swiftwater
barracks.

As many as 2,000 teen-agers who attended the concert went to
the Promised Land State Park in Pike County afterwards to
party but were chased away by police early Sunday morning.
Needles and syringes were found at the park.

Police believed some of the teens attending the concert were
also responsible for vandalizing the Martz bus terminal in
Mount Pocono. Initials were scratched into the windows and
graffiti was spray-painted on the building.

Some of the thousands of young adults had gone to the resort
not for the drugs, but for what they called a unique musical
experience they couldn't get in their hometowns.

But in the long run, Fernbach said, the music may not be what
Pocono residents remember of the International Music
Conference.

"I'm sure the event will be overshadowed by the fact that
someone died while attending the concert," he said.
                                   Copyright                            Return to www.poconorecord.com

As a person who lived in East Stroudsburg for a good part of her life, I
am shocked the local officials even allowed this rave.  Now it will
never happen again knowing how insular the area is and how it reacts
when one party goes bad but yet they give the first day of hunting off
as a school holiday.  it is also just so surreal for me to think of
doing drugs in those places they mentioned considering i know all the
places they mentioned well and  i was not into drugs when  living there.

*weird*  That article was a trip for me in itself....

Cassandra

Hi all!  ]=}

 In light of the recent death on the east coast (thanks for the info 
Troy!) I thought I would post this report.

 At a recent UG, an individual lost touch with reality. Screaming, 
muttering nonsense, climbing on top of a truck and eating dirt where 
only some of the behaviors we witnessed. Luckily it was daylight by this 
time and we were able to keep said person from hurting them self. Said 
person was completly unresponsive to anyone for a long time.

 This person admitted to consuming a lot of MDMA. We also suspect LSD 
was involved.

 BE FUCKING CAREFUL!!!!! You idiots who OD are ruining the scene!!!!


Ran D. Dreams

While it wasn't what I expected last night, I had a good time.
The music was some of the best I've heard there, but there
was no crowd.  A few of us loyalists and a few local yokels.
What happened?  Macadio was great and so was Trent.
He kicked my ass.  I admit a lot of it had to do with that one
drunk guy going up to all of you cute grrrlies out there,
spilling his beer and trying to put the mack down on all of you.
I could smell his breath a mile away.  

There were a couple of tracks that Trent spun that I really
have to get a hold of.  Does anyone have his email address?
Does he have a tape of his schtuff?  

Your Jedi Bitch,
jedi666boy

p.s. - And on the megan front...  I'll just keep my mouth shut
before I put my foot in it.  You looked great out there...  ;)

Jerry Springer is an asshole and his show beautifully represents how our
society is so jacked up in that it spends too much time giving a shit
about other people's personal business. 

If everyone would just accept everyone else's acts for what they are and
merely take them with a grain of salt instead of trying to change them to
their standards, we would live in a much more respectful society.  Go to
Europe or anywhere else.  When you're pondering why you like Europe ,and
much of the rest of the world for that matter, so much more (atleast in
my case) than America, you'll find that one of the reasons why is 'cause
people are more accepting to things that happen and don't try and change
them to what they think is proper which is a common thing in this
biblically strangled country.

Our society needs to understand how to respect people for who they are
and not to try and change them to their individual standards.  We are all
individuals and we should all be loved and respected for our thoughts and
actions that make us special.

Hmmm, don't mind my rambling.

C Ya'll later.

Drekster

Hi again Adder,

You shared:

>On Wed, 22 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:
>
>> >Let's examine that line of reasoning for a second. By having no zoning, I
>> >could open a concrete factory that ran 24 hours a day, or how about
>> >a garbage dump right next to your property and that would be ok with you
>> >since it is after all my property?
>>
>>         There is an alternative to zoning; it is called common sense.  If
>> you're opening a business, you don't want to piss off all your neighbors,
>> and you're going to try to reach reasonable accomodations with people.
>
>Not in the U.S. If something is not implicitly illegal(and sometimes even
>when it is...) then people *will* do it.

        Clearly respect for the law breaks down when there are too many bad
laws on the books.  Consider how it would be if the only law we had was a
law against murder -- people would have a lot of respect for the law,
because it would uphold a value that virtually everyone agreed with.  Most
people like to consider themselves law-abiding citizens, so they don't
break the law just for the hell of it.  But when you get to the point where
you have truly stupid laws which openly invite ridicule like the statutes
prohibiting "hate speech" or defacing government currency, people *will*
break the law for the hell of it.  And somewhere quite a way down that path
from laws which almost everyone respects to laws which few respect and even
fewer can wholeheartedly believe in, you will find zoning laws.

>> Furthermore, your examples are quite extreme.
>
>However they are completely valid.

        Valid in that they possibly could happen, yes.  But a strong case
for zoning would argue against what's most often likely to occur in the
absence of zoning laws, not against far-fetched hypotheticals.

>> I would venture to say that 99% of what people want to do with their
>> property that is prohibited by zoning would have less of a negative
>> impact on their neighbors than opening a garbage dump or concrete
>> factory in a residential area.
>
>Did you know the 86.5% of all statistics are made up? Really, all one can
>do is guess. Zoning takes out much of that guesswork.

        All right, now that was a really cheap shot.  8(   I was obviously
using "99%" as a figure of speech, not as an actual statistic.

>>         In the few cases where someone actually went ahead and did
>> something like this, they could always be taken to court.  Subjecting you
>> to regular doses of loud noise or foul stench that did not exist when you
>> moved into your property could definitely be considered a violation of your
>> property rights, and I think most judges and juries would be inclined to
>> look favorably on the plaintiff in such a case.
>
>And without a standard set of applicable laws, decisions would likely be
>reached in an even more haphazard and conflicting fashion than they are
>now.

        I think there is ample reason to believe that a system based on
private property rights, rather than government zoning, would result in
fewer haphazard and conflicting decisions, not more.

        Right now people wishing to make improvements on their property are
forced to go through a bureaucratic process during which they can be
arbitrarily denied permission for their project by government officials
based on an interpretation of the law, even if no one else objects to what
they are doing.

        At least under a libertarian approach you would know that the
government wouldn't stop you from doing your thing on your own land if none
of your neighbors had a problem with you.  Thus only if there really was a
problem would the law need to get involved, which would simplify matters
enormously.

>> >Zoning laws, right or wrong(or however misapplied) exist for a reason, and
>> >sometimes they are good reasons.
>>
>>         There is almost always a good intention behind every additional
>> measure of power and control exerted by government.  Very often new laws
>> are invoked as necessary to correct problems caused by previous state
>> interventions!  You say that housing in San Francisco is scarce and
>> expensive, therefore people cannot be expected to turn down decent living
>> places just because of a little late-night noise.  Instead, you seem to
>> imply, they should move in and then pretend they weren't aware of the
>> problem beforehand in order to press neighborhood businesses to change in
>> order to accomodate them.
>
>Please, don't attempt to put words in my mouth.

        Aw, come on, not even good, tasty nutritious ones?  Eat your words,
dammit!  Don't you know that other kids are starving in Japan?  ;)-

>What I stated is that when
>a person moves in to a dwelling is that they have the right (legally and
>"morally") to receive "quiet enjoyment" of that property.
>
>If there is blame to be laid it is with the person(s) making the zoning
>decisions.

        If they deserve blame, it's not for failing at an impossible task,
but for thinking they could do it in the first place.  The essential
problem with zoning is that no single person or committee is capable of
guessing the best uses for a particular piece of land within a city's
boundaries.  Neighborhoods change.  People and businesses come and go.
Technologies change, land use needs change.  Even if by some miracle you
could draw up a perfect map today, it would be obsolete in a week.  It
wouldn't matter if the zoning board was composed of the kindest, wisest,
most capable human beings on earth; the process would still be a futile
waste of time, money, and resources in which someone is bound to be
unfairly screwed.

>What I find in the attitude expressed by you and others is myopia. It is
>the inherient inability to see things from any other perspective but your
>own. It is what leads to the constant "us vs. them" syndrome that so much
>of this society enjoys.

        Look, I do not hate city planners (or cops, or unethical promoters)
regardless of what I may say against their *practices*.  They're all human
beings.  Know ye that I am a generous God, who believes in redemption (just
kidding.)  But seriously, taking a strong position on something doesn't
necessarily mean that one is unable to see other perspectives, just that
one feels strongly!

        I'm sure you're not suggesting that every hothead on SFRaves who
regularly gets into strident and vocal back-and-forth arguments on the list
about all manner of subjects with all manner of persons is a victim of
myopia.  Glass houses, y'know... ;)

>> I also feel that if many of you who are
>> >railing about your rights to dance would quickly change your opinion if
>> >you found yourselves unable to sleep at 3 a.m. due to noise.
>>
>>         Usually when I'm unable to sleep it's because of emergency
>> vehicles, car alarms, and public works crews who seem to enjoy tearing up
>> the pavement near my apartment with jackhammers before 8 o'clock in the
>> morning.  I've found these to be much worse insomniants (wordcheck?) than
>> the steady, low pitch thud-thud-thud of a sound system.
>
>Do you live right next to a club? Could you at all entertain the
>possibility that hearing that thud-thud-thud night after night after night
>might begin to bother you after a while?

        Yes I'm sure it would, and I acknowledge that it probably would
bother most people.  But the point I was making is that for me, and I
suspect many others, raves and clubs are not the noise polluters that cause
me the most loss of sleep, yet they seem to be unfairly singled out by the
authorities.  Furthermore, I recognize and acknowledge peaceful slumber as
a legitimate aspiration of the masses.  ;)  However there does not seem to
be a similar recognition among anti-club residents of the legitimacy of
late-night dance parties.  Now you tell me who is suffering from "the
inability to see things from any other perspective but your own"?

>>         Certainly emergency vehicles, if not the other items are recognized
>> as a necessary public good.  But why cannot raves be similarly recognized?
>
>Please. As a person that enjoys music, and has gone to a couple of clubs
>in my life time, if I had to make a decision as to which was more
>important me shaking my ass at 3 a.m. or the ability for someone to sleep
>so they can get up and live their life, I would side with the person
>needing sleep.
>
>> Surely the amount of happiness that is created is worth something to the
>> community.  I don't believe the few should be sacrificed for the good of
>> the many, but in a moral grey area such as we seem to have with the SOMA
>> neighbors-club dispute, the happiness of hundreds ought to count for at
>> least as much as the undisturbed sleep of one or two, wouldn't you say?
>
>No. And being to give a yes and no answer is the crux of the issue. Common
>ground must be found for there to be hope of everyone being happy....

        So given that you think one or two people's undisturbed sleep is
inherently more important than the joyous celebration of hundreds, what
common ground do you suggest?

May the bass be with us,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

writes:
>  Go to Europe or anywhere else.  When you're pondering why 
>you like Europe ,and much of the rest of the world for that matter, so 
>much more (atleast in my case) than America, you'll find that one of 
>the reasons why is 'cause people are more accepting to things that 
>happen and don't try and change them to what they think is proper 
>which is a common thing in this biblically strangled country.

<Begin MooK's rhetoric>
NOTE: My point is at the bottom if ya don't want to read the reasoning
below.

Actually there are many countries that it is not possible to live outside
the norm withot endangering yourself. In Pakistan (or is it Afghanistan)
they are fighting a Religious Civil war over and if the conservative
muslims win, women won't be able to go outside unacompanied or uncovered.
In China it's against the law to have any religion. In the Serbian area
they're still killin' folks because they are a different race. Almost
everyday in Israel there are people killing each other over land and
religious beliefs. In my home country (Ireland) they've only just this
month made a peace agreement that should last. I can go into greater
deatil and cite more examples but I think you get the point.

This country is notorious for its hypocracy but it does have something
that most other places don't have and that's freedom. Slowly but surely
that freedom is fading as we keep adding new laws and making more things
illegal, but it is more free than a large part of the world. With that
freedom comes the bad as well as the good. But it's the good that makes
having freedom worth dealing with the bad.

POINT: Granted there is a lot wrong with this country, but the freedoms
it offers are the reasons living here is not only bearable but desirable.

MooK<><

can say. It is art and understanding art both at the same time. It is
beautiful."

period> anymore, but i can remember many happy latenites < the insomniac
showing is at 2 am i think, or at least it used to be > curled up on the couch
watching jerry and the audience grill the scapegoat guests... I especially love
it when there's a lil brawl and jerry kinna puts his hand up to his face as if
he's trying to look pained that 'ppl resort to violence'... but under that hand
you can totally see a grin, as if goin thru his head is 'HEHEHEH RATINGS'...

On Wed, 29 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:

> break the law for the hell of it.  And somewhere quite a way down that path
> from laws which almost everyone respects to laws which few respect and even
> fewer can wholeheartedly believe in, you will find zoning laws.

No, that is where *you* will find them. I see both the necessity and the
value of zoning laws. 

> >> Furthermore, your examples are quite extreme.
> >
> >However they are completely valid.
> 
>         Valid in that they possibly could happen, yes.  But a strong case
> for zoning would argue against what's most often likely to occur in the
> absence of zoning laws, not against far-fetched hypotheticals.
> 

As someone else pointed out, zoning laws were enacted *because*
"far-fetched" hypotheticals were happening.


> >And without a standard set of applicable laws, decisions would likely be
> >reached in an even more haphazard and conflicting fashion than they are
> >now.
> 
>         I think there is ample reason to believe that a system based on
> private property rights, rather than government zoning, would result in
> fewer haphazard and conflicting decisions, not more.

And could very likely result with waste dumps in people's back yards, or
total anarchy in the layout of cities. I'm sorry that you feel that this
is far-fetched, but I don't agree.

>         At least under a libertarian approach you would know that the
> government wouldn't stop you from doing your thing on your own land if none
> of your neighbors had a problem with you.  Thus only if there really was a
> problem would the law need to get involved, which would simplify matters
> enormously.

And what if the neighbors had a problem with what you did *after* it was
up? Are you supposed to tear it down? Are the neighbors supposed to
monitor any changes any of their other neighbors want to make to their
properties?

Starchild, this is pointless. You can argue with me all you want, but when
it comes down to it, you are arguing about how things should be, not how
things are. The club owners are going to win or lose based on current statutes,
and efforts on their parts, not by arguing how things *should be*.

> >of someone in half and putting them back together again
> >represented death and rebirth or reincarnation.
>

> things like death when they could just as easily cut somebody apart for
> real to sacrifice to the Earth Goddess or whomever... pretty un-PLUR if you

Actually I'd disagree with this 'un-PLUR' comment. All societal values
aren't the same as our being 'the western world' or our being 'america' or
our being 'ravers' or your 'being you :)', values, and just because they
aren't doesn't make them wrong, nor un-PLUR.  In fact, in many societies
it was a serious HONOR to be sacrificed to whatever diety, some cultures
even held contests and the winner was the one sacrificed.

>         But maybe they just couldn't afford to hire any decent magicians.

> religions put the bulk of their cashflow into crafting gold idols.
> 
>                                 <<< Starchild >>>

Which in lots of cultures was believed to hold part of the spirit of the
diety and bring them that much closer to their followers. :)

> >         At least under a libertarian approach you
>would know that the
> > government wouldn't stop you from doing your
thing on your own land if none
> > of your neighbors had a problem with you.  Thus
>only if there really was > > problem would the law
need to get involved, which would simplify matters
> > enormously.

Wow what a scary thought! This would enhance every
possible problem you could think of. It would create
caos and would cause police so many problems they
wouldn't have enough folks to cover it. You should
think about that statement again.

Example:
I could be a big time drug dealer. Put up crank labs
all over town. Since I can build anything I want
until you have an issue. When whole neighborhoods
start blowing up you might start retracting that.
Because,
to start with, my lab looks ordinary enough, like a
shed or add on to a house. Its already a huge problem!

Imagine if there were no zoning laws. I could build a
cement runway down my stairwell out on to 20th
street. So I can ride my mountain bike off my second
story.
O.K. the neighbors have an issue because my little
contraption blocks the sidewalk, but there are no
zoning laws so that would have to be determined in
a court of law. In the meantime, I'm building a skate
board park in my backyard for the local kids. Sure
its noisy but again it would have to be determined in
court. You see my point?



> Starchild, this is pointless. You can argue with me
all you want, but when
> it comes down to it, you are arguing about how
things should be, not how
> things are. The club owners are going to win or
lose based on current statutes,
> and efforts on their parts, not by arguing how
things *should be> 

Or should you sa,y "How they are never going to be
period." Your right they will win or lose (lose)
straight out - upright. I was at Spundae on Sunday
night and the cops came around 2:00am there were
probably 50 people in the whole club and the music
was turned down considerably. I mean I play louder in
my bedroom with neighbors O.K. They shut down the
upstairs outside and said they might close for the
night. It didn't happen but a bouncer told me point
blank they are on their way out and thats that. I
wish it weren't
true but it is.

Layne

Here's what I do for a drugless high... 
(although you can argue food is a drug) 
 
I eat a lot of pizza 
 
Quantity is about a deep dish medium at Zacherys. 
I guess a good deal of blood from my brain rushes 
to my stomach leaving me somewhat lightheaded: 
I endup being somewhat goofy. 
 
I guess not as intense as what Giles is talking 
about, but my friends and I all definitly reconize 
it as a pizza high! 
 
 
zza

Peter Sandifer wrote:

> Techno is definitely the dominant sound at Burning Man, but my thought
> about it is that the techno is there because of its futuristic,
> fin-de-siecle feel. 

It is not a county fair where the promoters pipe in muzak over the "Sound System"
hoping to establish a mood. But if you had drank your water and sat in the shade 
instead of getting heatstroke, you would have found that out.

>  But there's definitely not anything remotely ravey
> about Burning Man, for me.

Now, *I know* you are one of the most non-linear creative/intelligent people on this 
list, so I am going to just delete that statement and pretend I didnt read it.
 
>  in fact, i don't remember seeing any ravers there.  (unless they were all
> nekkid!)

Remember all those sound systems(pumping differant forms of dance music) you passed by 
in a heatstroke daze. Each of those sound systems were carted out by "ravers". A 
differant crew brought out their own sound system. Maybe your definition of "Rave" is 
10,000 ravers <no outsiders> and a 100,000 watt sound system. 
but some people would call a 500 watt system, 10 dancers, a camp fire 
and 200 naked people walking by banging drums- a rave. 

I saw 7 of those and I didnt make the rounds of the whole place.

Unless someone else has been wigging out and jumping on trucks and eating
dirt at UG's lately...

The person was a little out of sorts (1 hit of blotter), but not on E.

This was a bad trip, not an OD, and there's a big difference Randy (LSD
OD's are something I don't even really acknowledge... at least not in the
classical toxicity sense, although the weirdness of bad trips does tend
to increase with larger doseages).

In light of the fact that this was a personal friend of mine, I'd like to
see this stay what it was, a bad night, and part of the risks associated
with drug use, not some irresponsible kid freaking out from eating to much
vitamin L or E or whatever the rumor chain will eventually make it
(probably fifteen bumps of ketamine and a pound of meth by next week).

The set and setting seemed pretty ideal for dosing (assuming you're into
that kinda stuff), an underground goa
beach party in a really nice location...  the dosage reasonable... the
only lesson here is that humans don't have absolute control over the nooks
and crannies of their brains, we ALL have the potential to lose it every
once in a blue moon and that's why we should look out for each other. 

The message was right on Randy, but the example poor.  I've seen people
eat tens hits and be okay and people lose it on very small amounts...  the
lesson is support and community and the base understanding that you are
taking risks when you put WHATEVER in your system. We should do our best
to take care of our own... that's the unity thing everybody talks about,
but sometimes we just get a little crazy...

Peace,
AndyW

Subject: Derrick May & the origins of techno
Cc: Steven Allas <smallas@apollogrp.edu>
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

Hi Rave Friends,

        This is kind of a tangent to the whole black/white music
discussion, but I'm curious if anyone can identify for me the specific May
songs or albums, or even the club(s) he spun at where techno was supposedly
born.

        I know he has been widely credited with this creation (in the PBS
series on rock 'n roll, for example), but if one individual is really as
influential here as is claimed, it seems strange that the specifics of this
creation are not more widely known.  I don't have any reason to believe
that May is not responsible for techno, or that the credit should be shared
more widely; I really don't know that much about it.  But if he is indeed
the father of techno, I would be interested in hearing the first music he
produced in that genre.

        Specifically I'd like to know what it was about his music that made
it so different that it came to be recognized as the start of a whole new
musical classification.  I seem to recall hearing that one key innovation
was learning to use electronic equipment like the (Apollo?) 303 to produce
sounds that it hadn't originally been intended to produce, but I'm not sure
if that was a reference to May or to someone else, or even if the first
individual pioneers of the techniques are positively identified.

        I'm sure someone on this list will be able to clue me in on the
history...

May the bass be with us,
                                <<< Starchild >>>

Moki shared (in part):

>Techno was born in Detroit with Derrick May (he's
>black).  It's the grittier side of life and eschewed the bleakness
>surrounding the motor city at the time.  Though it may have been adopted
>by more whites as a form of music.  The creation of the genre by a
>person of color is incidental as I think had it been by some "white" guy
>then it's just as redundant.

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 29 21:01:04 1998
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 1533 invoked by uid 6000); 29 Apr 1998 21:01:03 -0000
Received: (qmail 1519 invoked by uid 47); 29 Apr 1998 21:01:01 -0000
Date: 29 Apr 1998 21:01:01 -0000
Message-ID: <19980429210101.1518.qmail@hyperreal.org>
From: mikew@hyperreal.org
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: raves at Burning Man
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


> i still don't get the rave/BM connection, although it's been made before.
> Techno is definitely the dominant sound at Burning Man, but my thought
> about it is that the techno is there because of its futuristic,
> fin-de-siecle feel.   But there's definitely not anything remotely ravey
> about Burning Man, for me.
> 
> in fact, i don't remember seeing any ravers there.  (unless they were all
> nekkid!)

It may have something to do with when you arrived at Burning Man.

Last year my group left SF at midnight on Thursday and arrived on
Friday morning.  Friday night was completely intense -- possibly one of 
the best parties I have ever been to.  There were at least 5 different
rave sound systems set up at various places, each one having anywhere
from 10 to 150 people dancing like maniacs.  Each one had a distinct
musical style and a different "look and feel" from the others.  And
the people were party like it was (forgive the cliche) 1999.  All this
started around 9pm, and it did die down around 2am or so.

Saturday night was way more mellow.  Most of those same sound systems
were not operational at all on Saturday night.  I think people were
saving their energy for the burn on Sunday night.  And Sunday night
seemed to focus on the burn and not really on dance music.

So if you weren't there on Friday night last year, you missed most
of the rave action.


Mike

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Wed Apr 29 21:07:09 1998

Mark Grant and Lego spinning house

then go to Buddha Lounge around 1 or so...

Electronic Trip at Dome Room
w/ Tom Pazen

Liquid Kitty for starters around 10:30 on Division and past Ashland
then=20
Karma w/Derrick Carter and Diz

Friday night:
Best bet: the PURE party at Metro w/ Derrick Carter
also
Red Dog w/ Johnny Fiasco and Lego
or=20
Karma w/Terry Bristol and Tom-E
or=20
Future Rhythm at Smart Bar
w/ Tom Pazen

Saturday night:
CroBar w/ Terry Bristol and Psycho Bitch
or
Karma w/ Ralphy Rosario and Matt Warren

Sunday night:
Double Door w/ Jessie de la Pena and Liquid Soul

But on any night, stop by Dusk on Augusta and Wood.  It's a bar to =
start
the evening off with and plan your assault on the city.  However, do =
not
go to Stardust, Neo, or Convent.  Go to anything that is produced by
PURE.

Got eat at Okno or Blackbird or Iggy's.  Let me know how your week
turned out. =20

Shoot, Hernie.

You know when them jimmies start rolling the boomers onto the alkali flats
the sun shines happier than on days when they don't.    But catch:  drip
that wax in the sun, and for what?
Playa dust and techno beats at the edge of the millenium?   Dig that noise
green!  The burning man jimmies bust out of the embryo naked just like the
ravers,  and jam it til the universe collapses.
Acid beats shine sweet the world round.  Embrace that machine, it's the
language of Now.

Night time on the desert?  Stars twist a dome around ravers & burners
alike.  One vibe?    One love?

Find a way to set beats on fire, you'll be Harvey's archangel.

But Funky Tekno Burning Man Rave ?   That soup don't stick.   I reckon you
flipped a microchip.
Hip?  Don't trip.

-bOom

PS:  I dig that Sirius account green, Paul Hayden.

	Wed, 29 Apr 1998 17:24:29 -0700 (PDT)
Date: Wed, 29 Apr 1998 17:24:29 -0700 (PDT)
From: Noah Apodaca <unclenoa@netcom.com>
Subject: Re: Derrick May & the origins of techno
To: "Ravers 'Round the Bay" <sfraves@hyperreal.org>
In-Reply-To: <v0153050ab16ce0eec5a1@[208.196.121.158]>
Message-ID: <Pine.3.89.9804291752.A15827-0100000@netcom5>
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: TEXT/PLAIN; charset=US-ASCII
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


There's no argument that "American" techno was born in Detroit by 
innovators like Derrick May.  However, electronic music in general and 
electronic dance music in specific wasn't really anything all that new.  
You can go back to albums from teh 60's and 70's and find really great 
"electronica" that wasn't classified yet as "techno".

Of course, there are also the other influences like Kraftwerk, YMO, the 
Art of Noise and others who were really trying to push the limits of 
music and sound recording using modern technology.  

May's big contribution was not the use of electronic devices to make 
music.  I think that the credit comes from the fact that May and some 
others merged that European electronic sound with the rising Chicago 
"house" sound and tried to add to it an element of the angst from life in 
big cities (eg. Detroit).  The result were these highly repetative, 
highly electronic tracks with that "4-on-the-floor" house drum track.  

:/  

I'd be really interested in a compilation of really early stuff from the 
first days of the Detroit scene.



On Wed, 29 Apr 1998, Starchild wrote:

> Hi Rave Friends,

> discussion, but I'm curious if anyone can identify for me the specific May
> songs or albums, or even the club(s) he spun at where techno was supposedly
> born.
<<<snip>>>>

> Art of Noise and others who were really trying to push the limits of

It's nice to see someone giving YMO credit for a change. ;)

There are several Sakamoto Ryuichi's solo works that are very very cool
eletronica.  If anyone's interested in some cools sounds by the insect pianoman
drop me a line...

(wonder how many will get that reference...) (^_')

BTW, YMO are argued to have been the _first_ to have invented "techno", according
to an NHK special I saw several years ago... ;)
--
James Miller
NihonLinks Consulting
http://www.nihonlinks.com

[Moki]  You've got the calendar, so you can aptly "get jiggy with it" as

said he wanted the Chicago house type experience and I recommended the
best bets.

dancing to what you want to hear.  Are you finding yourself at a loss
for where to go and what to do in S.F.?  I'm sure people on this list
can give you great advice on where to go.  Good luck.

I try to break the day and nights down in 1 1/2 hour increments so let
me know if you want me to design something for you and I'll try to have
at least three revolving party plans which you can alternately spin on
your floor and then jump off your couch to see which one you land on.
This is more involved than my recommendations with Brent.  But as they
say, for a nominal fee, anything is possible.

  by taz.hyperreal.org with SMTP; 30 Apr 1998 01:46:35 -0000
Received: from [207.93.14.92] (HELO [10.0.0.2]) by mail.ednet.net (Stalker SMTP Server 1.6) with ESMTP id S.0000051667 for <sfraves@hyperreal.org>; Wed, 29 Apr 1998 17:43:43 -0800
X-Sender: joe@mail.ednet.net
Message-Id: <v04003a08b16d8702f6dd@[10.0.0.2]>
In-Reply-To: <v0153050ab16ce0eec5a1@[208.196.121.158]>
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Date: Wed, 29 Apr 1998 18:49:28 -0700
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org
From: Joe Rice <joe@justiceleague.com>
Subject: Re: Derrick May & the origins of techno
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

At 1:55 PM -0700 4/29/98, Starchild wrote:
>Hi Rave Friends,
>
>        This is kind of a tangent to the whole black/white music
>discussion, but I'm curious if anyone can identify for me the specific May
>songs or albums, or even the club(s) he spun at where techno was supposedly
>born.
>

May DJ'ed at the Music Institute in Detroit, mid-eighties. I'd argue that
Juan Atkins had more influence over early techno than May, through the
Cybotron and early Metroplex releases, although to some degree he and May
were (and are) contemporaries.

Check Model 500 "Classics" on R&S. The aforementioned Innovator comp for
the May stuff is also essential, and if you get lucky in the used bins, get
any of the Buzz records compilations - "Virtual Sex", "Panic in Detroit",
and " Relics."

Here are 3 short interviews with Kevin Saunderson, Juan Atkins, and Derrick
May, which appeared on the seminal Network records comp "Emotions Electric."

>Kevin Saunderson
>Date Of Birth
>5.9.64
>
>Born
>Brooklyn, New York
>
>Education
>Bellville High School.
>Eastern Michigan University
>
>What is life?
>Living, thinking, moving.
>
>Favourite Soda?
>Blue Cream Soda
>
>Kevin Saunderson is..
>A human being trying to be better
>
>Derrick May is..
>A very helpful brother who hip people like
>
>Juan Atkins is..
>A man in another world
>
>What is music?
>Emotion expressed through sound
>
>What is Techno?
>Using old and new technology to create a futuristic sound
>
>What have you done with your money'?
>I bought a lovely house in a great area and made an
>investment by owning my own recording studio
>
>Why is technology perceived as being cold?
>Because people are scared of progress
>
>Have you ever ridden the Trans Europe Express?
>No
>
>Would you die if you lost the ability to hear?
>No.  I have a lot to live for
>
>Do you like robots?
>Yes
>
>Do you like Gary Numan?
>No, but I loved Cars
>
>Favourite machine?
>Roland SD 8000
>
>Who is the originator?
>Juan Atkins
>
>Who Is the innovator?
>Kevin Saunderson
>
>Who is the elevator?
>Mr May
>
>Is there a future for the world?
>If there's a tomorrow there's a future, good or bad
>
>Juan Atkins
>Date Of Birth
>12.9.62
>
>Education
>Bellville High.  Washentaw Community
>College, Recording Institute Of Detroit
>
>What is Techno?
>Music that sounds like technology
>
>Where would Techno be without England?
>Where would England be without Techno?
>
>Greatest Techno record?
>Home Computer - Kraftwerk
>
>Does It still exist?
>Does the space shuttle still exist?
>
>Do you love machines?
>I don't love anything that can't love me back
>
>Favourite machine?  Roland R-8
>
>What would you do if you had a chance to
>make a record with Kraftwerk?
>Take plenty of notes
>
>Why has Techno inspired some of the most
>pretentious music journalism of the last decade?
>Because there is nothing else to talk about except so called new
>music trends that happened ten or twenty years ago
>
>Kevin Saunderson is...
>A go getter
>
>Derrick May is...
>Creative
>
>Juan Atkins is...
>A man with a vision
>
>Who is the originator?
>Juan Atkins
>
>Who Is the innovator?
>Derrick May
>
>Who is the elevator?
>Kevin Saunderson
>
>Will you ever stop making music?
>No
>
>What is music?
>Sound painting
>
>Is there a future for this world?
>Yes.  But not as we know it now
>
>Derrick May
>Date Of Birth
>6.4.63
>
>Education
>School Of Hard Knox
>
>Current yearly salary?
>None of your fucking business
>
>First record bought?
>'Tommy The Who
>
>What does the phrase Bellville Three mean to you?
>Nothing
>
>Does George Clinton have anything to do with Techno?
>No
>
>What is Techno?
>Bullshit Hype
>
>Favourite Drum machine?
>Roland TR 808
>
>Preferred keyboard?
>Trade secret
>
>What inspires you to make music?
>Nothing at the moment
>
>Will you ever stop making music?
>Maybe yes, maybe no
>
>Ambition
>To score films
>
>Kevin Saunderson is..
>Extremely energetic
>
>Juan Atkins is...
>A thoroughbred that doesn't want to run
>
>Derrick May is..
>(No response)
>
>Who Is the innovator?
>Kraftwerk
>
>Who is the originator?
>Cybotron
>
>Who is the elevator
>Otis
>
>What is the Third Wave?
>A progressive state of mind
>
>What makes you happy?
>Anything that doesn't ask me questions
>
>Is there a future for this world?

Joe

	[Moki]  I mostly chill with Ramiro and the Uniting Souls who
throw the Sunshine Daydream parties when I'm up there.  There are house
parties but you gotta hang with your friends right?  I dig the Mark
Farina sets and more on the funky house side of music.  But if there's
mad true hip-hop jungle then I'm there.  You probably know about most of
the same things I figure are going on.  You just have to keep an ear out
for the unannounced parties I guess.  Like the last phat one I went to
was the Chocolate Factory spinning at the Yoga Center, that was dope and
the crowd size was just right.  Aight den, I'm out...peace be with
you...

	aloha,
	moki
	sending island vibes in waves...

> > > -----Original Message-----

dreamer@ziplink.net (Starchild) writes:
>This is kind of a tangent to the whole black/white music
>discussion, but I'm curious if anyone can identify for me the specific May
>songs or albums, or even the club(s) he spun at where techno was supposedly
>born.
>
>I know he has been widely credited with this creation (in the PBS
>series on rock 'n roll, for example), but if one individual is really as
>influential here as is claimed, it seems strange that the specifics of this
>creation are not more widely known.  I don't have any reason to believe
>that May is not responsible for techno, or that the credit should be shared
>more widely; I really don't know that much about it.  But if he is indeed
>the father of techno, I would be interested in hearing the first music he
>produced in that genre.

I have a CD compilation of some old Derrick May tracks from 1986-1990.  I'd
be happy to make a CD-R copy of it for you if you'd like.

Here are the Derrick May tracks that are on the CD...

Long Ago: "A Relic"
Rhythim is Rhythim: "Beyond the Dance"
Long Long Ago: "Another Relic"
Rhythim is Rhythim: "Strings of Life"
Mayday: "Wiggan" (Stacy Pullen remix)
Mayday: "MS 6"
Rhythim is Rhythim: "The Dance"
Longer than Long Ago: "A Relic"
Rhythim is Rhythim: "Drama"

Subject: [bsp] Static mixtapes!
Mime-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset="us-ascii"
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk

After many unforeseen technical difficulties, the Static mixtapes are
finally here!

The 2 tape Static set will be available for $10 at both Static and Sabotage
each week until they run out.  Each of the sides contains a mix from one of
the four Static residents- Bre'Ad, Sutekh, Re'Ach, and Quantum23.  The
tapes have been professionally duplicated onto chrome cassettes and come in
a handy dual cassette case with full color insert.

In case you're not familiar with the music we play... Re'Ach and Quantum23
are all (okay, maybe 90%) about dark, brutal drum and bass.  Bre'Ad plays
an eclectic mix of hip-hop, electro, funk, and downtempo.  And I play a
mixture of dark, minimal techno, tech-house, electro, and experimental
weirdness.

We will most likely not be selling these in stores, so if you are unable to
come to either of the nights, then email me and we can probably work out a
mail order deal...  

In case you don't know where to go:  
STATIC tuesdays at Liquid, 2925 16th St. SF (www.nodeOne.com/static)
SABOTAGE wednesdays at Il Pirata, 2007 16th St. SF (www.egatobas.com)

-Seth

If we are talking about drugless highs, I gotta say, the two best things are
skateboarding and snowboarding.  And going to kick ass skapunk, ska, and punk
shows.  And some good jungle/drumnbass events.  And when you finally get your
beats to match.  And when you find that record you been lookin for for days.

the moon and back,  more times than even plausible. And I could keep going.
But I won't.  I don't do drugs, unless it's herbal or over the counter.  I
wonder if I could sell tylenol at a rave for $1 a hit?  HA HA HA!!!

"Hey you, don't watch that, whatch this!! This is the heavy heavy monsta
sound,  It's the (n word I don't know but it sounds like) Naziest sound
around.  So if you comin in off the street, and your beginning to feel the
heat, well listen busta, you betta start to move you feet, to the rockinest,
rock steady beat of MADNESS, ONE STEP BEYOND!!!!!"

I think their intro says it all.  It was the most awesome show I have been to
in a long time.  It was like watching 20 or so years of history unfold before
my very eyes.

I haven't danced so hard in so long.  I can still hear the trumpet blare in my
ears, see the drummer fly on his set.

Fuck, maybe I'm not a junglist after all.  Maybe I am a rude girl.  Naw, fuck
dat.  I'm a Rude Girl Junglistic Punk Rock K1dd.  Maybe I'm confused.  Maybe
it's almost 3 in the morning and I am tired, all because I saw an awesome show
(no wait, it was a concert) tonight.

Now it's time for me to get to bed.

Oh, by the way, I am talking about the madness concert I saw tonight. And for
all you ravers who don't know, Madness is an old school ska band.  Kicken ass
STILL baybee.

Ms. K1dd

Skankin in my dreams, Rudies on a mission.

said he wanted the Chicago house type experience and I recommended the
best bets.

dancing to what you want to hear.  Are you finding yourself at a loss
for where to go and what to do in S.F.?  I'm sure people on this list
can give you great advice on where to go.  Good luck.

I try to break the day and nights down in 1 1/2 hour increments so let
me know if you want me to design something for you and I'll try to have
at least three revolving party plans which you can alternately spin on
your floor and then jump off your couch to see which one you land on.
This is more involved than my recommendations with Brent.  But as they
say, for a nominal fee, anything is possible.

Derek's plea for universal acceptance is natural and important. What is
more important, however, is acceptance of yourself.  This is the only way
to be truly content. If others don't accept you then we must see that as
very sad and a reflection of their own self-doubts.

If you are still interested, read on:

THE VILLAGE MIND

There is much heterogeneity all over the world guys, and definitely in the
United States, regarding these issues:  acceptance, freedom and violence.
Acceptance in other countries cannot be generalized because of the extreme
variability - it depends highly on what communities one has come into
contact with. Country borders are imaginary, remember - what IS real are
the streets/sidewalks/natural barriers that divide one community with one
set of beliefs from another.

Freedom in THIS country is only as available as the government makes it,
please remember.  We are not an anarchist state. We could have a whole list
just to discuss various freedom issues brought to the courts here, some of
which would amaze you all.  Violence towards others is a different topic
all together, as seen by the existence of it in the inner cities and poor
communities of this free domain (for one example!). Freedom does NOT equal
lack of violence or guaranteed acceptance, just as the existence of
violence does not mean that there is no freedom present (see the horrid
writings on KKK and white supremacy). Subcultures make their own rules and
there are places in the U.S. where you do not have the freedom to be who
you are because someone will persecute you in one way or another.  It is
called the Village Mentality.  No matter how, when or if you encounter it -
NEVER FORGET IT!  Someday we will all be (or have been) challenged in our
beliefs and prejudices towards others and we must NEVER fall to the Mind of
the Village.

Love, Freedom, AND Acceptance

Terri

Well then, you'll probably be happy to read the following message taken
off uk.music.rave...

Newsgroups: uk.music.rave
Subject: sort of drum and bass with a kinda ska feel.....Brixton
Date: Mon, 27 Apr 1998 20:34:43 +0100


There's been some fucking top new music being played around Brixton
recently, and as I've yet to track it down I thought I'd find out if
anyone elses is listening to it.

It kinda sounds like drum and bass - quite fast and dark - but has an
irresistable ska backbeat to it that makes it really dancy and almost
pogo-able (!)

I first heard it down the Loughborough Junction three weeks ago, and
then some bloke was playing it on a Thursday at the Dogstar a while
back.

It's the freshest thing I've heard for a long time- anyone else been
grooving to it?

Mike
PS Dogstar's open till 2.30 in the week with *no* dress policy and *no
admission prices, same goes for the Junction.

My point is well taken. It has nothing to do with being paranoid (at
least for me, some people may react with paranoia), it is about having
certain rights. I know when I access a computer terminal, and surf the
net / WWW that I give up certain rights to privacy. I know each time I
swipe a credit card, travel, purchase something, etc, that information
is being gathered on me. I know it is highly possible to gather this
information and use it for malicious intent.

My point is, if you have an interest in this at all, to just read it --
and form whatever opinion you wish.

I personally view this as an invasion of my privacy, whether or not I am
in public.
But I am sure, people could argue otherwise.

There are also benefits to surveillance. Hell, it's not like the Fed's
haven't been using this technology for years using Satellites.

Thanks for sharing your opinion.

-- PHreaK Moi

X-Mailer: Mozilla 4.04 [en]C-PBI-NC404  (Win95; I)
To: hackerelite@deathsdoor.com
CC: sfraves@hyperreal.org
Subject: Re: Big Brother Could be Watching You

business, our rights are something of a piece of red tape, or
meaningless if you will.  So, something to be aware of yes, this
survailence issue, but by bringing it up are you merley stirring up the
paranoia?  The underlying fear in us all....of being watched ; 0.....Or,
are you really just passing along information for discussion, in either
case you have done both.

> net / WWW that I give up certain rights to privacy. I know each time I
> swipe a credit card, travel, purchase something, etc, that information
> is being gathered on me. I know it is highly possible to gather this
> information and use it for malicious intent.
> 
> My point is, if you have an interest in this at all, to just read it --
> and form whatever opinion you wish.
> 
> I personally view this as an invasion of my privacy, whether or not I am
> in public.
> But I am sure, people could argue otherwise.
> 
> There are also benefits to surveillance. Hell, it's not like the Fed's
> haven't been using this technology for years using Satellites.

is intresting, but not something to get my feathers in a ruff about.

me.  I like playing cat and mouse with the big boys of the corporate
world......being security consious in the computer world is definatley a

Vortexbrad wrote:

> In a message dated 4/29/98 5:50:52 PM, jamiller@cyberdude.com wrote:
>
> >There are several Sakamoto Ryuichi's solo works that are very very cool
> >eletronica.  If anyone's interested in some cools sounds by the insect
> pianoman
> >drop me a line...
>
> Well, it might help to know that his name is ryuichi sakamoto  (not vice
> versa)

As a further TANGENT to the b/w music discussion...

Japanese sirnames preceed the given name.  So the above composer/musician in
question would be addressed as Sakamoto Ryuichi (title) in Japanese.

How to write Japanese names in English and how foreign names should be
written in Japanese is actually quite a hotpot of discussion.  In spite of
being a Japanese/English bilingual and having been in a  position of public
policy for some years, I generally order Japanese names as they appear in
their native order when writing them in English.  I order my name Sirname,
Given Name when writing it in Japanese.  Both conventions buck the
"traditional" and tend to throw people off though... ;)  If you're
interested in why I would do this feel free to drop me a line.  It may not
be appropriate to digress any furhter here.

Regarding Sakamoto's work, I don't have anything at my fingertips but one of
my fav albums of Sakamoto's solo work, I think it was titled "Ongaku
Mokugan".   I think there were a couple tracks in "Merry Christmas Mr.
Lawrence" (??? English title?) from it.  I can look it up later sometime if
anyone's interested.  One of my all time favorite albums though very
ambient'ish though so might not appeal to alot of hte people on this list.

> :)
>
> --vortex

PHReaK Moi wrote:
>
> My point is well taken.

<snip>
It is now, thank you.

Gracias =P aka Merci Beaucoup aka Thanks again ;)

<snip>

Thank God, the govt. did something close to good for the people once,
RIGHTS!...We have some yes.  However, as I'm sure your aware of, anyone
who has been alive more than a yr knows that when it comes to Govt.
business, our rights are something of a piece of red tape, or
meaningless if you will.

I concur with you there, there is definately something to be said about
government surveillance, which is a great source of debate for us all. I
agree with you that there is little you can do about it, yet, there are
some countermeausures (heck, if they spy on us, why don't we spy on
them?) -- I suppose that is where hacking comes into play.

So, something to be aware of yes, this
survailence issue, but by bringing it up are you merley stirring up the
paranoia?

Not really here to string up paranoia, moreso to inform the masses (if
they care) and to spark a discussion on the issue, since I know it is
close to my heart and may be of interest to other folks.

The underlying fear in us all....of being watched ; 0....'

This is definately an underlying fear. For me, it is more of an
intrusion that I do not welcome, moreso than being fearful of it.
However, I do find the idea of being constantly watched disturbing and
rather frightful. It makes me think of the book 1984 and how things are
seemingly more like that environment as each day passes.

.Or,
are you really just passing along information for discussion, in either
case you have done both.

Passing along info, opening room for discussion from interested parties.
I am definately interested in what others think about this and what
other think should be done about it.

<snip>

Sooooo......my point, or opinion, (as you asked for), is that the matter

is intresting, but not something to get my feathers in a ruff about.
Security with computers on the other hand is something intresting to
me.  I like playing cat and mouse with the big boys of the corporate
world......being security consious in the computer world is definatley a

NRR thread worth pusuing, perhaps, if ther's intrest, I'll start one.

I second that. I personally just find it interesting and want to keep
better informed on the subject. My main interest is compromising network
security and learning better ways to prevent it, specializing in network
crytography and encryption, and changes in the laws that affect the use
of it and it's exportation.

Perhaps this is a discussion you and I should share personally, unless
others are interested in it as well.

-- Gabe

Life's Ponderings	

 To handle yourself, use your head;
 To handle others, use your heart.

 Anger is only one letter short of danger.

  Great minds discuss ideas;
 Average minds discuss events;
 Small minds discuss people.

 God gives every bird it's food,
 But he does not throw it into it's nest.

 He who loses money, loses much;
 He who loses a friend, loses more;

 Beautiful young people are accidents of nature,
 But beautiful old people are works of art.

 Learn from the mistakes of others.
 You can't live long enough to make them all yourself.

 The tongue weighs practically nothing,
 But so few people can hold it.

---"Terri E. Young" <tyyoung@ucdavis.edu> wrote:

> THE VILLAGE MIND
> 
> There is much heterogeneity all over the world
guys, and definitely in the
> United States, regarding these issues:  acceptance,
>freedom and violence.
> Acceptance in other countries cannot be generalized
>because of the extreme
> variability - it depends highly on what communities
>one has come into

While I see your point, my point was made directly to
certain comments made along the lines that in Europe
you have more religious freedom which obviously is
incorrect.

Now lets state for the record I studied overseas in
France and Germany. I have never been treated more
poorly, as I was in France than any other country in
the world. 

I was born in Columbia and have lived in Panama and
Guatemala as well.(damn close to third world countries)
Where the people did not spit on me (literally).
After our country lost many men trying to save their
country
more than once.

My experience is from living it not just talking about
it or reading about it in a book. I believe Derek has
been abroad as well, so its just different perspective.
Perhaps both of us need to word our responses
differently to reflect this. 

I don't condone everything about this country. Nor
do I believe in the way it is run, completely. I do
know this. No other country has given as much money,
time, and effort to make this world a better place.
Most countries can't even begin to get close. So I
consider the good with the bad and I'm happy to be 
accepted here as an American period. Everything
in-between is people and their interaction with one
another.
 

Derek:

You say the people here "are FUCKED and we are all
egotistical" and yada, yada, yada Derek. I took that
comment pretty personally since you made it so broad.
Be aware of what you say Derek, people remember. We
are not all that way and you become more and more
like that by making judgements on large groups of
people whom you do not know personally.

Thanks for comments folks, have a great day.
Layne

You could recruit an underground community of rebels (probably younger
kids) that all wear minor disguises to shoot black paint pellets at
these cameras when they are located.  You just spread the word to the
young community that this needs to be done and I'll bet it's the next
coolest thing to kill a camera.  That's what you would do, like the rat
hunters in lesser developed countries.  You just keep shooting the
hidden cameras with black paint and render the authorities on their
heels.  But then again, they really do have a bombing threat on the city
so I suppose it's justified in their minds.  And think if some terrorist
groups decided to make S.F. a target for their agendas?  Would you be so
quick to discount using the surveillance system in place in London?

It's the age old debate, does the end justify the means.  Just say that
hypothetically, the city of London had fewer bombings, or even no more
bombings because of this security system.  Would the cameras be
justified then?  

The difference is that the city is not a private place like when you
enter a building or a home, or a store.  But when you enter a federal
building or any other gov't. building, there usually is a security
camera system due to risk factors.  So, since there is a risk factor in
the city of London, you'd be hard pressed to argue against the cameras
being present.  Is it for the greater good?  I would cautiously say yes.


But here's the real crux, what will happen when there is no longer any
bombings and the authorities still have all the cameras up?  And there
you have the real danger.  These agencies will have to justify just like
the CIA and all the other black box operatives.  Immediate saftey always
has a higher price paid by future generations.  

I've lived under martial law and eventually was forced to flee from it.
It's always a little hazy when you talk about a large number of people's
safety.  What do you all think?

Aloha,
Moki

it's a one way street and once u start down it, there is no going back.

i *for one* enjoy my privacy when i am outdoors.  I would rather get
mugged than have a camera staring at me 24 hours a day. I don't want
to be a robot, forced to live by their rules and worst of all their
*ideals*.

U guys can kiss raves and everything else goodbye..cuz they'll be on u
like fly's on sh*t.  No more UG's, not more anything.

sorry.

ramble mode off.

=)
dan




---Steven Allas <smallas@apollogrp.edu> wrote:
>
> It's the age old debate, does the end justify the means.  Just say
that
> hypothetically, the city of London had fewer bombings, or even no more
> bombings because of this security system.  Would the cameras be
> justified then?  
> 
> The difference is that the city is not a private place like when you
> enter a building or a home, or a store.  But when you enter a federal
> building or any other gov't. building, there usually is a security
> camera system due to risk factors.  So, since there is a risk factor
in
> the city of London, you'd be hard pressed to argue against the cameras
> being present.  Is it for the greater good?  I would cautiously say
yes.
> 
> 
> But here's the real crux, what will happen when there is no longer any
> bombings and the authorities still have all the cameras up?  And there
> you have the real danger.  These agencies will have to justify just
like
> the CIA and all the other black box operatives.  Immediate saftey
always
> has a higher price paid by future generations.  
> 
> I've lived under martial law and eventually was forced to flee from
it.
> It's always a little hazy when you talk about a large number of
people's
> safety.  What do you all think?
> 
> Aloha,
> Moki
>

not to fuel the paranoia or anything, but...

has anyone else noticed all of the tall white poles with video cameras
on top that seem to have been installed along all major highways within
the past few months? and I'm not talking about two or three here and
there.... they are all over the place. I've seen them on 101, 280, 880,
87, 17, etc....

at first i just noticed the cameras at places where there are usually
traffic jams during commute hours and didn't think much of them... i
figured they were the cameras that tv stations use for their traffic
updates and what not... but i keep seeing more and more of them...
sometimes less than a mile away from each other.... my only guess is that
CALTrans is working on an advanced implementation (adding video feed) of
their real-time traffic report that they have been doing in san diego for
the past 4 years or so (which i might add is very impressive):

   http://www.maxwell.com/caltrans/sd/sd_transnet.html

any other ideas about what purpose they serve?

oh, and how about those weird looking devices that are starting to show up
right before the exits for truck weigh stations? seeing as how i've seen
so many episodes of the x-files, i can't help but wonder if someone is
working on a way to scan vehicles as they drive under those 
contraptions... wouldn't that be something...  =)

okay, enough conspiracy theory for one day... time to go relax  =)
it's a good thing i don't seriously think like this all the time...

-matt (aka mc^2)
CFC

"Go that way, really fast! If something gets in your way, turn!"
 - Better Off Dead

Date: Thu, 30 Apr 98 14:57:53 -0700
x-sender: shimmer@pop3.concentric.net

Precedence: bulk

the music institute was where a lot of this was going on...

the belleville three, generally understood as the trio that "invented" 
techno are juan atkins, derrick may and kevin saunderson. they all went 
to belleville high in suburban detroit. juan is a couple years older than 
the other two, his little brother was in the same class as kevin and 
derrick, a few years behind. juan and derrick (if memory serves) had a 
sound system called "deep space" acutally i think it was juan and kevin. 
anyway they would do these parties around detroit. juan was the first to 
record, one foot in depeche mode, ultravox 80's style... as cybotron with 
another guy he met, at technical college (ypsilanti if i remember) 
outside of detroit. there are other first generation detroiters that get 
less credit though, eddie fowlkes started producing around the same 
time.... i have an almost complete bibliography on detroit techno if 
anyone cares to hit me up for it.. some good stuff has been written on 
it, (but not as good as what's coming ;) .. )

sm

It's insidious...

(I love that word, insidious)

Caltrans last year sent out a brochure about Bay Bridge commute
alternatives to commuters...  How did they know know which cars are bridge
commuters?  It turns out that they recorded the license plate of all cars
crossing the bridge on video, and sent the brochure to each of the auto's
owners.

David

At 03:37 PM 4/30/98 -0700, David Minuk wrote:
>It's insidious...
>
>(I love that word, insidious)

>Caltrans last year sent out a brochure about Bay Bridge commute
>alternatives to commuters...  How did they know know which cars are bridge
>commuters?  It turns out that they recorded the license plate of all cars
>crossing the bridge on video, and sent the brochure to each of the auto's
>owners.
>
>David

>On Thu, 30 Apr 1998, mc^2 wrote:
>
>> 
>> not to fuel the paranoia or anything, but...
>> 
>> has anyone else noticed all of the tall white poles with video cameras
>> on top that seem to have been installed along all major highways within
>> the past few months? and I'm not talking about two or three here and
>> there.... they are all over the place. I've seen them on 101, 280, 880,
>> 87, 17, etc....
>> 
>> at first i just noticed the cameras at places where there are usually
>> traffic jams during commute hours and didn't think much of them... i
>> figured they were the cameras that tv stations use for their traffic
>> updates and what not... but i keep seeing more and more of them...
>> sometimes less than a mile away from each other.... my only guess is that
>> CALTrans is working on an advanced implementation (adding video feed) of
>> their real-time traffic report that they have been doing in san diego for
>> the past 4 years or so (which i might add is very impressive):
>> 
>>    http://www.maxwell.com/caltrans/sd/sd_transnet.html
>> 
>> any other ideas about what purpose they serve?
>> 
>> oh, and how about those weird looking devices that are starting to show up
>> right before the exits for truck weigh stations? seeing as how i've seen
>> so many episodes of the x-files, i can't help but wonder if someone is
>> working on a way to scan vehicles as they drive under those 
>> contraptions... wouldn't that be something...  =)
>> 
>> okay, enough conspiracy theory for one day... time to go relax  =)
>> it's a good thing i don't seriously think like this all the time...

The one and only time I went to 2nd and Jackson I couldn't breath at all. It
was way too hot and there was so much smoke in the air I had to go outside.
I went back in and still had trouble brething so a small group went to a
friends car and listened to a tight mix tape in the company of cool people
and talked about everything. I had a good time but the location was horrible
because of : POOR AIR CIRCULATION & OVERCROWDING. The second problem was due
to the promoters but the first is a building problem.

From sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org Thu Apr 30 23:46:20 1998
Return-Path: <sfraves-owner-sfraves-archive=hyperreal.org@hyperreal.org>
Delivered-To: sfraves-archive@hyperreal.org
Received: (qmail 13706 invoked by uid 6000); 30 Apr 1998 23:46:18 -0000

Message-ID: <19980430234608.13379.qmail@hyperreal.org>
From: dhchung@hyperreal.org
Subject: This Week's SFR Calendar!
To: sfraves@hyperreal.org (SF Raves)
Date: Thu, 30 Apr 1998 16:46:08 -0700 (PDT)
Cc: sfraves-calendar@hyperreal.org (SFR Calendar)
X-Mailer: ELM [version 2.4ME+ PL37 (25)]
MIME-Version: 1.0
Content-Type: text/plain; charset=US-ASCII
Content-Transfer-Encoding: 7bit
Sender: sfraves-owner@hyperreal.org
Precedence: bulk


   The weekend starts tonight - there are lots of Thursday parties nowadays.
   There's the Jungle Life one-off, and Eklectic and Sound Design; I haven't
   been to Gelatin, the new Royal Jelly, or Raindance yet, but they look
   like they're worth checking out.  

   Last Friday I checked out Bohemian Lounge, in a new (restored) space
   in the Mission, it's a weekly, so you have another chance to check it
   out this week.  Or there's a ton of other events, the Anarchist Disco
   looks old-school, and there's a Cinco De Mayo (pre)party, Casa de Alma.
   Mayday and Deep round out the SF events, then there's Jack Da House and
   Close Up inland.  

   Saturday looks good too, leading off with the AIDS Dance-A-Thon at the
   concourse.  Conscious Session looks pretty good, and FedEx and Intoxication
   look like they'll go big.

   Finally, Monday is the last day to register to vote for the June 2nd
   primary, you need to register to vote for the gubernatorial primary and
   numerous important local initiatives...


                              The SFR Calendar
                                      
           http://www.hyperreal.org/raves/sf/calendar/gencal.cgi

                                 Info Lines
                                      
     * Be-At Info Line - 415-626-4087. Usually has 5-10 listings, updated
       daily.
     * the Buzz-line, a global party network - 650.569.3300
     * Clubline - 415.979.8686
     * Frequency 8 Trance/Techno infoline - 415.541.5019
     * The Groove Line - 415.331.1500 ext.4788
     * Mixology-Music (north bay) - 707.526.1230
     * Housewares Rave Line - 415.281.0125
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                             Radio/TV/Net Shows
                                      
     * Sunday night 8pm-10pm - "Soundz of Resistance" w/DJ Poohbear.
       Underground electronic music, mainly jungle/drum and bass, dub and
       hard techno along with guest DJs, interviews and not-so-random
       amples of life. KZSC 88.1 (Santa Cruz)
     * Sunday night 11pm-2am - "The Dreaming/Innermind Show" w/DJ Miracle
       & Mr. Monchichi. House, Jungle, Trip-Hop, Ambient, Dub,
       Break-Beats & guest DJs. KSCU 103.3 (Santa Clara)
     * Sunday night midnight-1am - "Shortwave" - Electronic music in all
       of its guises. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Monday night 9:30pm-midnight - "The Autobahn" w/dj Sutekh. Man and
       machine made music. KALX 90.7 (Berkeley)
     * Tuesday night 11:30pm-1:30am - "Conscious Groove" -
       ambientdowntempojunglehousetrancedrumnbasstriphop spun by weekly
       guest DJs. Hosted by Stephanie aka Miss fat slice. Free Radio
       Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
       [4.21.98 - Steven Tune]
       [4.28.98 - Ethan (Friends & Family)]
     * Wednesday night 9pm-11pm - free form music mix. KPFA 94.1
       (Berkeley)
     * Wednesday night/Thursday morning - "the tube" hosted by miss laura
       aka lola. an electronic excursion into ambient soundscapes,
       ethereal trance, and washes of other whimsical muzik. KAZU 90.3
       (Monterey Bay Community Radio)
     * Thursday morning 5am-7am - A postmodern Garrison Keillor on crack,
       DJ Boomerang Fidget spins hilarious tales of backwoods meth labs,
       urban decay and redneck ravers; all with a social conscience.
       Also, ambient & techno. Free Radio Berkeley 104.1 (Berkeley)
     * Thursday morning 10am-2pm - "The Further Adventures of Aardvark" -
       trip-hop to experimental to ambient to gabba etc, etc. KSJS 90.5
       (San Jose).
     * Thursday 7pm-11pm - The Beta Lounge - Live on the net - electronic
       music and culture, worldwide. http://www.betalounge.com/
     * Thursday night 9pm-mid - "An Epiphany of Sound" hosted by J.C. The
       best in beats to satiate your inner child. Electronic dance,
       noise, spoken word, world music and more. Also available in
       RealAudio. KZSU 90.1 (Stanford)
     * Friday 10am-3pm - weekly DJ netcasts. x-radio.
     * Friday 3pm-6pm - free form music mix. KUSF 90.3 (SF) (also
       available on Realaudio
     * Friday 9:30am-noon - Snappy the Aligator plays deep groove music
       that dips into cool electronic sounds, classic soul, reggae &
       more. KALX, 90.7 FM (Berkeley)
     * Fridays 9pm-midnight - Andrew from Groove Merchant spins on KUSF
       90.3 (SF)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - midnight-noon. House/techno mix
       with Johnny K, Ozone & guests - KCSS 91.9 Central Valley (Turlock)
     * Friday night/Saturday morning - "Just Desserts" w/Mr.Goodwrench -
       10pm-2am Jungle, Detroit, Techno, Acid House, whacked-out Dub, and
       noise KFJC 89.7 - Los Altos Hills
     * Friday night - Moondance. Ambient; 3am-7:30am, KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday afternoon - "Bus Stop" - music and talk w/guest DJs from
       SF and beyond. 2pm-3pm. KUSF 90.3 SF.
     * Saturday night 11pm - Flux Television, Viacom Channel 53 -
       Ambient, acid jazz and house music videos & interviews. (415)
       281-3377. flux@flux.net
     * (every other) Saturday night 10p-12:30a - "1984" w/DJ Richtoffen.
       House, Trance and German rave. 90.1 (Chico)
     * Saturday night - "amp" 1am. MTV.
     * Saturday night - "Subsonic". 1am-6am, KITS 105.3 SF.
     * Saturday night - "House Nation" w/"Anthems Mix", Top 10s from
       guest DJs and "London Connection w/DJ Doubt". 2am-4am, WILD 94.9
       SF.
     * Ambiance Magazine - 9:30p weds-sun PNC Cable 2 (Modesto &
       Oakdale), 9p fri & sat, marcus cable ch 9 (ceres & turlock).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
   For a search interface to the calendar, see the Late Train club
   section (http://www.latetrain.com/clubs/).
     _________________________________________________________________
   
                            Administrative Notes
                                      
   If anyone has info on any other events, send it to me! I can't
   possibly hope to get all the info every week.
   
   This info gets sent via email every Thursday. To subscribe or
   unsubscribe to the calendar mailing list, send e-mail to
   majordomo@hyperreal.org with either the line
   
   subscribe sfraves-calendar or
   unsubscribe sfraves-calendar
   
   There is also an sfraves discussion mailing list for issues related to
   clubs, parties, house and techno music, etc. To subscribe, send e-mail
   to majordomo@hyperreal.org with the line
   
   subscribe sfraves
   
   in the body of the message.
   
   
    Derek Chung - dhchung@hyperreal.org

>You say the people here "are F**KED and we are all
>egotistical" and yada, yada, yada Derek.

As a society yes the people here are full of them selves and very
hypocritical.
As individuals, most of us are really nice caring individuals.

>I took that comment pretty personally since you made it so broad.

I hope you don't take this personally but lighten up, Derek wasn't saying
everybody here are jerks, but that most of the societal norm is wacked and
that's where the problem lies.

>Be aware of what you say Derek, people remember. We
>are not all that way and you become more and more
>like that by making judgements on large groups of
>people whom you do not know personally.


I do see the danger of making generalizations and I get upset whenever
anything I am associated with is generalized about, but the greater society
as an enitity does take on a different personality which may be very
different than its members and what they want it to be. In such cases it is
our intellectual responsibilty to identify its differences and attempt to
bring it back in line with the ideals of the people.

MooK<><

Idealists like me get to identify the problems and come up with answers that
"theoretically" work. The rest of you actually have to try and get those
answers to work in the real world.

D. and I had such a wonderful day yesterday - best in a long time!  Then,
today our house got broken into.  Only one thing was taken, but the whole
house was ransacked!!  I'm feeling quite un-PLURed now. We are students who
don't own much of anything and nothing of value - I guess they learned
that!  I don't feel the urge to take what's not mine and I have a hard time
understanding it.  

sigh.
